What is an integrated service team?	"It is a team in which members are collected based on their area of knowledge to address <font color=""#00c3c3"">one common goal</font>. The key point here is that there areas in which member <font color=""#00c3c3"">knowledge overlaps</font> but each has <font color=""#00c3c3"">their own scope</font> in which they contribute to the team."	"<img src=""paste-13397f6fec53865ec513cd2574c03ca54587a5f5.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What do you need to do to start building an integrated service team? (4)	"1. Identify your <font color=""#00c3c3"">needs</font><div>2. Identify your <font color=""#00c3c3"">limitations</font></div><div>3. Identify <font color=""#00c3c3"">who</font> you want to work with</div><div>4. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Build relationships</font> with other professionals</div>"	"<img src=""paste-9313627471cc0e59103994a346c94281eb38bb37.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
Explain the sports medicine model for an integrated service team.	You have the athlete in the middle, then the sports therapist and conditioning coach on the outside that have the most info on the athlete<div>Eg: Chronic injuries, and day-to-day life</div><div>And then you have the others around that.</div>	"<img src=""paste-0fb305ee6bd36d38fa4a4582a75cfbdbdbd2a859.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What does CSEP stand for?	Canadian Society of Exercise Physiology			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What does NSCA stand for?	National Strength and Conditioning Association			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What are the two exercise certificates that CSEP provide?<div><br></div><div>Who can each prescribe exercise for?</div>	"<div>1. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Certified Exercise Physiologist</font>&nbsp;(CEP)<br></div><div>- basically the <font color=""#00c3c3"">top-tier exercise prescriptors</font> who can prescribe for <font color=""#00c3c3"">high performance athletes</font> and <font color=""#00c3c3"">disabled individuals</font></div><div><br></div><div>2. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Certified Personal Trainer</font> (CPT)</div><div>- basically the more <font color=""#00c3c3"">common trainer</font>, and is restricted to working with <font color=""#00c3c3"">healthy individuals ages 15-69</font></div>"	"<img src=""paste-650588aac0ce4448e6a87f462bd87b1aef3abb83.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What are the 4 designations that NSCA provides? (International Organization)	1. Certified Strength and Conditioning Specialist<div>2. NSCA-Certified Personal Trainer</div><div>3. Tactical Strength and Conditioning Specialist</div><div>4. Certified Special Populations Specialist</div>	"<img src=""paste-453d8a023e93b8fe77f92d12cce912d468eded9b.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What does AFLCA stand for? What is it for?	"Alberta Fitness Leadership Certification Association<div>- primarily provides support/training for fitness professionals</div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">basically a weekend course</font> (LA Fitness trainers)</div>"	"<img src=""paste-86bb454079944db3d273b38fb5283e184f3e8c6c.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What does CSPA stand for? What does it do?	Canadian Sport Psychology Association<div>- Development of mental and emotional skills, techniques, attitudes, perspectives, and processes.</div>	"<img src=""paste-4e441f251579ab00cdc18d38e0a94560fa475a80.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
"What is the use for us with <font color=""#00c3c3"">Dieticians of Canada</font>"	It is a valuable resource to consider because nutrition is out of our scope (not mine :))	"<img src=""paste-f2c6c1bd808541dc8ab9daedd5dc7a3ab987e7a5.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
Sports Medicine Physician	A sports doctor, highly skilled in musculoskeletal injuries and is NOT the same as a family doctor.<div>- specialized for sport</div><div>- <b>referral</b>&nbsp;often needed</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
Sports Physiotherapist<div><br></div><div>What kind of level is it?</div>	Very similar scope of practice and training as an athletic therapist.<div>- basically a physiotherapist focused on sports</div><div><br></div><div><b>Certificate</b>&nbsp;and <b>Diploma </b>level.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
Sports Chiropractor<div><br></div><div>How many hours of field work is needed for a Sports Chiropractor?</div>	Needs to learn exercise physiology, sport nutrition, sport psychology, advanced imaging, sport specific research, acute and chronic injury management and sport&nbsp;<span>administration training</span><div><span><br></span></div><div><b>1000</b>&nbsp;hours is needed!</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
Certified Athletic Therapist	"Specialize in musculoskeletal injury recognition, management, treatment, and return to activity.<div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">human musculoskeletal system</font></div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">exercise physiology</font></div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">biomechanics</font></div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">basic emergency care</font></div>"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What are the four specific areas of expertise for a certified athletic therapist?	1. Prevention<div>2. Immediate Care</div><div>3. Clinical Assessment</div><div>4. Treatment, rehabilitation, and reconditioning</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
"Explain how an certified athletic therapist can help with <font color=""#00c3c3"">prevention</font>?"	- Equipment fitting and modification<div>- Conditioning</div><div>- Movement Screening</div>	"<img src=""paste-05d50236b82e03d1a334e463b0a5be3797be497b.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
"Explain how a Certified Athletic Therapist specializes in&nbsp;<font color=""#00c3c3"">immediate care</font>?"	- Acute injury recognition and management<div>- Emergency interventions and EAP management (what is EAP?)</div><div>- On and off field evaluation skills</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
Explain how a Certified Athletic Therapist specialises in clinical assessment?	- Understand pathology of injuries and illnesses<div>- Coordination with other medical practitioners</div>	"<img src=""paste-d5a6224ebf3e6be225218b0c72630a7e0219befc.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
"Explain how a Certified Athletic Therapist specializes in <font color=""#00c3c3"">treatment, rehabilitation, and reconditioning</font>?"	- develop therapy skills through continuing education<div>- Emphasis on exercise based treatment and rehab (faster to get back into the game)</div><div>- Knowledge of exercise physiology</div><div>- Indentifying key performance indicators to guide and athlete's return to performance</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Integrated_Service_Team
What are the three tissue reponses to strain?	1.&nbsp; Elastic Response<div>2. Yield Point</div><div>3. Tissue Failure</div>	"<img src=""paste-e2df0b13597cdb36c803458ec21a2f5403784602.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain the elastic response to tissue strain	When tissue strain happens and there is no negative response<div>- tissue responds without deformation</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain yield point to tissue strain.	This is the point in which the tissue is brought to the point of adaptation<div>- 'plastic' changes</div><div>- can either be positive or negative</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain tissue failure in regards to tissue response	This is when you force the tissue well beyong its yield point which results in injury<div><br></div><div>Strain --&gt; Rupture --&gt; Tear --&gt; Fracture</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the mechanisms for causing injury? (5)	1. Compression<div>2. Tension</div><div>3. Shearing</div><div>4. Bending</div><div>5. Torsion</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain compression in regards to tissue loading (injury)	Basically a crushing blow which causes bruising.<div>- getting punched, charlie horsed, one drastic hit or repeated submaximal hits.</div>	"<img src=""paste-60f9c0708d7e22acdf5c11a225cafb4dab469ae0.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain what an injury due to tension is.	Pulling force which stresses beyong yield point<div>- often results in sprains, strains, or avulsion type injuries.</div>	"Avulsion: the action of pulling or tearing away<div><img src=""paste-c0a88261617c79763bf487da545966914a7b4de2.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain what an injury due to shearing is.	Force moving across the parallel organisation of tissue<div>- Eg: road rash, usually on skin.</div>	"<img src=""paste-383dcf7383411ef46c7a914ed4b366796f2893d7.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain what an injury due to bending is.	Caused by three forces while structure is under axial load<div><br></div>	"Already bowed structures encounter axial loading.<div><img src=""paste-2fb4e3ab5ad9ea615e19bd440f10e7f242ce2119.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-4b9deeca4760bb7f360c60362186ff28c1cd4b10.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain what an injury due to torsion is.	Loads caused by twisting in opposite directions from opposite ends.<div>- stress encountered will be perpendicular and parallel to the loads</div><div><br></div><div>Eg: Arm wrestle injuries on humerus</div>	"<img src=""paste-c86739a59dcc340599f9779b147e0b019790dcd7.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the 3 diagnosis for the severity of an injury?	1. Life threatening<div>2. Serious</div><div>3. Non-life threatening/non-serious</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Life threatening injury	Athlete is at immediate risk of their health, wellbeing, or life.<div><br></div><div>Eg: Severe bleeding, head injury</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Serious injury	A debillitating injury which will have significant implications on the ability of an athlete to continue playing sport.<div>- may require surgery or extensive rehab</div><div><br></div><div>Eg: ACL tear, shoulder dislocation</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Non-life threatening/non-serious injury	Majority of sports injuries fall into this category<div>- wide variety of debilitation, time lost, and rehab is necessary</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Acute injury	Immediate onset, often directly after a mechanism of injury<div>- athlete may not report pain right away</div><div>- often accompanied by swelling</div><div>Requires some form of immediate intervention.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Chronic Injury	Injury often due to a number of small acute events or micro-traumas<div>- can be caused by numerous factors</div><div>- due to habits</div><div>- usually longer in duration</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Recurrent Injury	Injury heals in a weakened or stretched position<div>- often as a result of improper or vacant rehab period</div><div>- unstable and susceptible to re-injury</div><div>- significant influence on performance</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Intrinsic Injury	Injury resulting from athlete dysfunction or overuse.<div>- something within the athlete</div><div>- not really influenced by the physical environment around them</div><div><br></div><div>Eg: Cramps</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Extrinsic Injury	Injury due to interacting with an opponent or structure		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Environmental Injury	Injury due to the result of the surroundings<div><br></div><div>Eg: Sunburn, frostbite.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What does EAP stand for?	Emergency Action Plan	This plan should be in place for all events you are involved in		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the key roles to an EAP? (3)	1. Charge person: most capable to handle injury<div>2. Call person: calls ambulance and relays all info to EMS</div><div>3. Control person: The person who will keep onlookers away from the injury scene&nbsp;</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Go through the procedure when activating an EAP	1. Activate protocal<div>- call person calls EMS</div><div>- control person secures equipment and does the general help</div><div><br></div><div>2. Charge person performs intervention</div><div>3. Control person meets ambulance and call person relays info</div><div>4. Ensure medical info goes with athlete to hospital</div><div>5. Have someone accompany athlete to hospital</div><div>6. Complete injury report form</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
When should EMS be called?	"<img src=""paste-f2387b0343ece763a94a898b5153e977742e2954.jpg"">"			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
When should injury evaluation begin?	It begins once life-threatening injuries has been ruled out.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is the acronym for the secondary survey to understand the extent and severity of the injury in injury evaluation.	History<div>Observations</div><div>Palpation</div><div>Special Tests</div>	HOPS		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain 'history' in HOPS	"What do you want to know when investigating an injury?<div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">sounds and sensations</font> (did this athlete have a severe fracture?)</div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">Position</font> of the body/limb</div><div>- Was there <font color=""#00c3c3"">contact</font> with an opponent/strucutre?</div><div>- What <font color=""#00c3c3"">way</font> did the limb go?</div><div>- What <font color=""#00c3c3"">direction was the force/blow</font> applied to the body?</div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">Where </font>is the pain?</div>"	Do you have pain anywhere else?	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain 'observation' in HOPS	"What can you <font color=""#00c3c3"">see</font> injured vs. uninjured<div>- have a side-by-side comparison&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>- SHARP</div><div>- Deformity</div><div>- Severe Bleeding</div>"	In ideal cases, the history portion of the injury evaluation should give you ample information so that you do not have to move too much in the observation portion.	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What does the acronym SHARP mean?	Swelling<div>Heat</div><div>Altered Function</div><div>Redness</div><div>Pain.</div>	"<img src=""paste-c6d60b99f3bcc88c06451e38ce398d358b64812c.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain 'palpation' in HOPS	"What can you feel injured vs. uninjured?<div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">expose the area</font> as best as you can (take off equipment)</div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">apply appropriate pressure</font> depending on severity of injury</div><div>- know what <font color=""#00c3c3"">surface structures</font> you are touching (anatomy)</div>"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain 'special tests' in HOPS	"<font color=""#00c3c3"">Specific</font> to the type of injury sustained and structures involved.<div>- performed by <font color=""#00c3c3"">trained individuals</font></div><div>- used to <font color=""#00c3c3"">specifically identify structures</font> involved and severity of injury</div><div>- may include<font color=""#00c3c3""> ligament tests, range of motion, strength testing, vascular</font></div>"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Diaphysis	Shaft of bone<div>- covered by compact bone</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Epiphysis	"Composed of cancellous bone and has <font color=""#00c3c3"">hylaine cartilage</font> covering<div>- provides areas for muscle attachment</div>"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Periosteum	Dense, white fibrous covering<div>- contains blood vessels and osteoblasts</div>	"<img src=""paste-8cfb98bb24128bd19c88bb547864a845c6a06f97.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
7 Classifications for bones	1. Long Bones<div>2. Short Bones</div><div>3. Flat Bones</div><div>4. Sutural Bones</div><div>5. Pneumatized Bones</div><div>6. Sesamoid Bones</div><div>7. Irregular Bones</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
How does bone growth (ossification) occur?	Ossification occurs from synthesis of bones organic matrix (work of osteoblasts and osteoclasts)			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What do osteoblasts do?	Osteoblasts create bone.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What do osteoclasts do?	Osteoclasts break down bone in meduallary cavity.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Explain bone growth. (6 steps)	"1. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Ossifcation</font> occurs (via osteoblasts/clasts)<div>2. Diaphysis and epiphyseal growth plates <font color=""#00c3c3"">grow towards each other</font></div><div>3. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Cartilage matures</font> and immature osteoblasts replace to ultimately <font color=""#00c3c3"">form solid bone</font></div><div>4. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Bone diameter increase</font> (osteoblasts) while <font color=""#00c3c3"">osteoclasts break down</font></div><div>5. At full size bone <font color=""#00c3c3"">maintains a state of balance</font> (osteoblastic and osteo-clastic activity are equal)</div><div><br></div><div>6. Over time, bone loss begins to exceed external bone growth</div><div>- as thickness decreases, bones are less resistance to forces (osteoporosis)</div>"			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Wolff's Law	This law explains a bones functional adaptation to stress.<div><br></div><div>Stress imposed on tissue will determine the lines of strength (the more stress the stronger the bone)</div>	"<img src=""paste-13cf3a21ad6498c927ae8a302ca22e2c2870316d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the two ways fractures can be classified.	Closed or open.	"<img src=""paste-0f9ab29d52d55f9f3fd9a795e39eea7ff4b17bc9.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a closed fracture?	Fractures where there is little movement displacement<div>- most fractures are classified as this.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a open fracture?	Fracture that involves displacement of the fractured ends and breaking through the surrounding tissue.		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are signs and symptoms of a fracture? (5)	Deformity, pain, point tenderness, swelling, and pain<div>- possible crepitus</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is crepitus?	Bone grinding on bone (think of gravel grinding together in a bag)	"<img src=""paste-d8c428f64fd4ba6c2a02721b14e657c5a1808066.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the 6 types of fractures?	1. Greenstick<div>2. Comminuted</div><div>3. Linear</div><div>4. Transverse</div><div>5. Oblique</div><div>6. Spiral</div>	"<img src=""paste-8755814e90174a3f50788bea6990d30adfc47f36.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are green-stick fractures?<div><br></div><div>Who commonly gets this fracture? Why?</div>	Partial fracture/break<div>- usually occurs in youth, often times they won't have a full fracture.</div><div>- it's because their bones are more flexible</div>	"<img src=""paste-da45a8a3b18025575a8154eb7a8617e60a7d7940.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a comminuted fracture?	A break of the bone in more than two fragments.	"<img src=""paste-f3aff9c69c004cf9fc80745723694bb0396aedd3.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a linear fracture?	An incomplete fracture, basically cracks are forming.<div>- a fracture that runs parallel to the bone</div>	"<img src=""paste-57aaa0da4113a5d906fd8b53df56ef71832d177b.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a transverse fracture?	A fracture when the break is perpendicular to the shaft.	"<img src=""paste-d2376b5eb8510d5cadeb4e444f063d3c13350ad0.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is an oblique fracture?	A fracture in which the break is at an angle to the shaft.	"<img src=""paste-75f03b3aa852097f69260f9750a27ae15fc2b54a.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a spiral fracture?	A fracture due to torsion<div>- common in skiing</div>	"<img src=""paste-f30d983d2ed1883d7bbb08460ff56fec31e7c53a.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Stress Fractures	Basically fractures lead by a progression of multiple factors<div>- overload</div><div>- focal microfractures</div><div>- periosteal or endosteal response</div><div>- linear fractures (that progress into displaced transverse fractures)</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are focal microfractures?	Fracture when bone growth is not keeping up with bone fracture.		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are some typical causes for stress fractures?	1. Coming back to competition too soon after injury<div>2. Changing events without proper conditioning</div><div>3. Starting initial training too quickly</div><div>4. Changing training habits</div><div>5. Variety of postural and foot conditions</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are some signs and symptoms that you would see in stress fractures? Explain the early stages as well as the later stages.	"<font color=""#00ffff"">Early Stages</font>: focal tenderness and pain, there might be an ongoing minor ache or pain a high-risk area.<div><br></div><div><font color=""#00ffff"">Later Stages</font>: As it progresses the pain will become more constant; it won't be something that goes away with pain killers. It will just become more progressive.</div>"			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are some common sites for stress fractures to occur?	Tibia, fibula, metatarsal shaft, calcaneus, femur, par interarticularis (vertabra), ribs, and humerus			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Avulsion Fractures	Separation of bone fragment from cortex via pull of ligament or tendon.<div><br></div><div>The connection between the ligament and the bone will pull away from the bone itself, not just a tear (sprain).</div>	"<div>Don't know if this is the right photo hehe</div><img src=""paste-0c250234ca2a9b01d4878a0fa5ecd8a88d37198c.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are 3 types of epiphyseal conditions attributed to bone injuries?	1. Injury to growth plate<div>2. Articular epiphysis</div><div>3. Apophyseal injuries</div><div><br></div><div>Occurs most often in children aged 10-16 years old.</div>	"<div>Most susceptible to youths (apophyseal = injury due to fast growth)</div><img src=""paste-7af6b730ed9cf0f87a071786bb36c53b3934183e.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What age group is most susceptible to apophyseal injuries?	Young physically active individuals.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is apophyseal injuries?<div><br></div><div>What are examples of this?</div>	When athletes have a really massive growth spurt and the bone itself grows faster then the tendon to accomodate that length.<div><br></div><div>Stresses in the growth plates of adolescent athletes.</div>	"Eg: Severs Disease (Heels Pain)<div><img src=""paste-94948e5afbdfdf53c93a732c4c9d319165cfc8c1.jpg""><br></div><div>Eg: Osgood-Schlatter Disease</div><div><img src=""paste-326b4b341948992c92e5d1740c889c65599af1af.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is Severs disease?<div><br></div><div>What type of injury is this?</div>	It is an apophyseal injury to the heel. It is when the calcaneus grows too fast causing pain to the heel.	"<img src=""paste-94948e5afbdfdf53c93a732c4c9d319165cfc8c1.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is the Osgood-Schlatter disease?<div><br></div><div>What type of injury is it?</div>	It is an apophyseal injury when the femur grows too fast for the muscle. The knee then looks like it has a bump lower then it should be.	"<img src=""paste-326b4b341948992c92e5d1740c889c65599af1af.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the 6 basic characteristics of synovial joints.	1. A joint capsule<div>2. Articular cartilages</div><div>3. A joint cavity filled with synovial fluid</div><div>4. A synovial membrane lining the joint capsule</div><div>5. Accessory structures*&nbsp;</div><div>- ligaments? - menisci (fibrocartilage) - muscles?</div><div>6. Sensory nerves and blood vessels</div>	"<img src=""paste-9936390c6ace23743448bbdb786f7a628a0e8b2d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Name 4 types of synovial joint injuries.	1. Ligament sprains<div>2. Dislocations</div><div>3. Subluxations</div><div>4. Bursitis</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the grades of ligament sprains? What does each grade mean?	Grade 1: some pain with minimal loss of function, no abnormal loss of motion, mild tenderness<div><br></div><div>Grade 2: Pain, moderate loss of function, little bit of tearing but the ligament is still in tact.</div><div><br></div><div>Grade 3: Extremely painful with inevitable loss of function. It is a complete tear and may represent subluxation.</div>	"<img src=""paste-3fae5ba05ff811933f54b43c1c7062421ad55026.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a subluxation?	It is a partial dislaction causing incomplete separation of two bones.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>The ball has started to make itself out of the labrum but the muscles pulled it back in.</div><div>- not catastrophic because it has not completely separated</div>	"<img src=""paste-9f4ead18d10b35686b655646909a8d048f3c7696.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a dislocation?	It is the complete separation of two bones and usually results in a gross deformity. Usually obvious.<div><br></div><div>X-ray is very important for first time dislocations.</div>	"<img src=""paste-2f93827399f051acf8992262bfa1a811fa68ee1e.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Should you get an X-ray during first time dislocations? Why is this important?	Yes you should, this is very important for first time dislocations because we have to make sure there is no fractures that are there when we set the bone back in place. If there is a fracture piece situated inbetween the bones when the alignment happens then that would not be good!			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What happens to joint structures after a dislocation?	Static and dynamic stabilizing structures of the joint are damaged and therefore the joint will forever be weaker then it once was. This also means that subsequent dislocations would be easier to happen.	"""Once a dislocation, always a dislocation"""		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is bursitis?	Bursa are fluid-filled sacs in synovial joints.<div><br></div><div>Sudden irritation can cause acute bursitis whereas constant external compression can cause chronic bursitis.</div><div><br></div><div>Repeated trauma can lead to calcification and degeneration of internal bursa linings.</div>	"Doctors will not drain this often because it will increase the risk of infection and will likely to continue to swell up after the treatment. Just try to be as conservative as possible.<div><img src=""paste-c4fa1d3d0ac4d19bd110e66d6c7a45b9addf613c.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Which structure is stronger, a ligament or a tendon? Why?	A tendon is a lot stronger then a ligament. This is because tendons have wavy, parallel, and collagenous fibers whereas a ligament is just parallel.	This is why tears usually occur in muscles and not tendons		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
How much PSI can a tendon produce and maintain?	8 700 - 18 000 psi!			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What percentage of increased length is the breaking point of tendons?	6-8% of increased length occuring at a high velocity.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are three types of injuries that can occur to a tendon?	Tendinitis, tendinosis, and tenosynovitis			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is tendinitis?	Swelling/pain (inflammation) usually when the individual activates that tendon or when it is stretched.<div><br></div><div>Can lead to crepitus (stickiness or creakiness feeling)</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is tendinosis?	Can become this if tendinitus goes untreated. There is less welling but the tendon itself becomes weaker and harder to move.<div>- As you age it is harder for your tissues to heal and therefore is more common in middle or old age.</div><div>- treatment involves stretching and strengthening</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is tenosynovitis?<br>	Inflammation of the synovial sheath.<div>- acute case where there is rapid onset, crepitus, and diffuse swelling</div><div>- chronic cases result in thickening of tendon with pain and crepitus</div><div>- often occurs in long flexor tendon of the digits and the biceps tendon</div>	"<img src=""paste-f0c06de66862211d056b59ab87f15b033be9de93.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are muscle tears?	"These can also be considered ""strains""<div>- stretch tear, or rip to muscle or adjacent tissue</div><div>- may range from minute separation of connective tissue to complete tendinous avulsion or muscle rupture</div>"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the different grades to a muscle strain? What do each represent?	Grade 1: Fibers have stretched but not that much torn (some torn)<div>- is still willing to contract muscle</div><div>- usually brought to attention after the fact</div><div><br></div><div>Grade 2: Many fibres have been torn and contracting hurts like a bitch. May have some swelling and discoloration and usually a depression or divot is palpaple</div><div><br></div><div>Grade 3: Complete rupture of musclulotendinous junction; significant pain that diminishes due to nerve damage.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a contusion?<div><br></div><div>May result in the generation of ______.</div>	Injury resulting from a sudden blow to the body<div>- hematoma results from blood and lympth flowing into surrounding tissue</div><div>- blood forms a clot encapsulated by connective tissue</div><div><br></div><div>Chronically inflamed and contused tissue may result in generation of calcium deposits</div>	"<img src=""paste-30789b2545d64f7bb7eff64e5b65aa053816591d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is myositis ossificans?	It is when there is a muscle that is chronically inflamed and contused which results in the generation of calcium deposits.	"Prevention through padding.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-846eb026b7e0cbcec584dc2de940943f3a0956b6.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is Ectopic Calcification (myositis ossificans)?	It is a form of chronic musculoskeletal injury.<div><br></div><div>Striated muscle becomes chronically inflamed resulting in myositis.</div><div><br></div><div>Osteoid material accumulates rapidly and will either resolve in 9-12 months or mature with repeated trauma</div><div><br></div><div>With maturation, surgery is required for removal.</div><div>Common in quads and brachial muscles.</div>	"Myositis: inflammation and degeneration of muscle tissue<div><img src=""paste-3aebac127fa921c051afdfec3f0368c4949e6a31.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Muscle Cramps	Painful involuntary skeletal muscle contraction.<div>Occurs in well-developed individuals when muscle is in shortened position.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Muscle Guarding	When an injury happens, muscles tighten around the injured joint as a protective mechanism (limits ROM).<div>- Involuntary muscle contraction in response to pain following the injury</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Muscle Soreness	Overexertion in strenuous exercise resulting in muscular pain.<div>Generally occures following participation in an activity that individual is unaccustomed to.</div>	Eg: When you take a break from working out and then come back too hard.	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the two types of muscle soreness?	1. Acute-onset muscle soreness<div>2. Delayed onset muscle sorness (DOMS)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Acute-onset muscle soreness	Muscle soreness that occurs right away after a workout.		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS)	Muscle soreness that occurs at around 2 days after a workout.&nbsp;		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the primary mechanisms to injury to nerves?	"<font color=""#00c3c3"">Compression</font> and <font color=""#00c3c3"">tension</font> are primary mechanisms.<div>- can be acute (smashing funny bone) or chronic (continuous tightness of pec minor)</div><div><br></div>"			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What types of responses result from injury to nerves?	Causes pain and can result in sensory responses such as:<div>Pinch, burn, tingle, muscle weakness, and radiating pain.</div><div><br></div><div>Long-term problems can go from minor nerve problems to paralysis.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Neuropraxia<div><br></div><div>Can result from ______</div>	Most common form of nerve injury from acute trauma.<div>- interruption in conduction through nerve fiber via compression, stretch, or blunt trauma</div><div>- impacts motor more than sensory function</div><div>- temporary loss of function</div><div><br></div><div>Can result from fractures and dislocations.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
"What is the Brachial Plexus ""burner"" or ""stinger""?"	A type of injury to nerve.<div>Hyper-stretch of brachial plexus often due to acute trauma</div><div>- common in contact sports.</div>	"<img src=""paste-ba7ee770a0ae41ac254f633167d1439c88424787.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the movements of the spine?	Flexion, extension, right and left lateral flexion, and right and left rotation.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is the difference in movement between the cervial vs the thoracic spine?	There is more movement in the cervical spine and less movement in the thoracic spine.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How should an individual prevent injury to the cervical spine?	Muscle strengthening the neck!! (get that thick thick)<div>- prior to impact, the athlete should <b>brace the neck</b>&nbsp;(isometric contraction of neck)</div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ed1bba6a96de4d98240e7657cc435e6931d1836e.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How does an individual prevent injury in their thoracic spine when doing stuff?<div><br></div><div>Give an example.</div>	Make sure you have correct posture and available range of motion.<div>- functional strength and biomechanics</div>	"Eg: Doing OHP, sticking your head out so that the weight doesn't fall forward.<img src=""paste-3dd4214f49de3d0b7608df65514d0568ab2834a0.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How does an individual prevent injury in the lumbar spine?	Avoid stress (the hunch back)<div>Make sure everything you do is symmetrical to each other (feet and hamstrings)</div><div><br></div><div>Also, strengthen your back by doing back extension exercises, apparently according to Stu Mcgill, your lumbar spine only has a certain number of times it can do flexion.</div>	"<img src=""paste-9a20f991fd141b807f79b516d11790387f85962e.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is the Mcgill Big 3? What is the purpose of it?	1. Modified crunch<div>2. Raised hand side plank</div><div>3. Bird dog</div><div><br></div><div>The purpose of these exercises was to limit the amount of stress/flexion on the lumbar spine as much as possible (you only have a certain limit of flexion possible in the lumbar)</div>	"<img src=""paste-e7a570f762ba5429c522bd8f59ea23dcc6480b75.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How do we prevent injury when lifting in general?	Have good range of motion through stretching and mobility.<div><br></div><div>Use correct technique.&nbsp;</div><div>Use spotters when lifting.</div><div><br></div><div>Stabilize your trunk</div><div>- keeping your core contracted will reduce excessive pelvic tilt.</div>	"<img src=""paste-202ec54f15e7ccba8543f55f5550eca8977857f3.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are the muscles that control your posture? (3 maybe 4)	1. Multifidus<div>2. Transverse Abdominis</div><div>3. Pelvic Floor</div><div>4. Diaphragm?</div>	"<img src=""paste-0d46dec185c8066adf28f873d65f8b2fc95d5389.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is the first thing you should do when assessing a possible acute spinal injury?	"First we have determine the history of the injury and rule out if it was actually a spinal cord injury.<div><br></div><div>- What happened?</div><div>- <font color=""#00c3c3"">Pain in neck? Numbness, tingling, burning?</font></div><div>- can you move your ankles and toes</div><div>- do you have equal strength in both hands?</div><div><br></div><div>Positive responses to any of these questions will necessitate extreme caution!</div>"	"Follow HOPS!<div><img src=""paste-eeb73c764dab583ae1d741f7b412896e208ec16a.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
When assessing the spine, what observations must be do?	- body type<div>- postural alignments (kyphosis/lordosis) and any asymmetries&nbsp;</div><div>- assess height differences between anatomical landmarks</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Kyphosis	Excessive rounding of the thoracic spine<div>- kyphosis leads to a little forward head!&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""paste-67458a611256a81e06aab36fc1ccb0a8a633faad.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Lordosis<div><br></div><div>Which pelvic tilt?</div>	Excessive lumbar extension. Likely comes with an anterior pelvic tilt.	"<img src=""paste-cefc64d3be30a1fd2df00e9a0e649fe9a2ae4080.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Scoliosis	S-shaped curvature of the spine. Irregular patterns of the spine.	"<img src=""paste-378ca07b07d73bc29abf2e995c987db5225d74c8.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some things you should observe when assessing the cervical spine?	- symmetry of shoulders (depends on the sport too)<div>- observe from all angles</div><div>- willingness of the patient to move the head and neck freely &gt; assess active range of motion</div>	"<img src=""paste-14dc8a137a410f212849d5d80b6ef7dc462da68e.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some things you should observe when assessing the thoracic spine?	- upper thoracic spine and shoulder ROM<div>- lower thoracic region pain (possible costal involvement)</div><div>- facet joint involvement (with deep inspiration and chin tucked to chest, unwillingness to rotate or side flex accompanied by pinpoint pain)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some things you should observe when assessing the Lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint spine?	It is challenging to look for issues here<div>- equal levels (shoulders and iliums)</div><div>- symmetrical soft tissue structures bilaterally</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What should you look for when palpating the spine when assessing for spinal cord injury?	Spinous processes<div>- red flag if sharp pain</div><div>Transverse processes</div><div>- rib articulations</div><div>Sacrum and sacroiliac joint (SI)</div>	"When palpating the spinous processes, it it hard to pinpoint the exact spot, but at least you know it is a spinous process!<div><img src=""paste-d7b4c3e6ce4115ce29e430422cac1a93e85d2832.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are special tests you should do when evaluating the spine for possible injury? (4)	1. Straight-leg raise<div>2. Press-ups</div><div>3. Neurological exam</div><div>4. Reflex testing</div>	"Press up:<div><img src=""paste-ba354d3352826b112c42c9f4cc2aee9ea2af4a44.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Spinal special test - <b>straight-leg raise</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>What are the 3 different ranges that tell us about the spine?</div><div><br></div><div>Should you do this test passively or actively?</div>	"<img src=""paste-b09bb873aca7e47c14c2692e6da7807545e338a6.jpg"">"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Spinal special test - Press-ups<div><br></div><div>What would this test for?</div>	"<img src=""paste-1248c372e8c82078c3c41480b406d21ef030d828.jpg"">"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Spinal special test - Neurological exam	- Sensation testing (dermatome)<div>- Strength testing (myotome)</div>	"<img src=""paste-151765bba45c9a85947a60fb429426e425bd5fef.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Spinal special tests - reflex testing<div><br></div><div>The reflexes in the upper extremity are ______?</div><div>- which nerve roots? (3)</div><div>The reflexes in the lower extremity are ______?</div><div>- which nerve roots? (2)</div>	"<img src=""paste-108d760179939f4b9cca5e8ae5ab23a7c3fdbe6d.jpg"">"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is a common mechanism of injury for cervical fracture?	An axial load with a flexed spine.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some signs and symptoms of cervical fractures?	Neck pain/cervical pain<div>- weakness/numbness in limbs</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-d55e88845ca1493ec9fd2ecfdda04d9ea257e44e.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-324bf305dd68764793acac48bea9b42cfc3b3bdd.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How would you manage a suspected cervical fracture?	- Patient should be stabilzied, collared, and spine boarded regardless of level of consciousness<div>- use extreme care and caution</div><div>- stabilize the spine in where it is</div>	"<img src=""paste-c29435aba8cf7a3295ce08a6499b979a1747b7e3.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some etiology of acute strains of the neck and upper back (cervical spine)	- sudden unexpected movements of the head<div>- generally involves upper traps, scalenes, splenius capitis, and cervicis</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some signs and symptoms of acute strains of the neck and upper back (cervical spine)	- localised pain/point tenderness<div>- restricted motion and reluctance to move neck in any direction</div><div><b>May have to rule out Csp involvemnent when on-field/sideline</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What should you do to manage acute strains of the neck and upper back (cervical spine)?	Use a cervical collar<div>- may need referral to sports med</div><div>- will respond well with conventional therapy and progressive rehab</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some etiology of cervical sprains? (Whiplash)	Similar MOI as a strain (sudden unexpected movement of the head) but with more <b>force</b>&nbsp;and <b>velocity</b><div>- snapping or high force/velocity will lead to ligament damage of the Csp</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some signs and symptoms of cervical sprains? (Whiplash)<div><br></div><div>Similar to a strain but...</div><div>Tenderness...</div><div>May develop over night...</div>	- similar to a strain but <b>takes longer to heal</b><div>- tenderness of spinous and transverse processes</div><div>- significant muscle spasm and guarding (may develop slowly/overnight)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some management techniques of cervical sprains? (Whiplash)	Similar to strains, use a cervical collar<div>- also get sports med to look</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is acute torticollis?<div><br></div><div>Results from a...</div>	Wryneck<div>- pain on one side of the neck upon wakening</div><div>- result of <b>synovial capsule impingement</b> within a facet</div>	"<img src=""paste-a186da08bf3047e571804a85e0065005a4d4fe73.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some signs and symptoms of acute torticollis?	- palpable point tenderness and muscle spasm, restricted ROM, and muscle guarding			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What can you do to manage for acute toricollis?	- traction, superficial heat, cold treatments, and NSAIDs	NSAIDs = Non-steroid anti-inflammatory		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is the etiology of cervical cord and nerve root injuries?	Mechanisms include lacerations, compression, stretch, or blunt trauma			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some signs and symptoms of cervical cord and nerve root injuries?<div><br></div><div>Cord lesions here will result in death...</div>	- impact on motor and/or sensory function<div>- <b>cord lesions at or above C3 result in death</b></div><div>- incomplete lesions can result in a vast array of disability</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What can you do to manage cervical cord and nerve root injuries?	You can't do much, just handle with extremem caution to minimize further spinal cord damage.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is brachial plexus neurapraxia?<div><br></div><div>Also called...</div><div>Disrupts ______ without degenerative changes.</div>	Also called Burner.<div>- It is an injury to the cervical spine causes by stretching or compression of the <b>brachial plexus</b></div><div>- disrupts peripheral nerve function without degenerative changes</div>	"<img src=""paste-0e3fb0a5d836c57ca599f50fcb0f45de247838c6.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What some signs and symptoms of brachial plexus neurapraxia?	- burning, numbness, tingling, pain traveling from shoulder to hand<div>- repeated injury can cause neuritis (inflammation of nerves), muscular atrophy, and permanent damage</div><div>- severity will influence duration (partial vs complete tear)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What can you do to manage for brachial plexus neurapraxia?	- basically just wait it out, and return to activity once signs and symptoms resolve<div>- able to achieve pre-injury strength and sensation</div><div>- padding to limit neck ROM during impact</div>	"<img src=""paste-77d2f7d248b925d2954385f46a11800cc1388530.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is neuritis?	Inflammation of nerves.		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
"What are some etiology for ""low back pain""?"	"First of all, saying ""low back pain"" it too general.&nbsp;<div>- mechanical defects of the spine (posture, obesity, and body mechanics)</div><div>- back trauma</div><div>- muscle imbalances</div><div>- repetitive patterns</div>"	When we talk about muscle imbalances, it doesn't necessarily have to be about the muscles in the lower back but the muscles upper and lower of it.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some signs and symptoms of low back pain?	- pain and general weakness<div>- an <b>antalgic</b> gait (fancy word for a limp)</div><div>- neurological signs and symptoms if it becomes disk related</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
Antalgic Gait	The presense of some sort of pain when walking, obstruction of walking; altered gait<div>- fancy word for a limp</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What could we do to manage low back pain?	- Correct alignments and body mechanics<div>- strengthening and stretching to ensure proper segmental mechanics</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some etiology of vertebrae fracture and dislocation?<div><br></div><div>Usually from...</div><div>Dislocations are/are not rare.</div>	- compression fractures or fracture of the spinous or transverse processes<div>- fracture usually the result of <b>trunk hyperflexion</b></div><div>- dislocations are rare</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are some signs and symptoms of vertebrae fracture and dislocation (lumbar)	- compression fracture will require x-ray for detection<div>- point tenderness</div><div>- palpable defects on spinous and transverse processes</div><div>- swelling and significant guarding</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How would you manage vertebrae fracture and dislocation (lumbar)?	- x-ray and physician referral<div>- transport with extreme caution and care to minimize movement of the segments</div>	"<img src=""paste-d1376be482a21772a5c09d258a5306b9832d693b.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is Sciatica?<div><br></div><div>Tightness of which muscle?</div>	Some sort of aggravation of the sciatic nerve by:<div>- nerve root <b>compression</b></div><div>- anatomical <b>irregularities</b></div><div>- <b>tightness</b> of the <b>piriformis </b>muscle</div><div><br></div><div>The sciatic nerve is hella thick, there is a high chance for it to become pinched or disrupted.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are signs and symptoms Sciatica?<div><br></div><div>Which neurological test will test for this?</div>	- shart shooting pain, tingling and numbness<div>- sensitive to palpation</div><div>- straigh-leg raise intensify pain</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How would you manage Sciatica?	- in acute conditions, must remove from aggravating activity until healed (ICE - ice, compression, elevation)<div>- in chronic cases, requires assessment and rehab</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is a herniated disc?<div><br></div><div>What causes it?</div>	Remember what Stu Mcgill said? Constant lumbar flexion will result in a higher risk of herniated disc.<div>- caused by<b> abnormal stresses</b> and the <b>degeneration</b> due to use (forward bending and twisting)</div>	Its like taking a jelly donut, squeezing it, and the jelly being spurted out the side.	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What are signs and symptoms of a herniated disc?<div><br></div><div>Straight-leg raise where?</div><div>When are symptoms worse?</div>	"<img src=""paste-5656ec665fb2ff6131e6d1a91b3586c0a515ba5f.jpg"">"			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
How would you manage a herniated disc?	"<img src=""paste-b8876d73d61ae6e48d9134cf893f84fa94191b21.jpg"">"			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is Spondylolisis<div><br></div><div>Which fracture is it?</div>	Degeneration of the vertabrae due to congenital weakness (stress fracture results)<div>- Joint between spinous process and body where one side (spondy) develops a fracture</div><div>- still half in tact</div><div><br></div><div>A fracture at the <b>pars interarticularis </b>of the thoracic vertebrae</div>	"<img src=""paste-a748ffc917fff00067663dd9fd261cc265eb4cb2.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is Spondylolisthesis	Slipping of one vertabrae above or below another and is often associated with spondylolysis.<div>- this is a progression of spondylolysis (both sides are fractured not with nothing in the bone keeping anything in place)</div>	"<img src=""paste-f7103f34aa8784ab9a0a3c81e1538093f82830dc.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine

What are some rehab techniques for the low back? (6)	1. Flexibility<div>2. Strengthening exercises (extension/flexion)</div><div>3. Neuromuscular control (re-educate muscles to contract appropriately)</div><div>4. Core/dynamic stabilization</div><div>5. Functional progressions (movements slowly become more complex)</div><div>6. Return to activity (takes the same amount of time to heal as most extremity injuries)&nbsp;</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Spine
What is Physiotherapy?	Treatment of injuries or diseases by multiple methods.<div><br>Such as massage, heat treatment, and exercise (exercise is crucial)</div><div><br></div><div>Focus on changes to the body to help improve function following disease or injury.</div>	"<img src=""paste-55c47b7eeb21aa77c787f0e27102693f35df1b45.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What does physiotherapy encompass?	In every health-related setting, I feel like it encompasses a little bit of everything.<div><br></div><div>You have to take into though, that you are then not an expert, so <b>know your scope.</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-f99c6a7b29231669727f2d61bb194a87e9de8ce3.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What are the 3 different levels of Sport Physiotherapy? What age group has the highest amount of injuries?	Ages 15-19 years old<div>- the age group that plays sports the most</div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e107d0bb869d89664cc415e842992ce5c03df074.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What are common youth sport conditions? (4)	1. Osgood Schlatter's Disease<div>2. Sever's Disease</div><div>3. Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome</div><div>4. ACL rupture</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What physiological differences must we consider when doing rehabilitation on youth?	One of our main concerns is that youth are still growing, therefore we must consider their growth plates and such.<div><br></div><div>Also, recovery and sleep times will be different.</div>	"<img src=""paste-7ed330932d791fe06c5a02c22d3d42f8a82e8f1d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What cognitive differences must we consider when working with youth during rehab?	The brain is not fully developed in youth, and therefore their executive functions are affected.<div><br></div><div>This might affect their ability to make good choices, either by actually undergoing rehab excercises or going into play too quickly.</div>	"<img src=""paste-26207d6aee4a1d14fa867de14b3ab2384bed7e48.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What social differences must we consider when working with youth during rehab?	They are youth, maybe they are embarrassed to use crutches or is teased doing an exercise at the gym (who knows!)<div>- depression may occur</div>	"<img src=""paste-2641f4d713ec41c5f5a9ff3c0a23cd939feb9fdd.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What schedule differences must we consider when working with youth during rehab?	First of all, we have to consider that youth doesn't have a car and that they have a bunch of other things to do. Can they really have time to come to the clinic twice a week and go to the gym.<div><br></div><div>MUST WORK AROUND THEIR SCHEDULE DO NOT BE INSENSITIVE!!!</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
What are key differences we must consider when looking at a youth patient coming in for rehabilitation? (4)	1. Physiological Differences<div>2. Cognitive Differences</div><div>3. Social Differences</div><div>4. Schedule Differences</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
Taking into account the key differences we must look out for in youth rehabilitation, how might we work adapt our exercise prescription for them? (3)	"1. Make if <font color=""#00c3c3"">fun</font><div>2. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Convenient</font> (at home exercises if need be)</div><div>3. <font color=""#00c3c3"">Social</font> (bring a friend day)</div>"	"<img src=""paste-37c3a20ca45ad036fed875c608b0d4f2f822484f.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-5006978751f6bd11d26684dd0345f11844ef1bf8.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Intro_to_Physiotherapy
Let's say you approach an athlete got tackled and hit the back of their head on a wall. You see a little blood but nothing seems to be abnormal. The athlete says that he is fine, what would you do in the scenario?	"In situations like this, we must have a <b>""Black and White"" </b>mentally; basically, it is a concussion or it is not. Therefore we <b>must</b>&nbsp;<b>assess SCAT </b>and <b>err on the side of caution.</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Assume that all mechanisms significant enough to have caused <b>trauma to the skull</b> have also caused <b>trauma to the brain</b>.</div>"	"This is where the skillset of the assesser is very important!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-fb28c2bf8e506f58397de3a58147e3463cb0e4f3.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How does a brain injury occur?	A direct blow, or sudden snapping of the head forward, backward, or rotation to the side.	"<img src=""paste-e4e68129f6bdb844b8ab1aea38cb826f2ec1d887.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are some symptoms an individual will experience with a brain injury?	<b>1.</b> Loss of consciousness<div><b>2.</b> Disoreientation or Amnesia</div><div><b>3. </b>Motor Deficits</div><div><b>4. </b>Cognitive Deficits</div>	You have to note that each injury is variable and can present many symptoms.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is Cerebral Contusion?<div><br></div><div>1. Commonly occurs when _____</div>	It's when there is small hemorrhages or intracerebral bleeding within the <b>cortex, brain stem, or cerebellum</b>.<div><br></div><div>1. Commonly occurs when <b>head strikes a stationary object</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-4105b8d6ae60efd0d3b9dff1a9aca8a995932675.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of Cerebral Contusion?<div><br></div><div>2. Severity will _____ based on the extent of the injury.</div><div>3. Neurological exam is ______ but ______ persist.</div>	Will likely experience <b>loss of consiousness</b>&nbsp;and then become <b>very talkative once conscious</b>.<div><br></div><div>2. Severity will <b>vary greatly</b>&nbsp;based on the exten of the injury.</div><div>3. Neurological exam is <b>normal</b>&nbsp;but headache, dizziness, and nausea <b>persist.</b></div><div>- basically screening (eg: SCAT) will be normal but symptoms will persist</div>	"<img src=""paste-4105b8d6ae60efd0d3b9dff1a9aca8a995932675.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage for a cerebral contusion?<div><br></div><div>3. Return to play occurs when patient is ______</div>	1. Hospitilization and CT or MRI tests on the brain.<div>2. Treatment varies according to patient's clinical status</div><div>3. Return to play occurs when patient is <b>asymptomatic</b>&nbsp;and <b>CT scan is normal</b>.</div>	"<div>Asymptomatic: shows no symptoms</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-4105b8d6ae60efd0d3b9dff1a9aca8a995932675.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is an Epidural Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>1. Blood pressure leads to ______ and ______</div><div>2. How long can it take to create the hematoma?</div>	A blow to the head or skull fracture that <b>tears the meningeal arteries</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>1. Blood pressure leads to <b>rapid blood accumulation</b>&nbsp;and <b>creation of hematoma</b></div><div>2. Within minutes to hours.</div>	"<img src=""paste-6b7e7f7160c8f207344ea0c9366e10b68c571e5f.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of an Epidural Hematoma?	In the beginning, <b>LOC</b> followed by a <b>period of lucidity</b> showing <b>few S/S of serious head injury</b>.<div><br></div><div><b>Gradual progression </b>of S/S.</div><div>- head pains, dizziness, nausea, dilation one pupi, deterioration of consciousness, depression of pulse and respiration.</div>	"<img src=""paste-6b7e7f7160c8f207344ea0c9366e10b68c571e5f.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage an Epidural Hematoma?	CT scan may be necessary for diagnosis.<div><b>Must relieve pressure</b>&nbsp;to avoid disability or death.</div>	"<img src=""paste-6b7e7f7160c8f207344ea0c9366e10b68c571e5f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is a Subdural Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>1. Can present rapidly if ______</div><div>2. Can have a delayed onset if ______</div>	When <b>acceleration/deceleration forces </b>tear vessels that <b>bridge dura mater</b> and the <b>brain</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>1. Can present rapidly if <b>arterial</b></div><div>2. Can have a delayed onset if <b>venous bleed</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-018a31d44d82e5addd27e2955808495b17a033dc.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of Subdural Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>- What is the difference between a <b>simple</b>&nbsp;subdural hematoma and a <b>complicated</b>&nbsp;subdural hematoma?</div><div><br></div><div>1. Both show signs of ______</div>	<b>Simple: LOC</b> generally <b>does not occur</b><div><b>Complicated: </b>results in <b>LOC</b> and <b>dilation of one pupil</b>&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>1. Both show signs of headache, dizziness, nauea, or sleepiness.</div>	"<img src=""paste-018a31d44d82e5addd27e2955808495b17a033dc.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage a Subdural Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>2. Will further scans be necessary?</div>	1. <b>Immediate medical attention</b><div>2. CT scan or MRI is necessary to determine extent and location of injury</div>	"<img src=""paste-018a31d44d82e5addd27e2955808495b17a033dc.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is the difference between epidural and subdural hematomas?	Epidural hematoma are usually caused by bleeding from the <b>middle meningeal artery</b>&nbsp;(between the duramater and skull) caused by a <b>severe blow to the head</b> (BAM).&nbsp;&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Subdural hematoma on the other hand, is bleeding in the brain caused by <b>jostling of the brain </b>which stretches the veins/arteries.</div>	"<img src=""paste-30ec336c8c2d6d48edbe0fdf5d67b4067b64783f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are Migraine Headaches?<div><br></div><div>1. Exact causes are ______</div><div>2. Triggers could include ______</div>	<b>Recurrent </b>attacks of severe headache<div>1. exact causes<b> unknown</b></div><div>2. Triggers could include food, medications, sensory stimuli, lifestyle changes, or changes in estrogen levels</div><div>- <b>Basically a variety of factors</b></div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of Migraine Headaches?<div><br></div><div>1. Throbbing pain located on ______</div>	1. Throbbing pain on <b>on side of the head</b><div><br></div><div>Bright flashing lights, colored zigzag lines, <b>blind spots</b>, loss of vision on one side.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Sudden onset </b>with possible <b>gastrointestinal problems</b>&nbsp;and <b>sensitivity to light</b>, <b>sounds, </b>or <b>smells.</b></div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are Scalp Injuries?<div><br></div><div>1. Can occur in conjuction with ______</div>	Tend to be caused by <b>blunt trauma </b>or <b>penetrating trauma</b>&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>1. Can occur in conjunction with <b>serious head trauma.</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-9022320c45aff55726fafeb7b160d9ef1e573fc5.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are Mandible Fractures?	Generally fractures near the <b>frontal angle </b>of the mandible from a <b>direct blow.</b>	"<img src=""paste-99ddd73b8b6fe018bb3bc67e64e72251f71030b0.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are S/S of Scalp Injuries?	Usually difficult to pinpoint exact site but <b>bleeding is often extensive.</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage a Scalp Injury?<div>1. When should you go to a physician to get stitches?</div><div>2. Smaller wounds can be covered with ______.</div><div>3. What if hair is in the way?</div>	1. Wounds larger than <b>1/8 inch in depth</b>&nbsp;should be referred to a physician (need stitches!).<div>2. Smaller wounds can be covered with <b>protective covering and gauze.</b></div><div>3. If hair is in the way; if it is long enough, you can <b>braid the hair</b> around the wound to <b>provide support</b> around the laceration</div>	"<img src=""paste-cf1b5bfce017d6236819855c405669dc63635d71.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are S/S of Mandible Fractures?	Deformity, <b>loss of occlusion of teeth</b>, <b>pain when biting</b>, bleeding around teeth, and <b>lower lip anesthesia</b>.	"<img src=""paste-9c2c9f403d84cbbb35c30e5795b3169a19550fdc.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage a Mandible Fracture?	Temporary immobilization with <b>elastic wrap </b>followed by <b>reduction and fixation</b>.&nbsp;<div>- Wrap the fking head.</div>	"<img src=""paste-90c5301c24dc511626020d749396017a5e49ae92.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is a Mandibular Luxation?<div><br></div><div>1. Involves which joint?</div><div>2. Mechanism of injury?</div>	1. It involves the <b>temporomandibular joint </b>(TMJ)<div>2. Generally a blow to the <b>open mouth </b>from the <b>side.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>- my nigga just popped out.</div><div>- basically a dislocated jaw.</div>	"<img src=""paste-85735954fefa576b096febdba45638ec8960e76d.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of Mandibular Luxation?	<b>Locked-open </b>position of the jaw overriding <b>malocclusion</b>&nbsp;of the teeth.<div>- basically can't close mouth because of jaw dislocation.</div>	"<img src=""paste-31076fcd7c104433924f87879dd905d3cd9c69a0.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage a Mandibular Luxation?<div><br></div><div>1. Primary management? Immobilization?</div><div>2. Follow-up with ______.</div><div>3. When can they return to play?</div><div>4. What can be a problem after management?</div>	1. <b>Cold application</b>&nbsp;with <b>elastic immobilzation and reduction</b><div>2. Follow-up with <b>soft diet, NSAIDs, and analgesics</b></div><div>3. <b>Gradual </b>return to activity <b>7-10 days</b>&nbsp;following acute period.</div><div>4. Can be <b>recurrent </b>and result in <b>TMJ dysfunction.</b></div>	"<div>The follow-up portion just refers to <b>anti-inflammatory</b> (NASAIDs) and <b>pain killers</b> (analgesics)</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-31076fcd7c104433924f87879dd905d3cd9c69a0.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is a Temporomandibular Joint Dysfunction?	It is a <b>disk-condyle derangement</b> of the TMJ (disk is positioned anteriorly).	"<img src=""paste-e94a7965ef161a231a0841be45e7f909ac4a7902.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of TMJ Dysfunction?<div><br></div><div>1. What kind of pain is it?</div><div>2. ______ disk derangment.</div>	1. Headaches, earaches, vertigo, inflammation, and neck pain (pain at the joint or jaw)<div>2. Muscle dysfunction, limited ROM, or <b>internal disk derangement</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face

What is a Zygomatic Complex Fracture?	A fracture due to a <b>direct blow</b> to the cheekbone.	"<img src=""paste-d7c2a6b83dc03dec64875a7d08f1355b96871399.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face

What is a Nasal Fracture?	Its basically a broken nose due to a <b>direct blow</b>.<div>- A fracture of the nose.</div>	"<img src=""paste-4fd62867528a276c0e47f707c3a12a76b05bda15.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of Nasal Fractures?	<b>Hemorrhaging</b> (nose-bleed), immediate swelling, and <b>deformity</b>.	"<img src=""paste-4fd62867528a276c0e47f707c3a12a76b05bda15.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage a nasal fracture?<div><br></div><div>It this a serious injury? Will if affect the athlete's return to play?</div>	1. Control bleeding and refer to a physician for x-ray, examination, and reduction<div>2. Uncomplicated and simple fractures will <b>pose little problem</b> for the athlete's quick return.</div>	"<img src=""paste-4fd62867528a276c0e47f707c3a12a76b05bda15.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is Epistaxis?	It is a nose bleed.<div><br></div><div>Results from a <b>direct blow</b>, <b>sinus infection</b>, <b>high humidity</b>, <b>allergies</b>, a <b>foreign body</b>, or some other <b>serious facial injury</b>.</div>	"<img src=""paste-535effcec052765251e16776c275f6cb663d5e72.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of Epistaxis?<div><br></div><div>2. ______ may require more medical attention.</div>	1. Bleeding for one or both nostrils<div>2. <b>Persistent bleeding</b> may require more medical attention</div>	"<img src=""paste-535effcec052765251e16776c275f6cb663d5e72.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage Epistaxis?<div><br></div><div>1. What would you do to stop the bleeding?</div><div>2. After bleeding, can the athlete return to play?</div>	1. Sit upright, slighly forward and apply pressure to affected nostril<div>2. After bleeding, patient can return to play but should <b>not blow nose</b>&nbsp;for at least <b>2 hours</b>&nbsp;</div><div>3. Mystery heel smash method?</div>	"<img src=""paste-535effcec052765251e16776c275f6cb663d5e72.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is the <b>Mystery Heel Smash Method</b>&nbsp;to fix Epistaxis?	You lay the individual on their back, lift the leg, and hammer the heel.<div>- It will stop the nosebleed</div><div>- Don't know how or why but it works</div>	"<img src=""paste-535effcec052765251e16776c275f6cb663d5e72.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are tooth fractures?	A tooth chipping because of <b>impact </b>to the <b>jaw </b>or <b>direct trauma</b>	"<img src=""paste-027dfb9b1dc21f9c5edf41bc2d5b50061543e737.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of a tooth fracture?<div><br></div><div>1. Uncomplicated tooth fracture?</div><div>2. Complicated tooth fracture?</div><div>3. Root fractures?</div>	1. Uncomplicated: fragments <b>without bleeding</b><div>2. Complicated: <b>bleeding</b> and great deal of <b>pain</b></div><div>3. Root fracture need <b>x-ray follow up</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-027dfb9b1dc21f9c5edf41bc2d5b50061543e737.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage a tooth fracture?<div><br></div><div>1. Uncomplicated tooth fracture?</div><div>2. Complicated tooth fracture?</div><div>3. Root Fracture?</div>	1. Uncomplicated/complicated <b>do not</b> require immediate attention<div>- bleeding can be controlled via gauze</div><div>- cometic reconstruction of tooth</div><div>2. <b>Must follow up</b> immediately following competition</div><div>- may need tooth repositioning along with bracing, and use of mouthpieces in the future.</div>	"<img src=""paste-993ab34621989b091435a45e41135b57359eb5ac.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is a tooth subluxation, luxation, and avulsion?	Losing teeth due to a direct blow.	"Note:&nbsp;<div>Subluxation - tenderness</div><div>Luxation - partial avulsion</div><div>Avulsion - tooth knocked out</div><div><img src=""paste-98c1efe54df59eae61bd074674189f402b10898b.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of a tooth subluxation/luxation/avulsion?	<b>Subluxed: </b>tooth may be loose in socket with little or no pain<div><b>Luxation: </b>no fracture has occured but there is displacement</div><div><b>Avulsion: </b>tooth is gone my nigga.</div>	"<div>This would be a luxation.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-98c1efe54df59eae61bd074674189f402b10898b.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage tooth subluxation/luxation/avulsion?<div><br></div><div>Referall should occur within...</div>	"Referral should occur <b>within 48 minutes</b><div><b>Luxation: attempt tooth repositioning</b> with immediate referral to dentist</div><div><b>Avulsion: </b>can be replanted with a ""Save a Tooth kit, milk, or saline but this <b>rarely</b>&nbsp;happens (priority is not on tooth replanting)</div>"	"<img src=""paste-98c1efe54df59eae61bd074674189f402b10898b.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is Auricular Hematoma?	"Also known as ""<b>Cauliflower Ear</b>""<div><br></div><div>Occurs from <b>compression</b> or <b>shearing</b> injury to the ear</div><div>- can be single or repeated</div><div><br></div><div>Accumulation of blood in the ear, common in athletes</div>"	"<div>This is why some athletes wear tape on their ears.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-c82b07fc94edf02de60fb5cb2085d892b1c7112e.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of Auricular Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>1. What do you see occur?</div><div>2. What happens if left unattended?</div>	1. <b>Hemorrhaging</b> and <b>fluid accumulation</b><div>2. If unattended, <b>coagulation</b>, <b>organization</b>, and <b>fibrosis</b> occur</div>	"<img src=""paste-c82b07fc94edf02de60fb5cb2085d892b1c7112e.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage an Auricular Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>1. How would you prevent it?</div><div>2. ______ will minimize hemorrhaging</div><div>3. What if effects persist?</div>	1. Wear proper <b>ear protection</b> (tape)<div>2. <b>Cold application </b>will minimize hemorrhaging</div><div>3. Physician <b>aspiration</b>, <b>packing</b>, and <b>pressure</b> if persists</div>	"<img src=""paste-c82b07fc94edf02de60fb5cb2085d892b1c7112e.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What <b>very important things&nbsp;</b>must you consider when assessing the eye?	Use <b>extreme caution</b>&nbsp;when evaluating the eye.<div><br></div><div>Transportation to hospital should take place with patient in <b>recumbent </b>position.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Both eyes should be covered together.</b></div><div>- movement of unaffected eye will cause movement in affected eye.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What questions should you ask when assessing the <b>history</b>&nbsp;of a possible eye injury? (4)	<b>1.</b>&nbsp;What was the mechanism of injury?<div><b>2. </b>Was loss of vision gradual or immediate?</div><div><b>3. </b>What was the visual status before injury?</div><div><b>4. </b>Was there LOC?</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What type of observations should you make when assessing a possible eye injury?	1. External structures inspected for swelling, discoloration, penetrating objects, and movement of the lid<div>2. Inspect globe of the eye for lacerations, foreign bodies, hyphema, and deformities</div>	"<div><br></div><img src=""paste-2064da80fe5b1c22b783c9b09d42b6a1ad66b910.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
Tracking of the eye should only occur when ______.	Only if the individual is okay with moving their eye - no pain. Because if there is a foreign object then moving can damage it significantly.	"<div><br></div><img src=""paste-2064da80fe5b1c22b783c9b09d42b6a1ad66b910.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
Where should you palpate the eye when assessing for an eye injury?<div><br></div><div>What are you looking for?</div>	You should palpate the <b>orbital rim </b>for point <b>tenderness</b>&nbsp;and <b>bont deformity</b>.	"<img src=""paste-93555db9eeca37d734fecd474ff23487b748ad7f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What types of special tests can you do to assess an eye injury?	1. <b>Pupillary test</b>: testing <b>dilation</b>&nbsp;and <b>accomodation</b><div>- testing with a flashlight</div><div>2. <b>Basic acuity test</b>: using a Snellen Chart, or asking to <b>look at letters from a shirt</b>.</div>	"<img src=""paste-4fd70551adf90b0c34bc4141d3a751d428657ecb.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is an Orbital Hematoma?	Also known as a Black Eye.<div><br></div><div>It is a blow to the area surrounding the eye resulting in <b>capillary bleeding</b>.</div>	"<img src=""paste-0688135865ca09532e4d43ca325939d34d4fc00b.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are S/S of an Orbital Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>What are signs of a more serious condition?</div>	Signs of a more serious condition may be displayed as a <b>subconjuctival hemorrhage.</b><div>- bleeding of a vessel in the eye</div>	"<img src=""paste-9c230d856dd87d7284fbff879d2e6164142810d9.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage an Orbital Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>What should you not do after acute eye injury?</div>	1. Put ice<div>2. <b>Do not blow nose</b> after acute eye injury</div>	"<img src=""paste-b99cbcbe9d778fd41592b065c82b675f54a55642.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are S/S of someone having a foreign body in their eye?	1. Considerable pain and disability			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage an athlete who has foreign bodies in their eye?<div><br></div><div>What if the foreign body is embedded in the eye?</div>	NO attempt should be made to remove by <b>rubbing or recovering with fingers</b>.<div><br></div><div>Close eye and determine location (upper or lower lid) - pull to cause tearing</div><div><br></div><div>Wash eye with saline - <b>rinse with affected eye at bottom</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>If object is embedded, close and patch <b>both eyes </b>and refer to physician.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are Corneal Abrasions and Lacerations?<div><br></div><div>How does the eye become abraded?</div>	Damage to the eye due to scraping of some sort.<div><br></div><div>Cornea becomes abraded when patients attempt to <b>remove objects from eye by rubbing</b>.</div>	"Eg: A fingernail scraping an athletes eye.<div><img src=""paste-aa40de3f4562fabf608b261271e5affc75b2f9a0.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What are the S/S of a Corneal Abrasion and Laceractions?	Severe pain and <b>watering of the eye</b>.	"Eg: A fingernail scraping an athletes eye.<div><img src=""paste-aa40de3f4562fabf608b261271e5affc75b2f9a0.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
How would you manage Corneal Abrasions and Lacerations?<div><br></div><div>What does the diagnosis require?</div>	1. <b>Patch eye</b>&nbsp;and refer to a physician<div>2. Diagnosis requires a <b>fluorescein strip</b>&nbsp;(stains abrasion bright green</div><div>3. <b>Antibiotic ointment is applied </b>with a semipressure patch of the closed eye lid.</div>	"Eg: A fingernail scraping an athletes eye.<div><img src=""paste-aa40de3f4562fabf608b261271e5affc75b2f9a0.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injuries_to_Head_and_Face
What is Hyphema?<div><br></div><div>Also called...</div>	A <b>blunt blow to the eye</b> making it have a red or yellowish tinge<div>- the zombie eye</div>	"<img src=""paste-10b4e30cb42a8e6e19d73f536a497c00da9b74c3.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are the S/S of Hyphema?	1. A collection of blood in the <b>anterior chamber </b>of the eye<div>2. <b>Reddish tinge </b>in anterior chamber (blood may turn pea green)</div><div>3. Vision is partially or completely <b>blocked</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-10b4e30cb42a8e6e19d73f536a497c00da9b74c3.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
How would you manage Hyphema?	Refer to physician.<div><br></div><div>Bed rest and elevation (30-40 degrees), <b>both eyes patched</b>, <b>sedation</b>, and <b>medication </b>to reduce anterior chamber pressure.</div><div><br></div><div>- basically patch both eyes and go to physician.&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""paste-10b4e30cb42a8e6e19d73f536a497c00da9b74c3.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is a Retinal Detachment?	When you get a <b>blow to the eye</b>&nbsp;that can partially or completely <b>separate retina from the back of the eye</b><div>- basically the eyeball following out</div>	"<img src=""paste-dcf6325d6b1250e1fa7f108328168e2452c55daa.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
