What are S/S of Retinal Detachment?<div><br></div><div>1. How painful is it?</div><div>2. What are early signs of this?</div><div>3. How does it progress?</div>	"1. Painless<div>2. <b>Early signs</b>: specks floating before the eye, flashes of light, blurred vision</div><div>3. Gradual <b>""curtain""</b> falling over the field of vision (blindness)</div>"	"<img src=""paste-dcf6325d6b1250e1fa7f108328168e2452c55daa.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
How would you manage a Retinal Detachment?	<b>Immediate referral to an ophthamologist</b>&nbsp;(what is this lol)	"<img src=""paste-dcf6325d6b1250e1fa7f108328168e2452c55daa.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is an Acute Conjunctivitis?	It's basically <b>pink eye</b>.<div><br></div><div>Caused by bacteria, allergens, irritation, and is commonly associated with a cold or upper respiratory conditions.</div>	"<img src=""paste-136bd635eab8556ba51451644fa93944166e3cde.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What are S/S of Acute Conjunctivitis?	<b>Eyelid swelling</b> with <b>purulent discharge and itching</b> associated with an allergy.	"<img src=""paste-136bd635eab8556ba51451644fa93944166e3cde.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
How would you manage Acute Conjunctivitis?	Refer them to a physician as soon as possible. Since this is <b>highly infectious</b>, you <b>will not</b>&nbsp;allow them around the team until possibility of spreading is gone!	"<img src=""paste-c9a5ab78c35054e70579b456ca47d7d3bf875eec.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
When would you need to <b>transport </b>(if emergent) or <b>refer</b>&nbsp;and eye injury? (5)	1. Extended loss or decrease of vision<div>2. Narrowing of peripheral vision</div><div>3. Altered/assymetrical pupil reaction</div><div>4. Prolonged double vision</div><div>5. Altered lid function/severe swelling</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
Define a Sports Related Concussion (SRC).	A complex <b>pathophysiological process </b>affecting the brain, induced by <b>traumatic </b>biomechanical forces.	Note: You do not need to be hit in the head to have a concussion!<div><br></div><div>Eg: Whiplash type injury (shaking the brain)</div><div><br></div><div>Also considered a <b>mild traumatic brain injury</b></div>	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What can cause a <b>Sport Related Concussion </b>(SRC)?	"<b>Direct blow </b>to the head, face, neck, or elsewhere on the body with an <b>""impulsive"" </b>force <b>transmitted to the head</b>."			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
For an SRC, what would be a typical symptom for the athlete?	<b>Rapid</b>&nbsp;onset of <b>short-lived impairmnet</b>&nbsp;of <b>neurological function</b>.	A longer-lived impairment would be considered a <b>traumatic brain injury.</b>&nbsp;		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
An SRC is typically due to a&nbsp;{{c1::functional disturbance}} rather than a&nbsp;{{c2::structural injury}}	No abnormality of standard <b>structural neuroimaging</b>, may see this later with advanced imaging.	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When an athlete gets a SRC, does that athlete lose consciousness?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The athlete may or may not lose consciousness.}}<br></div>	Wide range of clinical symptoms.	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
Resolution of clinical and cognitive features typically follows a&nbsp;{{c1::sequential course.}}		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
"What is ""<b>Post Concussion Symptom""</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Occurs in a small percentrage of causes <b>(10-15%)</b>&nbsp;where symptoms of concussion are prolonged.}}<br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are the different levels of severity for a concussion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is no levels of severity, severity should be <b>equal all across the board</b>}}<br></div>	Abandoned all grading systems.	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
The majority (85-90%) of concussions resolve in ______<div><br></div><div>{{c1::7-9 days.}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What should you do if a concussion is suspected?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Remove from play and have them assessed by a trained healthcare provider}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
How does a concussion occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When an athlete is moving at a high rate of speed and collides with another object</div><div><br></div><div>The brain shifts inside the skull and <b>strikes</b>&nbsp;the bony surfaces. Direct impact to the brain causes&nbsp;<b>acceleration</b>&nbsp;of the brain leading to <b>shear, tensile, and compression forces</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ed983cf0452f506e925313f8c4bd220822d958fe.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What is a <b>contrecoup </b>injury?	It is the result of a primary impact which causes an acceleration (Eg: brain) creating a <b>secondary impact</b>&nbsp;away from the actual impact site.	"Hitting the head, the brain is driven back and the posterior side hits the skull.<div><img src=""paste-de7588371474ed99f40c6fa4564cd08527fd1bdf.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
How would you check for the S/S of a concussion?	"1. Ask them, ""on a scale of 0 to 100, how do you feel?<div>2. ""What makes you not 100%?</div><div>3. Checklist - SCAT5</div>"	"<img src=""paste-3ca4c913a728fc757c12c68aea44a1bd381d2bab.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
Field Evaluation of Concussion<div><br></div><div>1. In our medical evaluation, we must pay particular attention to excluding a&nbsp;{{c1::spinal cord injury}}.</div><div><br></div><div>2. The player&nbsp;{{c2::should never be left alone}} immediately following the injury</div><div><br></div><div>3. What should we do over the initial few hours following injury?</div><div>{{c3::<b>Continual monitoring </b>for deterioration}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are on-field assessment tools for concussion? (5) - FSKBS	<b>F</b>ield SCAT5<div><b>S</b>CAT5</div><div><b>K</b>ing-Devick</div><div><b>B</b>alance</div><div><b>S</b>ubjective Assessment</div>	<b>King-Devick</b>: More sport specific then SCAT5<div><br></div><div><b>Subjective Assessment: </b>If you know a buddy that got hit with a bar, passed all his SCAT tests but seems to be acting differently. That is a subjective assessment that is much more important and is crucial.</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are <b>clinical evaluations </b>of concussion you can use? (3)	1. <b>Neuroimaging </b>(CT, MRI)<div>- contributes little to the actual concussion evaluation but is used when suspician of <b>intracerebral structural lesion</b><br><div>2. <b>Balance Assessment</b></div><div>- Balance error scoring system (BESS)</div><div>3. <b>Neuropsychological Assessment</b></div></div><div>- best done after <b>symptom resolution</b></div><div>- this is because it is most sensitive compared to baseline</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When is a neuropsychological assessment for concussion best done?	It is best done <b>after symptom resolution</b>&nbsp;as this test is the most sensitive compared to baseline.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
How would you manage a concussion?	You don't, you basically let them <b>REST UNTIL ASYMPTOMATIC</b><div>- by rest I mean mther fking <b>absolute rest</b></div>	"Beware things that will stimulate the brain!<div><br></div><div>Also, remember that symptoms should resolve in 7-10 days (so absolute rest for this amount of time)<br><div><img src=""paste-7a7f8da2321a56a7de9335a27301808934759671.jpg""><br></div></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are some <b>Clinical Management</b>&nbsp;of Concussions?	1. Maybe go see a <b>psychologist</b> (plays a role)<div>2. <b>Pharmacotherapy: </b>anxiety or sleep (drugs)</div>	Make sure that athlete isn't on any drugs that can mask symptoms.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
If an athlete has symptoms from a concussion for 10 days, and it finally resolved, what would you tell them to do?	A common approach is to require the athlete to <b>remain asymptomatic</b>&nbsp;for the same amount of time as it took for them to become asymptomatic.<div><br></div><div>So, GO FKING REST FOR ANOTHER 10 DAYS TO MAKE SURE UR SHIT IS NOT COMING BACK</div>	However, start process when asymptomatic should be <b>at least 24-48 hours.</b>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
After an athlete is asymptomatic of a concussion for the required period, how would you return them back to learning?<div><br></div><div>What are the 4 Steps?</div>	1. ADL that do not give athlete symptoms<div>2. School activites</div><div>3. Return to school part-time</div><div>4. Full-time school</div>	"<img src=""paste-d408cb119058ebaa32809ff62b78ee4b337b9b36.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-b59addc4e7d092ccc54fe52c319d8aec75626ef7.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
For the <b>steps to return to play </b>(from SCAT5), how long should you wait to progress each step?<div><br></div><div>What happens if symptoms pop-up again mid progression?</div>	There should be a <b>minimum 24 hours </b>between each step.<div><br></div><div>The process is <b>paused</b>&nbsp;with any recurrence of symptoms.&nbsp;</div><div>- when paused, wait for symptoms to go away, then resume <b>where you left off</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-6ac6247779b81ad7bfd8d525a09ca6b4699a189f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are some other factors you should take into account when returning an athlete who had a concussion back into play? (3)	1. <b>Must pass graded exertion first</b>&nbsp;<div>- meaning the athlete should be gradually put to exertion and made sure that remains asymptomatic</div><div>2. Is the athlete <b>confident </b>to go back?&nbsp;</div><div>- maybe adjusting helmet/protective equipment to make them feel more safe</div><div>3. Consider <b>atrophy and how much they've missed</b>.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What should you consider if the concussed individual is an adolescent? (4)	1. Must include both patient as parent in the process<div>- also important to have physician/pediatrician in the process</div><div>2. Symptoms <b>may take longer</b> to resolve</div><div>3. Consider extending symptom free period before protocol</div><div>4. Consider extending length of the <b>graded exertion protocol</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-80544c506e643109fd197cf2fb07fea861ad0b6b.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What should you consider when the concussed individual is a student?	Need to <b>inform teachers/professors</b>&nbsp;on their cognitive limtaions atm.<div>- apply for extensions or deferrals for exams</div><div><br></div><div><b>Long-term accomodations </b>may be necessary depending on length of recovery</div>	Important to reduce the anxiety of the athlete. You step in and ensure the athlete is being supported in the academic as well as the physical side.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are some ways you can prevent a concussion from occuring? (4)	1. Look at the <b>past medical history</b> of the athlete, if the had a past SRC they are <b>susceptible!</b><div>2. <b>Education</b>: make sure athletes, coaches, and parents all know the S/S of a concussion</div><div>3. <b>Rule Changes</b>: Eg: football tackling in youth or increase severity of penalties in professional level</div><div>4. <b>Protective Equipment</b>: make sure their properly fitted and shit</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are the risks of an athlete that has already been concussed before?<div><br></div><div>What is important to glean for previous experince?</div>	Having a past SRC is a <b>risk factor </b>for future SRC.	<b>Important </b>to find out how prior concussions were managed (gives us info on wait times and return to play)		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What is the Q-Collar?	"It's a new technology that will apparently decrease the chances of concussion by manipulating the brain's blood flow which in turn will keep the brain from ""sloshing around"" and getting damaged."			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are some challenges from specifically <b>sport </b>concussion?	1. Fast pace of the game<div>2. Athletes are stubborn as fk and say they don't got a concussion</div><div>3. Pressure from coaches/parents</div><div>4. limited resources to assess athlete</div><div>5. Injuries are subtle and difficult to detect</div><div>6. Objectivtity of assessment (not very objective)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
Who is Rowan?<div><br></div><div>What is Rowan's Law?</div>	Rowan was basically a girl who experienced 3 concussions and played in 3 consecutive games. She told noone which led to <b>Second Impact Syndrome and death.</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Rowan's Law requires all coaches and team trainers to review the government-approved Conccusion Awareness Resources every year to prevent this from happening.</div>	"<img src=""paste-b15e7711635b0e2e1ed4da99ea784c741da76daf.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What is <b>Second Impact Syndrome?</b>	<b>Rare condition</b>&nbsp;in which a second concussion occurs before a first concussion has properly healed.<div><br></div><div>Causes rapid and severe brain swelling.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
Second Impact Syndrome<div><br></div><div>1. Most cases of second impact syndrome occur in ______</div><div>2. Is or is not life-threatening?</div><div>3. What is the mortality and disability rate?</div><div>4. Most likely occur if age is ______</div>	1. <b>Young athletes</b><div>2. It is <b>life-threatening</b></div><div>3. Mortality rate is around <b>50%</b> while the disability rate is nearly <b>100%</b></div><div>4. Most likely occur if age is <b>under 20</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
How did the Rowan tragedy affect the policy and procedure for RTP from concussion?	1. Policies are more <b>extensive</b><div>2. Ontario provincial government legislation</div><div>3. Many NSO/PSO follow suit without mandated legislation</div><div>4. Follows a <b>strict </b>and <b>structured RTP </b>process</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What are the 6 steps to managing an RTP for concussion?	<b>1. </b>Symptom Limited Activity<div><b>2. </b>Light Aerobic Activity</div><div><b>3. </b>Sport-specific exercise</div><div><b>4.</b>&nbsp;Non-contact training drills</div><div><b>5. </b>Full Contact Practice</div><div><b>6. </b>Return to Sport</div>	"<img src=""paste-06de66f91009d4050bd82f749c44b37a31c8814a.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When doing step 1 of managing an RTP_____<div>1. What are the key parameters?</div><div>2. What is the goal?</div><div>3. Give some examples.</div>	1. Doing <b>ADL</b> that do not provoke symptoms (non-sport specific)<div>2. <b>Gradually</b> introducing them back in cognitively stimulating activity</div><div>3. Reading for short periods of time or exposure to varying types of lighting/sunlight</div>	"<div>Step 1: Symptom Limited Activity</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-06de66f91009d4050bd82f749c44b37a31c8814a.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When doing step 2 of managing an RTP_____<div>1. What are the key parameters?</div><div>2. What is the goal?</div><div>3. Give some examples.</div>	1. Non-sport specific <b>controlled activities</b> that do not put the athlete at risk<div>2. Increase heart rate to <b>moderate levels</b></div><div>3. Stationary cycling, treadmill jogging</div><div>- only swimming if the person is a swimmer!</div>	"<div>Step 2: Light Aerobic Activity</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-e7bdf6df0dc1950a91e73895b0bffb215791ca27.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When doing step 3 of managing an RTP_____<div>1. What are the key parameters?</div><div>2. What is the goal?</div><div>3. Give some examples.</div>	1. Sport-specific exercise where risk of head impact or contact <b>does not exist.</b>&nbsp;Not likely integrated back with teammates yet.<div>2. <b>Sport specific skills</b>, isolated performance drills that c<b>ognitively challenge</b> the athlete&nbsp;</div><div>3. Soccer: juggling, shooting</div><div>- Hockey: stick handling, shooting</div><div>- Baseball: throwing/catching</div>	"<div>Step 3: Sport-specific exercise</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-e7bdf6df0dc1950a91e73895b0bffb215791ca27.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When doing step 4 of managing an RTP_____<div>1. What are the key parameters?</div><div>2. What is the goal?</div><div>3. Give some examples.</div>	"1. Introduce high intensity drills/activities<div>- integrate back into practice but with ""<b>red shirt</b>""</div><div>- can start resistance training</div><div>2. Technical/tactical drills that involve <b>interacting with teammates/opponents</b></div><div>- Experience situations with reaction time/decision making</div><div>3. Soccer: small area game</div><div>- Hockey: system drills, powerplay, breakout</div><div>4. Baseball: infield grounding and playmaking</div><div>- outfield drills.</div>"	"<div>Step 4: Non-contact training drills</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-e7bdf6df0dc1950a91e73895b0bffb215791ca27.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When doing step 5 of managing an RTP_____<div>1. What are the key parameters?</div><div>2. What is the goal?</div><div>3. Give some examples.</div>	1. Full contact practice but must be in a <b>controlled situation</b> and must be<b> cleared by a physician</b><div>2. <b>Introduce sport-specific contact</b>, <b>restore confidence</b> through <b>exposure</b>, evaluate <b>abilities</b> of athlete</div><div>3. Soccer: corner kick, heading the ball</div><div>- Hockey: live action play; battle drills in corner</div><div>- Baseball: batting, running bases in a live scrimmage</div>	"<div>Step 5: Full Contact Practice</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-e7bdf6df0dc1950a91e73895b0bffb215791ca27.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
When doing step 6 of managing an RTP_____<div>1. What are the key parameters?</div><div>2. What are key considerations?</div>	1. Completed last stage <b>without hesitancy</b>, so <b>athlete is confident</b>!<div>- <b>written clearance</b> from physician</div><div>- conditioned enough to be able to return <b>without risk of injury</b></div><div>2. First game back may bring on symptoms again so consider this stage as <b>something to be passed</b> with no symptoms after the game</div>	"<div>Step 6: Return to Sport</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-e7bdf6df0dc1950a91e73895b0bffb215791ca27.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What is the Alberta Concussion Alliance?<div><br></div><div>What should we look into them for?</div>	They are basically an extensive list of resources for everything concussion management.<div>- return to learning protocol</div><div>- return to sport protocl</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
Who should you have as part of your IST around an athlete with a concussion? (4)	1. <b>Sports medicine physician</b> OR <b>family doctor </b>who has an interest/understanding of concussion<div>2. <b>Athletic Therapist/Physiotherapist</b></div><div>- soft tissue symptom management from initial injury</div><div>3. <b>Chiropractor</b></div><div>- cervical spine hypomobility and misalignment may present as concussion symptoms</div><div>4. <b>School Staff</b></div><div>- understand the limitations and requirement for cognitive rest</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
How would you establish a <b>protocol </b>for concussion?	1. <b>Work with coaching staff and managers</b><div>2. <b>Make clear guidelines</b></div><div>- take athlete out of game</div><div>- who the athlete should follow up with</div><div>- who makes the decision to put athlete back into RTP</div><div>- who makes the final call on when the athlete can RTP</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Concussion
What is the difference between <b>Tendinitis</b>&nbsp;and <b>Tenosynovitis?</b>	There actually isn't that much of a difference.<div><br></div><div>Tenosynovitis is tendinitis but with <b>inflammation</b>&nbsp;of the <b>tendon sheath lining.</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is the difference between <b>Cervical, Thoracic, and Lumbar vertabrae?</b>	Cervical: transverse foramen, dens on axis, bifidus processes<div><br></div><div>Thoracic: Costal + demi facets</div><div><br></div><div>Lumbar: Pedicles</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is the difference between cervical strain and sprain?	Sprain is basically a strain but more severe and takes longer to heal.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What is the difference between <b>spondylolisis </b>and <b>spondylolisthesis?</b>	Spondylolisis is a partial break of the vertabrae (one side) whereas spondylolisthesis is a complete slipping of the vertabrae.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_1::Injury_Identification
What type of <b>screening </b>should we do for <b>injury prevention</b>? (5)	1. Medical History<div>2. Physical Examination</div><div>3. Orthopedic Screening</div><div>4. Wellness Screening</div><div>5. Health Maintenance and Personal Hygiene Screening</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>screening</b>&nbsp;for injury prevention?<div><br></div><div>What is the purpose?</div>	It is an <b>initial preparticipation </b>exam prior to start of practice.<div><br></div><div>The purpose is to <b>identify athlete </b>who may be at <b>risk</b>.</div><div>- it also establishes a <b>baseline </b>and <b>insurance and liability issues</b>.</div>		t	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What does screening <b>medical history </b>entail?<div><br></div><div>Updated...</div>	Used to identify past and existing medical conditions.<div><br></div><div>Updated <b>yearly </b>and closely reviewed by medical personnel.</div>	Create a <b>personal information card</b>&nbsp;(medical pre-screening cards)	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>physical examination</b>?	Assessment of <b>height, weight, body composition, blood pressure, pulse rate, vision, skin, dental, ear, nose, throat, heart, lung function, abdomen, lymphatic, genitalia, and maturation index</b>.&nbsp;	Rare opportunity to have a 'healthy' athlete spend time with a physician	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>orthopedic screening</b>?	Screening of bone.<div><br></div><div>Often only done when an athlete <b>first starts </b>a program.</div>	More common in professional sport settings as part of a confirmation of physical wellness.	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>wellness screening</b>?<div><br></div><div>What questions should you ask?</div>	Purpose is to determine if athlete is engaged in a healthy lifestyle<div><br></div><div>Questions about:</div><div>- Diet</div><div>- Exercise&nbsp;</div><div>- Weight control</div><div>- Lifestyle habits (smoking, alcohol)</div>	Also, immunizations?	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>health maintenance </b>and <b>personal hygiene screening</b>?	Questions about <b>skin care</b>, <b>dental hygiene</b>, <b>sanitation</b>, <b>immunizations</b>, <b>avoiding infectious and contagious diseases</b>, and <b>sleep habits</b>.<div><br></div><div>Basically looking at your hygiene and health.</div>		y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the <b>4 things </b>you must take into account before putting an individual into a <b>fitness and conditioning </b>program?	1. Training Age<div>2. Sexual Maturity</div><div>3. Components of Fitness</div><div>4. Injury Prevention Protocols</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>training age</b>?<div><br></div><div>Why is it important in fitness and conditioning?</div>	It is basically an estimate on how long you've been working out for.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>How used to training is your body?</div>	Provides insight on how athlete will adapt to an increase in training and competition intensity.	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>sexual maturity</b>?<div><br></div><div>Why is it important in fitness and conditioning?</div>	Basically there will be a wide variance in <b>physical development </b>throughout adolescence.<div><br></div><div>This is important so we take into account the normal amount of muscle mass a 15 year old vs a 18 year old should have.</div>	Greater concern in collision and contact sports.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the <b>two </b>components of fitness?	1. Plyometric Ability<div>2. Flexibility</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>plyometric ability</b>?<div><br></div><div>How is important to injury prevention?</div>	It is basically the <b>stretch-shortening cycle</b>.<div><br></div><div>The ability to create a stretch right before an activity (backswing) to increase the power of that activity.</div><div><br></div><div>Rapid stretch and eccentric contraction followed by a rapid concentric contraction.</div><div><br></div><div>It is important to injury prevention because eccentric contraction are what causes most injuries!</div>	Throwing a baseball, you <b>wind-up </b>before throwing, giving it more force.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How is <b>flexibility </b>important for injury prevention?	Being flexibile will allow your joints to <b>smoothly </b>go through a full ROM as well extend past normal ranges without injuries.	"<img src=""paste-654a098805ca6d26346b3fc753031eddcdbc0053.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the different types of <b>injury prevention protocols</b>? (4)	1. Fitness Testing<div>2. Functional assessments and movement screens</div><div>3. Warm-up</div><div>4. Dynamic-warmup</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How is <b>fitness testing </b>important as an injury prevention protocol?	It provides with info regarding fitness and prepardeness (baseline information)<div><br></div><div>Is the athlete physically capable of performing the task needed for the sport?</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How is <b>functional assessments and movement screens&nbsp;</b>important as an injury prevention protocol?	Provides info on movement patterns, balance, and coordination.<div><br></div><div>Will be able to see <b>asymmetries </b>that can lead to injury.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How is <b>warm-ups&nbsp;</b>important as an injury prevention protocol?<div><br></div><div>How about <b>dynamic warm-ups</b>?</div>	Precaution against unnecessary muscuoloskeletal injury and soreness.<div><br></div><div>Prepares body for work.</div><div><br></div><div>Dynamic warm-ups are good because it <b>enhances coordination</b>&nbsp;and <b>motor ability </b>and prepares muscle for <b>more activity-specific movements</b>. Also <b>stimulates CNS function</b>.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What was the <b>FIFA 11+ </b>injury prevention protocol?<div><br></div><div>How much % decrease?</div>	Specifically designed for soccer to reduce the occurance of <b>non-contact knee injuries</b>.<div><br></div><div>Pre-event protocol.</div>	"<img src=""paste-80a459c553323aa92e0a52409bc454b1fba85580.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are <b>areas of concern </b>for <b>environmental stress</b>&nbsp;on performance?	1. Hyperthermia<div>2. Hypothermia</div><div>3. Lightning Storms</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How do we prevent&nbsp;<b>heat stress</b>?	Body must be able to <b>dissipate heat </b>to maintain homeostasis.<div><br></div><div>We have to make sure the athlete is prepared to withstand high heat.</div><div><br></div><div>We can change equipment and certain clothing, as well as allow <b>sweat evaporation</b>&nbsp;</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
(T/F) Heat stress is not possible when competing in the <b>cold</b>.	False.<div><br></div><div>If heat dissipation is limited and dehydration occurs then heat stress is very much possible.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What must the air be for <b>for evaporation to occur</b>?<div><br></div><div>What humidity impairs evaporation?</div><div>What humidty stops evaporation?</div>	The air must be relatively <b>water free</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Impairs: </b>65%&nbsp;</div><div><b>Stops</b>: 75%</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is a <b>sign </b>of heat stress?<div><br></div><div>Specifically the amount of water lost.</div>	Losing <b>1 litre of water </b>per hour for up to 2 hours is a sign of heat stress!			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
If heat stress is not properly addressed, what illness may occur?	Heat Illness!			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are some methods to <b>prevent heat illness</b>? (4)	1. Hydration<div>2. Fluid and electrolyte replacement</div><div>3. Acclimatization</div><div>4. Monitoring Methods</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
<b>Hydration </b>to prevent heat illness.<div><br></div><div>1. How many hours before activity should an athlete hydrate?</div><div><br></div><div>2. What colour should the urine be?</div><div><br></div><div>3. What urine colour is an indication of dehydration?</div><div><br></div><div>4. What fluid drinking pattern should be adopted?</div>	1. <b>24 </b>hours before!<div>2. The urine should be <b>light yellow</b></div><div>3. <b>Dark urine </b>indicates dehydration</div><div>4. Fluids should be consumed at <b>regular intervals</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-0ae34c8815c731e292094f17d7535d6c86fed741.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
When and how much fluids should be consumed prior to exercise?	<b>17-20 </b>ounces of water or sports drink <b>2-3 hours prior </b>to activity and an additional <b>7-10 </b>ounces <b>10-20 minutes </b>before exercise.	How we should just focus on simply drinking water - just drink water regularly througout the day.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How many ounces of water or sports drink should you drink <b>2-3 hours </b>prior to activity?	17-20 ounces			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How many ounces of water or sports drink should you drink <b>10-20 minutes&nbsp;</b>prior to activity?	7-10 ounces!			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
When does <b>mild dehydration </b>occur?	Mild dehyration occurs when <b>2% </b>of body weight is lost in fluid.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What will <b>dehydration</b>&nbsp;impair?<div><br></div><div>What are the <b>signs </b>and <b>symptoms</b>?</div><div><br></div><div>How would you manage this?</div>	1. Dehydration will impair <b>cardiovascular </b>and <b>thermoregulatory </b>responses.<div><br></div><div>2. Signs/symptoms are <b>thirst</b>, <b>dizziness</b>, <b>dry mouth</b>, <b>irritability</b>, <b>excessive fatigue</b>, and possible <b>cramps</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>3. To manage we must <b>move individual to cool environment</b>&nbsp;and begin <b>rehydration</b>.</div><div>- They are considered good when they return to normal weight and are absent of symptoms.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How many litres does the body require when engaged in <b>minimal activity daily</b>?	The body requires <b>2.5L </b>of water daily when engaged in minimal activity.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
In high activity, how much water will an adult typically lose per hour?	~ <b>1.5L per hour</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What percentage of <b>drop in bodyweight</b>&nbsp;results in thirst?<div><br></div><div>What happens if thirst is ignored?</div>	<b>1-2% </b>drop in body weight results in thirst.<div><br></div><div>If thirst is ignored then <b>DEHYDRATION OCCURS</b>.&nbsp;</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is the maximum amount of fluid that is<b> ever replaced</b> during exercise?	Generally, <b>only 50% of fluid is ever replaced </b>and should therefore be replaced before, during, and after exercise.	"Reiterates the importance of consistently drinking water throughout the day --&gt; as regularly as possible.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-4354429f7056638f4fb8efdb91786d032184b201.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>acclimatization </b>in preventing heat illness?<div><br></div><div>What are ways to acclimatize?</div>	Basically <b>priming </b>your body and getting it used to high temperatures.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><b>80% </b>of acclimatization can be achieved during first 5-6 days with two-hour morning and afternoon practice sessions.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Equipment restrictions </b>may help athlete gradually acclimate.</div>	Being accustomed to heat and exercising in heat		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are <b>monitoring methods </b>in preventing heat illness?	1. Monitoring bodyweight pre and post activity (Greater than <b>2% loss </b>of body weight is considered a threat - should be removed until normal weight is achieved)<div><br></div><div>2. Heat, sunshine and humidty should be monitored</div>	"<img src=""paste-0f563d297ae3db6696a306ce40f7571837aa94f4.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>heat syncope</b>? (Collapse)<div><br></div><div>Caused by...</div><div>Managed by...</div>	<b>Rapid fatigue </b>and <b>overexposure </b>due to <b>standing</b> in heat for <b>long periods</b> of time.<div><br></div><div>Caused by <b>peripheral vasodilation </b>or <b>pooling of blood </b>in extremities resulting in dizziness and fainting.</div><div><br></div><div>Treated by <b>laying down in cool environment</b>, <b>consuming fluids</b>, and <b>elevating lower extremities.</b></div>	It gets so hot that your arms/legs vasodilate and accumulate too much blood.	y	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>heat cramps</b>?<div><br></div><div>Managed by...</div>	Painful muscle spasms due to excessive <b>water loss and electrolyte imbalance</b>.<div><br></div><div>Just <b>replenish </b>fluids and electrolytes.</div>	Drinking pickle juice may help with heat cramps --&gt; cheapter then gatorade.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
Whatn are some <b>heat associated injuries</b>? (5)	1. Heat Syncope<div>2. Heat Cramps</div><div>3. Exertional heat exhaustion</div><div>4. Exertional heat stroke</div><div>5. Acute exertional rhabdomyolysis</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>exertional heat exhaustion</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Results from...</div><div>2. Inability to sustain...</div>	1. Results from <b>inadequate fluid replacement</b>.<div><br></div><div>2. Inability to sustain <b>adequate cardiac output</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-a1c774dc6cbe8ea7a7298ff0db27066734391d98.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the S/S of <b>exertional heat exhaustion</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. May develop...</div><div>2. Core/rectal temp...</div><div>3. Performance?</div>	1. May develop <b>heat cramps </b>or become <b>faint/dizzy</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>2. Core/rectal temperature will be &lt;105 degrees F</div><div><br></div><div>3. Decrease in performance.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How would you treat <b>exertional heat exaustion</b>?	1. Fluid ingestion<div>2. Place in cool environment</div><div>3. Remove excess clothing</div>	Remember to <b>continue to monitor vitals</b>!!!		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What happens if exertional heat exhaustion is not appropriately treated?	It could <b>progress </b>to exertional heat stroke.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
When is an individual who had exertional heat exhaustion ready to <b>return to play</b>?	They must be <b>fully hydrated </b>and <b>cleared by a physician</b>.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>exertional heat stroke</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. S/S?</div><div>2. Core temp?</div><div>3. Breakdown of...</div>	<b>Serious life-threatening condition</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>1. CNS dysfunction</b>, LOC, sudden collapse, <b>hot skin</b>, <b>minimal sweating</b>, shallow breathing, strong rapid pulse.</div><div><br></div><div>2. Core temp <b>&gt;105degree F</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>3. Breakdown of <b>thermoregulatory mechanism</b>.</div>	MINIMAL SWEATING WITH HOT SKIN		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How would you <b>manage </b>an exertional heat <b>stroke</b>?	<b>Drastic measures </b>must be taken to cool athlete!<div><br></div><div>1. Remove clothing</div><div>2. Sponge with cool water</div><div>3. Ice packs</div><div>4. Dunk em in ice or cold water</div><div>5. Transport to hospital</div><div>6. <b>cool first </b>and then transport!</div>	Death may result if not treated appropriately.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>acute exertional rhabdomyolysis</b>?<div><br></div><div>Associated with...</div>	Sudden <b>catabolic destruction/degeneration </b>of <b>skeletal muscle </b>(myoglobin and enzyme leakage into vascular system).<div><br></div><div>Due to <b>intense exercise in heat and humidity.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Associated with individuals that have <b>sickle-cell trait</b>.</div>	Heat Associated Injury<div><br></div><div>Breakdown of skeletal muscle because of such a high exertion, this goes into blood to the kidney = renal failure.</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the S/S of <b>acute exertional rhabdomyolysis</b>?<div><br></div><div>Severe cases?</div>	1. *Gradual muscle weakness&nbsp;<div>2. Swelling</div><div>3. Pain</div><div>4. *Dark urine</div><div>5. *Renal Dysfunction</div><div><br></div><div>In severe cases = sudden collapse, *renail failure, and <b>death</b></div>	Should be referred to a physician immediately!		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the affects of <b>cold weather </b>on activity?	Most activity allows for <b>adequate heat production </b>and dissipation, allowing for sufficient functioning.<div><br></div><div>There is however an impact on <b>warm-up </b>and <b>down time.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Temperature + wind + chilliness + dampness </b>can increase chances of <b>hypothermia</b>.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
{{c1::65}}% of body heat is lost through radiation where&nbsp;{{c1::50}}% is through head and neck.<br><div><br></div><div>{{c1::20}}% is lost through evaporation.<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::2/3}} is lost through skin and&nbsp;{{c1::1/3}} is lost through respiration.<br></div>	"Heat Loss<div><img src=""paste-90e294d57f86835b42e0a7ee46231c935dc58b00.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
When does problems arise due to <b>cold weather</b>?	Problems arise when <b>heat lost exceeds heat production</b>.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
(T/F) A drop in core temperature at 84 degree F will induce shivering.	False<div><br></div><div>Drop in core stimulates shivering but stops after temp drops below <b>85-90 degree F</b>!</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
(T/F) You are not in danger of death when core temperature falls to 86 degree F.	True.<div><br></div><div>You are in danger of death when temp falls below <b>77-85 degree F.</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
At what drop in core temperature does shivering stop?	Below 85-90 degree F.	"<img src=""paste-a525a64ef1f3cb982428904eb51926f4635ed042.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
At what core temperature drop means imminent death?	Below 77-85 degree F	"<img src=""paste-a525a64ef1f3cb982428904eb51926f4635ed042.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How would you <b>prevent cold injuries</b>? (5)	1. Suitable clothing/gear for weather<div>2. Waterproof and windproof fabric that allow <b>passage of heat and sweat </b>and allow movement</div><div>3. Layers and <b>adjusing layer depending on activity</b></div><div>4. Be aware of <b>inadequate clothing</b></div><div>5. Be aware of <b>hydration levels</b> (blood viscosity: more water = less viscous = better blood flow = warmer)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
Why must we aware of <b>lightning safety</b>?	It is the <b>second cause of death</b>&nbsp;by weather phenomena.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How do we enforce <b>lightning safety</b>?	1. implement EAPs - decision-making regarding removal and return to field as well as monitoring<div><br></div><div>2. Have a shelter ready for storm</div><div><br></div><div>3. Avoid large trees, flag/light poles, water, telephones, pools, showers, metal.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is an indicator of <b>imminent danger </b>of a lightning strike?<div><br></div><div>What should you do?</div>	If hair stands up on hand.<div><br></div><div>You should get down on the ground <b>but </b>not flast as that increases surface area.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
How do you <b>estimate the distance away </b>a storm is (lightning safety).<div><br></div><div>What count indicates <b>inherent danger</b>?</div><div><br></div><div>What count indicates that <b>everyone should leave the field</b>?</div>	From the time lightning is sighted to the clap of thunder count, <b>divide by 5 </b>to calculate number of miles away.<div><br></div><div>Inherent danger: <b>30 seconds</b></div><div>LEAVE THE FIELD: <b>15 seconds</b></div>	Dam, that means it was a lot closer then I thought.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What 3 things are <b>critical </b>for protective equipment in injury prevention?	1. <b>Selection</b><div>2. <b>Fitting</b></div><div>3. <b>Maintenance</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
Which sports usually need <b>protective equipment</b>?	Contact sports idiot!			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the <b>legal concerns </b>surrounding equipment?	1. <b>Litigation</b>: manufacturer must warn user against potential risks<div><br></div><div>2. <b>Liability</b>: if equpiment results in injury because of defect/inadequacy product, the manufacturer is liable</div><div><br></div><div>3. <b>Modified</b>: If the equipment is modified, <b>the modifier </b>is liable</div>	To avoid litigation, individuals should exactly follow specific use instructions of equipment		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is <b>litigation</b>?	The process of taking legal action.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the different <b>equipment certifications </b>in Canada?<div><br></div><div>Canada...</div><div>Hockey...</div><div>National...</div>	1. <b>Canadian Standards Association </b>(CSA): establishes minimum safety requirements<div><br></div><div>2. <b>Hockey Equipment Certification&nbsp;Council </b>(HECC): Independent testing organization ensuring standards for <b>helmets, visors, and facemasks</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>3. <b>National Operating Committee on Standards for Athletic Equipment </b>(NOCSAE): American safety organization</div>	Remember that equipment certification has an expiration!		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What must you consider in injury prevention when dealing with <b>football helmets</b>?	These helmets generally has <b>air-or fluid filled pockets </b>to absorb force.<div><br></div><div><b>Padding inflates to fit the player's head shape</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>How much does the helmet move while moving it around?</div><div><br></div><div>Football helmets take more effort to check airway in emergency situations (most likely have to use shears)</div>	"<img src=""paste-5be3b975c66daf2b263e47ab6f1008a6e93826bd.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What kind of <b>face guard system </b>does football helmets have?	They have <b>isolated attachment points </b>from the shell, thus reducing jarring from low-level impacts to the face guard.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What must you consider for injury prevention when working with <b>hockey helmets</b>?	1. Must be able to <b>withstand high velocity impacts</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>2. Should be able to disperse force</div><div><br></div><div>3. Must be approved by CSA or HECC</div><div><br></div><div>4. <b>Many options </b>exist to fit individual needs and therefore <b>fit is priority </b>over bells and whistles.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are <b>protective equpiment </b>for head and neck protection?	1. <b>Face Protection</b>: facemask<div>2. <b>Throat Protection</b>: prevents laryngotracheal injuries (common in baseball catchers/lacrosses goalies/ice hockey goalies)</div><div>3. <b>Teeth Protection</b>: Mouth guards</div><div>4. <b>Eye Protection</b>: eye and glasses guards</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What type of <b>mouth guards</b>&nbsp;are the best?	<b>Customized intraoral </b>mouth guards.<div>- made by the dentist in your IST<br><div><br></div><div>Should fit comfortably and not impede speech or breathing.</div><div><br></div><div>Should extend back as far as last molar.</div></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
When is <b>eye and glasses guards </b>necessary?	In sports with <b>fast moving projectiles.</b>	Be careful though because eye guards can limit vision.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is the role of&nbsp;<b>trunk and thorax </b>protective equipment?	Protect regions such as:<div><br></div><div>1. Bony protuberances</div><div>2. Shoulders</div><div>3. Ribs</div><div>4. Spine</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
Give an example of a trunk and thorax protective equipment	<b>Football Shoulder Pads</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the two type of football shoulder pads?	1. <b>Cantilevered</b>: bulkier and used by those engaged in blocking and tackling<div>2. <b>Noncantilevered</b>: Do not restrict motion (quarterback and recievers)</div>	"<img src=""paste-907702bdca0ac50b8be93524b91c7859ea4f1f64.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the rules for fitting <b>shoulder pads</b>?	<div>Rules for fitting:</div><div><br></div><div>1. Width of shoulders measured</div><div>2. Inside of pad should cover lateral aspect of shoulder</div><div>3. Epaulets and cups must cover deltoid and allow motion</div><div>4. Neck opening must allow athlete to raise arms over head</div><div>5. With split-clavicle pads, channel for top of shoulder must be in proper position</div><div>6. Straps underneath arms should hold pads firmly in place without soft tissue restriction</div>	"<img src=""paste-82f2956eb76db508a80a2c3aa07e78be6e9b71a4.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are examples of <b>groin equipment </b>for protective equipment?	1. <b>Sports Cup</b><div>2. <b>Core-shorts</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-c08db2c8bf8f02f1352dc75a2d6f47c0422ac781.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
Are <b>socks </b>considered protective equipment?	Yes, poorly fit socks can cause abnormal stress on foot.<div><br></div><div>Socks can offer essential protection from <b>lacerations</b>.</div>	"Kevlar Wrap Socks<div><img src=""paste-3513d02b056b830c6f9374e9fa86b9fbb4a97d82.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What are the different types of <b>bracing </b>for protective equipment?	1. <b>Ankle Braces</b><div>2. <b>Knee Braces</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
Why would you consider ankle braces over taping?	It is better then a seasons worth of taping and is <b>cost effective</b>.<div><br></div><div>Compared to tape, the device will not lossen significantly with use.</div>	"<img src=""paste-414e76956c88c8b3611506439e3d63c15af73158.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
When/why would you need to use <b>knee braces</b>?	Worn to prevent re-injury or further injury to ligaments.<div><br></div><div>Often worn <b>prophylactically.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Functional: </b>used during rehab to provide functional support and is ready-made and customized.</div>	"Prophylactically: guarding/preventing the spread of a disease/injury<div><img src=""paste-b69752d4ab90be94c7978a4da83f423c052af9cc.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
Who usually uses <b>neoprene </b>knee braces? (with medial and lateral support)	Used by those who have sustained collateral ligament injuries<div><br></div><div>Some are also used to provide support in those who have patellofemoral conditions.</div>	"<img src=""paste-b69752d4ab90be94c7978a4da83f423c052af9cc.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Prevention
What is the role of a <b>sport chiropractor</b>?	Indirectly facilitate an athlete's performance by early determination and treatment of injury <b>by working with coaches and other sport health professionals</b>.<div><br></div><div>They treat <b>neuromusculoskeletal dysfunction</b>&nbsp;using chiropractice adjustments, soft tissue therapies, modalities, and rehabilitative measures to <b>restore and enhance </b>the body to peak performance.</div>	"Working with others is the most important aspect!<div><img src=""paste-0f7fc8893131a5dac756ea10d9e42abe20212df2.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What are the 4 components of a <b>daily training environment</b>?	1. Readiness<div>2. Movement</div><div>3. Technical/Skill Specific</div><div>4. Communication</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What kind of effects does <b>joint manipulation/mobilization </b>have on the body? (3)<div><br></div><div>What do each do?</div>	1. Biomechanical effects (improved ROM)<div>2. Muscular reflexogenic effects (alter muscle tone)</div><div>3. Neurophysiological effects (pain modulation)</div>	Similar to oiling a squeaking joint = sometimes alleviates pain.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What is <b>tribonucleation</b>?	Taking a confined space, fluid is in our joints, if I separate that ever so slightly and some point there will be more space then fluid, gas will fill that space, that instantaneous moment gas fills that space is the sound of the crack. Nothing is going out of place!			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What are the effects of <b>soft tissue manipulation</b>?	Decrease muscle tone and help facilitate muscle remodeling.<div>- help stimulate the muscle to reorganize.</div>	"<img src=""paste-35999a3f439e4aa57450cba4cba7be2eff2540aa.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What is the least painful contraction for a muscle?	An isometric contraction because there is <b>no change in length</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What is <b>stage 1 </b>of chiropractice rehabilitation?	<b>Promote healing of the injured tissue</b>.<div><br></div><div>We can use electric modalities and joint manipulation to protect from guarding.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What is&nbsp;<b>stage 2 and 3&nbsp;</b>of chiropractic rehabilitation?	1.<b>&nbsp;Regain full muscle function and neuromuscular control</b>.<div><br></div><div>Specifically over the injured muscle.</div><div>- isometric training should be incorporated because it is the least painful</div><div><br></div><div>2. We must <b>develop neuromuscular control of trunk and pelvis with progressive movement speed.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>3.&nbsp;<b>Pain free running up to maxiaml speed.</b></div>	Rehab is just an extension of purposeful training		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Chiropractice_and_Sports_Sciences
What are the <b>Phases of the Inflammatory Response</b>? (3)	1. <b>Inflammatory Response Phase</b><div>2. <b>Fibroblastic Repair Phase</b></div><div>3. <b>Maturation-Remodeling Phase</b></div>	When we are injured, we start to go through the inflammatory response		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How long does it take to approximately go through the 3 phases of the inflammatory response?	1. The inflammatory response phase usually takes around <b>4 days</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>2. The fibroblastic repair phase usually takes around <b>6 weeks</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>3. The maturation-remodeling phase usually takes around <b>2-3 years</b>.</div>	"Know that there is a <b>lot of overlap </b>especially between the fibrobalstic and maturation phases.<div><img src=""paste-140b61ac6b50b76a045b43d254f0c1183f793e24.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What are the <b>signs </b>of inflammation?	<b>SHARP</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>S</b>welling</div><div><b>H</b>eat</div><div><b>A</b>ltered Function</div><div><b>R</b>edness</div><div><b>P</b>allor/Pain</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is <b>pallor</b>?	Blanching or discoloration			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
When does healing begin in the inflammatory response phase?	Healing begins <b>immediately</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is the initial reaction by phagocytes in the inflammatory response phase?	1. Protect<div>2. Localize</div><div>3. Decrease injurious agents</div><div>4. Prepare for healing and repair</div>	"<img src=""paste-619ebb3b5d39675dc6295f020c23542c3c978d5a.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What are the <b>key stages </b>for the inflammatory response phase? (3)<br><br><div>How long does each last?</div>	1. <b>Vasoconstriction</b>&nbsp;and coagulation occur to seal blood vessels (shunting of the blood to the area - localize the damage to prevent spread of damage) - You won't see immediate swelling<div><br></div><div>2. <b>Vasodilation</b>: swelling starts to occur. Increase in blood flow in the area and <b>24-36 hours.</b> Occurs after <b>5-10 minutes</b>.</div><div>- slowing of vasodilation leads to increased blood viscosity resulting in edema (swelling)</div><div><br></div><div>3. <b>Clot Formation: </b>beings <b>12 hours after injury </b>and typically completes within <b>48 hours</b>. Ceullular debris from the damaged tissue is removed through phagocytosis.</div>	"<img src=""paste-e875eb38642be64958eb31f4155b5567f663bfb8.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-ddf5591fb7208ce6831d24e44b543b6a246c4cee.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
After an injury, when does <b>vasodilation occur</b>?<div><br></div><div>How long does the initial effusion of blood and plasma last?</div>	After 5-10 minutes.<div><br></div><div>The initial effusion lasts <b>24-36 hours</b>.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
When does <b>clot formation </b>begin after an injury?<div><br></div><div>When does it complete?</div>	It begins <b>12 hours </b>after injury and typically complete within <b>48 hours.</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What steps should you take during the <b>first 48 hours </b>after an injury? (two methods)<br>	<b>RICE: </b>Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation.<div><br></div><div><b>POLICE</b>: Protection, Optimal Loading, Ice, Compression, Elevation</div>	"<img src=""paste-2b3b6276a93ed26ea07a4a07923956f9a3265cb9.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How to you <b>properly ice </b>and injury?<div><br></div><div>What should you be wary of?</div>	Using frozen water, especially crushed ice is best. The <b>smaller the ice cubes, the better</b>.<div><br></div><div>You can also use:</div><div>1. Cold water immersion</div><div>2. Ice cups</div><div>3. Cold spray (is not effective in the acute phase)</div><div>4. Bag of frozen veggies</div><div><br></div><div>You should be careful of <b>reusable gel packs </b>and <b>instant cold chemical packs </b>- always remember to have a <b>layer </b>between the icepack and the skin</div>	"<img src=""paste-6f8bcd4e083635b7cbe533075d8779597864a427.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is the difference to icing an injury using frozen water vs a reusable gel pack?	The problem with gel packs is that the temperature goes below zero (<b>higher likelihood for skin to be damaged</b>)<div><br></div><div>On the other hand, ice is good because it melts and does not go below 0 degrees.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How do you properly apply ice to an injury?	<b>Time Frame</b>: <b>20 min</b> on &amp; <b>1 hr</b> off, multiple applications if possible<div><br></div><div><b>Apply directly to the skin </b>unless there is a cold allergy.</div>	"<img src=""paste-2b0acd43a51ed56f0ee256a14c66015961c8d6c1.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How do you explain icing to someone for the first time?	1. Cold/pain<div>2. Burning</div><div>3. Aching - throbbing</div><div>4. Numbness</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What are some <b>contraindications to ice</b>? (5)	1. Reynaud's Syndrome - Ice allergy<div>2. Diabetes</div><div>3. Recent Surgery</div><div>4. Sensitive Skin</div><div>5. Altered Sensation</div>	"<img src=""paste-418eae0b2ae6c5c80c2e1c9919dd6f93fdd5333d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is <b>phase 2 </b>of the inflammatory response?	<b>Fibroblastic repair phase</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
The fibroblastic repair phase is also called ______.	<b>Fibroplasia</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How does the <b>fibroblastic repair phase </b>work?	This is when the tissue tries to <b>regenerate itself.</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>1. Swelling goes down, discomfort lessons and there is some function back in the limb</div><div><br></div><div>2. Formation of <b>delicate connective tissue </b>(granulation tissue) that develop collagen or 'scar tissue'</div><div><br></div><div>3. Tensile strength increases with <b>proliferation </b>of collagen.</div><div><br></div><div>Basically your tissue is continually regenerating and healing in the fastest way possible regardless of muscle direction. So <b>patching up </b>the injury.</div>	"<img src=""paste-8f5a17cbefb3562cec44c623e2b945adc509b749.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What does it mean if <b>prolonged scar </b>tissue formation can create <b>barrier </b>to injury <b>recovery</b>?	Is you disrupt the injury over and over, the cycle of inflammation will start over again and therefore will cause barriers to injury.<div><br></div><div>1. Adhesive Capsulitis</div><div>2. Tendon and ligament adhesions</div><div>3. Bursa Adhesions</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is <b>phase 3 </b>of the inflammatory response?	<b>Maturation and Remodeling</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How does the <b>maturation and remodeling </b>phase work in the inflammatory response?	There is a continued breakdown of synthesis of collagen = increased strength.<div><br></div><div>Note that the <b>realignment of collagen </b>is relative to <b>applied tensile forces </b>(SAID principle)</div><div><br></div><div>Tissue will gradually assume normal appearance.</div><div><br></div><div>In this phase your muscles will breakdown the unaligned collagen and all that's left is the aligned collagen. Exercise is critical because contractions (applied tensile forces) affect this alignment.</div><div><br></div><div>Typically just doing a contraction in the injured proper direction will induce this.</div>	"<img src=""paste-5a12d19d9fdb4a2bf7daec9330ef355d0055aeba.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How long does the <b>maturation and remodeling </b>phase take?	It may require several years to complete!<div><br></div><div>Just depends on the extent of the injury.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How can we incorporate the 3 phases of the inflammatory response into <b>rehabilitation</b>?	1. Initially may require some immobilzation or restricted ROM to allow for optimal healing<div><br></div><div>2. As healing moves to repair phase, <b>controlled activity is added</b>. Work towards regaining optimal function - protective bracing could be incorporated.</div><div><br></div><div>3. During remodeling, <b>ROM and strength exercises </b>should be incorporated - facilitates tissue strengthening and realignment</div>	Must be aware of pain and other clinical signs to gauge response to rehab stimulus.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is <b>chronic inflammation</b>?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>How can it impede healing?</div>	<div>It is a result of failed acute inflammation response.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>It is when inflammation occurs within <b>months to years </b>from the result of repeated microtrauma and overuse.</div><div><br></div><div>Proliferation of connective tissue and tissue regeneration.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is the difference between <b>subacute </b>inflammation and <b>chronic </b>inflammation?	Subacute inflammation: When symptoms occur ~ <b>1 month </b>post injury<div><br></div><div>Chronic inflammation: <b>months to years</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What are the <b>4 types of soft tissue </b>in the body?	1. <b>Epithelial Tissue</b> (skin/vessel/organ lining)<div>2. <b>Connective Tissue</b> (tendons/ligaments/cartilage/fat/blood)</div><div>3. <b>Muscle Tissue</b> (skeletal/smooth/cardiac muscle)</div><div>4. <b>Nerve Tissue</b> (brain/spinal cord/nerves)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How does <b>cartilage heal </b>when damaged?	1. <b>Limited </b>capacity to heal because little or <b>no direct blood supply</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>2. If area involves <b>subchondral bone </b>(enhanced blood suply) granulation tissue is present and healing may proceed normally.</div>	"<img src=""paste-64a5ea77d5a9462ab55709f53dc3b1d0f1642ccc.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How does <b>ligament </b>heal when damaged?<div><br></div><div>Why is the ligament important?</div><div><br></div><div>How long is full healing?</div>	Follows the convential healing sequence (acute/repair/remodeling phases)<div><br></div><div><b>Repair phase </b>will involved random laying down collagen, as scar forms, will mature and realign in reaction to stresses and strain.</div><div>- important for regaining <b>static stability </b>of a joint.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Remodelling Phase </b>where you strengthen the muscles around the joint is important for <b>dynamic stability.</b></div><div><br></div><div>Full healing may require <b>12 months </b>or greater.</div>	"Static stability is I'm guessing is keeping the joint in place whereas dynamic stability is being stable while moving.<div><img src=""paste-90cab7c614c0551b36c60ce42ba9281d0f965abd.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is the difference between <b>surgically repaired </b>ligaments and <b>naturally repaired </b>ligaments?	Surgically repaired ligaments <b>tend to be stronger </b>due to decreased scar formation.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
Explain how ligament healing affects <b>dynamic </b>and <b>static stability</b>.	<b>Static</b>: Repair phase will patch everything up and is important for static stability<div><br></div><div><b>Dynamic</b>: Muscle strengthening of the muscles around the joint is important for dynamic stability</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How does <b>skeletal muscle </b>heal after an injury?<div><br></div><div>How long would healing last?</div>	<b>Initial bleeding </b>followed by <b>proliferation </b>of ground substance and fibroblast.<div>- obvious bruising in grade 2+ muscle strains<br><div><br></div><div>Collagen will mature and orient along lines of tensile force.</div></div><div><br></div><div>Myoblastic cells form = regeneration of new myofibrils.</div><div><br></div><div>Healing could last 6-8+ weeks depending on the muscle injured (primary vs accessory)</div>	"<img src=""paste-686e3a6d5696f4cbc5a4825ece54a0f61a490f65.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is the difference between an injury of <b>primary vs accessory </b>skeletal muscle?	Primary muscle injury takes less time to recover then accessory. This is simply because we use primary muscles more and therefore the <b>remodeling phase </b>is a lot easier.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How does a <b>tendon </b>heal after injury?<div><br></div><div>Explain the healing process of non-surgical healing.</div>	Requires dense fibrous union of separated ends.<div><br></div><div>Abundance of collagen is required for good tensile strength.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Weeks 1-2</b>: Injured tendon will <b>adhere </b>to surrounding tissue</div><div><br></div><div><b>Week 3</b>: Tendon will gradually separate</div><div><br></div><div><b>Week 4-5</b>: Tensile strength gradually returns</div>	"<img src=""paste-25bbd9a2eaae27c3bbc2af7437cd45b7bc0d1e8c.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What are the <b>5 stages </b>of bone <b>acute fractures</b>?	1. Hematoma Formation<div>2. Cellular Proliferation</div><div>3. Callus Formation</div><div>4. Ossification</div><div>5. Remodeling</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
Explain <b>hematoma formation </b>of the 5 stages of acute bone fractures.<br>How long does it last?	<b>Hematoma </b>(blood clot) is formed within the medullary cavity and the surrounding tissue develops during the first <b>48 hours</b>.	"<img src=""paste-38e32a7914334c17ccbb41db2da6e09967663624.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
Explain <b>cellular proliferation&nbsp;</b>of the 5 stages of acute bone fractures.	Blood supply is disrupted by clotting vessels and cellular debris.<div><br></div><div>Osteoblasts fill the internal and external calluses to immobilize the site</div>	"Remember Wolffs law<div><img src=""paste-af20a52b494f2052bfacf3cc8b22de754507ee1f.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
Explain <b>callus formation&nbsp;</b>of the 5 stages of acute bone fractures.	Calluses are formed by bone fragments that bridge the fracture gap	"<img src=""paste-af20a52b494f2052bfacf3cc8b22de754507ee1f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
Explain <b>Ossification&nbsp;</b>of the 5 stages of acute bone fractures.	Hard callus becomes more well formed as osteoblasts lay down cancellous bone replacing the cartilage.	"<img src=""paste-af20a52b494f2052bfacf3cc8b22de754507ee1f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
Explain <b>remodeling&nbsp;</b>of the 5 stages of acute bone fractures.	Essenstially Wolffs Law. As you put strain on the bone, it will start to tear away at the random directional bone and increase bone size or something.			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
Is there a difference between upper extremity bone fractures vs lower extremity?	Yes.<div><br></div><div>It is alot easier for lower extremity fractures to adapt because of the constant applied stress.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How long does a <b>bone fracture last</b>?	Time is dependent on severity, and site of fracture as well as age and extent of trauma.<div><br></div><div>Time ranges from <b>3-8 weeks</b>.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
How should you manage an <b>acute bone fracture</b>?	Must be appropriately immobilized until <b>x-rays</b> reveal the presense of a hard callus.<div><br></div><div>Can limit participation for weeks or&nbsp; months.</div>	Remember that you don't want to reset or anything with a fracure.<div>Well this is a fracture and not a dislocation though lol.</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What are the factors that <b>impede </b>bone healing? (3)	1. <b>Poor Blood Supply </b>(bone may die and union/healing will not occur)<div>2. <b>Poor Immobilization </b>(result of poor casting allowing for motion between bone parts - may result in improper bone fusion and bone deformity.</div><div>3. <b>Infection</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What is <b>avascular necrosis</b>?	When one small artery providing blood to the bone is cut off and therefore <b>nutrients </b>to the bone is cut off = <b>necrosis</b>&nbsp;= tissue degrades and dies	"<img src=""paste-c369b7fad0dce50c2764429eb9c7a71a99fe78de.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Tissue_Response_to_Injury
What are the <b>arches of the foot</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Metatarsal arch}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Transverse arch}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Lateral Longitudinal arch}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Medial Longitudinal Arch}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-17e4c6321a8cd6748ff3ddc0be4991c8cd01d32d.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
Foot is integral to the lower extremity&nbsp;{{c1::kinetic chain}}	"<img src=""paste-144fa5801d74c8873927fa938e35d4f7878cfaaa.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the movements of <b>foot pronation</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Eversion}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Abduction}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Dorsiflexion}}</div>	"<div>Triplanar Movement</div><img src=""paste-b499c25ba33910fe1f13b2adeeab49299d54c5c1.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the movements of <b>foot supination</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Inversion}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Adduction}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Plantarflexion}}</div>	"Triplanar Movement<div><img src=""paste-23faa27e3d204659375495ea2040276a5598fd8a.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>phases </b>of a normal gait?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Stance Phase:}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Swing Phase}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-bf3271880e3abe47ea306f70c272617f59edc0b0.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
Explain the <b>stance phase </b>in a normal gait...<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Starts with initial contact of the<b>&nbsp;heel on the ground </b>and ends with <b>toe-off</b>}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Accounts for&nbsp;{{c1::60}}% of gait cycle</div><div>Involves {{c1::weight bearing}} in {{c1::closed kinetic chain}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e4f614decf240d9d55e42d1e43b1393934fe25db.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What does it mean when I say that the stance phase involves weight bearing in a <b>closed kinetic chain</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>The <b>kinetic chain </b>of a normal gait is when you start <b>heel strike </b>in <b>supination </b>and then follow through to toe-off in <b>pronation</b>}}<br></div>	- Tibia externally rotates with supination on initial contact<div>- Internal rotation of the tibia occurs as foot moves through pronation</div>	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
Explain the <b>swing phase </b>of a normal gait...<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Represents the time between <b>toe-off </b>and the <b>subsequent initial contact</b>}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Period of&nbsp;{{c1::non-weight bearing}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-89593f16d35fae670d413f8ed53e6fda22778e99.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
At heel strike, the foot is a&nbsp;{{c1::shock absorber}} and then {{c1::adapts}} to uneven surfaces during stance		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
Foot transitions to {{c1::rigid lever}} to provide {{c2::propulsive force}} at toe off.		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
Pronation allows for unlocking of&nbsp;{{c1::midfoot}} and&nbsp;{{c1::shock absorption}}		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
When can occur if there is <b>excessive </b>or <b>prolonged </b>pronation or supination in the gait cycle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It can contribute to overuse injuries.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-038af66ffa0a9023b67dd69c7cd302498955c092.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What occurs when we have <b>excessive pronation </b>in our gait?<div><br></div><div>What is it traditionally called?&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::Flat Feet}}</div><div><br></div><div>It is the major cause of&nbsp;{{c1::stress injuries}}.</div><div><br></div><div>In what phase does it have <b>prolonged pronation</b>?</div><div>{{c1::In the propulsive phase}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Results in:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Loose foot or Hypermobility}}</div><div>Where in the foot does it allow more motion?</div><div>{{c1::More <b>midfoot motion</b>}}</div><div>Where does it cause <b>more pressure </b>on?</div><div>{{c1::The metatarsals}}</div><div>Where does it increase rotation?</div><div>{{c1::The Tibia}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-7a9237a0ab907bdd16b7013108382002a800220b.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What knee position would you normally see in someone who is <b>flat-footed</b>?<div><br></div><div>Why is this?<br><div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div><b>Excessive pronation </b>will not allow foot to <b>resupinate </b>to provide <b>rigid lever </b>for toe-off.</div><div><br></div><div>Therefore you will not get that firm push off --&gt; will have more <b>valgus </b>movement.}}<br></div></div>	"<img src=""paste-7a9237a0ab907bdd16b7013108382002a800220b.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What occurs when we have&nbsp;<b>excessive supination&nbsp;</b>in our gait?<div><br></div><div><b>Results in:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::Rigid Foot or Hypomobility}}</div><div><br></div><div><b>Why does it result in this?</b></div><div>Decreased mobility in the&nbsp;{{c1::calcaneocuboid joint}}</div><div><br></div><div>Where does it cause weight absorption?</div><div>&nbsp;{{c1::First and fifth metatarsals and inefficient ground reaction force absorption}}</div><div><br></div><div>Limits&nbsp;{{c1::tibial internal rotation}} which affects&nbsp;{{c1::the kinetic chain (ending kinetic chain at the knee}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What kind of injuries does <b>excessive supination </b>cause?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Inversion ankle sprains}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Medial tibial stress syndrome}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Iliotibial band friction syndrome}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Trochanteric bursitis}}</div>	"<div>Looking at this, inversion sprains makes sense</div><img src=""paste-79941c4a1f238e5da410a79829eadc0056c3496a.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How do you <b>reduce foot injuries</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Proper Footwear}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Hygiene}}</div>	<b>Proper Footwear</b>: Sport demand specific or orthotics<div><b>Hygiene</b>: Toenails/calluses, clean socks/shoes, and avoid long lasting moisture to avoid athlete's foot</div>	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What should you assess in <b>foot assessments</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1:: Basically HOPS again.</div><div><br></div><div><b>History</b>: location of pain (heel, toes, arches), training surfaces or changes in footwear, does footwear increase or decrease comfort?</div><div><br></div><div><b>Observations</b>: does the patient favour the foot, antalgic gait, or unable to bear weight? How is the arch shaped? Static or dynamic foot alignment? Are there structural deformities?</div><div><br></div><div><b>Palpation</b></div><div><b>Special Tests</b></div><div>}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg

What is <b>Sever's Disease</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>It is an <b>apopohyseal </b>injury to the calcaneus when the length of the tibia signicficantly increases but the gastroc and achillies hasn't grown enough = pulls on heel and causes pain}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>What <b>kind </b>of injury is it?</div><div>{{c1::It is a <b>traction </b>injury (also apophyseal)}}<br></div>	"This happens to the heel because of multi-joint muscles!<div><img src=""paste-0d15fbffac0f1b39883536f8f1a2757932d79850.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Sever's Disease?<div><br></div><div>1. Predominant in&nbsp;{{c1::children}} and&nbsp;{{c1::adolescent}} athletes</div><div>2. Pain occurs at&nbsp;{{c1::posterior heel below Achilles attachment}}</div><div>3. Pain occurs during&nbsp;{{c1::vigorous activity and <b>ceases </b>following activity}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>Sever's Disease?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::POLICE}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Heel lift </b>could relieve some stress (just lift heel)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Soft tissue massage or the like}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Retrocalcaneal Bursitis</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Inflammation of&nbsp;{{c1::bursa beneath Achilles tendon}}</div><div>2. Result of&nbsp;{{c1::pressure and rubbing}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::chronic condition that <b>develops over time</b> and may take extensive time to resolve}}</div><div>4. May develop into&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Exostosis </b>(Haglund's deformity}}</div>	"<div><b>Exostosis</b>: Thickening of the bursa with scar tissue</div><img src=""paste-90f47269eea83687629c145cdbd940ab4e82aa19.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of&nbsp;<b>Retrocalcaneal Bursitis</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.
