What is <b>Cuboid Subluxation</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Often confused with&nbsp;{{c1::plantar fasciitis}}</div><div>2. May occur with conjunction with&nbsp;{{c1::inversion ankle MOI:</div><div>Inversion MOI can lead to the peroneal tendon moving the cuboid, leading to subluxing mechanism}}</div><div>3. Primary reason for pain is&nbsp;{{c1::stress on fibularis longus muscle when the foot is inverted}}</div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-73814db531bde4d8c0a594aa5bc95456aa63df9b.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Cuboid Subluxation?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Pain along 4th and 5th metatarsals and over the cuboid (because displacement of cuboid)}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Pain to heel area, and pain may increase following prolonged non-weight-bearing period}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>a cuboid subluxation?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Cuboid manipulation (Chiro stuff)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Orthotics}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
1. [[oc1::<b>Initial Contact (heel strike) -&nbsp;</b>Ext/rot of tibia, supination]]<div><div>2. [[oc2::<b>Loading Response -</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation]]</div><div>3. [[oc3::<b>Midstance -&nbsp;</b>Int/rot of tibia, pronation]]</div><div>4. [[oc4::<b>Terminal Stance</b><b>&nbsp;-</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation]]</div><div>5. [[oc5::<b>Preswing (Toe-off) -&nbsp;</b>Ext/rot of tibia, supination]]</div></div>	What are the <b>stages </b>to the stance phase?<div><br></div><div>Where does the <b>tibia</b> pronate?</div><div>What <b>movement</b> is happening in each phase?</div>		"<img src=""paste-e86aa98a239e543fd5302c2e87129df1e1979a27.jpg"">"	1,1,0 | n,n,n,n	1. {{c1::<b>Initial Contact (heel strike) -&nbsp;</b>Ext/rot of tibia, supination}}<div><div>2. ...</div><div>3. ...</div><div>4. ...</div><div>5. ...</div></div>	1. <b>Initial Contact (heel strike) -&nbsp;</b>Ext/rot of tibia, supination<div><div>2. {{c2::<b>Loading Response -</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation}}</div><div>3. ...</div><div>4. ...</div><div>5. ...</div></div>	1. ...<div><div>2. <b>Loading Response -</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation</div><div>3. {{c3::<b>Midstance -&nbsp;</b>Int/rot of tibia, pronation}}</div><div>4. ...</div><div>5. ...</div></div>	1. ...<div><div>2. ...</div><div>3. <b>Midstance -&nbsp;</b>Int/rot of tibia, pronation</div><div>4. {{c4::<b>Terminal Stance</b><b>&nbsp;-</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation}}</div><div>5. ...</div></div>	1. ...<div><div>2. ...</div><div>3. ...</div><div>4. <b>Terminal Stance</b><b>&nbsp;-</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation</div><div>5. {{c5::<b>Preswing (Toe-off) -&nbsp;</b>Ext/rot of tibia, supination}}</div></div>																1. {{c21::<b>Initial Contact (heel strike) -&nbsp;</b>Ext/rot of tibia, supination}}<div><div>2. {{c21::<b>Loading Response -</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation}}</div><div>3. {{c21::<b>Midstance -&nbsp;</b>Int/rot of tibia, pronation}}</div><div>4. {{c21::<b>Terminal Stance</b><b>&nbsp;-</b>&nbsp;Int/rot of tibia, pronation}}</div><div>5. {{c21::<b>Preswing (Toe-off) -&nbsp;</b>Ext/rot of tibia, supination}}</div></div>	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Pes Planus Foot</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Also called&nbsp;{{c1::Flat Foot}}</div><div>2. Associated with&nbsp;{{c1::excessive pronation}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Weak supportive structures}}</div><div>4. Due to&nbsp;{{c1::consistent high impact activity}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-4f42c5c9d64b55aad28e972304aa4e90de050cc7.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Pes Planus Foot?<div><br></div><div>1. Pain and weakness/fatigue in&nbsp;{{c1::medial longitudinal arch - biggest weakness}}<br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Bulging navicular}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Flattening of medial longitudinal arch}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-4f42c5c9d64b55aad28e972304aa4e90de050cc7.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>Pes Planus?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::If nothing is causing athlete pain then nothing should be done to correct problem}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::orthotics can be beneficial}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Strengthening of intrinsic muscle of the foot</div><div>This makes sense because excessive pronation causes stress medial side}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5eaff25cb6a32aec0326132b6d808b12b9615c54.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Pes Cavus</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Also known as&nbsp;{{c1::high arch foot}}</div><div>2. Associated with&nbsp;{{c1::excessive supination and a higher arch than normal}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Accentuated high medial longitudinal arch}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e178802aca8068ffc62fac7e9e580139ff0c1881.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Pes Cavus?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Poor Shock Absorption}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Heavy callus development on ball and heel of foot (makes sense)}}</div><div>3. High probability of&nbsp;{{c1::Medial Tibial Stress Syndrome}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e178802aca8068ffc62fac7e9e580139ff0c1881.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>Pes Cavus?<div><br></div><div>1. If asymptomatic&nbsp;{{c1::no attempt should be made to correct}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Orthotics}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Release achilles/gastroc complex and plantar fascia}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e178802aca8068ffc62fac7e9e580139ff0c1881.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Plantar Fasciitis</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>The <b>catch-all </b>term used for <b>pain in proximal arch and heel</b>.}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Plantar Fascia</b>?<div><br></div><div>What does it do?<br><div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Dense, broad band of connective tissue attaching proximally to the <b>medial surface </b>of the calcaneus and fans out over the <b>plantar aspect </b>of the foot.</div><div><br></div><div>Works to maintain <b>stability </b>of the foot and <b>bracing </b>the longitudinal arch.}}<br></div></div>	"<img src=""paste-9d82e6ccf1cbde7a6d1965d66e375243f22e7e13.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How is <b>Plantar Fasciitis </b>caused?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Increased tension/stress on fascia particularly during <b>push-off </b>of running phase}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Change from <b>rigid supportive footwear </b>to&nbsp;<b>flexible&nbsp;footwear</b>}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Common with <b>excessive pronation</b>}}.</div>	"<img src=""paste-9d82e6ccf1cbde7a6d1965d66e375243f22e7e13.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Plantar Fasciitis?<div><br></div><div>1. Pain in&nbsp;{{c1::anterior medial heel}}</div><div>2. <b>Increased pain </b>in the {{c1::morning}}</div><div>3. Increased pain with&nbsp;{{c1::forefoot dorsiflexion}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-9d82e6ccf1cbde7a6d1965d66e375243f22e7e13.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>Plantar Fasciitis?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Conservative </b>treatment}}</div><div>2. Soft orthotic with&nbsp;{{c1::deep heel cup}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Simple arch taping and <b>night splint </b>to maintain position of static stretch}}</div><div>4. Vigorous stretching of the&nbsp;{{c1::Achilles/Gastroc}} and exercises that increase&nbsp;{{c1::great toe dorsiflexion}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Maybe NSAIDs}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-9d82e6ccf1cbde7a6d1965d66e375243f22e7e13.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-3c0868019942d86b9a9663aeea7a572139853c2d.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are <b>Metatarsal Stress Fractures</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. The most common metatarsal stress fracture is&nbsp;{{c1::March Fracture: a <b>second metatarsal </b>fracture}}</div><div>2. Fifth metatarsal fracture occur at insertion of&nbsp;{{c1::peroneus brevis}}</div><div>3. Due to a&nbsp;{{c1::change in running pattern:</div><div>Eg: Increasing mileage, running hills, or running on a harder surface}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Metatarsal Stress Fractures?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;Dull ache during&nbsp;{{c1::weight bearing}} and progressing pain&nbsp;{{c1::at rest}}</div><div>2. Progresses from&nbsp;{{c1::diffuse to localized pain}}</div><div>3. Symptoms usually come after&nbsp;{{c1::an increase in duration/intensity or type of training}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>metatarsal stress fractures?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Bone Scan}}</div><div>2 .Partial {{c1::weight bearing until asymptomatic at rest}}</div><div>3. Initial Immobilization (aircast) until&nbsp;{{c1::fully weight-bearing without pain}}</div><div>4. Return to running should be&nbsp;{{c1::gradual}}</div>	Special attention given to biomechanics throughout return to sport and make sure to evaluate footwear	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is a Hallux valgus deformity?<div><br></div><div>1. Also known as&nbsp;{{c1::Bunion}}</div><div>2. {{c1::<b>Exostosis </b>of first metatarsal head}}</div><div>3. Bursa becomes&nbsp;{{c1::inflamed and thickens, enlarges joint, and causes lateral malalignment of great toe}}</div>	"Exostosis: overgrowth<div><img src=""paste-9f4d495b7278cc29e2aa2c26614f72721d133582.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a Hallux valgus deformity?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Tenderness, swelling, and enlargement of joint}}</div><div>2. As inflammation continues...{{c1::angulation increases causing painful ambulation}}</div><div>3. What may develop in great toe flexors?&nbsp;{{c1::Tendinitis}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-9f4d495b7278cc29e2aa2c26614f72721d133582.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>Hallux Valgus?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Wear correct fitting shoes, appropriate orthotics}}</div><div>2. Place a pad over&nbsp;{{c1::first metatarshophalangeal joint, and tape splint between first and second toes}}</div><div>3. Engage in&nbsp;{{c1::foot exercises for intrinsic and extrinsic muscles}}</div><div>4. What may be necessary?&nbsp;{{c1::Bunionectomy}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-9f4d495b7278cc29e2aa2c26614f72721d133582.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-089df0adff58751f01c576b5fd2aa0a876a8aa61.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is a <b>sprained toe</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Caused by&nbsp;{{c1::kicking non-yielding objects}}</div><div>2. Pushes joint&nbsp;{{c1::beyond normal ROM disrupting ligaments and joint capsule}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a Sprained toe?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Immediate pain and <b>intense </b>but <b>short-lived</b>}}</div><div>2. Swelling and discoloration occuring within&nbsp;{{c1::1-2 days}}</div><div>3. Stiffness and residual pain will last&nbsp;{{c1::several weeks}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>a sprained toe?<div><br></div><div>1. Precautionary&nbsp;{{c1::x-ray may be necessary}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Budding taping toes to immobilize}}</div><div>3. Begin&nbsp;{{c1::weight bearing as tolerable}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>great toe hyperextension</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Also known as&nbsp;{{c1::turf toe}}</div><div>2. What are the <b>S/S </b>of great toe hyperextension (turf toe)?<div><br></div><div>1. Pain and swelling, which increases during&nbsp;{{c1::push-off in walking, running, and jumping}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d063dea49556a0ff02bf6a652bbbd26ae940927d.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>great toe hyperextension?<div><br></div><div>1. Increase&nbsp;{{c1::rigidity of forefoot region in shoe}}</div><div>2. Taping the&nbsp;{{c1::toe}} to prevent&nbsp;{{c1::dorsiflexion}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Rest; discourage activity until pain free}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d063dea49556a0ff02bf6a652bbbd26ae940927d.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is a <b>Subungual Hematoma</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Direct pressure: dropping something on toe or kicking}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Repetitive shearing forces on toenail}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-0c4c105de4c4d509b04147066671f16a790ffc35.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Subungual Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>1. Accumulation&nbsp;{{c1::of blood underneath toenail}}</div><div>2. Likely to cause&nbsp;{{c1::extreme pain and ultimately loss of nail}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-0c4c105de4c4d509b04147066671f16a790ffc35.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>a Subungual Hematoma?<div><br></div><div>1. Apply&nbsp;{{c1::ice pack immediately}}</div><div>2. Relieve pressure within&nbsp;{{c1::12-24 hours (drill nail) - must be sterile to prevent infection}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-0c4c105de4c4d509b04147066671f16a790ffc35.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What type of joint is the <b>ankle joint</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A <b>stable </b>hinge joint}}<br></div>	Square shape of talus adds to stability of the ankle	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What <b>prevents </b>medial or lateral displacement of the ankle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The malleoli}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg

When is the ankle in the <b>least </b>stable position?<div>{{c1::Plantarflexion}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg

What <b>functional tests </b>could you do to assess the leg and ankle?<div><br></div><div>1. <b>Plantarflexion</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Walk on toes}}</div><div>2. <b>Dorsiflexion</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Walk on heels}}</div><div>3. <b>Inversion</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Walk on lateral borders of feet}}</div><div>4. <b>Eversion</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Walk on medial borders of feet}}</div>	If there is any <b>pain/difficulty </b>bearing weight, DO NOT perform! What are the <b>Ottawa Ankle Rules</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Rules for <b>field assessment </b>to see if an athlete with an ankle injury needs to go in for an <b>x-ray</b>}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Inability to bear weight for <b><u>four steps </u></b>(two on each foot) at time of injury/examination}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Tenderness over <b><u>inferior or posterior</u> </b>pole of either <b><u>malleoli</u> </b>or <b><u>midfoot</u> </b>area}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Tenderness along <b><u>base of fifth</u> </b>metatarsal or navicular bone}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d570a2402a3e984c9979dbb52b827a539a73e4c9.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a grade 1&nbsp;<b>inversion </b>ankle sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Mild pain and disability}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Weight bearing is <b>minimally impaired</b>}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Point tenderness </b>over ligaments}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-1bb3dc6142e586b3ecb17b3e53e3989939be8236.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg

What are the <b>S/S </b>of a <b>grade 2 </b>ankle inversion sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. What would you feel or hear?&nbsp;{{c1::Pop or snap}}</div><div>2. How much pain would you feel?&nbsp;{{c1::Moderate pain with difficulty bearing weight}}</div><div>3. Palpation?&nbsp;{{c1::You feel tenderness}}</div><div>4. What is present?&nbsp;{{c1::Edema}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-ff976117a92a9c8a8d137560733bdab28c1cd20f.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg

What is a <b>grade 3 </b>ankle inversion sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. How common is this?&nbsp;{{c1::Relatively uncommon}}</div><div>2. What is it caused by?&nbsp;{{c1::Significant force}}</div><div>3. What does it often result in?&nbsp;{{c1::Talocrural subluxation}}</div><div>4. What ligaments does it cause damage to?&nbsp;{{c1::Anterior talofibular, posterior talofibular, and calcaneofibular ligaments}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-7aeb72aa3ebf8e015f349e56fab2d44070b3a024.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a grade 3 ankle inversion sprain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Severe pain, swelling, <b>hemarthrosis</b>, and discoloration}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Unable to bear weight}}</div>	"Hemarthrosis: Bleeding episodes into a joint cavity<div><img src=""paste-7dc3efd9d66b3c42331cdb19d7d2cfbcb3688d26.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>a 3rd grade ankle inversion sprain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::POLICE}}</div><div>2. Immobilized for&nbsp;{{c1::4-6 weeks}}</div><div>3. Initially&nbsp;{{c1::non-weight bearing}} until pain decreases</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Traditional rehab and progress as tolerated}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Surgery may be warranted to stabilize ankle}}</div>	Don't mobilize them too early; likely needs to be screened for a fracture.<div>Everything is similar to grade 2 but just takes a lot longer</div>	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What percentage of ankle sprains does <b>eversion ankle sprains </b>represent?<div>{{c1::5-10}}%<br></div><div><br></div><div>Why is this the case?</div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Bony protection and ligament strength lessen occurence}}</div><div><br></div><div>Where does the damage occur?</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Damage to deltoid ligament and possibly fractures the fibula}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-fa021d64c768d8c5b71e90b018adb23f502915f9.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an <b>Eversion ankle sprain</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Mirror symptoms of an inversion sprain}}</div><div>2. Where is the pain predominately?&nbsp;{{c1::Pain is mostly medial}}</div><div>3. Potential for&nbsp;{{c1::lateral malleoli pain (fracture)}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>an eversion ankle sprain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Same course of treatment as inversion sprain}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Grade 2 or higher will present with considerable instability}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is a <b>syndesmotic sprain</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Also known as a&nbsp;{{c1::high ankle}}</div><div>2. Injury to the&nbsp;{{c1::distal tibiofibular joint (anterior/posterior tibiofibular ligament}}</div><div>3. The MOI is&nbsp;{{c1::forced rotation often in dorsiflexion}}</div><div>4. Which ligaments are often involved?&nbsp;{{c1::Medial and lateral ligaments}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b657a07825b687a2d8f284632488c6e085e52d24.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-a8e02232331e32edbfa60ec59e6f75c06578285c.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a syndesmotic sprain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Severe pain and loss of function}}</div><div>2. Multiple&nbsp;{{c1::ROM elicit symptoms}}</div><div>3. Pain worsens with&nbsp;{{c1::weight bearing and dorsiflexion}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b657a07825b687a2d8f284632488c6e085e52d24.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>a syndesmotic sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. Difficult to treat and may require&nbsp;{{c1::months to recover}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Same course of treatment as other sprains - likely longer immobilization and rehab}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Surgery may be required}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-b63534cfc7105dc13536b594b22004fe9869d5fb.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-b657a07825b687a2d8f284632488c6e085e52d24.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Chronic Ankle Instability</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Develops following&nbsp;{{c1::1/3}} of all acute ankle sprains.</div><div>2. Causes&nbsp;{{c1::mechanical and functional}} instability.</div>	Rehab must encompass all aspects to retain injured joint and limb	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Mechanical Instability</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Loss of <b>static instability</b>}}</div>	The actual stability of the joint itself	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Functional Instability</b>?<div>{{c1::Perception that the ankle is unstable}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>What are the <b>3 components </b>of functional instability?</div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Proprioception}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Kinesthetic awareness - knowing where your foot is in space)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Strength problems}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>Achilles Tendinosis</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Inflammatory condition involving tendon and sheath}}</div><div>2. Causes&nbsp;{{c1::fibrosis and scarring}} that can restrict tendon motion in sheath</div><div>3. Tendon is overloaded due to&nbsp;{{c1::consistent stress beyond internal resistance}}</div><div>4. How does it progress?&nbsp;{{c1::Gradual onset and worsens with continued use}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-3d527d698528c57b68317623fb480ebe90c767ea.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Achilles Tendinosis?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Generalized pain and stiffness}}</div><div>2. Palpable pain&nbsp;{{c1::proximal to calcaneal insertion}}</div><div>3. Later stages include&nbsp;{{c1::morning stiffness}}</div><div>4. What occurs in <b>active </b>plantarflexion and passive dorsiflexion?&nbsp;{{c1::Crepitus}}</div><div>5. What might happen with <b>chronic inflammation</b>?&nbsp;{{c1::May lead to thickening}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-3d527d698528c57b68317623fb480ebe90c767ea.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>Achilles Tendinosis?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Reduce stress on tendon and address structural faults (biomechanics)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::NSAIDS}}</div><div>3. Strengthening must&nbsp;{{c1::progress slowly in order to not aggravate the tendon}}</div><div>4. What type of strengthening is the most optimal for increasing strength of tendon?&nbsp;{{c1::Eccentric strengthening}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-3d527d698528c57b68317623fb480ebe90c767ea.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is an <b>Achilles Tendon Rupture</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. When does it occur?&nbsp;&nbsp;{{c1::Sudden stop and go - forceful dorsiflexion (ankle) with knee moving into full extension (because gastroc is a two-joint muscle}}</div><div>2. At what ages of athletes is this most commonly seen?&nbsp;{{c1::&gt;= 30 years old (can be observed at any age)}}</div><div>3. Do people who have this usually have a history with ankle injuries?&nbsp;{{c1::No, there is usually no precipitating factors}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-9d7f052f12c3b027baa34457073bf640a948242e.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an Achilles Tendon Rupture?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Sudden <b>snap </b>(kick in the leg) with immediate pain, which <b>rapidly subsides</b>}}&nbsp;</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Point tenderness, swelling, discoloration, decreased ROM}}</div><div>3. Obvious&nbsp;{{c1::indentation}}</div><div>4. Occurs&nbsp;{{c1::2-6 cm proximal to the calcaneal insertion}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-9d7f052f12c3b027baa34457073bf640a948242e.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>an Achilles Tendon Rupture?<div><br></div><div>1. Usual management involves&nbsp;{{c1::surgical repair for serious injuries}}</div><div>Return of&nbsp;{{c1::75-80}}% of function</div><div><br></div><div>2. When nonoperative treatment:</div><div>Non-weight bearing cast on for&nbsp;{{c1::6+ weeks}}</div><div>Walking cast for&nbsp;{{c1::2+ weeks}}</div><div>Return of&nbsp;{{c1::75-90}}% of function</div><div><br></div><div>3. Rehabilitation lasts about&nbsp;{{c1::6 months}}</div>	"<div>The reason why non-operative has better return to normal function is because if it is non-operative we already assume it is less serious.</div><img src=""paste-9d7f052f12c3b027baa34457073bf640a948242e.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is <b>medial tibial stress syndrome</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Also known as&nbsp;{{c1::Shin-splints}}</div><div>2. Where is the pain?&nbsp;{{c1::Anterior portion of shin}}</div><div>3. Accounts for&nbsp;{{c1::10-15}}% of all running injuries and&nbsp;{{c1::60}}% of leg pain in athletes</div><div>4. What is it caused by?&nbsp;{{c1::Repetitive microtrauma}}</div><div>5. What are the <b>greatest </b>contributors to MTSS?&nbsp;{{c1::Weak muscles, static foot structure, improper footwear, training errors, and biomechanics}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-257c86353b8dffdc23dc8d760c47712a395ea0e7.jpg""><div></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of MTSS?<div><br></div><div><b>4 grades </b>of pain:</div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Pain after activity}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Pain before and after activity and not affecting performance}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Pain before, during, and after activity, affecting performance}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Pain so severe performance is impossible}}</div><div><br></div><div>Which stages have high risk of stress fracture?</div><div>{{c1::Stages 3 and 4}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-257c86353b8dffdc23dc8d760c47712a395ea0e7.jpg""><div></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>MTSS?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Physician referral for X-ray/bone scan}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Activity Modification}}</div><div>3. Correction of&nbsp;{{c1::abnormal biomechanics}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Therapy (modalities and soft tissue work)}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Arch taping and orthotics}}</div>	"<div>Requires involvement of entire IST.</div><div>Biomechanics because this mostly happens due to improper running.</div><img src=""paste-257c86353b8dffdc23dc8d760c47712a395ea0e7.jpg""><div></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What is a <b>stress fracture of tibia</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Common&nbsp;{{c1::overuse condition, mostly those with structural and biomechanical insufficiencies}}</div><div>2. Where do runners tend to develop this?&nbsp;{{c1::Lower third of lower leg}}</div><div>3. Who does this often occur in?&nbsp;{{c1::Nonconditioned and inexperienced individuals - may be as a result of drastic change in environment}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-edac491ce9ad1bae152ab8633c3ab06483f3a832.jpg""><br></div><div></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a stress fracture of Tibia?<div><br></div><div>1. Pain more intense&nbsp;{{c1::after exercise than before}}</div><div>2. Point tenderness&nbsp;{{c1::basically everywhere, difficult to discern bone and soft-tissue pain}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Results of bone scan}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-edac491ce9ad1bae152ab8633c3ab06483f3a832.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
How would you <b>manage </b>a stress fracture of the tibia?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Discontinue stress-inducing activity}}</div><div>2. {{c1::PWB until symptoms have resolved at rest}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Cycling before running}}</div><div>4. After being pain free for {{c1::~ 2 weeks}}, patient can gradually return to running</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Biomechanics}} must be addressed.</div>	"<div>PWB: Partial weight bearing</div><img src=""paste-edac491ce9ad1bae152ab8633c3ab06483f3a832.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Foot_and_Lower_Leg
What type of joint is the knee?<div>{{c1::Hinge Joint}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What is <b>stability </b>dependant on (around the knee)?<div>{{c1::ligaments, joint capsule, and muscles surround the joint}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>movements </b>of the knee?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Flexion}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Extension}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Rotation}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
Why does the knee have a <b>rotational component</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. This is because of the&nbsp;{{c1::screw home mechanism:</div><div>As the knee extends, it <b>externally rotates </b>because the medial femoral condyle is larger than the lateral condyle}}</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
Which muscle <b>unlocks </b>the knee allowing the knee to flex?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Popliteus muscle}}<br></div>		KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What does the <b>posterior cruciate ligament </b>prevent?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Prevents excessive internal rotation of the knee}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Limits anterior translation of the femur when the tibia is fixed}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5b36fb4f8967cab758adf79646df42d2039bbc4c.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What does the <b>anterior cruciate ligament&nbsp;</b>do?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Prevents excessive internal rotation and hyperextension}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Stabilizes knee in full extension}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5b36fb4f8967cab758adf79646df42d2039bbc4c.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What does the <b>patella </b>do?<div><br></div><div>1. Provides a mechanical advantage in&nbsp;{{c1::flexion}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Distributes compressive stresses on the femur by increasing contact between patellar tendon and femur}}</div><div>3. What happens to the patella when moving from extension to flexion?&nbsp;{{c1::The patella glides laterally and further into trochlear groove}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-082c9e20e375d995cd682d4fe0cd2749f35e5454.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How does the knee relate to the <b>kinetic chain</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>There are forces directly above and below the knee and therefore forces must be absorbed and distributed}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Often the&nbsp;{{c1::weakest link}}</div>	Knee is very susceptible to injury resulting from absorption of forces	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What should you <b>observe </b>when assessing a knee injury?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Knee symmetry or asymmetry}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Leg-length discrepancy - maybe due to pelvic rotations}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Q angle}}</div>	"<div>Pelvic rotation: one of the pelvic bone is displaced</div><img src=""paste-1f03f9e7c47a585bbc05cec8159a99ef4a830684.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What is the normal Q angle for males/females?<div><br></div><div>Males:&nbsp;{{c1::10 degrees}}</div><div>Females:&nbsp;{{c1::15 degrees}}</div>	"<div>Exaggerated angles often lead to <b>improper patella tracking</b></div><img src=""paste-bb5b54acf21dfb18044cd727a124ed7b98d6f2f2.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee

What can we do to <b>reduce the risk </b>of injuries to the knee?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Physical Conditioning:</div><div>Strength/flexibility/cardio/endurance/agility/speed/balance, must all meed demands of the sport}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Functional and Prophylactic Knee Braces:</div><div>Used to <b>prevent </b>and <b>reduce </b>severity of injuries. How can a <b>medial collateral ligament sprain </b>occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Severe blow from lateral side (<b>valgus force</b>!)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4633b9fd9e6309458032f4e3f375951df2894b58.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are <b>S/S </b>of a <b>grade 1 </b>MCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Little fiber tearing or stretching}}</div><div>2. Stable&nbsp;{{c1::valgus}} test</div><div>3. Little or no&nbsp;{{c1::joint effusion}}</div><div>4. Relatively normal&nbsp;{{c1::ROM}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-f903721624d7a469b312b91257a2cfa85979c38f.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>a grade 1 MCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. POLICE for&nbsp;{{c1::at least 24 hours - NWB or PWB if needed}}</div><div>2,&nbsp;{{c1::Conventional rehab - accelerate exercise to avoid atrophy}}</div><div>3. May take up to&nbsp;{{c1::2-3 weeks}} to resolve</div>	"<img src=""paste-f903721624d7a469b312b91257a2cfa85979c38f.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a grade 2 MCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. What is torn?&nbsp;{{c1::Complete tear of deep capsular ligament and partial tear of superficial layer of MCL}}</div><div>2. Laxity at&nbsp;{{c1::30 degrees flexion}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Slight swelling}}</div><div>4. Pain along&nbsp;{{c1::medial aspect of knee}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-4e39075c9051f4f6d385024c1632ffd0ca27ffe1.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>a grade 2 MCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. POLICE for&nbsp;{{c1::48-72 hours}}</div><div>2. Crutch use until&nbsp;{{c1::acute phase has resolved}}</div><div>3. What should you use prior to the initiation of ROM activities?&nbsp;{{c1::Brace}}</div><div>4. How would you progress?&nbsp;{{c1::Gradual progression from <b>isometrics </b>to <b>closed kinetic chain exercises</b>&nbsp;and <b>sport specific tasks</b>}}</div><div>5. How long is a typical return to play?&nbsp;{{c1::4-6 weeks}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-4e39075c9051f4f6d385024c1632ffd0ca27ffe1.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a grade 3 MCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. Stability? {{c1::Complete loss of medial stability}}</div><div>2. Swelling?&nbsp;{{c1::Minimum to moderate swelling - because swelling can move in and out}}</div><div>3. Pain?&nbsp;{{c1::Immediate pain followed by ache/throbbing}}</div><div>4. Motion?&nbsp;{{c1::Loss of motion due to <b>effusion </b>and <b>hamstring guarding</b>}}</div><div>5. Valgus Stress Test?&nbsp;{{c1::Positive at <b>all ranges </b>- super sloppy knee}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-be23c2d57785e2de350df796e8825e015d34749b.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>a grade 3 MCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. POLICE until&nbsp;{{c1::ongoing acute symptoms resolve}}</div><div>2. Limited ROM with brace for&nbsp;{{c1::3-5 weeks}}</div><div>3. How would you progress?&nbsp;{{c1::Slowly progress weight bearing and increased ROM for first 2-4 weeks}}</div><div>4. How would rehab look like?&nbsp;{{c1::Similar to grade 1 and 2 once function has returned}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-be23c2d57785e2de350df796e8825e015d34749b.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How does a <b>lateral collateral ligament sprain </b>occur?<div><br></div><div>1. Result of&nbsp;{{c1::varus force}}</div><div>2. How is tibia rotated?&nbsp;{{c1::Internally rotated}}</div><div>3. Where can severe damage occur (Not at LCL)?&nbsp;{{c1::cruciate ligaments, ITB, and meniscus}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-1264145e6db0e29790355eec019d0101830a674d.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-e6f97f32d67efb00e7416129d5d78685cef9763d.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an LCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. Pain and tenderness over&nbsp;{{c1::LCL}}</div><div>2. Swelling and effusion around&nbsp;{{c1::LCL}}</div><div>3. Joint&nbsp;{{c1::laxity with varus testing}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-1264145e6db0e29790355eec019d0101830a674d.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>a LCL sprain?<div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Same as how you would manage MCL injuries}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-1264145e6db0e29790355eec019d0101830a674d.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
<div>There are two types of ways an ACL sprain can occur.</div><div>{{c1::Non-contact}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Contact}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a738f093f179be5213093575077d606711ee6620.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How does a <b>non-contact </b>ACL sprain occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>So basically, the athlete is <b>decelerating </b>from a jump or run and lands (WB causes axial force) with knee near <b>full extension </b>and <b>adducted/knee valus</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Axial and valgus force produces <b>anterior shear </b>and <b>internal rotation subluxation </b>of the tibia on the femur causing the snap}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>1. What is the likelihood for this mechanism to cause ACL sprain vs contact?&nbsp;{{c1::80% more likely}}</div><div><br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9064b2abdb9b06b8ec5e797b5f5c3afb83563729.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-a738f093f179be5213093575077d606711ee6620.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How does a <b>contact </b>ACL sprain occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Athlete is decelerating and <b>usually </b>changing direction.&nbsp;</div><div>Knee is planted on the ground with the knee <b>abducted</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>Contact occurs <b>laterally </b>and <b>posteriorly </b>forcing the knee into a <b>valgus </b>and <b>internal rotation </b>with anterior shear}}`</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9064b2abdb9b06b8ec5e797b5f5c3afb83563729.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-a738f093f179be5213093575077d606711ee6620.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are <b>other factors </b>that may contribute to the cause of ACL sprains?<div><br></div><div><b>Intrinsic Factors:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::</div><div>Femoral notch, ACL size, kinetic alignment <b>(Q-angle)</b>&nbsp;and faulty biomechanics.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Extrinsic Factors:&nbsp;</b>{{c1::</div><div>Conditioning, skill acquisition, playing style, equipment, and preparation time}}</div><div><br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9064b2abdb9b06b8ec5e797b5f5c3afb83563729.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-a738f093f179be5213093575077d606711ee6620.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an ACL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. Sound?&nbsp;{{c1::A pop with severe pain and disability}}</div><div>2. Tests?&nbsp;{{c1::Positive anterior drawer and Lachman's sign}}</div><div>3. Swelling?&nbsp;{{c1::Rapid swelling at the joint line}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9064b2abdb9b06b8ec5e797b5f5c3afb83563729.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-a738f093f179be5213093575077d606711ee6620.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>an ACL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::POLICE and use crutches (NWB or PWB)}}<br>2. What may be necessary to determine extent of injury?&nbsp;{{c1::MRI or arthroscopy}}</div><div>3. What does surgery involve?&nbsp;{{c1::Joint construction with grafts (tendon) - include hamstring, patellar tendon, or cadaver (achilles)}}</div><div>4. How long does it take to <b>return to sport</b>?&nbsp;{{c1::12+ months}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-d498f512bdcaa5d8fddaf8be946cfc443d91e7e8.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-a738f093f179be5213093575077d606711ee6620.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How does a <b>posterior cruciate ligament sprain </b>occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>When you <b>fall on a bent knee</b>&nbsp;is the most common way to get a PCL sprain}}</div><div><br></div><div>1. When are you most at risk for this?&nbsp;{{c1::When your knee is 90 degrees in flexion}}</div><div>2. Sometimes referred to as&nbsp;{{c1::dashboard injury:</div><div>called this because it may result when flexed knee of car driver or passenger hits the dashboard}}</div>	"<div>Relatively uncommon</div><div><img src=""paste-26f35522305458529801297d1dbc8da6ecf25c65.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a PCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1. Feeling?&nbsp;{{c1::Feel a pop in the back of the knee}}</div><div>2. Swelling/Tenderness?&nbsp;{{c1::Has tenderness but little swelling in the popliteal fossa}}</div><div>3. Tests?&nbsp;{{c1::Laxity with posterior sag test}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-26f35522305458529801297d1dbc8da6ecf25c65.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>a PCL sprain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::POLICE}}</div><div>2. What should rehab focus on?&nbsp;{{c1::Quad strength}}</div><div>3. Can be&nbsp;{{c1::surgical or nonoperative}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-26f35522305458529801297d1dbc8da6ecf25c65.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are <b>meniscal lesions</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Most common MOI is&nbsp;{{c1::rotary force with knee flexed or extended}}</div><div>2. Medial meniscus injury is due to {{c1::torsional and valgus forces}}</div><div>3. Where can tears happen?&nbsp;{{c1::Longitudinal, oblique, or transverse}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-c0cac5260a8963ccf13b36f23ee8320ef19ecfe6.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Meniscal Lesions?<div>1. Effusion develops over&nbsp;{{c1::48-72 hours period}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Joint line pain</b>}}</div><div>3. Intermittent&nbsp;{{c1::locking and giving away (not always present)}}</div><div>4. Pain with squatting below&nbsp;{{c1::90 degrees}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-a1d3b1c286de07a159637a3b00fed1e41115114e.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2f9347867e583d2d0c4f9cb6d869cd859f80f047.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>meniscal lesions?<div><br></div><div>1. Often&nbsp;{{c1::further testing is required}}</div><div>2. What happens when surgery happens?&nbsp;{{c1::All efforts are made to preserve the meniscus with full healing being dependent on location}}</div><div>3. What does a <b>menisectomy rehab </b>allow?&nbsp;{{c1::PWB and quick RTP &lt; 4 weeks}}</div><div>4. What will a <b>repaired meniscus </b>require?&nbsp;{{c1::Immobilization, NWB and a gradual return to activity over 10-12 weeks}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-f6c698e0c37bc7f5b6f1bd30f298ab4c458b1d1f.jpg""><img src=""paste-a1d3b1c286de07a159637a3b00fed1e41115114e.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What is <b>Knee Bursitis</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Can be <b>acute </b>or <b>chronic</b>&nbsp;and can be <b>prepatellar </b>(due to continued kneeling) or <b>infrapatellar </b>(due to overuse of patella tendon}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-56a1d361345842a8825c36298351158f2e879d29.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-4ab0009551edaae2da4129c581edb2714ea3a69a.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What are the <b>S/S </b>of Knee Bursitis?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div><b>Localized</b> swelling around the knee that is <b>ballotable</b>}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>1. Swelling in popliteal fossa may indicate a&nbsp;{{c1::Baker's cyst:</div><div>Bursa in the posterior aspect of the knee}}</div>	<div>Associated with <b>semimembranosus bursa </b>or <b>medial head of gastrocnemius</b></div>Ballotable: squishy or bogginess	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee

What causes <b>Osgood-Schlatter Disease</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Apophysitis occuring at the tibial tubercle</div><div>- Develops a bony callus, enlarging the tubercle}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>How do symptoms resolve?&nbsp;{{c1::It resolves with aging}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e40d36ccef986ddb8063632af1f598b1141071a4.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee

Tightening of&nbsp;{{c1::quadriceps}}</div>	Quads tighten because gastroc tightens causing knee flexion making quads more tight	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
How would you <b>manage </b>Osgood-Schlatter disease?<div><br></div><div>1. Reduce&nbsp;{{c1::stressful activity}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Ice before and after activity}}</div><div>3. Focus on&nbsp;{{c1::quad muslces - soft tissue release, static stretching}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e40d36ccef986ddb8063632af1f598b1141071a4.jpg"">"	KIN_240::Pre-Midterm_2::Knee
What <b>3 components </b>must the thigh have to <b>withstand </b>injury forces?	1. Optimal Strength<div>2. Endurance (cardiovascular + muscular)</div><div>3. Mobility</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is critical to perform <b>dynamic activities </b>and provide a base of support with the pelvis for whole body motion?	Muscle Function	Because of demands of both dynamic force production and trunk stability, this region is vulnerable to injury		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is <b>lower cross syndrome</b>?<div><br></div><div>What are ways we can combat this?</div>	When you got something like weak abdominals which in turn sees weakness in the glutes (lower cross).<div><br></div><div>This causes tightness in areas like the hip flexors and thoracolumbar extensors causing anterior pelvic tilt.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Ways we can combat this are the russian twists (I think thats what they called)</div>	"<img src=""paste-50ad264b030cf405b6d61c102c899d5eed47ef41.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are <b>critical </b>in preventing injury in thigh, hip, and groin?	Maintaining <b>strength </b>and <b>flexibility</b>!!<div><br></div><div>Need a well designed resistance training program and sport specific training.</div>	"<img src=""paste-3e3cb055ab2a84ca612339e5eeceb09c988ea549.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>two-joint muscles </b>of the thigh?	1. <b>Rectus Femoris</b>: only quad muscle that crosses hip - <b>extends knee </b>and <b>flexes the hip</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>2. <b>Hamstrings</b>: crosses knee joint posteriorly and all <b>except the short head of the biceps </b>cross the hip - <b>flexes the knee </b>and <b>extends the hip</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you assess the thigh?	Basically <b>HOPS</b><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>History</b>: onset, previous history</div><div><b>Observation</b>: make sure comparing bilaterally, swelling, deformity, discoloration, anatalgic gait?</div><div><b>Palpation</b>: a bunch of shit</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is the most <b>common </b>thigh injury in contact sports?	Quadriceps contusion			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>quadriceps contusion</b>?	A direct <b>crushing force </b>to quadriceps.<div><br></div><div>Often acute but can result from repeat sub-acute trauma.</div>	"Most common thigh injury in contact sport.<div>Extent of force determines degree - also should take equipment into account.</div><div><br></div><div>Was the athlete prepared for the impact? Being ready will lessen the severity.&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-e898478e6103ae5dc3ea6bcede0bd22ef2f39916.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a Quadriceps contusion?	1. Pain with <b>temporary loss of function</b><div>2. <b>Early effusion</b> with palpable painful region (most cases)</div><div>- will get that jelly fluid like feeling and then dissipate</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-e898478e6103ae5dc3ea6bcede0bd22ef2f39916.jpg""><br></div><div>Here the left leg has swelling that tracked down into the lower chamber of the thigh</div><div><img src=""paste-29406302238d37c1b830e25353e794d7d58a0e2c.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a Quad Contusion?<div><br></div><div>Early Management...</div><div>RTP Management...</div>	Remove and POLICE, NSAIDS and analgesics.<div><br></div><div>NWB/PWB for more <b>severe </b>cases.</div><div><br></div><div>Initial management: picture below</div><div>- <b>optimal position</b></div><div>- bring heel as close to bum as possible until slight stretch</div><div>- wrap and apply with ice (ice goes in wrap)</div><div><br></div><div>Getting them movement in a pain free ROM <b>as early as possible</b>.&nbsp;</div><div>- getting that painfree motion back is essential (reintroduces contraction to the muscle area)</div><div><br></div><div>Early Management:&nbsp;</div><div>1.&nbsp;<b>Cryotherapy </b>with gentle stretching and <b>transition </b>to heat after acute stages of healing.</div><div>2. Tensor for compression during ADL</div><div>3. Progress with weight bearing in water and slowly progress</div><div><br></div><div>RTP management:</div><div>1. Often be able to RTP while still being symptomatic (as long as safe ROM and strength)<br></div><div>2. Padding/Protection is essential</div><div>3. ongoing management (soft tissue)&nbsp; likely necessary</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-e0cec4ca720891b49096055ea079fd1e2bc33dda.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-cfa33f508ca1d01fc0288c1419a6e2c6595f815e.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>major consideration </b>when dealing with a quadriceps contusion?	<b>Ectopic Calfification (myositis ossificans)</b><div><br></div><div>The depth of the contusion to the quad is so significant that it disrupts the <b>periosteum</b> of the femur.</div><div><br></div><div>With that there will be the release of osteoblastic material that may <b>go into the muscle itself</b>!</div><div><br></div><div>Either resolve in 9-12 months or mature with repeated trauma</div>	"Concern for <b>severe </b>quadriceps contusion or <b>repeated </b>quadriceps contusion.<div>Need surgery to take out this bone<br><div><div><img src=""paste-f1ab9bb9c23dd557dffbe5fc3809e345448c0020.jpg""><br></div></div></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>quadriceps muscle strain</b>?<div><br></div><div>What types of sports is this most common in?</div>	Due to <b>overstretching </b>of the quadriceps at the knee (flexion) and hip (extension).<br><div><br></div><div>May also occur because a forceful abrupt activation of the quadriceps in a compromised position</div><div>- against an immovable or resisting force</div>	"More common with sports that don't have contact.<div><img src=""paste-fe52de8e476242ec504982623a982978ebb8a10b.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a quadriceps muscle strain?	<b>Loss of function </b>at the <b>knee flexion ROM </b>and <b>Hip flexion and knee extension strength</b>.<div><br></div><div>Complete tear will likely present with palpable deformity (quad rolling up the thigh!)</div>	Pain, point tenderness, spasm		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a <b>grade 1 muscle strain</b>?	Will complain about the tightness in front of thigh and mild discomfort but near <b>normal gait </b>and <b>mobility.</b>	Testing their ability could bring on symptoms.		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a <b>grade 2 muscle strain</b>?	We will see some form of <b>limp </b>or <b>antalgic gait</b>.<div><br></div><div>Will have ROM at knee but will have <b>pain</b>&nbsp;and <b>discomfort</b>.</div><div>- pain with knee extension and hip flexion</div><div><br></div><div>Swelling is noticeable and will the <b>move </b>with some <b>bogginess</b>.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a <b>grade 3 muscle strain</b>?	Super pain. Pain with palpation.<div><br></div><div>Can't bear weight.</div><div><br></div><div>Isometric contractions may produce <b>defect </b>or <b>bulge </b>in muscle.</div>	"Palpable deficit - that's a fking knee not a heel bro<div><br></div><div>Gray image - tear that was not surgically repaired (bulk of muscle closer up to the hip)<br><div><img src=""paste-29d8095efa6cccccb350aff2ecaf627e62d87e7e.jpg""><br></div></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a quadriceps muscle strain?	RICE, NSAIDs, and Analgesics.<div><br></div><div>Grade 1. Wrapped during ADL and activity</div><div><br></div><div>Grade 2: ICE and compression for <b>3-5 days </b>with gradual increase in pain free knee ROM</div><div><br></div><div>Grade 3: <b>Crutch </b>for <b>7-14 days</b>&nbsp;with compression for support.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you do a <b>rehab progression </b>of a quadriceps muscle strain?	1. Start off with <b>isometrics&nbsp;</b><div>2. <b>Concentric </b>only bilateral strengthening</div><div>3. <b>Concentric-Eccentric loading</b></div><div>4. <b>Eccentric Overloading</b></div><div>5. Plyometric/Maximal effort</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>hamstring muscle strain</b>?	There are multiple theories of injury because it is mostly <b>intrinsic </b>MOI.<div><br></div><div>1. Hamstring and Quad contract together</div><div>2. Change in role from hip extendor to knee flexor</div><div>3. Fatigue, posture, leg length discrepancy, lack of flexibility, and strength imbalances.</div>	No clear definition to why an athlete is predisposed to a hamstring injury	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a Hamstring Muscle Strain?	Most often occur at mid muscle belly or closer to origin!<div><br></div><div><b>Grade 1</b>: &lt;20% fibres torn, soreness during movement and point tenderness (not that bad)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Grade 2</b>: &lt;70% fibres torn, Hear a sharp snap or tear (majority in this)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Grade 3</b>: &gt;70% fibres torn, <b>rupturing </b>of tendinous junction or muscular tissue. Severe swelling and <b>ecchymosis </b>(bruising)., <b>palpable </b>deficit (hole).</div>	"<img src=""paste-94190580b4b1b1cec598c901c71b68e35b0ea1b2.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-cde6dfe024e6dccce1acbed57fa3cb0e2fd6bf02.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a hamstring muscle strain?	POLICE, NSAIDs, and analgesics.<div><br></div><div>Similar to quadriceps strain.</div><div><br></div><div>Need to develop&nbsp;<b>prequisite&nbsp;</b>strength so that this <b>intrinsic </b>injury does not happen again.</div><div><br></div><div>Focus on <b>eccentric strength training </b>to reduce likelihood of repeat hamstring injuries.</div><div><br></div><div>May require several months to recover.</div><div>- sport specific deficiencies focused on in later stages.</div>	Because it is mostly an intrinsic injury, we want to figure out WHY this happens (focus on this).		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
There is great&nbsp;{{c1::static}} stability in the hip due to the ligaments surrounding the joint itself.		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are <b>key considerations </b>when assessing the hip and pelvis?	1. A lot of forces occur at the hip during different degrees of locomotion<div>2. The most common injury here is <b>muscle strains</b></div><div>3. There is an intricate balance of muscle forces - if one muscle is fked it will mess up everything else.<br></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is the <b>most common </b>injury in the hip and pelvis?	<b>Muscle strains</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>assess </b>the hip and pelvis?	<b>HOPS </b>again!<div><br></div><div>History: numbness, tingling, <b>radiating pain </b>(could be nerves!)</div><div><br></div><div>Observation:&nbsp;</div><div>1.&nbsp;<b>Pelvis Tilt</b>&nbsp;- anterior or posterior&nbsp;</div><div>- lordosis (anterior - erector spinae and rectus femoris is tight) or flat back (posterior - tight rectus abdominus and hamstring muscle)</div><div>2. <b>Lower-limb alignment</b></div><div>3. <b>Pelvic Landmarks</b>&nbsp;- ASIS, PSIS, and iliac crest (ilium rotation)</div><div>4. <b>Walking</b></div><div>5. <b>Leg length discrepancy</b></div><div>6. <b>Femoral Anteversion and Retroversion </b>(normal is 15 degrees)</div><div><br></div><div>Palpation: a bunch of shit</div><div><br>Special Tests:</div><div>1. Kendall's Test</div><div>2. Trendellenburg's test</div>	"<img src=""paste-eb9147fa294953dbd6fce75ab06d14e73a35c62a.jpg""><div>ASIS of the athlete</div><div><img src=""paste-e41c28f6428e7b0c325fea22a29460459c907166.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is <b>femoral anteversion </b>and <b>femoral retroversion</b>?	Femoral Anteversion is when the angle between foot and femoral condyle is less then 15 degrees<div>- femoral condyle has to move laterally to compensate<br><div><br></div><div>Femoral Retroversion is when the angle between foot and femoral condyle is more then 15 degrees</div></div><div>- femoral condyle has to move medially to compensate<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cac193a8ccff876d19eccd9dac1102ea0386a7bf.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is the <b>normal angle </b>between the neck and shaft of femur?	15 degrees!	"<img src=""paste-cac193a8ccff876d19eccd9dac1102ea0386a7bf.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is the <b>Kendall's Test</b>?	A test to assess the hip and pelvis<div>- evaluates <b>rectus femoris </b>tightness (legit thomas stress test)</div>	"<img src=""paste-f5b4d9d874f615d78273cd6c4c7d6fedd2c39183.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is the <b>trendelenburg's test</b>?	Tests to assess the hip and pelvis<div>- assesses the <b>gluteus medius </b>muscle</div><div>- if able to lift non stance leg = good</div><div>- if unable to life non-stance leg = bad</div><div>- The strength to support the body with a single leg</div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9037b548a7bc14b1afe65ad285811e599778b675.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is an <b>adductor strain</b>?	<b>Twisting motion </b>at trunk/pelvis with <b>hip external rotation </b>or <b>excessive abduction</b>.	One of the more difficult hip injuries to evaluate and manage	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an Adductor Strain?	1. Pull or tearing sensation during active movement<div>2. Pain and considerable weakness</div><div>3. Limitations with other movements at the hip and trunk</div><div>- <b>adduction </b>will be impaired the most</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>an Adductor Strain?	POLICE, NSAIDs, and Analgesics<div><br></div><div>1. Must determine <b>exact </b>muscle or muscles involved</div><div>2. Reduce <b>inciting movements</b></div><div>3. <b>Restrict dynamic exercise </b>until near complete pain free</div>	"Often more problematic and <b>delayed</b> muscle strain RTP<div><img src=""paste-42bd8025f582b15dcbf2fca11373211e6aec7342.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is <b>trochanteric bursitis</b>?	<b>Inflammation </b>at the site where <b>gluteus medius </b>inerts or the <b>iliotibial (IT) band </b>passes over the trochanter	Important to&nbsp;<b>differentiate&nbsp;</b>between <b>acute </b>or <b>chronic</b><div>- acute is easy management</div><div>- chronic, something is breaking down in their kinetic chain</div>	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a trochanteric bursitis?	1. Pain in <b>lateral hip </b>that may <b>radiate </b>down the leg<div>2. Tenderness over lateral aspect of greater trochanter</div><div>3. <b>Redness </b>and <b>swelling around greater trochanter </b>(more severe cases)</div>	"<img src=""paste-3dcded59060af7ec60a36ec0e168389a80ad48ea.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a trochanteric bursitis?	POLICE, NSAIDs, and analgesics (most important if acute)<div><br></div><div>1. <b>Protection</b></div><div>2. If chronic, look at <b>soft tissue </b>or <b>biomechanics</b>!!</div>	"<img src=""paste-3dcded59060af7ec60a36ec0e168389a80ad48ea.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>hip labral tear</b>?	Occurs due to <b>repetitive movement </b>causing <b>degeneration </b>or <b>breakdown </b>of the labrum.<div><br></div><div>Can also occur acutely due to hip dislocation!&nbsp;</div>	"Maybe similar to the spastic children!<div><img src=""paste-134b6eab2ac96e3011b64273916ef62a9a1b62ba.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a hip labral tear?	Often times <b>asymptomatic</b>&nbsp;which makes it hard to see!!!!<div><br></div><div>May have <b>clicking, locking, stiffness </b>and <b>limited ROM </b>(similar to injuries to meniscus)</div><div><br></div><div>Pain in groin and hip</div><div>- hip internal rotation</div>	"<img src=""paste-134b6eab2ac96e3011b64273916ef62a9a1b62ba.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a hip labral tear?	Typically goes to doctor or surgeon<div><br></div><div>Focus on hip ROM, strength, and stability.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Avoid </b>painful movements and ranges</div><div><br></div><div>May need to get <b>surgery</b></div>	"<img src=""paste-134b6eab2ac96e3011b64273916ef62a9a1b62ba.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is <b>Sciatica/Piriformis Syndrome</b>?	Any pain produced by irritation of the <b>sciatic nerve</b><div><b><br></b><div><div>Can be due to a&nbsp;<b>disk problem, direct trauma&nbsp;</b>or&nbsp;<b>trauma from surrounding structures</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>Most&nbsp;commonly due to&nbsp;<b>a tight piriformis&nbsp;</b>(if not an acute situation)</div></div></div>	"Extremely common hip injury.<div>Often misdiagnosed as <b>sciatic nerve irritation.</b></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f85adf1ccd35a283950b8809ef08997ff8d447d2.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is <b>sciatica/piriformis syndrome </b>often misdiagnosed as?	Sciatic nerve irritation			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of sciatica/piriformis syndrome?	MUST be able to differentiate <b>low back problems </b>from piriformis syndrome!!<div><br></div><div><b>Deep pain </b>in the <b>gluteal </b>or <b>hip </b>region <b>without low back pain</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>Pain <b>radiates </b>to the <b>back of the thigh, lateral calf and foot</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>sciatica/piriformis syndrome?&gt;	<b>Manual therapy</b> until symptoms are managed (usually really good)<div><br></div><div>Soft-tissue release and mobility stretching exercises (<b>self-myofascial release</b>) are good.</div><div><br></div><div>Address asymmetry and bio-mechanics that may lead to piriformis tightness!</div>	Reduce aggravating movement in more chronic situations		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>hip pointer </b>(contusion)?	Contusion of <b>iliac crest </b>and <b>abdominal musculature</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Direct blow often to an unpadded area</div>	"<img src=""paste-ea3fcd15568f37698f46ef285b243b12d51ce616.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a <b>hip pointer</b>?	1. Pain and muscle spasm<div>2. Significant mobility impairment</div><div><br></div><div>Many muscle groups involved at the iliac crest and therefore a pretty debilitating injury</div>	"<img src=""paste-ea3fcd15568f37698f46ef285b243b12d51ce616.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a hip pointer?	POLICE, and NSAIDs until function returns<div>1. in more severe cases, restrict activity and x-ray</div><div>2. Often <b>takes longer</b> to return to play compared to other contusions</div><div>3. <b>PAD </b>the FKING AREA!</div><div>- foam and pad gelling</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are <b>key considerations </b>when assessing the abdomen and the thorax?	1. Injuries here can produce <b>life-threatening </b>situations<div>2. Therefore should focus on signs/symptoms of life-threatening conditions</div><div>- <b>monitor vitals </b>(breathing, circulation, blood pressure, and any indication of internal bleeding or shock)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>assess </b>the abdomen and thorax?	<b>HOPS</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>History:</div><div>MOI injury? Difficulty breathing? Light-headed, or nauseous? Type of pain? Family history of heart injuries?</div><div><br></div><div>Observation:</div><div>How is there breathing, restricted or painful? <b>Symmetry </b>of breathing? <b>Body position</b>? Thorax asymmetry? Abdominal guarding/tightness?</div><div><br></div><div>Palpation:</div><div>Symmetry of chest, <b>ribs</b>, <b>intercostal spaces</b>, <b>tenderness, rigidity</b>, and <b>deformity</b>. Anterior/Posterior (AP) pressure to assess fracture.</div><div><br></div><div>- position of palpation is picture below!</div>	"<img src=""paste-44cbd81af9cb91a678d29dd0230a03f03d640471.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>body position's </b>when assessing the abdomen and thorax would indicate certain injuries?<div><br></div><div>1. Leaning toward side that is injured or splinting area with hand?</div><div><br></div><div>2. Lie on side with knees pulled to chest?</div><div><br></div><div>3. Lying on side holding genitals?</div>	1. Thorax injury<div>2. Abdominal injury</div><div>3. Male external genitalia injury</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>rib contusion</b>?	Blow to the rib cage that bruise ribs or musculature		y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a rib contusion?	1. <b>Painful breathing </b>(particularly if muscles are involved)<div>2. <b>Point tenderness and pain with rib compression</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a rib contusion?	The most important thing here is just <b>time-off</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>POLICE and anti-inflammatory substances.</div><div><br></div><div>Rest and make sure to have protective equipment!</div>	"<img src=""paste-9fd263b4ff229b60980db85455bcbf60bed8f23c.jpg""><div><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>rib fracture</b>?	Direct blow or result of a violent muscular contraction (contracting too hard lol)	Beware of a flail fracture!	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>flail chest</b>?	A rib fracture where 3 or more consecutive ribs are fractured!	"<br><img src=""paste-bd8746dbe8fd22562bfb12e66840dfb360d2b749.jpg""><div><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a rib fracture?	Pain with inspiration!<div><br></div><div><b>Crackling or crepitus with breathing.</b></div>	Point tenderness, and possible deformity with palpation.		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a rib fracture?	1. Remove from play RIGHT AWAY<div>2. Refer to physician for x-ray</div><div>3. Support <b>rest </b>and <b>rib brace</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>costochondral separation</b>?	Direct blow to the <b>anterolateral aspect </b>of the rib cage.	"<img src=""paste-dfcc23f882d53ffd8c133f479d1841b52a75c691.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a costochondral separation?	1. Pain with breathing<div>2. Localized pain in costochondral junctions</div><div>3. Point tenderness and possible deformity</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a costochondral separation?	JUST FKING <b>REST </b>and immobilization.<div><br></div><div>Takes around <b>1-2 months </b>to heal.</div>	"<img src=""paste-dfcc23f882d53ffd8c133f479d1841b52a75c691.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the three different types of&nbsp;<b>lung injuries</b>?	1. Pneumothorax or collapsed lung<div>2. Tension pneomothorax</div><div>3. Hemothorax</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is <b>pneumothorax</b>?	Pleural cavity becomes filled with air causing a <b>lung to collapse</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Can be <i>spontaneous</i>&nbsp;(often more common in young males and tall/lean - genetic predisposition) and will produce pain, difficulty breathing</div>	"Often called collapsed lung<div><img src=""paste-6c7505021cf4a8cfbb31df0baf71cdb6c602671c.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is <b>tension pneumothorax</b>?	A progressive state of pneumothorax.<div><br></div><div>Collapse of lungs still happen but the <b>pressure </b>is more intense.</div><div><br></div><div>Pleural sac on side side fills with air displacing the lung and heart and <b>compressing </b>the opposite lung.</div>	"May cause shortness of breath, chest pain, cyanosis, distention of neck beins, and deviated trachea<div><img src=""paste-50e68e852b8b63d30e436baf59d8c300bcbdb791.jpg""><br></div>"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>hemothorax</b>?	<b>Tearing </b>or <b>puncturing </b>of the lungs or pleural tissue	"Painful breathing, dyspnea, coughing up frothy blood, and signs of shock<div><img src=""paste-8948bc827df83d9e0964a29ae13c9bf59bbc18b9.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a lung injury?	Each of these conditions are medical emergencies and require <b>IMMEDIATE ATTENTION!</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Recognition of altered vitals is essential.</div><div>Transport patient to hospital immediately!</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is a <b>kidney contusion</b>?	Result of external force to rib<div><br><div>Susceptible to injury due to potentially exposed nature</div></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of kidney contusion?<br>	<b>Shock</b>, nausea, vomiting, rigidity of back muscles and <b>hematuria </b>(blood in urine)<div><br></div><div><b>Referred pain </b>(costobertebral angle posteriorly radiating forward around the trunk)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>a kidney contusion?	24-hour observation and gradual increase of fluid intake<div><br></div><div>Surgery required if hemorrhage fails to stop.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Bed rest </b>and close observation after activity resumes.</div>	"Be mindful of kidney referral pattern<div><img src=""paste-3c737e7be7f78a0dcd236f0f5bbe1aeecadc7fbc.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is an <b>injury of the spleen</b>?	Direct blow or infectious <b>mononucleosis </b>(causing an enlarged spleen)	Must be cautious with someone who contracted mono!<div>- higher risk of spleen injury</div>	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an injury to the spleen?	Signs of shock, abdominal rigidity, <b>nausea and wanting to vomit</b>.<div>- can be life threatening due to spleen's ability to <b>splint itself --&gt; </b>therefore symptoms may be <b>DELAYED which is BAD</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Kehr's Sign</b>: acute referred pain to the <b>left shoulder </b>when in the position below.</div>	"Kehr's Sign<div><img src=""paste-1f03eddbc511cc053395fc337a8d3e715bee1df2.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is an ability that the <b>spleen </b>has that is life-threatening if an injury happened to it?	It's ability to splint itself is life-threatening!<div><br></div><div>This is because S/S will be delayed and therefore you might be too late to manage it!</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What is the <b>Kehr's Sign</b>?	It is a sign to detect an injury to the spleen.<div>Basically get the person to get in the position below. A person with an injury to the spleen will have referral pain to the left shoulder.</div>	"<img src=""paste-1f03eddbc511cc053395fc337a8d3e715bee1df2.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
How would you <b>manage </b>an injury to the spleen?	Conservative treatment involved <b>1 week </b>of hospitalization and gradual return to activity<div>- even if it doesn't seem that bad, because the spleen has an ability to splint itself so be careful</div><div><br></div><div><b>Close monitoring </b>in cases of Mono</div><div>- regular visits to doctor</div><div>- Ultrasound to confirm size of spleen before RTP (to see if spleen return to normal size)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Hip_and_Abdomen
What are the <b>key considerations </b>for assessing the glenohumeral joint?	1. Extremely complicated region of the body<div>2. High degree of mobility but lower stability</div><div>3. Involved in a variety of overhead activities related to sports and is susceptible to a number of repetitive and overused type of inuries</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
Why does the glenohumeral joint have a <b>great degree of mobility and limited stability</b>?	1. Round humeral head articulates with <b>flat glenoid </b>- nothing to hold head of the humerus in place			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What allows the glenohumeral joint to increase stability?	1. Rotator cuff and long head of the biceps provide dynamic stability<div>2. Glenoid labrum <b>deepens </b>the socket to increase stability</div>	Note that the shoulder has high mobility and limited stability.		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
The shoulder has a great degree of&nbsp;{{c1::mobility}} but has limited degree of&nbsp;{{c1::stability}}.		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is&nbsp;<b>critical&nbsp;</b>to functional movement of the shoulder?	The relationship between scapula stabilizing muscles and the glenohumeral joint!	Scapulohumeral rythym		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is <b>scapulohumeral rhythym</b>?	It is the movement of the scapula relative to the humerus.<div><br></div><div><b>Initial 30 degrees </b>of glenohumeral abduction <b>does not incorporate scapular motion</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>After the initial 30 degrees of abduction, there is a <b>2:1 ratio </b>between glenohumeral and scapulothoracic joint motion.</div><div><br></div><div>So basically, as the humerus moves 30 degrees, scapula won't move, but as it moves another 30 degrees the scapula will move <b>15 degrees </b>as a 2:1 RATIO!!</div><div><br></div><div>Scapula only moves when we proceed beyond 30 degrees of the humerus abduction.</div>	"<img src=""paste-05d4157d669c60a455500e98a7294c427174f3a6.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would we <b>reduce </b>the number of shoulder injuries?	1. Proper physical conditioning<div>2. Activity specific strengthening</div><div>- strengthen through a full ROM and bilaterally!</div><div>3. Prepatory movements should be used before explosive/ballistic movements are attempted</div><div>- basically <b>warm-up</b>!</div><div>4. <b>Instruction on how to fall</b>: breakfalling</div><div>5. Protective equipment</div><div>6. Biomechanics of sport: know the proper movements in a sport (talk to the coaches)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you assess the shoulder complex?	HOPS<div><br></div><div><b>History</b>:&nbsp;</div><div>Focus on numbness, altered sensation, or change in temperature of limb. Location/cause of pain, and previous injury.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Observation</b>:&nbsp;</div><div>Position/shape of clavicle, any assymetries, <b>scapulohumeral rhythm</b>. <b>Posture </b>(kyphosis/lordosis)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Palpation</b>: --&gt; a bunch of shit</div><div><br></div><div><b>Special Tests</b>:</div><div>Active and passive ROM</div><div>Resisted ROM</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are <b>clavicular fractures</b>?	Fall on the outstretched arm (FOOSH) - <b>most common</b> mechanism.<div><br></div><div><b>Fall on the tip of shoulder</b>&nbsp;</div><div>Direct impact.</div>	"Fairly common shoulder injury.<div>Occurs primarily in the middle third clavicle.&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-da8a19f8ec59169b2f24018798592fe05fb3c8bb.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a clavicular fracture?	1. Supporting arm on injured side in a position of comfort<div>- sling in this position<br><div>2. Clavicle <b>is lower</b></div><div>3. Palpation has pain, initial effusion, and possible deformity.</div></div>	"<img src=""paste-da8a19f8ec59169b2f24018798592fe05fb3c8bb.jpg""><div>The rugby player is the most at risk here for a clavicular fracture</div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a clavicular fracture?	<b>Closed Fracture</b>:&nbsp;<div>Acute management: <b>sling, swath, refer</b></div><div><br></div><div>Immobilization for <b>2-8 weeks </b>depending on location and severity of fracture.</div><div><br></div><div>Early therapy and ROM is beneficial but <b>must </b>respect tissue healing guidelines</div><div><br></div><div>May require <b>surgical management </b>increasing secondary complications.</div><div>- length of rehab is longer in surgeries&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""paste-ec7124b1aa8b727632059afb45cee2dfc4f5b82b.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-4e6c55908d7c1dce341873246b5e126fed5f67bf.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is an <b>AC Sprain</b>?	Acromioclavicular sprain...<div><br></div><div>Result of a direct blow (FOOSH type) from any direction</div>	If the clavicle doesn't strain (landing in a FOOSH type mechanism) then most likely this occurs.		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an AC sprain?	Grade 1: Point tenderness and pain with movement but <b>no disruption </b>of AC joint<div>- still has quite a bit of pain compared to other grade 1 sprains<br><div><br></div><div>Grade 2: <b>Tear or rupture </b>of AC ligament with <b>partial displacement </b>of <b>lateral end </b>of clavicle. <b>Decreased ROM!</b></div><div><b>- </b>forward flexion (past 90 degrees) and arm adduction will cause <b>significant pain </b>(also with a grade 3)</div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Grade 3: <b>Rupture</b> of AC and CC ligaments</div></div><div>- <b>piano key </b>sign --&gt; step deformity</div>	"6 different sprains of AC grade but we are gonna be sticking with the 3 grading system<div><img src=""paste-0f46a50a7414689fe3be4f848710db4031f4855d.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What movements cause pain in a grade 2 or 3 AC sprain?	Forward flexion (above 90 degrees) and adduction of the shoulder will cause pain!	"<img src=""paste-0f46a50a7414689fe3be4f848710db4031f4855d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
"What is the <b>""Piano Key"" Sign</b>?"	A large deformity of the AC joint.<div><br></div><div>It is called a piano key sign because if you press on it, it will bounce back up like a piano key!</div>	"<img src=""paste-260282e00cdbbe4db169790c6e5fd493b9d76ce4.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>an AC sprain?	<div><b>Early Rehab:</b></div>Ice, stabilization, and referral to physician.<div><br></div><div>Sling for <b>5-7 days </b>or until able to support arm without pain.</div><div><br></div><div>Slowly reduce use of sling and increase use of arm in all ROM and it is <b>very important to include therapy at this stage</b>!</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Later Rehab</b>:&nbsp;</div><div><b>Aggressive rehab </b>with all grades.</div><div>- progress as quickly as patient is able to</div><div>- padding and protection may be required for RTP</div>	"Therapy important because poorly managed by family physician.<div><img src=""paste-21b607c18650b291e7ae796ec7b55711a2be11ae.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>sternoclavicular sprain</b>?	An indirect force or a blunt trauma to the sternoclavicular joint.	Commonly known as SC joint.<div>A much more stable structure (because closer to the midline and doesn't not get exposed to the same forces that an AC joint will have)</div>	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a sternoclavicular sprain?	<b>Grade 1</b>: Pain/slight disability<div><br></div><div><b>Grade 2</b>: pain, subluxation with deformity, swelling, point tenderness, and decreased ROM.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Grade 3</b>: Gross deformity (dislocation), pain, swelling, and decreased ROM</div><div>- possibly <b>life-threatening </b>if dislocation occurs <b>posteriorly</b>.</div>	"A lot less damaging (at each grade) compared to an AC sprain.<div><img src=""paste-ba86781043fed178aa554c1e08bacd436a52fa4c.jpg""><br></div><div>This is what a grade 3 will look like.</div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a sternoclavicular sprain?	POLICE and reduction if necessary<div><br></div><div>Immobilize for <b>3-5 weeks </b>followed by graded reconditioning.</div>	"<img src=""paste-ba86781043fed178aa554c1e08bacd436a52fa4c.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>glenohumeral joint sprain</b>?	"Forced <b>abduction </b>and/or external rotation or a direct blow usually P-A.<div><br></div><div>""Overstretch"" injury primarily to the capsule</div>"		y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a glenohumeral joint sprain?	Pain during movement (especially when recreating MOI)<div><br></div><div>Decreased ROM and pain with palpation.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a glenohumeral joint sprain?	RICE for 24-48 hours; sling if needed<div><br></div><div>When full ROM without pain then resistance training can be initiated.</div>	Usually not debilitating<div>- precursor to subluxation/dislocation</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
