What is an <b>acute glenohumeral subluxations and dislocations</b>?	<b>Subluxation</b>: partial dislocation of the shoulder<div><br></div><div><b>Anterior Dislocation</b>: Forced <b>abduction </b>and <b>external rotation </b>(putting our arm in a throwing arm movement --&gt; anterior-inferior distraction)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Posterior Dislocation</b>:</div><div>- less common then anterior</div><div>- forced <b>adduction </b>and <b>internal rotation</b>&nbsp;(falling on an extended and internally rotated shoulder --&gt; putting your hand on the small of your back will put you in this position)</div><div>- another MOI is an <b>extended</b> and <b>internally</b> rotated shoulder!</div>	"<div><br></div><img src=""paste-99eb58638d02f391710a1be548dcd8df1080f0a5.jpg""><img src=""paste-3aa6fa5aef783b1948a2f41b75b27d964c27692a.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a shoulder dislocation?	<b>Anterior-Inferior dislocation</b>:&nbsp;<div>- flattened deltoid, prominent humeral head in axilla&nbsp;</div><div>- arm carried in slight abduction and external rotation</div><div><br></div><div><b>Posterior Dislocation</b>:</div><div>- prominent acromion and coracoid process</div><div>- arm in adduction and internal rotation</div>	"<img src=""paste-99eb58638d02f391710a1be548dcd8df1080f0a5.jpg""><div>Posterior</div><div><img src=""paste-f568aace2d285bac16fa0a1d89ef3c622ecae603.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a shoulder dislocation?	POLICE and reduction by a physician.<div><br></div><div>Immobilize following reduction for ~<b>3 weeks.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Perform <b>isometric exercises </b>while in a sling.</div><div><br></div><div>Progress as pain and ROM allows (PRE).</div>	PRE: progressive resistance exercise.<div>Remember that the measures and evaluations will be drastically different in different sports and positions.</div>		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are some <b>common complications </b>for GH dislocations? (7)	1. Bankart Lesion<div>2. Hill-Sachs Lesion</div><div>3. SLAP Lesion</div><div>4. Brachial nerves and vessels may be compromised</div><div>5. Rotator cuff injuries</div><div>6. Fractures</div><div>7. Bicipital tendon subluxation and transverse ligament rupture</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>bankart lesion</b>?	An anterior defect of labrum of the shoulder&nbsp;	"<div>GH dislocation complication</div><img src=""paste-927947bc323c914a8ac0b222a627dc82e1605932.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>Hill-Sachs Lesion</b>?	Compression of bone against anterior glenoid rim creating <b>divot </b>in the humeral head<div><br></div>	"<div>GH dislocation complication</div><img src=""paste-d755849480f8a99b12f62a7180c19ac1454ec885.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>SLAP </b>lesion?	Damage to <b>S</b>uperior <b>L</b>abrum from <b>A</b>nterior to <b>P</b>osterior.<div><br></div><div>Labrum pulled away from anterior to posterior.</div><div><br></div><div>Biceps tendon insertion is pulled away from labrum creating that tearing.</div>	"<img src=""paste-eb59cf3f937a546a3d97f922dac870496c534f97.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is <b>chronic GH instability</b>?	When you have dislocated the shoulder before, now there is a significant static stability lost and mobility decreases resulting in damage to other soft tissue structures.<div><br></div><div>The notion that once you dislocate, it will never be good again.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a chronic GH instability?	1. Ongoing impingement of both tendons and neurovascular<div>2. Ongoing feelings of <b>instability</b></div><div>3. Loss of strength in certain end ranges</div>	This is when the shoulder is <b>unstable!</b>		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a chronic GH instability?	<b>Strengthening </b>of rotator cuffs and scapula stabilizers (make sure that the athlete has as much strength to support the movements that occur)<div><br></div><div><b>Harnesses </b>and <b>restraints </b>could be a thing (bracing and taping).</div><div><br></div><div>At the end of the day though, the athlete will likely need some sort of <b>surgical stabilization </b>to return to high level play.</div><div>- strengthening should be continued before surgery is opted</div><div>- Post-surgical shoulders will often still dislocate given the right circumstances!</div>	"<div>The problem with this bracing is that it is very limiting! Depending on the sport, this bracing may not be viable.</div><img src=""paste-3bd1b49cf9c2ee7845af1b0f7edb626167e55732.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>Shoulder Impingement</b>?	<b>Mechanical compression </b>of structures within the glenohumeral joint...<div><b>More common structures:</b></div><div>1. Supraspinatus tendon</div><div>2. Subacromial bursa</div><div>3. Long head of biceps tendon</div><div><br></div><div>More common in overhead repetitive activities (overhead press!)</div><div><br></div><div>Often a results of poor <b>mechanics </b>or <b>postural faults</b>.</div><div><br></div>	Can be a stand-alone injury without history of shoulder dislocation but often occurs with previous history of dislocations		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a shoulder impingement?	<b>Usually something minor </b>but slowly progresses to sharp debilitating pain.<div><br></div><div>Often described as <b>deep </b>or <b>inside </b>the GH joint</div><div>- not able to be touched!</div>	"<img src=""paste-fd92653830da3b934442e3ba3bd0a5ae56b53e00.jpg""><div>This is impingement underneath the acromion</div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a shoulder impingement?	<b>Address mechanics</b>&nbsp;(however it is not always correctable --&gt; certain sports will still bring on shoulder impingement)<div><br></div><div>Therefore we must do all that we can to <b>reduce </b>the restrictions around GH joint through <b>manual therapy</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>Focus on strengthening <b>rotator cuff </b>muscles to improve alignment of humeral head and glenoid cavity!</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is <b>shoulder bursitis</b>?	Occurs alongside shoulder impingement.<div><br></div><div><b>Subacromial bursa </b>most commonly affected.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><b>Fibrosis </b>may lead to constant inflmmation and reduction of subacrimal space</div><div><br></div><div>Basically inflammation of bursa on the shoulder.</div>	May increase the likelihood of shoulder impingement		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of shoulder bursitis?	Pain with movements overhead<div><br></div><div>Positive impingement tests!</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>shoulder bursitis?	NSAIDs to reduce inflammation.<div><br></div><div>Address the mechanics!</div><div><br></div><div>Address muscle restrictions - any tightness that elicits muscle posture</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
When talking about shoulder bursitis, what are the two bursa's that can be inflamed, and which one is the more common one?	1. Subacromial bursa<div>2. Subcoracoid bursa</div><div><br></div><div>The subacromial bursa is the more common one to be inflamed.</div>	"<img src=""paste-4101f3e0cf57d3f9c41d067268ede3e135f5223f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>humerus fracture</b>?	Proximal fractures occur due to a direct blow, a dislocation, or a fall on outstretched arm (or torsion) --&gt; or a FOOSH type injury<div><br></div><div>May be <b>life-threatening </b>because danger to nerves</div><div><br></div><div>Epiphyseal fractures are more common in youth caused by axial loading forces</div>	"<img src=""paste-c058e2d24ea280caf09b497f17001808e98c2295.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
Why is a <b>humerus fracture </b>life-threatening?	Because it poses danger to nerve and bloody supply!	"<img src=""paste-20686aecdec2c4e5a3f743428ea436bc6fa0c06b.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a humerus fracture?	Pain, swelling, point, tenderness, <b>obvious deformity</b>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a humerus fracture	Immediate application of <b>splint, treat for shock!</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Location and severity of bone will dictate RTP timeline.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are <b>key considerations </b>when assessing the elbow?	1. Complex joint with flexion, extension, pronation, and supination<div>- 145 degrees of flexion and 90 degrees of supination and pronation</div><div><br></div><div>2. Has a <b>bony limitation </b>(limit to ROM) and high amounts of support because multiple muscles cross this</div><div><br></div><div>3. <b>Carrying angle </b>(similar to Q-angle)</div><div>- normal females = 10-15 degrees, males 5-10 degrees</div><div><br></div><div>4. Critical link in kinetic chain of upper extremity</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
For the elbow, what are the degrees of <b>flexion</b>, and <b>pronation and supination</b>?	145 degrees of flexion and 90 degrees of supination and pronation.			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is the <b>carrying angle </b>of the elbow?<div><br></div><div>What is the normal degrees?</div>	The carrying angle is similar to the <b>q-angle </b>of the hip joint but just for the elbow.<div><br></div><div>Males: <b>10-15 degrees</b></div><div>Females: <b>5-10 degrees</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>prevent </b>elbow injuries?	Stressing the notion of mechanics type thing.<div><br></div><div>Throwing or hitting counts (basically number of throws you have done), age and skill specific equipment and routine stretching.</div>	Baseball has really paved the way for this!		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>assess </b>the elbow?	HOPS<div><br></div><div>History: basic shit</div><div><br></div><div>Observations:</div><div><b>Carrying angle</b>, and <b>cubitus recurvatus</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Palpation:</div><div>A bunch of shit</div>	"<img src=""paste-78be329e24204ff2f63e221d79858502d859fc05.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-3849fbffc24f11e09807399543bea570a8aa9770.jpg""><br></div><div>Cubitus recurvatus: amount of hyperextension available</div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is <b>cubitus recurvatus</b>?	The amount of hyperextension involved.<div><br></div><div>Typically what you want to observe when assessing the elbow.</div>	"<img src=""paste-3849fbffc24f11e09807399543bea570a8aa9770.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is an <b>olecranon bursitis</b>?	Inflammation to the bursa to the olecranon on the elbow.<div><br></div><div>Since it is superficial location, it is really susceptible to acute injury.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an olecranon bursitis?	Swelling will appear almost <b>spontaneously </b>and without usual pain and heat.<div>- heat will present if acute swelling is not managed initially.</div>	"<img src=""paste-b44fbb3f5e30c3e3f53b7ad3e551e3de8395cbac.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>an olecranon bursitis?	1. <b>Immediate compression</b>&nbsp;(and ice if not too painful) and elevation to reduce effusion<div>2. If swelling fails to resolve, aspiration may be necessary</div><div>3. <b>Padding </b>in order to return to play</div>	"<img src=""paste-cf8c74f712602bd86b1835e13cb0e0a02d7a35bf.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is an <b>ulnar collateral ligament sprain</b>? (UCL sprain)	<b>Valgus force </b>either acutely or from repetitive trauma&nbsp; as a person lands in a FOOSH position on the elbow.<div><br></div><div>Can also be accompanied by ulnar nerve injury and/or wrist flexor strain.</div>	"<img src=""paste-61a617f199372935d76afe903f8c96f73d629a73.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a UCL sprain?	Pain on <b>medial aspect </b>of elbow.<div><br></div><div>Possible paresthesia, positive <b>Tinel's sign.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Pain </b>with <b>valgus stress test </b>at 20 degrees.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is <b>Tinel's sign</b>?	A test of the integrity of the UCL.<div><br></div><div>You are just tapping over the ulnar nerve.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>A positive sign will be numbness/pain when tapping the ulnar nerve.</div>	Elbow		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a UCL sprain?	1. Immobilzation&nbsp;<div>2. Conventional strengthening and assessment of biomechanics (in chronic cases)</div><div><br></div><div>3. Surgical intervention may be necessary --&gt; <b>Tommy John Procedure</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is the <b>Tommy John Procedure</b>?	A surgical intervention to the UCL (elbow).<div><br></div><div>Reconstruction of UCL using palmaris longus autograft.</div><div><br></div><div>Full recovery takes 18-24 months.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is <b>Lateral epicondylitis</b>?	Commonly known as <b>tennis elbow</b>.<div><br></div><div>Common with repetitive backhand type movements.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Microtrauma to extensor muscles of the elbow.</div>	"<img src=""paste-90d6afca432f65e4abc22f644826f3a1ab1deaa7.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of lateral epicondylitis?	Aching pain after activity.<div><br></div><div>Wrist extension strength diminishes.</div><div><br></div><div>Loss of elbow ROM if left untreated.</div>	"<img src=""paste-90d6afca432f65e4abc22f644826f3a1ab1deaa7.jpg""><div><b>Tennis elbow!</b></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a lateral epicondylitis?	1. POLICE and NSAIDs<div>2. Deep tissue massage at CET and soft tissue treatment of wrist extensors.</div><div><br></div><div>3. <b>Compression sleeve</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>4. Adjusting biomechanics strengthening to avoid recurrence</div>	"<img src=""paste-90d6afca432f65e4abc22f644826f3a1ab1deaa7.jpg""><div><b>Tennis elbow!</b></div><div><img src=""paste-105e18ecfbb842ce3e9e8135ddb3e6e5b09455e9.jpg""><b><br></b></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is a <b>medial epicondylitis</b>?	Commonly known as <b>golfer's elbow</b>.<div><br></div><div>High amounts of valgus force and <b>flexion force </b>happening at the elbow.</div><div>- wrist flexors and pronator teres</div><div><br></div><div>May include <b>ulnar nerve neuropathy</b>.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of medial epicondylitis?	Pain with forceful wrist flexion, elbow extension, or elbow supination.<div><br></div><div>Tenderness at CFT and medial epicondyle.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>a medial epicondylitis?	POLICE and NSAIDs.<div><br></div><div>Severe cases may require <b>splints.</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><b>Strength </b>is the key to reducing the likelihood of this injury occuring.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What is an <b>elbow dislocation</b>?	Caused by FOOSH injury with elbow <b>extended </b>or severe twist of forewarm with elbow at <b>or</b> near 90 degrees flexion (twisting or shearing alongside the 90 degrees).<div><br></div><div>Bones can be displaced backward, forward, or laterally (any of these directions are possible)</div><div>- posterior (backward) is the more common --&gt; hyperextension type shit.</div><div><br></div><div>More easily distinguished because of the <b>alignment of the bone</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>You can tell the difference between a humeral fracture vs an elbow dislocation because the <b>medial and lateral epicondyles </b>are still aligned with shaft of humerus.</div><div>- humeral fracture will not be in alignment --&gt; references condyles might tell difference.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an elbow dislocation?	<b>Obvious deformity </b>and inability/unwillingness to move shoulder/elbow/wrist/hand.<div><br></div><div>Potential complications with median and radial nerves and blood vessels (limb-threatening injury --&gt; not life threatening but still emergency)</div><div>- therefore must check vitals&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""paste-9ddb769ff79340aae3423b24c8403bb8d05d34c9.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>manage </b>an elbow dislocation?	Stabilize, and transport via EMS if necessary.<div><br></div><div>Physician should <b>reduce </b>immediately.</div><div><br></div><div>Immobilization following reduction in flexion <b>3+ </b>weeks followed by extensive rehab!</div>	"<img src=""paste-9ddb769ff79340aae3423b24c8403bb8d05d34c9.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Shoulder_and_Upper_Arm
How would you <b>assess </b>the forearm?	HOPS<div><br></div><div>History:</div><div>Cause, symptoms, swelling, discoloration</div><div><br></div><div>Observation:</div><div>Deformities, ROM, pain with motion, swelling, etc.</div><div><br></div><div>Palpation: A bunch of shit</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are <b>forearm fractures</b>?	Common due to <b>falls </b>(FOOSH) and <b>direct blows</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>May include both radius and uln</div><div>- MOI will give insight to involvement of one or both.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of forearm fractures?	Audible <b>pop or crack</b>&nbsp;followed by moderate to severe pain.<div><br></div><div>Edema and ecchymosis with possible crepitus</div><div>- ecchymosis is delayed (bruising) will be seen after.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a forearm fracture?	POLICE followed by splinting until definitive care is available.<div><br></div><div>Long-term splinting followed by rehabilitation plan.</div>	"<img src=""paste-c332fc1a07abc30f38caf232516a8ddba509c55f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>colle's fracture</b>?	A fracture in the lower end of radius or ulna.<div><br></div><div><b>FOOSH </b>forcing radius and ulna into <b>hyperextension </b>via wrist extension!</div><div><br></div><div>Less common is the <b>reverse Colles' freacture </b>(Smith fracture)</div><div>- anterior displacement of distal fragment</div>	"<img src=""paste-bfb8fb010b3d5936e17c89181cb7d02fcc7bc697.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is the <b>smith fracture</b>?	The reverse Colle's fracture.<div><br></div><div>Anterior displacement of distal fragment of radius and ulna.</div>	"<img src=""paste-c5a39a897c132ae4837a8fc5614bd9fe7d8ba522.jpg"">"	y	KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a Colle's fracture?	Often a visible <b>dinner fork deformity</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Can be misdiagnosed as bad sprain when no deformity present.</div><div><br></div><div>Tendons may be torn/alvulsed, and there may be median nerve damage</div>	"<img src=""paste-b6ca481df8c9e0cebfff895e45360a7ccd4f2c5b.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a colle's fracture?	Cold compress, splint wrist, and refer to physician.<div><br></div><div>X-ray cuz its a fracture (immobilize)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Severe sprains should be treated as fractures</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>In children, injury may cause lower epiphyseal separation</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the 3 major nerves of the wrist and hand?	1. Ulnar<div>2. Median</div><div>3. Radial</div>	"<img src=""paste-d2915985c6f4ab8183ef96ffe9f451713c0db420.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you assess the wrist and hand?	HOPS<div><br></div><div>History:</div><div>Past history and shit</div><div><br></div><div>Observation:</div><div><b>Thumb to finger touching </b>and <b>color of nailbeds/cap refill</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Palpation:</div><div><b>Anatomical Snuffbox</b>&nbsp;and shit</div><div><br></div><div>Special Tests:</div><div><b>Tinel's Sign</b></div><div>- tap over the median nerve</div><div><b>Phalen's Test</b></div><div><b>Temperature Check</b></div><div><b>Capillary refill test</b></div><div><b>Sensation/motor test</b></div><div><b>Functional evaluation</b></div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you perform the <b>Tinel's </b>sign to assess the wrist and hand?	Tap over the <b>median nerve</b>. Test for numbess and sting			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is <b>Phalen's Test</b>?	It test for carpal tunnel syndrome.<div><br></div><div>Put back of hands together for one minute and check for pain.</div>	"<img src=""paste-f222619be4a86b1ab52f36de4173a3a98d74d3c9.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>wrist sprain</b>?	Any <b>forced movements </b>of the wrist and often unexpected or uncontrollable.<div><br></div><div>Many ligaments and therefore injury to multiple ligaments</div>	"<img src=""paste-07f4ff9bfc9d3337c6b0549d74f0df94f2bef304.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a wrist sprain?	Pain, swelling, difficulty. with movement	"<img src=""paste-07f4ff9bfc9d3337c6b0549d74f0df94f2bef304.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a wrist sprain?	Refer to physician with x-ray if <b>severe.</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>POLICE, splint, analgesics.</div><div><br></div><div>Active rehab as soon as symptoms allow</div><div>--&gt; tape for support can benefit healing and prevent further injury</div>	"<img src=""paste-07f4ff9bfc9d3337c6b0549d74f0df94f2bef304.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>Triangular fibrocartilage complex injury </b>(TFCC)?	Occurs at the <b>ulnar side </b>of the wrist --&gt; a little meniscus point between distal end of ulna and carpal.<div><br></div><div><b>Violet twist </b>or <b>torque </b>of the wrist.</div><div>Often associated with sprain of UCL.</div>	"<img src=""paste-4b2d26c4b26439f66966f814f3b02527802415ef.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a TFCC injury?	Pain along <b>ulnar side </b>of wrist, possible <b>clinking</b>, pain with <b>ulnar deviation</b>.<div><br></div><div>Swelling is possible and may not be much initially.</div><div><br></div><div>Patient may not report injury immediately.&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""paste-4b2d26c4b26439f66966f814f3b02527802415ef.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a TFCC injury?	Refer to physician immediately.<div><br></div><div>Conservative treatment initially --&gt; immobilize ~ 4 weeks.</div><div>- surgery if conservative treatment fails</div><div><br></div><div><b>Prevent painful loading or ROM</b></div><div><b>Tape can be very effective in managing symptoms</b>.</div>	"Very important athlete knows what movements cause them symptoms.<div><img src=""paste-dee214f0f5e6f1c92c9cf5420b6d479e661422aa.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is <b>carpal tunnel syndrome</b>?	<b>Compression </b>of median nerve due to inflammation of tendons and sheaths of carpal tunnel.<div><br></div><div>Result of <b>repeated </b>wrist flexion or direct trauma to <b>anterior aspect of wrist</b></div>	"Some form of irritation or compression of the carpal tunnel causing compression of the median nerve<div><img src=""paste-a17e39b57680859bb8a6e65b6ebc3518de17a5a1.jpg""><br></div>"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of carpal tunnel?	Sensory and motor deficits<div>- tingling, numbing, and paresthesia</div>	"<img src=""paste-a17e39b57680859bb8a6e65b6ebc3518de17a5a1.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>carpal tunnel?	Conservative treatment with rest, immobilization, NSAIDs<div><br></div><div>Focus on <b>healthy forearms</b></div><div>- if symptoms persist, <b>corticosteroid injection </b>may be necessary or <b>surgical decompression </b>of transverse carpal ligament</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is <b>deQuervain's Syndrome</b>?	Also known as the <b>Hoffman's Disease</b>.<div><br></div><div><b>Tenosynovitis </b>in thumb --&gt; extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.</div><div><br></div><div>Repetitive wrist movements in ulnar deviation or repetitive high <b>gripping </b>(barbell training)</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of deQuervain's Syndrome?	Aching pain which may radiate into hand or forearm.<div><br></div><div>Positive <b>Finkelsteins's test</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>Point tenderness and weakness</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is the <b>Finkelstein's test</b>?	Grabbing the thumb with your wrist and then going into ulnar deviation. See if you have pain in the radial region.<div><br></div><div>Positive sign is pain along EPB/APL!!</div>	"<img src=""paste-647377d4731b15a6fcbdd66b0ed114bf3fee1a20.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you manage <b>deQuervain's </b>syndrome?	Immobilization, rest, cryotherapy, and NSAIDs.<div><br></div><div>Manual therapy at the site of pain to reduce excessive fibrosis.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>dislocation/subluxation of lunate bone</b>?	Forceful <b>hyperextension </b>or fall on outstretch hand causing subluxation/dislocation of that lunate bone.	"<img src=""paste-d7897754b296bb0de5c6b4bf051b19e3299e4598.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S</b>&nbsp;of&nbsp;dislocation/subluxation of lunate bone?	Pain, swelling, and difficulty executing wrist flexion	"<img src=""paste-d7897754b296bb0de5c6b4bf051b19e3299e4598.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a dislocation/subluxation of lunate bone?	Treat acutely refer to physician for reduction if needed.<div><br></div><div>Can lead to <b>hypermobile lunate </b>or <b>unstable scapho-lunate complex </b>but can still be clinically fixed.</div><div><br></div><div>Perhaps taping it to make it more stable in the carpal area.</div>	"<img src=""paste-d7897754b296bb0de5c6b4bf051b19e3299e4598.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>scaphoid fracture</b>?	FOOSH type injury..<div><br></div><div>Outstretched hand, compressing scaphoid between radius and second row of carpal bones.</div><div><br></div><div>Often <b>fails to heal </b>due to <b>poor blood supply </b>(avascular necrosis)</div>	"<img src=""paste-e197f99bf965d7714800bd658b31f3351044712d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a scaphoid fracture?	Swelling/severe pain in the <b>anatomical snuff box</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Presents like wrist sprain</div><div>- pain with radial flexion</div>	"<img src=""paste-e197f99bf965d7714800bd658b31f3351044712d.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a scaphoid fracture?	Must be splinted and referred for x-ray.<div><br></div><div>Immobilize for ~<b>6 weeks</b>.</div><div><br></div><div>Regular x-ray checkups to monitor healing.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Wrist protection required </b>for at least 3 additional months.</div><div><br></div><div>Quite often this is a surgical management because the scaphoid becomes necrotic and unstable!</div>	"<img src=""paste-686c928bb2f9efff45458bc5bd7d7bd4796fbf2a.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>wrist ganglion injury</b>?	<b>Synovial cyst </b>(herniation of joint capsule or synovial sheath of tendon)<div><br></div><div>Generally appears following wrist strain</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a wrist ganglion?	Commonly appears on the back of the wrist (random small bumb may appear)<div><br></div><div>Often asymptomatic.</div><div><br></div><div>May feel soft, rubbery or very had --&gt; like a marble under the skin</div>	"<img src=""paste-8c51c396c669615083c592b5f413b77f636520bb.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a wrist ganglion?	Old method was to first to beat the shit out of and burst the cyst and then apply pressure pad --&gt; problem was the cyst would return.<div><br></div><div>Current practices include aspiration and chemical cauterization with subsequent pressure from pad.</div><div>- Cortisone injuecion also a common option</div><div><br></div><div>Not problematic or debilitating but just may be annoying.</div>	"<img src=""paste-8c51c396c669615083c592b5f413b77f636520bb.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is the difference between the&nbsp;<b>focused </b>vs <b>diffuse </b>mode of thinking?<div><br></div><div>How do these modes relate to learning?</div>	Focused mode thinking refers to actively thinking of something. Thought signal moves into familiar patterns that are usually set and consolidated already for us. A lot of different ideas jumble together making thinking space smaller in return.<div><br></div><div>However, how about problems that we haven't thought about yet? <b>(something new)</b></div><div>- your mind won't be able to get to the thought pattern because you don't even know what it is! Thoughts are too tightly packed!</div><div><br></div><div>This is where the <b>diffuse mode </b>of thinking comes in. It allows us to think in a more broad scale and have a general feel of solutions to problems. Afterwards, we could use focused mode to hone in on the solution.</div><div><br></div><div>This is why the best way to learn a hard problem is to first actively try to think of a solution, but then take a break and allow your subconscious to figure it out and then come back.</div>	"<div>Note that it seems that you can't be in both modes at the same time. Being in one mode would limit the access of the other.&nbsp;</div><img src=""paste-74b89f3c556a2acc347e91174b4930238d17226b.jpg"">"		Coursera::Learning_How_to_Learn
What type of thinking mode do you need to be in when you are trying to understand something new?	The diffuse mode of thinking.			Coursera::Learning_How_to_Learn
What is an <b>extensor tendon avulsion</b>?	Commonly called <b>mallet finger</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Blow to tip of finger avulsing extensor tendon from insertion.</div>	"<img src=""paste-fef0a9163f97dffe0aff9c9d2a26d52a3798948f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of an extensor tendon avulsion.	Pain at <b>DIP</b>&nbsp;joint<div>- not able to extend distal phalanx</div><div><br></div><div>Carrying at <b>30 degree </b>angle</div>	"<img src=""paste-fef0a9163f97dffe0aff9c9d2a26d52a3798948f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>an extensor tendon avulsion?	POLICE for 6-8 weeks!	"<img src=""paste-fef0a9163f97dffe0aff9c9d2a26d52a3798948f.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>Boutonniere deformity</b>?	Rupture of <b>extensor expansion </b>doral to the middle phalanx.<div><br></div><div>Tendon slides below axis of PIP joint, forces DIP joint into extension and PIP into flexion.</div>	"<img src=""paste-fede90ace1cd487790bdfb6539628f5946ab7ab5.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is the <b>S/S </b>of a Boutonniere Deformity?	Pain and obvious deformity --&gt; inability to extend DIP joint (refer to pic)<div><br></div><div>Swelling and tenderness</div>	"<img src=""paste-fede90ace1cd487790bdfb6539628f5946ab7ab5.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a Boutonniere deformity?	Cold application with proper splinting.<div><br></div><div>Splinting must continue for 5-8 weeks.</div><div><br></div><div>Athlete is encouraged to flex distal phalanx.</div>	"<img src=""paste-fede90ace1cd487790bdfb6539628f5946ab7ab5.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>Flexor Digitorum Profundus Rupture</b>?	Also known as <b>jersey finger</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>Rupture of digitorum profundus tendon from insertion on distal phalanx.</div><div><br></div><div>Often occurs with ring finger when athlete tries to grab a jersey.</div>	"<img src=""paste-bc0a8a352291cfa1dddae9b3dc227b4bc0ea5dc5.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are <b>S/S </b>of a Jersey finger?	DIP <b>cannot be flexed </b>finger remains extended<div><br></div><div>When you ask athlete to make a fist, the finger cant fully flex (look at pic).</div><div>Pain and point tenderness over distal phalanx</div>	"<img src=""paste-bc0a8a352291cfa1dddae9b3dc227b4bc0ea5dc5.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a Jersey finger?	<b>Must be surgically repaired</b>.<div><br></div><div>Extensive rehab requred, often unable to return to full function however doesn't impact performance too much</div>	"<img src=""paste-bc0a8a352291cfa1dddae9b3dc227b4bc0ea5dc5.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>Gamekeeper's Thumb</b>?	<b>Sprain </b>of ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of MCP joint of the thumb.<div><br></div><div>Forcevul <b>abduction </b>of proximal phalanx occasionally combined with hyperextension.</div>	"<img src=""paste-0064659ed11d92298c09918ee8c5f3ca6b1fd404.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of a Gamekeeper's Thumb?	Pain over UCL in addition to weak and <b>painful pinch</b>.	"<img src=""paste-0064659ed11d92298c09918ee8c5f3ca6b1fd404.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a Gamekeeper's Thumb?	If<b> instable</b>, should be referred to orthopedis.<div><br></div><div>If <b>stable</b>, x-ray should be performed to rule out fracture.</div><div><br></div><div>Thumb splint for at least 3 weeks or until pain free.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Thumb spica </b>should be used following splinting for support.</div>	"<img src=""paste-0064659ed11d92298c09918ee8c5f3ca6b1fd404.jpg"">"		KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What is a <b>dislocation of the phalange</b>?	PIP <b>Dorsal </b>dislocation &gt; hyperextension MOI<div><br></div><div>PIP <b>Palmar </b>dislocation &gt; Twisting in semi-flexed MOI</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
What are the <b>S/S </b>of dislocation of the phalange?	Pain and swelling over PIP.<div><br></div><div>Obvious deformity, disability, and possible avulsion.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
How would you <b>manage </b>a finger dislocation?	If angulated or unstable, splint on field and transport securely.<div><br></div><div>Splinting following reduction.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Buddy taping </b>and early ROM following splinting if appropriate.</div><div><br></div><div>May take upwards to <b>6-8 weeks </b>to recover.&nbsp;</div><div>- athlete will often not stay out of the lineup this long</div><div>- must protect as much as possible when athlete returns to sport.</div>			KIN_240::Pre-Final::Wrist_and_Hand
In your brain, what happens on the dendrites of neurons when you learn something new?	Many new synapses (connections) are formed on the dendrites.			Coursera::Learning_How_to_Learn
How does procrastination work?	1. You look at something and it gives you a slight unhappy feeling.<div><br></div><div>2. This slight unhappy feeling activates a part of your brain which funnels your attention onto a more pleasant task</div><div><br></div><div>3. Feel happy&nbsp; (temporarily)</div>	"<img src=""paste-614959625b508194817dd9325424717bca7fd5f7.jpg"">"		Coursera::Learning_How_to_Learn
Why are math and science sometimes more challenging than other areas?<div><br></div><div>What can you do to solve this?</div>	Because a lot of it is abstract knowledge.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Eg: If you are learning about cow's, you can relate it back to an actual cow.</div><div><br></div><div>If you are learning about derivatives, you can't really do that.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Just practice bro</b></div>			Coursera::Learning_How_to_Learn
How is sleep important for the brain?	It washes out toxins in your brain that accumulate during the day.<div><br></div><div>It also strengthens things you want to remember while erasing things that are less important.</div><div><br></div><div>Also helps you understand hard to understand concepts.</div>	"<img src=""paste-115a44b16d3ad9b605f22ea41233b9c59a88b03a.jpg"">"		Coursera::Learning_How_to_Learn
What is <i>Chunking </i>in learning?<br>	"Chunking is the process of taking a complex or large idea and compressing it into a single idea or ""zip"" file so it is easier to remember."			Coursera::Learning_How_to_Learn
What is a systematic review?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::An attempt to answer a question, using all the tools/sources that you can find.}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic Review:<div>Attempt to answer a question, using all the tools/sources that you can find.</div><div><br></div><div>Usually an intervention to a condition.</div><div><br></div><div>Bringing in all the studies to answer that question --&gt; the process.</div><div><br></div><div>""You have to be systematic with the methods and the process that you use to make the review"".</div>"	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the difference between systematic and non-systematic reviews?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Systematic reviews use robust methods where its main goal is to <b>reduce bias</b>&nbsp;whereas a non-systematic review is like inviting experts to provide an overview of the question which is <b>susceptible to bias</b>}}.<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic Review:<div>Attempt to answer a question, using all the tools/sources that you can find.</div><div><br></div><div>Usually an intervention to a condition.</div><div><br></div><div>Bringing in all the studies to answer that question --&gt; the process.</div><div><br></div><div>""You have to be systematic with the methods and the process that you use to make the review"".</div>"	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the difference between systematic reviews and meta-analyses?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Systematic reviews is the process of selecting, evaluating, and synthesizing all available evidence whereas meta-analysis is the statistical approach of combining the data derived from a systematic review}}.<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic Review:<div>Attempt to answer a question, using all the tools/sources that you can find.</div><div><br></div><div>Usually an intervention to a condition.</div><div><br></div><div>Bringing in all the studies to answer that question --&gt; the process.</div><div><br></div><div>""You have to be systematic with the methods and the process that you use to make the review"".</div>"	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
Why is putting background information on how you came to develop that review question important in a systematic review?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It tells the reader why what their reading is important and why they should read it}}.<br></div>	<div>1. Give eligibility criteria</div><div>2. Search strategy</div><div>3. Analysis of the results</div><div>4. Interpretation and presentation</div><div><br></div><div><b>Overall, just take your time thinking through your question!</b></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; review questions<div><br></div><div>Want to know original question</div><div>- well thought out review question, how did you come to ask this question?&nbsp;</div><div>- this is why i'm doing the review and why you should read it</div><div>- <b>basically just saying that putting a little blurb about why and how you came to the review question is important</b>&nbsp;(put in the background section of the protocol)</div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the correct type of review question for a systematic review for the following?<div><br></div><div>What is the effectiveness, safety, and acceptability of surgery versus medical therapy for heavy menstrual bleeding?<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Intervention Review}}<br></div>	<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the correct type of review question for a systematic review for the following?<div><br></div><div>In people with non-specific low back pain, what is the association between a person’s expectation of recovery (including general outcome expectations, treatment expectations, and self-efficacy expectations) measured in validated scales, and disability outcomes?<br></div><div>{{c1::Prognostic review}}<br></div>	<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the correct type of review question for a systematic review for the following?<div><br></div><div>What are the barriers and facilitators to the implementation of lay health worker programmes to improve access to maternal and child health?<br></div><div>{{c1::Qualitative review}}<br></div>	<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the correct type of review question for a systematic review for the following?<div><br></div><div>What is the impact of study design (including RCTs versus observational study designs) on estimated effect measures?<br></div><div>{{c1::Methodological review}}<br></div>	<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the correct type of review question for a systematic review for the following?<div><br></div><div>Can wearing compression stockings, compared to not wearing them, prevent deep vein thrombosis in people travelling on long-haul flights?<br></div><div>{{c1::Intervention review}}<br></div>	<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is the correct type of review question for a systematic review for the following?<div><br></div><div>Can a measurement of ferritin in serum, or plasma be used to detect iron deficiency?<br></div><div>{{c1::Diagnostic test accuracy review}}<br></div>	<div><br></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What are the advantages and disadvantages to narrow review questions?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.}}</div>	<div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What are the advantages and disadvantages to broad review questions?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct..}}</div>	<div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div></div><div>_____________________________</div>Systematic reviews --&gt; type of review questions<div><br></div><div>1. Intervention Review: What is the value of intervention x compared with no intervention?</div><div>2. Diagnostic test accuracy review: How well can test x diagnose Disease Y?</div><div>3. Prognostic review: time-course. Assesses probable course of future outcomes for people with specific health problem</div><div>4. Methodological review: Address questions about how research is conducted and reported</div><div>5. Qualtitative review: more emotional, asks question on feelings and experience.</div><div>___________________________________</div><div>Narrow vs broad review questions</div><div><br></div><div>Narrow is good because it is easier to read and more focused but it may need multiple reviews to answer your question.</div><div><br></div><div>Broad is good because it encompasses a lot, however it may miss some details that narrow authors have. Also, it is harder to conduct.</div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What does PICO stand for and when is it used?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::PICO stands for Participants, Interventions, Comparisons, and Outcomes.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>It's used for <b>intervention reviews</b></div><div>}}<br></div>	____________________________________<div><br></div><div>PICO format for intervention reviews</div><div><br></div><div>P: Participants (who are you interested in studying?)</div><div>I: Interventions (what is the intervention?)</div><div>C: Comparisons&nbsp;</div><div>O: Outcomes</div><div><br></div><div><br></div>	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
Why are rigorous methods of systematic reviews important?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::To reduce bias in the process of systematic review.}}</div>	Kin 372 Module 1 Test	KIN_372::Cochrane_Module_1
What is human motor control?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The study of neural control of human movement</div><div>- This encompasses many fields.}}<br></div>	"<div><div><b>Human motor control</b>: The study of neural control of human movement</div><div>- encompasses a lot of fields</div><div><img src=""paste-c3259dd0bb2473f84735f4f9973597cff1f89c27.jpg""></div></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>KIN 302 Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div>- ask him about kinesthesia and rehab</div><div><br></div><div>**Reviews at beginning of class**</div><div>- on test probably</div><div><br></div><div>- don't be a bitch and just read the readings</div><div><br></div><div>-videos are shared with us on eclass</div><div><br></div><div>Optional Lab?</div><div>- vvc 4-419 or 4-418</div><div>- Labs start two weeks ahead (week of the 14)</div><div>_______________________________</div><div><b>Course Content</b></div><div><br></div><div>How do humans walk?</div><div>- take home question</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Human motor control</b>: The study of neural control of human movement</div><div>- encompasses a lot of fields</div><div><img src=""paste-c3259dd0bb2473f84735f4f9973597cff1f89c27.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Surface EMG</b>: what we are doing in lab</div><div>- records activity from whole muscle from electrodes placed on skin (hence surface)</div><div><br></div><div>PRETTY SICK</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Reflex</b>: <i>involuntary </i>response to activation to a sensory receptor</div><div><br></div><div>receptor --&gt; afferent --&lt; integrating centre --&gt; efferent path</div><div>(negative feedback loop)</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f3c781642316366ea30a61e6f821fe6a1c106f2a.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>LUL</div><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1

What are the 3 most common types of equipment used by the professional responder?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>1. Trauma kit</div><div>2. Jump kit</div><div>3. first aid/responder kit&nbsp;</div><div>}}<br></div>	Chapter 2 of the First Responder Course Manual	Field_Diagnosis::First_Responder_Manual::Responding_to_the_Call
What is biomechanics?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Study of the effects of forces acting on living organisms including the effects of these forces on structures and function}}<br></div>	"<div><b>Biomechanics</b>: Study of the effects of forces acting on living organisms (focus on humans), including the effects of these forces on structure and function</div><div>- living organisms are unique in that they can adapt due to different forces that act on it.</div><div>- important for studying the adaptations in a body</div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><b>Biomechanics</b>: Study of the effects of forces acting on living organisms (focus on humans), including the effects of these forces on structure and function</div><div>- living organisms are unique in that they can adapt due to different forces that act on it.</div><div>- important for studying the adaptations in a body</div><div><br></div><div><b>How can biomechanics be applied?</b></div><div>- objectively explain human activities with physical quantities</div><div>- determine causes of an activity</div><div>- Rational decisions to improve function</div><div><img src=""paste-07feb8366beabbd3568f4e5d034ffdbc4e09aca0.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Door Knob versus Lever</b></div><div><img src=""paste-cb9b26c2a7401da51734a354c04ff2e70e745ed1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Uni implements mandatory lever because it isn't accessible to have a door knob</div><div>- must create a frictional force to turn the door knob (remember friction is from normal force)</div><div>- On the other hand, a lever is more accessible because of the moment arm (easier to open)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Why Learn Biomechanics?</b></div><div><img src=""paste-53b540f789bbe8cd2ce26baf18a38d0f45f2c650.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Practical and Theoretical applications</div><div>- improve performance: can be any activity (don't have to be an athlete)</div><div>- reduce injury, restore physical function, provide accomodations for disability</div><div><br></div><div>Movement Speed for Cyclic Activities</div><div>- He wants us to know how to walk properly</div><div><img src=""paste-6e85fca54328fbd9b82e0f30d29a5aa42cd3c86f.jpg""><br></div><div>- equations: do we need to know them?</div><div>- when we train, do we want to increase frequency or length?</div><div><br></div><div><b>How to Run Fast</b></div><div><img src=""paste-297fb68bd5f578e1ac09a10a8cda583c2e7a0937.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>&nbsp;- Found that Usain Bolts stride frequency was lower then the other finalists (previously thought that increase stride frequency = increase speed)</div><div>- also other athletes who do good have a lower stride frequency</div><div>- hes faster because he has a longer stride length</div><div>- over the course we will learn why stride length is more important than stride frequency</div><div><br></div><div><b>Squat Exercise</b></div><div><img src=""paste-273d15f6bb8e04caabf8aa92a09f0b4b9df104d8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Partial squat vs deep squat</div><div>- research says better muscle adaptation is ass to the grass (loading muscle better)</div><div>- minimum depth you should get is parallel squat.</div><div>- quarter squat has nothing.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Vastus Medialis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f0923d599d771b0f14dd8ebb6bb45a3c64f172f1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Vastus medialis is important because it helps hold the patella medially</div><div>- prevents patella from mal-tracking</div><div><br></div><div>Noone was able to conclusively demonstrate that there is two parts to the vastus medialis in the past</div><div>- two years ago we just managed to do it!</div><div>- vastus medialis longus</div><div>- vastus medialis oblique</div><div>- we calculated the force that each muscle was able to do</div><div><br></div><div><b>Must know physical quantities</b></div><div>- basically objective descriptors</div><div><img src=""paste-a501af928b8bcf1d7a1494db114503fb37b791db.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>Know these derived quantities</div><div><img src=""paste-d4390065c1ffd18570f220a1fa5e732912279af4.jpg""><br></div><div><b>___________________________________________________________</b></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1
How can biomechanics be applied?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We can objectively describe activities using physical quantities.</div><div>- we can then understand what is involved in causing an activity "Why did the ""building code"" change which made all door handles levers instead of knobs?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because door knobs are less accessible</div><div>- there is a frictional force you have to turn against, whereas for a lever, there is a moment arm which makes it easier to turn.}}<br></div>"	"<div><div><b>Door Knob versus Lever</b></div><div><img src=""paste-cb9b26c2a7401da51734a354c04ff2e70e745ed1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Uni implements mandatory lever because it isn't accessible to have a door knob</div><div>- must create a frictional force to turn the door knob (remember friction is from normal force)</div><div>- On the other hand, a lever is more accessible because of the moment arm (easier to open)</div></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><b>Biomechanics</b>: Study of the effects of forces acting on living organisms (focus on humans), including the effects of these forces on structure and function</div><div>- living organisms are unique in that they can adapt due to different forces that act on it.</div><div>- important for studying the adaptations in a body</div><div><br></div><div><b>How can biomechanics be applied?</b></div><div>- objectively explain human activities with physical quantities</div><div>- determine causes of an activity</div><div>- Rational decisions to improve function</div><div><img src=""paste-07feb8366beabbd3568f4e5d034ffdbc4e09aca0.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Door Knob versus Lever</b></div><div><img src=""paste-cb9b26c2a7401da51734a354c04ff2e70e745ed1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Uni implements mandatory lever because it isn't accessible to have a door knob</div><div>- must create a frictional force to turn the door knob (remember friction is from normal force)</div><div>- On the other hand, a lever is more accessible because of the moment arm (easier to open)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Why Learn Biomechanics?</b></div><div><img src=""paste-53b540f789bbe8cd2ce26baf18a38d0f45f2c650.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Practical and Theoretical applications</div><div>- improve performance: can be any activity (don't have to be an athlete)</div><div>- reduce injury, restore physical function, provide accomodations for disability</div><div><br></div><div>Movement Speed for Cyclic Activities</div><div>- He wants us to know how to walk properly</div><div><img src=""paste-6e85fca54328fbd9b82e0f30d29a5aa42cd3c86f.jpg""><br></div><div>- equations: do we need to know them?</div><div>- when we train, do we want to increase frequency or length?</div><div><br></div><div><b>How to Run Fast</b></div><div><img src=""paste-297fb68bd5f578e1ac09a10a8cda583c2e7a0937.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>&nbsp;- Found that Usain Bolts stride frequency was lower then the other finalists (previously thought that increase stride frequency = increase speed)</div><div>- also other athletes who do good have a lower stride frequency</div><div>- hes faster because he has a longer stride length</div><div>- over the course we will learn why stride length is more important than stride frequency</div><div><br></div><div><b>Squat Exercise</b></div><div><img src=""paste-273d15f6bb8e04caabf8aa92a09f0b4b9df104d8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Partial squat vs deep squat</div><div>- research says better muscle adaptation is ass to the grass (loading muscle better)</div><div>- minimum depth you should get is parallel squat.</div><div>- quarter squat has nothing.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Vastus Medialis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f0923d599d771b0f14dd8ebb6bb45a3c64f172f1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Vastus medialis is important because it helps hold the patella medially</div><div>- prevents patella from mal-tracking</div><div><br></div><div>Noone was able to conclusively demonstrate that there is two parts to the vastus medialis in the past</div><div>- two years ago we just managed to do it!</div><div>- vastus medialis longus</div><div>- vastus medialis oblique</div><div>- we calculated the force that each muscle was able to do</div><div><br></div><div><b>Must know physical quantities</b></div><div>- basically objective descriptors</div><div><img src=""paste-a501af928b8bcf1d7a1494db114503fb37b791db.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>Know these derived quantities</div><div><img src=""paste-d4390065c1ffd18570f220a1fa5e732912279af4.jpg""><br></div><div><b>___________________________________________________________</b></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1
How do we measure walking speed?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::length * stride frequency}}<br></div>	"<div><div>Movement Speed for Cyclic Activities</div><div>- He wants us to know how to walk properly</div><div><img src=""paste-6e85fca54328fbd9b82e0f30d29a5aa42cd3c86f.jpg""><br></div><div>- equations: do we need to know them?</div><div>- when we train, do we want to increase frequency or length?</div></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><b>Biomechanics</b>: Study of the effects of forces acting on living organisms (focus on humans), including the effects of these forces on structure and function</div><div>- living organisms are unique in that they can adapt due to different forces that act on it.</div><div>- important for studying the adaptations in a body</div><div><br></div><div><b>How can biomechanics be applied?</b></div><div>- objectively explain human activities with physical quantities</div><div>- determine causes of an activity</div><div>- Rational decisions to improve function</div><div><img src=""paste-07feb8366beabbd3568f4e5d034ffdbc4e09aca0.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Door Knob versus Lever</b></div><div><img src=""paste-cb9b26c2a7401da51734a354c04ff2e70e745ed1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Uni implements mandatory lever because it isn't accessible to have a door knob</div><div>- must create a frictional force to turn the door knob (remember friction is from normal force)</div><div>- On the other hand, a lever is more accessible because of the moment arm (easier to open)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Why Learn Biomechanics?</b></div><div><img src=""paste-53b540f789bbe8cd2ce26baf18a38d0f45f2c650.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Practical and Theoretical applications</div><div>- improve performance: can be any activity (don't have to be an athlete)</div><div>- reduce injury, restore physical function, provide accomodations for disability</div><div><br></div><div>Movement Speed for Cyclic Activities</div><div>- He wants us to know how to walk properly</div><div><img src=""paste-6e85fca54328fbd9b82e0f30d29a5aa42cd3c86f.jpg""><br></div><div>- equations: do we need to know them?</div><div>- when we train, do we want to increase frequency or length?</div><div><br></div><div><b>How to Run Fast</b></div><div><img src=""paste-297fb68bd5f578e1ac09a10a8cda583c2e7a0937.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>&nbsp;- Found that Usain Bolts stride frequency was lower then the other finalists (previously thought that increase stride frequency = increase speed)</div><div>- also other athletes who do good have a lower stride frequency</div><div>- hes faster because he has a longer stride length</div><div>- over the course we will learn why stride length is more important than stride frequency</div><div><br></div><div><b>Squat Exercise</b></div><div><img src=""paste-273d15f6bb8e04caabf8aa92a09f0b4b9df104d8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Partial squat vs deep squat</div><div>- research says better muscle adaptation is ass to the grass (loading muscle better)</div><div>- minimum depth you should get is parallel squat.</div><div>- quarter squat has nothing.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Vastus Medialis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f0923d599d771b0f14dd8ebb6bb45a3c64f172f1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Vastus medialis is important because it helps hold the patella medially</div><div>- prevents patella from mal-tracking</div><div><br></div><div>Noone was able to conclusively demonstrate that there is two parts to the vastus medialis in the past</div><div>- two years ago we just managed to do it!</div><div>- vastus medialis longus</div><div>- vastus medialis oblique</div><div>- we calculated the force that each muscle was able to do</div><div><br></div><div><b>Must know physical quantities</b></div><div>- basically objective descriptors</div><div><img src=""paste-a501af928b8bcf1d7a1494db114503fb37b791db.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>Know these derived quantities</div><div><img src=""paste-d4390065c1ffd18570f220a1fa5e732912279af4.jpg""><br></div><div><b>___________________________________________________________</b></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1
