What's the best way to squat biomechanics wise?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The best way to squat is a deep-squat</div><div>- It was scientifically proven that ass-to-the-grass caused the most adaptations to the quad muscle compared to the parallel squat. (the 1/4 squat had no increase in adaptation)</div><div>}}<br></div>	"<div><div><b>Squat Exercise</b></div><div><img src=""paste-273d15f6bb8e04caabf8aa92a09f0b4b9df104d8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Partial squat vs deep squat</div><div>- research says better muscle adaptation is ass to the grass (loading muscle better)</div><div>- minimum depth you should get is parallel squat.</div><div>- quarter squat has nothing.</div></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><b>Biomechanics</b>: Study of the effects of forces acting on living organisms (focus on humans), including the effects of these forces on structure and function</div><div>- living organisms are unique in that they can adapt due to different forces that act on it.</div><div>- important for studying the adaptations in a body</div><div><br></div><div><b>How can biomechanics be applied?</b></div><div>- objectively explain human activities with physical quantities</div><div>- determine causes of an activity</div><div>- Rational decisions to improve function</div><div><img src=""paste-07feb8366beabbd3568f4e5d034ffdbc4e09aca0.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Door Knob versus Lever</b></div><div><img src=""paste-cb9b26c2a7401da51734a354c04ff2e70e745ed1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Uni implements mandatory lever because it isn't accessible to have a door knob</div><div>- must create a frictional force to turn the door knob (remember friction is from normal force)</div><div>- On the other hand, a lever is more accessible because of the moment arm (easier to open)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Why Learn Biomechanics?</b></div><div><img src=""paste-53b540f789bbe8cd2ce26baf18a38d0f45f2c650.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Practical and Theoretical applications</div><div>- improve performance: can be any activity (don't have to be an athlete)</div><div>- reduce injury, restore physical function, provide accomodations for disability</div><div><br></div><div>Movement Speed for Cyclic Activities</div><div>- He wants us to know how to walk properly</div><div><img src=""paste-6e85fca54328fbd9b82e0f30d29a5aa42cd3c86f.jpg""><br></div><div>- equations: do we need to know them?</div><div>- when we train, do we want to increase frequency or length?</div><div><br></div><div><b>How to Run Fast</b></div><div><img src=""paste-297fb68bd5f578e1ac09a10a8cda583c2e7a0937.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>&nbsp;- Found that Usain Bolts stride frequency was lower then the other finalists (previously thought that increase stride frequency = increase speed)</div><div>- also other athletes who do good have a lower stride frequency</div><div>- hes faster because he has a longer stride length</div><div>- over the course we will learn why stride length is more important than stride frequency</div><div><br></div><div><b>Squat Exercise</b></div><div><img src=""paste-273d15f6bb8e04caabf8aa92a09f0b4b9df104d8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Partial squat vs deep squat</div><div>- research says better muscle adaptation is ass to the grass (loading muscle better)</div><div>- minimum depth you should get is parallel squat.</div><div>- quarter squat has nothing.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Vastus Medialis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f0923d599d771b0f14dd8ebb6bb45a3c64f172f1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Vastus medialis is important because it helps hold the patella medially</div><div>- prevents patella from mal-tracking</div><div><br></div><div>Noone was able to conclusively demonstrate that there is two parts to the vastus medialis in the past</div><div>- two years ago we just managed to do it!</div><div>- vastus medialis longus</div><div>- vastus medialis oblique</div><div>- we calculated the force that each muscle was able to do</div><div><br></div><div><b>Must know physical quantities</b></div><div>- basically objective descriptors</div><div><img src=""paste-a501af928b8bcf1d7a1494db114503fb37b791db.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>Know these derived quantities</div><div><img src=""paste-d4390065c1ffd18570f220a1fa5e732912279af4.jpg""><br></div><div><b>___________________________________________________________</b></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1
What is with the vastus medialis? Why is it so important?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Vastus medialis is important because it helps hold the patella medially which prevents the patella from mall-tracking (shifting sideways I think)}}<br></div>	"<div><div><b>Vastus Medialis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f0923d599d771b0f14dd8ebb6bb45a3c64f172f1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Vastus medialis is important because it helps hold the patella medially</div><div>- prevents patella from mal-tracking</div><div><br></div><div>Noone was able to conclusively demonstrate that there is two parts to the vastus medialis in the past</div><div>- two years ago we just managed to do it!</div><div>- vastus medialis longus</div><div>- vastus medialis oblique</div><div>- we calculated the force that each muscle was able to do</div></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><b>Biomechanics</b>: Study of the effects of forces acting on living organisms (focus on humans), including the effects of these forces on structure and function</div><div>- living organisms are unique in that they can adapt due to different forces that act on it.</div><div>- important for studying the adaptations in a body</div><div><br></div><div><b>How can biomechanics be applied?</b></div><div>- objectively explain human activities with physical quantities</div><div>- determine causes of an activity</div><div>- Rational decisions to improve function</div><div><img src=""paste-07feb8366beabbd3568f4e5d034ffdbc4e09aca0.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Door Knob versus Lever</b></div><div><img src=""paste-cb9b26c2a7401da51734a354c04ff2e70e745ed1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Uni implements mandatory lever because it isn't accessible to have a door knob</div><div>- must create a frictional force to turn the door knob (remember friction is from normal force)</div><div>- On the other hand, a lever is more accessible because of the moment arm (easier to open)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Why Learn Biomechanics?</b></div><div><img src=""paste-53b540f789bbe8cd2ce26baf18a38d0f45f2c650.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Practical and Theoretical applications</div><div>- improve performance: can be any activity (don't have to be an athlete)</div><div>- reduce injury, restore physical function, provide accomodations for disability</div><div><br></div><div>Movement Speed for Cyclic Activities</div><div>- He wants us to know how to walk properly</div><div><img src=""paste-6e85fca54328fbd9b82e0f30d29a5aa42cd3c86f.jpg""><br></div><div>- equations: do we need to know them?</div><div>- when we train, do we want to increase frequency or length?</div><div><br></div><div><b>How to Run Fast</b></div><div><img src=""paste-297fb68bd5f578e1ac09a10a8cda583c2e7a0937.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>&nbsp;- Found that Usain Bolts stride frequency was lower then the other finalists (previously thought that increase stride frequency = increase speed)</div><div>- also other athletes who do good have a lower stride frequency</div><div>- hes faster because he has a longer stride length</div><div>- over the course we will learn why stride length is more important than stride frequency</div><div><br></div><div><b>Squat Exercise</b></div><div><img src=""paste-273d15f6bb8e04caabf8aa92a09f0b4b9df104d8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Partial squat vs deep squat</div><div>- research says better muscle adaptation is ass to the grass (loading muscle better)</div><div>- minimum depth you should get is parallel squat.</div><div>- quarter squat has nothing.</div><div><br></div><div><b>Vastus Medialis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f0923d599d771b0f14dd8ebb6bb45a3c64f172f1.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Vastus medialis is important because it helps hold the patella medially</div><div>- prevents patella from mal-tracking</div><div><br></div><div>Noone was able to conclusively demonstrate that there is two parts to the vastus medialis in the past</div><div>- two years ago we just managed to do it!</div><div>- vastus medialis longus</div><div>- vastus medialis oblique</div><div>- we calculated the force that each muscle was able to do</div><div><br></div><div><b>Must know physical quantities</b></div><div>- basically objective descriptors</div><div><img src=""paste-a501af928b8bcf1d7a1494db114503fb37b791db.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>Know these derived quantities</div><div><img src=""paste-d4390065c1ffd18570f220a1fa5e732912279af4.jpg""><br></div><div><b>___________________________________________________________</b></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1

What is time?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The measure of succession between two events</div><div>- the <b>temporal distance </b>between two events}}<br></div>	"<div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be&nbsp;<b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1
Why does time exist?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Time exists because of the Second law of thermodynamics (the law of entropy). This law states that entropy is always increasing --&gt; hence we are always going forward into a state of disorder. This creates the <b>arrow of time</b>}}<br></div>	"<div><div><b>The fact that entropy in a closed system is always increasing creates the arrow of time.</b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be&nbsp;<b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1
Who was the one who created the base-60-system? What do we use it for?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The ones who created this system was the ancient Babylonians who used it to measure astronomical events. Hence time was broken down into 60units (1hour = 60min, 1min = 60sec).</div><div>We used it to measure time.}}<br></div>	"<div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div></div><div>_______________________________________</div><div><br></div><div>KIN 306, Lecture 1</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>Time (chapter 2)</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-d7881a43df862c2fcf30ff1df9cb8f2f4529f5f1.jpg""><br></div><div>What is time and why does it exist?</div><div>- comes back to the laws of thermodynamics</div><div>- 1st = cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred</div><div>- 2nd = nothing is 100% efficient</div><div><br></div><div>Big Bang</div><div>- certain amount of energy in this time</div><div>- now, we still have the exact same amount of energy</div><div>- energy in the big bang was very condensed</div><div>- now it is expanded all around</div><div>(low key, maybe magic was a thing long time ago)</div><div><br></div><div>Entropy</div><div>- we can not decrease the amount of entropy of the universe, only increase</div><div>- going to a state of disorder</div><div><br></div><div><b>We are moving forward to a more chaotic and disordered state</b></div><div>- this gives us an arrow of time --&gt; forwards</div><div>- conceptually, year 0 was super ordered state</div><div>- some future time will be when the universe is more disordered</div><div>- we measure time through events: the distance between two events would be <b>temporal distance</b>&nbsp;= time</div><div><br></div><div><b>Measuring Time</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a442f954084594cf828e3cd21272eadb97dccc9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- we measure time through days</div><div>- also have other units of time (lul cesium is the most precise)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Babylonian Trigonometry</b></div><div><img src=""paste-6a55b353ee0eccd5f4f730d76ad6c228e6199ff9.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- Still trying to figure out what this is but we can determine that it is a table to do trig (did this a long time ago)</div><div>- they used the base-60 systems (we use base-10): made it easier for them to do trig</div><div>- **technically we are just trying to catch up to ancient civilization technology!</div><div><br></div><div><b>Time Series Analysis</b></div><div><img src=""paste-f598dd11c58712f473b54ded206f3e3c42389052.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we are interested in is what is happening in space</div><div>- look at space at event 1 vs space 2 --&gt; does it change or not over time?</div><div>This is what is called a <b>time series analysis</b>.</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_1

What does the spinal cord do? "<div>What does it mean when I say ""the spine is somatotopically organized?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Different information groups and parts travel together.</div><div><br></div><div>eg: Arm movements have a set pathway in which they travel together.}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-6ebea5ba6c8648163da5f0d3af4ad7e3ac0ada53.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What do ascending pathways do?<div><br></div><div><div>1. {{c1::integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes}}</div><div>2. {{c1::mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway}}</div><div>3. {{c1::sends up sensory perception}}</div></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What do descending pathways do?<div><br></div><div><div><div><div>1. {{c1::mediate action on motorneurons}}</div><div>2. {{c1::modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators}}</div><div>3. {{c1::provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)}}</div></div></div><div><br></div></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is the major ascending pathway of the human body?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Dorsal columns}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What are the two parts to the dorsal columns?<div>Where is it located?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::fasciculus (leg)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::cuneatus (arm)}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
Describe the pathway of the dorsal columns.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla --&gt; crosses synapse to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to sensory cortex.}}</div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt;
