Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is the second most important ascending pathway?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Spinothalamic tract}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What information does the spinothalamic tract take?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::pain and temperature}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is different about the spinothalamic tract vs the dorsal columns in terms of their pathways?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::information from the spinothalamic tract crosses synapse at the spinal cord level! And it crosses over to the other side wheras the dorsal columns do not}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
<div>What is the most important descending pathway in humans?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::the corticospinal tract!}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
Describe the travel of information through the corticospinal tract.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What are the cells that originate the corticospinal tract?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::pyramidal cells}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
Where is the pyramidal cells?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Layer 5 of the motor cortex}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div></div></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is the difference in cell bodies and tracts in the brain compared to the spine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside}}</div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div></div></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
Why are there so many folds in the brain?<div>{{c1::To increase surface area}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div></div></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; Where is the somatosensory cortex located?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::parietal cortex}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is the thalamus, what does it do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is a collection of cell bodies which relays and processes <b>ascending </b>information}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What does the cerebellum do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::error correction, motor learning, and fine tuning}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is the function of the basal ganglia?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Indirectly controls movement}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""></div></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is the basal ganglia made of?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::4 pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain}}<br></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""></div></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What are the 4 pairs of interconnected nuclei of the basal ganglia called?<div><br></div><div><div>1. {{c1::striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Globus pallidus (internal and external segments)}}</div><div>3. {{c1::subthalamic nucleus (STN)}}</div><div>4. {{c1::substantia nigra (pars reticulata and pars compacta)}}</div></div>	"_______________________________________________<div><div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""></div></div></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Ascending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-835543b40a6cfe26b74c318c69f5c51b95c2d3ff.jpg""><br></div><div>1. integrates sensory feedback with movement control processes</div><div>2. mediate reflex pathways --&gt; stimuli goes to brain and back within the same pathway</div><div>3. sends up sensory perception</div><div><br></div><div><b>Descending Pathways</b></div><div><img src=""paste-7b151a3bc2f8aa129f3cd99bda7e69ce90a29e10.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>1. mediate action on motorneurons</div><div>2. modulate spinal reflex pathways through central pattern generators</div><div>3. provide info about movement commands (compare intended vs outcome)</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Dorsal Columns</b></div><div>- the major ascending pathway!</div><div>- two parts to the dorsal columns</div><div>- fasciculus (leg) and cuneatus (arm)</div><div><br></div><div>dorsal root ganglion --&gt; dorsal columns --&gt; crosses synapse in dorsal column nuclei in medulla to thalamus --&gt; up thalamus to synapse --&gt; crosses synapse to sensory cortex.</div><div><img src=""paste-18ecb6d2a6b84c879faf9227fbf672e152a83915.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-66fd653fe16a5b48769f1861e7f02226692a5e39.jpg""><br></div><div>____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Spinothalamic tract</b></div><div>- takes info from pain and temperature</div><div>- different from dorsal columns, info crosses synapse at the spinal cord to thalamus</div><div><img src=""paste-48d13a3bddb455bfe5e1d3c1859d87cd1a3691e0.jpg""><br></div><div><b>If someone had a spinal cord injury, what functions would they lose?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-1b1e81c5cd4e2f808d5a26052b23004fc86d3cfe.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Corticospinal tract (descending)</b></div><div>- most important descending pathway in humans</div><div>- starts in primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>primary motor cortex --&gt; crosses over in the medulla --&gt; projects to motoneurons and interneurons --&gt; skeletal muscle</div><div><img src=""paste-9ea6c73bb6e4cf403cf48e59a6b07880e9ed1f92.jpg""><br></div><div><b>The cells that originate the corticospinal tract</b></div><div>- pyramidal cells</div><div>- in layer 5 of the motor cortex&nbsp;</div><div><img src=""paste-9c224332f23e0ad28bf2aec6bb001c71219298e3.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>- dendrites project towards surface of brain</div><div>- axons project to spinal cord and form most of corticospinal pathway&nbsp;</div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Brain</b></div><div>- opposite to the spine, the cell bodies are on the outside and the myelinated tracts are on the inside</div><div>&nbsp;<img src=""paste-ef8ff5a5db1a4cd02fa4d91c9194f46c2abdc7f9.jpg""></div><div>- has folds (gyri and sulci) that serve to increase area of brain</div><div><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div><div>Motor areas are in frontal cortex --&gt; primary motor cortex and premotor areas</div><div>sensory areas in pariatel cortex --&gt; parimary somatosensory cortex</div><div>thalamus --&gt; collection of cell bodies (relay center)</div><div>Cerebellum --&gt; error correction, motor learning, fine tuning</div><div><img src=""paste-ae369f33ea2c451fd06183b0e5a7b11a796c1682.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The basal ganglia</b></div><div>- indirectly controls movement</div><div>- four pairs of interconnected nuclei in the brain</div><div>Nuclie = collection of cell bodies</div><div><br></div><div>1. of those pairs in the striatum --&gt; caudate + putamen</div><div>2. Globus pallidus</div><div>3. subthalamic nucleus</div><div>4. substantia nigra</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-771612dc5b533ee9284321093085f16869dcb280.jpg""><br></div><div>_______________________________________________</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy

What is rhythm?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The relative timing between events within a task}}<br></div>	"<div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><div>Rhythm:&nbsp; temporal sequence of events within a task; specifically, the relative timing between events within a task&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Tempo: Total time to perform a task or sequence of events</div><div>- absuolute time to perform all events</div><div>- frequency of performing a task</div></div><div><br></div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div>KIN 306 Lec 2<div><br></div><div><b>Chapter 2</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Rhythm:&nbsp; temporal sequence of events within a task; specifically, the relative timing between events within a task&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Tempo: Total time to perform a task or sequence of events</div><div>- absuolute time to perform all events</div><div>- frequency of performing a task</div><div>____________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Freestyle (front crawl) swimming stroke</b></div><div><img src=""paste-83cadcf91252350dc68bb72a043260ad0d72c559.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Basically the phases of the freestyle stroke</div><div>What does this tell us?</div><div>- helps us identify how good someone is (measuring rhythm)</div><div>- helps us identify injuries (maybe spends a lot of time in pull-through because it hurts their shoulder)</div><div>- can tell us if the athlete is overtrained</div><div>- gives us information before the athlete is willing to share it</div><div>___________________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Butterfly Swimming Stroke</b></div><div><img src=""paste-50beaba07aab120a45c005698dc0c5a0437fdfc3.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Different for the other stroke but we expect to be consistent at an expert level</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Frequency</b></div><div>The rate at which an event occurs or is repeated over a particular time period</div><div>f = 1/time between events (basically the period)</div><div>period = seconds per cycle</div><div>frequency = cycles per second</div><div><img src=""paste-30a203b43a3e68d582a77e98a5eb43709975b4b5.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Gait Cycle</b></div><div><img src=""paste-93457c9ee01646d1e223a2834ec091194d5b2b96.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Starts at heel contact of one foot and stops and heel contact of the same foot</div><div>- 60% stance and 40% swing (standard for most people)</div><div>- gait cycle changes with injury</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>!00 m Sprint</b></div><div><img src=""paste-c17cf45ff05785ede2de59c41d9a831127da4731.jpg""><br></div><div>Athlete 1 compared to athlete 2</div><div>- higher stride frequency is slower, has a lower stance time</div><div><br></div><div>US - Usain Bolt</div><div>- lower stride frequecy allows for higher time per stride, this will thus allow for a higher stance time which allows for the muscles to have more time on the ground to push off</div><div>- allows him to do more because he has more contact with the group</div><div>- need a long enough time to exert force</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Determining Gait Stride Frequency</b></div><div><img src=""paste-36b63b792871b98b785c6f86a7d241d6c7846e92.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we doing in lab</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Controlling Rhythm and Tempo</b></div><div><img src=""paste-a18d25a559cb5df2349e6955acbbd51077e114a8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>How can we control rhythm/tempo?</div><div>- metronome, music, verbal cues</div><div>- verbal cues --&gt; coxswain</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><br></div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_2

time</div><div><br></div><div>US - Usain Bolt</div><div>- lower stride frequecy allows for higher time per stride, this will thus allow for a higher stance time which allows for the muscles to have more time on the ground to push off</div><div>- allows him to do more because he has more contact with the group</div><div>- need a long enough time to exert
