What is tempo?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It refers to the absolute time to perform a task }}<br></div>	"<div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a7a97ef17b0c0c1124bba73993ba63d30d9e4e5a.jpg""><br></div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div>KIN 306 Lec 2<div><br></div><div><div><b>Freestyle (front crawl) swimming stroke</b></div><div><img src=""paste-83cadcf91252350dc68bb72a043260ad0d72c559.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Basically the phases of the freestyle stroke</div><div>What does this tell us?</div><div>- helps us identify how good someone is (measuring rhythm)</div><div>- helps us identify injuries (maybe spends a lot of time in pull-through because it hurts their shoulder)</div><div>- can tell us if the athlete is overtrained</div><div>- gives us information before the athlete is willing to share it</div></div><div>____________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Freestyle (front crawl) swimming stroke</b></div><div><img src=""paste-83cadcf91252350dc68bb72a043260ad0d72c559.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Basically the phases of the freestyle stroke</div><div>What does this tell us?</div><div>- helps us identify how good someone is (measuring rhythm)</div><div>- helps us identify injuries (maybe spends a lot of time in pull-through because it hurts their shoulder)</div><div>- can tell us if the athlete is overtrained</div><div>- gives us information before the athlete is willing to share it</div><div>___________________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Butterfly Swimming Stroke</b></div><div><img src=""paste-50beaba07aab120a45c005698dc0c5a0437fdfc3.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Different for the other stroke but we expect to be consistent at an expert level</div><div><br></div><div>_____________________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Frequency</b></div><div>The rate at which an event occurs or is repeated over a particular time period</div><div>f = 1/time between events (basically the period)</div><div>period = seconds per cycle</div><div>frequency = cycles per second</div><div><img src=""paste-30a203b43a3e68d582a77e98a5eb43709975b4b5.jpg""><br></div><div>_____________________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>The Gait Cycle</b></div><div><img src=""paste-93457c9ee01646d1e223a2834ec091194d5b2b96.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>Starts at heel contact of one foot and stops and heel contact of the same foot</div><div>- 60% stance and 40% swing (standard for most people)</div><div>- gait cycle changes with injury</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>!00 m Sprint</b></div><div><img src=""paste-c17cf45ff05785ede2de59c41d9a831127da4731.jpg""><br></div><div>Athlete 1 compared to athlete 2</div><div>- higher stride frequency is slower, has a lower stance time</div><div><br></div><div>US - Usain Bolt</div><div>- lower stride frequecy allows for higher time per stride, this will thus allow for a higher stance time which allows for the muscles to have more time on the ground to push off</div><div>- allows him to do more because he has more contact with the group</div><div>- need a long enough time to exert force</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Determining Gait Stride Frequency</b></div><div><img src=""paste-36b63b792871b98b785c6f86a7d241d6c7846e92.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>- What we doing in lab</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><b>Controlling Rhythm and Tempo</b></div><div><img src=""paste-a18d25a559cb5df2349e6955acbbd51077e114a8.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div>How can we control rhythm/tempo?</div><div>- metronome, music, verbal cues</div><div>- verbal cues --&gt; coxswain</div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div><br></div><div><br></div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Lecture_2

What are the two main coordinate systems used in this course?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Polar}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Cartesion}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div>KIN 306, Space, Lecture 2</div><div><br></div><div>Coordinate System:</div><div>1. Polar coordinate system</div><div>2. Cartesian coordinate system</div><div><br></div><div><b>What is Space?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Geometry</div><div>- a branch of math that looks at points, lines and shapes</div><div>- geometry allows us define space</div><div><br></div><div>Euclid -- came with several postulates that defined what space is</div><div>1. A straight line can be drawn between any 2 points which gives us a length/spatial distance</div><div>2. Any straight line can be drawn indefinitely in a straight line</div><div><b>1 and 2 are 1-D space</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>3. Given a straight line segment, a circle can be drawn where one endpoint is the centre and the length of the segment is the radius</div><div><b>Euclids third postulate gives us 2-D space</b><br></div><div><img src=""paste-bb5ef637c05228b74474d8de9cfe216a2cdc2a93.jpg""><br></div><div>4. All right angles are congruent</div><div>- If you have a right angle you will right angles at every other corner (corners)</div><div><img src=""paste-9c29cbc250dd65adb8765171d3509757de484ddc.jpg""><br></div><div>5. Given two lines, where a third line drawn intersects them in a way that the sum of the angles is less then 180 degrees, the two original line will eventually intersect with each other (forming a triangle)</div><div><img src=""paste-dbc844182fd2165eb860e558f1872ab8306b273c.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>What are the two most important shapes for us to understand mechanics?</div><div>- circles and triangles</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Space
Who is Euclid?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::An ancient Greek mathematician who is the father of geometry}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div>KIN 306, Space, Lecture 2</div><div><br></div><div>Coordinate System:</div><div>1. Polar coordinate system</div><div>2. Cartesian coordinate system</div><div><br></div><div><b>What is Space?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Geometry</div><div>- a branch of math that looks at points, lines and shapes</div><div>- geometry allows us define space</div><div><br></div><div>Euclid -- came with several postulates that defined what space is</div><div>1. A straight line can be drawn between any 2 points which gives us a length/spatial distance</div><div>2. Any straight line can be drawn indefinitely in a straight line</div><div><b>1 and 2 are 1-D space</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>3. Given a straight line segment, a circle can be drawn where one endpoint is the centre and the length of the segment is the radius</div><div><b>Euclids third postulate gives us 2-D space</b><br></div><div><img src=""paste-bb5ef637c05228b74474d8de9cfe216a2cdc2a93.jpg""><br></div><div>4. All right angles are congruent</div><div>- If you have a right angle you will right angles at every other corner (corners)</div><div><img src=""paste-9c29cbc250dd65adb8765171d3509757de484ddc.jpg""><br></div><div>5. Given two lines, where a third line drawn intersects them in a way that the sum of the angles is less then 180 degrees, the two original line will eventually intersect with each other (forming a triangle)</div><div><img src=""paste-dbc844182fd2165eb860e558f1872ab8306b273c.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>What are the two most important shapes for us to understand mechanics?</div><div>- circles and triangles</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Space
Why is geometry important in regards to space?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It's a branch of math that looks at points, lines, and shapes which allow us to define space!}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div>______________________________________________________________________________</div><div>KIN 306, Space, Lecture 2</div><div><br></div><div>Coordinate System:</div><div>1. Polar coordinate system</div><div>2. Cartesian coordinate system</div><div><br></div><div><b>What is Space?</b></div><div><b><br></b></div><div>Geometry</div><div>- a branch of math that looks at points, lines and shapes</div><div>- geometry allows us define space</div><div><br></div><div>Euclid -- came with several postulates that defined what space is</div><div>1. A straight line can be drawn between any 2 points which gives us a length/spatial distance</div><div>2. Any straight line can be drawn indefinitely in a straight line</div><div><b>1 and 2 are 1-D space</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>3. Given a straight line segment, a circle can be drawn where one endpoint is the centre and the length of the segment is the radius</div><div><b>Euclids third postulate gives us 2-D space</b><br></div><div><img src=""paste-bb5ef637c05228b74474d8de9cfe216a2cdc2a93.jpg""><br></div><div>4. All right angles are congruent</div><div>- If you have a right angle you will right angles at every other corner (corners)</div><div><img src=""paste-9c29cbc250dd65adb8765171d3509757de484ddc.jpg""><br></div><div>5. Given two lines, where a third line drawn intersects them in a way that the sum of the angles is less then 180 degrees, the two original line will eventually intersect with each other (forming a triangle)</div><div><img src=""paste-dbc844182fd2165eb860e558f1872ab8306b273c.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>What are the two most important shapes for us to understand mechanics?</div><div>- circles and triangles</div>"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Space
What were Euclids 5 postulates?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::A straight line can be drawn between two points in which it gives us a length/spatial distance}}<br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Any straight line can be drawn indefinitely in a straight line}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Given a straight line segment, a circle can be drawn where one endpoint is the centre and the length of the segment is the radius}}</div><div>4. {{c1::All right angles are congruent}}<br></div><div>5. {{c1::Given two lines, where a third line drawn intersects them in a way that the sum of the angles is less then 180 degrees, the two original line will eventually intersect with each other (forming a triangle)}}<br></div>	"<div>Euclid -- came with several postulates that defined what space is<br></div><div>1. A straight line can be drawn between any 2 points which gives us a length/spatial distance</div><div>2. Any straight line can be drawn indefinitely in a straight line</div><div><b>1 and 2 are 1-D space</b><br></div><div><br></div><div>3. What sensations do the dorsal columns provide?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::fine touch and proprioception}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9989ce1bb61376901a706fc0e42f339e1c02bcdb.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
If you had a spinal cord injury on the right side of your spine near the cervical area would you feel it when someone wiggled your right toe?<div><br></div><div>How about if someone dropped a brick on your right foot? Why?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::You would not feel the wiggling because the right dorsal columns corresponds to the right leg, however, you would feel the brick because the spinothalamic tract crosses over to the left side of the spine and therefore you will still feel the information. }}<br><div><br></div><div><br></div></div>	"<img src=""paste-9989ce1bb61376901a706fc0e42f339e1c02bcdb.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-265cffc2635ddf37be21a85674f2c2980374088e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What does a 1st order or a 2nd order neuron mean?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A first order neuron means that it has axons connected straight from the sensory receptor, a second or neuron means that it has synapsed once. Likewise, a third order neuron would mean that it synapsed twice!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9989ce1bb61376901a706fc0e42f339e1c02bcdb.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-265cffc2635ddf37be21a85674f2c2980374088e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
Does the corticospinal tract directly or indirectly affect the motor unit?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Actually both, it may have a mono-synpatic pathway which connects directly to the motor unit but it may also affect the motor unit via interneurons and such.}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-6ab2c19502a3b08219b81d94dca9f72b76641f0b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy
What is the difference between temporal and spatial summation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Temporal summation is when the action potentials are close enough in time. Spatial summation on the other hand is that the action potential is happening in two or more different places in the cell.}}<br></div>	"<div>You have to have a temporal summation to have summation happen in the first place!</div><div><img src=""paste-30a0d605ab608f2bf87d64f190580ec176ee852e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Basic_Neuroanatomy

What should you look for when checking LOR?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::AVPU</div><div>A: Alert</div><div>V: Verbal</div><div>P: Painful</div><div>U: unresponsive</div><div><br></div><div>Look to see if they are any one of these}}<br></div>	1. Imagine that you are a family physician who is in favor of the EIM approach.&nbsp; You would like to start prescribing exercise to your patients.&nbsp; What messages does the poster convey about exercise as medicine that you think are helpful in motivating your patients to become more physically active?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Say whatever you like here David, this is your own opinion}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7ec23950de5d3064db67ac1931f023ee06b9b64b.jpg""><img src=""paste-241f4b8f3e1257f57c4e293f30052df35c2cc3b4.jpg"">"	KIN_372::Exercise_is_Medicine
Imagine that you are a family physician who is unsure of prescribing exercise as medicine to your patients.&nbsp; What are some of the over-simplifications about exercise as medicine that are presented in the poster?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Say whatever you like here David, this is your own opinion}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7ec23950de5d3064db67ac1931f023ee06b9b64b.jpg""><img src=""paste-241f4b8f3e1257f57c4e293f30052df35c2cc3b4.jpg"">"	KIN_372::Exercise_is_Medicine
Cairney, McGannon, &amp; Atkinson (2018) describe 3 major taken-for-granted assumptions that the EIM approach is based on (please see the second required reading).<div><br></div><div>Briefly summarize each of these 3 assumptions<br></div><div><br></div><div><div>1. {{c1::Assumption that individuals in society are inactive (at least not as active enough to reap health benefits of exercise)}}</div><div><br></div><div>2. {{c1::Exercise is inherently good for everyone}}</div><div><br></div><div>3. {{c1::Assumes that the connection of exercise to medicine will enhance the credibility of exercise}}</div><div><br></div></div>	Cairney, McGannon, &amp; Atkinson (2018) describe 3 major taken-for-granted assumptions that the EIM approach is based on (please see the second required reading).<br><br>1) Briefly summarize each of these 3 assumptions.<div>1. Assumption that individuals in society are inactive (at least not as active enough to reap health benefits of exercise)</div><div>- blames the individual for their own actions</div><div>- if they cannot be active, it is their fault</div><div>2. Exercise is inherently good for everyone</div><div>- responses will be varies, and ultimately some will be bad</div><div>- a notion that exercise is something that everyone can do</div><div>- discriminate against certain bodies</div><div>- more doesn't necessarily mean better</div><div>3. Assumes that the connection of exercise to medicine will enhance the credibility of exercise</div><div>- will detract from the advice of fitness trainers and the like</div><div>- make impact the long-term engagement of exercise</div><div>- lower adherence rate<br><br>2) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to the general population?&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>I think the third assumption will give the most significant harm. I think the hardest thing about exercise is actually adhering to an exercise plan over the long term. If exercise is prescribed as medicine, I don't think that people will be able to adhere for a long time, and stop once affects start to disappear.<br><br><br>3) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to people who experience disability?&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>I think the second assumption will have the biggest impact on people with disability. There will be some individuals that just won't be able to be active, and this assumption ignores these people.</div>	KIN_372::Exercise_is_Medicine
Cairney, McGannon, &amp; Atkinson (2018) describe 3 major taken-for-granted assumptions that the EIM approach is based on (please see the second required reading).<div><br></div><div>In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to the general population?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::I think the third assumption will give the most significant harm. I think the hardest thing about exercise is actually adhering to an exercise plan over the long term. If exercise is prescribed as medicine, I don't think that people will be able to adhere for a long time, and stop once affects start to disappear.}}<br></div>	Cairney, McGannon, &amp; Atkinson (2018) describe 3 major taken-for-granted assumptions that the EIM approach is based on (please see the second required reading).<br><br>1) Briefly summarize each of these 3 assumptions.<div>1. Assumption that individuals in society are inactive (at least not as active enough to reap health benefits of exercise)</div><div>- blames the individual for their own actions</div><div>- if they cannot be active, it is their fault</div><div>2. Exercise is inherently good for everyone</div><div>- responses will be varies, and ultimately some will be bad</div><div>- a notion that exercise is something that everyone can do</div><div>- discriminate against certain bodies</div><div>- more doesn't necessarily mean better</div><div>3. Assumes that the connection of exercise to medicine will enhance the credibility of exercise</div><div>- will detract from the advice of fitness trainers and the like</div><div>- make impact the long-term engagement of exercise</div><div>- lower adherence rate<br><br>2) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to the general population?&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>I think the third assumption will give the most significant harm. I think the hardest thing about exercise is actually adhering to an exercise plan over the long term. If exercise is prescribed as medicine, I don't think that people will be able to adhere for a long time, and stop once affects start to disappear.<br><br><br>3) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to people who experience disability?&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>I think the second assumption will have the biggest impact on people with disability. There will be some individuals that just won't be able to be active, and this assumption ignores these people.</div>	KIN_372::Exercise_is_Medicine
Cairney, McGannon, &amp; Atkinson (2018) describe 3 major taken-for-granted assumptions that the EIM approach is based on (please see the second required reading).<div><br></div><div>In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to people who experience disability?&nbsp;<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::I think the second assumption will have the biggest impact on people with disability. There will be some individuals that just won't be able to be active, and this assumption ignores these people.}}<br></div>	Cairney, McGannon, &amp; Atkinson (2018) describe 3 major taken-for-granted assumptions that the EIM approach is based on (please see the second required reading).<br><br>1) Briefly summarize each of these 3 assumptions.<div>1. Assumption that individuals in society are inactive (at least not as active enough to reap health benefits of exercise)</div><div>- blames the individual for their own actions</div><div>- if they cannot be active, it is their fault</div><div>2. Exercise is inherently good for everyone</div><div>- responses will be varies, and ultimately some will be bad</div><div>- a notion that exercise is something that everyone can do</div><div>- discriminate against certain bodies</div><div>- more doesn't necessarily mean better</div><div>3. Assumes that the connection of exercise to medicine will enhance the credibility of exercise</div><div>- will detract from the advice of fitness trainers and the like</div><div>- make impact the long-term engagement of exercise</div><div>- lower adherence rate<br><br>2) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to the general population?&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>I think the third assumption will give the most significant harm. I think the hardest thing about exercise is actually adhering to an exercise plan over the long term. If exercise is prescribed as medicine, I don't think that people will be able to adhere for a long time, and stop once affects start to disappear.<br><br><br>3) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to people who experience disability?&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>I think the second assumption will have the biggest impact on people with disability. There will be some individuals that just won't be able to be active, and this assumption ignores these people.</div>	KIN_372::Exercise_is_Medicine
Are you in favor of the EIM approach?&nbsp; Would you use this approach in your professional practice to motivate your clients/patients to become more physically active?&nbsp; Please explain your answer.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<div>Yes, I am in favor of EIM. Despite the notion of adherence with prescribing exercise as medicine, it will still give them some sort of benefits compared to nothing at all. In regards to certain populations not being able to be physically active, or being active puts them at risk, I agree then that they should not be doing exercise. However, for most people, I would recommend exercise or to those that have the ability to be physically active. I believe trying out the non-medicated and low-risk prescription of exercise should come first, before prescribing medication to reduce risk and such.</div><div><br></div><div>It would also be great if medical practitioners would be able to refer or transfer a patient to an exercise trainer who has more experience. Similar to how a family doctor can refer a patient to a certain surgeon. I believe that way, it would make the system more integrated, and if the patient has access to this option, it may increase adherence, as well as allow people who need adaptations to have a professional work around them.</div>}}<br></div>	Cairney, McGannon, &amp; Atkinson (2018) describe 3 major taken-for-granted assumptions that the EIM approach is based on (please see the second required reading).<br><br>1) Briefly summarize each of these 3 assumptions.<div>1. Assumption that individuals in society are inactive (at least not as active enough to reap health benefits of exercise)</div><div>- blames the individual for their own actions</div><div>- if they cannot be active, it is their fault</div><div>2. Exercise is inherently good for everyone</div><div>- responses will be varies, and ultimately some will be bad</div><div>- a notion that exercise is something that everyone can do</div><div>- discriminate against certain bodies</div><div>- more doesn't necessarily mean better</div><div>3. Assumes that the connection of exercise to medicine will enhance the credibility of exercise</div><div>- will detract from the advice of fitness trainers and the like</div><div>- make impact the long-term engagement of exercise</div><div>- lower adherence rate<br><br>2) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to the general population?&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>I think the third assumption will give the most significant harm. I think the hardest thing about exercise is actually adhering to an exercise plan over the long term. If exercise is prescribed as medicine, I don't think that people will be able to adhere for a long time, and stop once affects start to disappear.<br><br><br>3) In your opinion, which of these assumptions of the EIM approach represents the most significant harm to people who experience disability?&nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>I think the second assumption will have the biggest impact on people with disability. There will be some individuals that just won't be able to be active, and this assumption ignores these people.</div>	KIN_372::Exercise_is_Medicine

What are the 3 phases of actional potentials? What happens at each phase?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Rising phase: Voltage-gated Na+ channels open, Na+ flows in}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Falling phase: Na+ channels close, K+ channels open, K+ flows out, cells repolarise&nbsp;}}</div><div>3. {{c1::Undershoot: Cell is refractory due to after-hyperpolarisation}}</div><div><br></div><div>Then goes back to resting membrane potential</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-75788124db81ec14648409ce297bfd724639bad1.jpg""><br></div><div>The more complicated version!!</div><div><img src=""paste-2ee8fe31818c9f880d0c57edb29ee2fcc11006db.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Membrane_Potentials

What is a motor pool?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Collection of cell bodies that innervate a certain muscle}}<br></div>	"eg: a motor pool that innervates the bicep and another that innervate the thigh&nbsp;<div><img src=""paste-6abc2c19612b339aaefb25ad731ee86c855a4dd7.jpg""><br></div><div>In the picture above, you can see a different motor pool for different muscles</div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
There is a wide range in motor unit&nbsp;{{c1::size}} and&nbsp;{{c1::type}}	"<div>This allows for a wide range of movements to be performed</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-2eb0f4c6c000c95d29e4b7cce1039aa3fa9beeda.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is the glycogen depletion method?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They stimulate a single motor axon to fatige (all the glycogen in the muscle fibres that it innervates get depleted). They then stain the muscles for glycogen, and the muscles that do not have glycogen corresponds to that single motor axon.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>This way we can identify which motor unit innervates which muscle</div><div>- This way we can also see that a single motor unit may innervate multiple fibres (distribution)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-20e5989f7da35273ca7482160d35486a16b25de1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Approximately how many muscle fibres do small motor units innervate? How about big motor units?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Small motor units innervate small amount of muscle fibres (eg:eye = 10) whereas the larger, the more muscle fibres will be innervates (eg: thigh = 1000s}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-12d33bed7898de0494f2d966a074fd7d8b7164b0.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is the main difference between small and large motor units besides the number of muscle fibres that they innervate?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The main difference is that small motor units are better for small finer control movements like moving the eyes whereas the larger motor units are better for more gross movements like moving the leg muscles}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-12d33bed7898de0494f2d966a074fd7d8b7164b0.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What are the three main types of muscle fibre?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Slow twitch oxidative: 1}}<br></div><div>{{c1::fast-twitch oxidative: 2a}}<br></div><div>{{c1::fast-twitch glycolytic: 2b}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b1e7cab8e95720cfbb1e6511307c63aec306a6be.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Do the fibres within a motor unit contain different types of muscle fibres?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, all fibres within a motor unit are of the same type}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b1e7cab8e95720cfbb1e6511307c63aec306a6be.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Comparing the FF, FR, and S muscle fibres, which muscle gets the peak twitch force?&nbsp; Which muscle fibre fatigues slowest?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::FF muscle fibres get peak twitch force whereas the slow muscle fibres fatigue the slowest}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3c5693749e5f2d8d617ea54fbef9bc5808beee7e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What does increasing recruitment mean (when applied to force production)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::As you increase force, you recruit more motor units and also change the type of motor units!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c916ed054dc70c6a48ddd7751ff2e804c875e29b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Which motor units do you recruit first?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::slow-twitch motor units}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fb6c2574fe618a9c6f9d79b4c29b43c59ea6bbfb.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
How do you change the contraction force of a muscle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Change the recruitment or rate coding of motor units!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fb6c2574fe618a9c6f9d79b4c29b43c59ea6bbfb.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
<div>Which type of motor units conduct action potentials the slowest?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Type S motor units}}<br></div><div><br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9fcc719561e55eb02f1ad9fb0e3a145854acd2d7.jpg""><br></div>Why are slow-twitch motor units recruited before the fast-twitch ones?"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Which type of motor unit has the lowest input resistance?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Type FF}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9fcc719561e55eb02f1ad9fb0e3a145854acd2d7.jpg""><br></div>Why are slow-twitch motor units recruited before the fast-twitch ones?"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Which type of motor unit has the highest input resistance?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::S type motor unit}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9fcc719561e55eb02f1ad9fb0e3a145854acd2d7.jpg""><br></div>Why are slow-twitch motor units recruited before the fast-twitch ones?"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Why do S type motor units conduct action potentials the slowest?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because it has the smallest axons as well as the highest input resistance}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9fcc719561e55eb02f1ad9fb0e3a145854acd2d7.jpg""><br></div>Why are slow-twitch motor units recruited before the fast-twitch ones?"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is input resistance?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Resistance to flow of ions across the membrane}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9fcc719561e55eb02f1ad9fb0e3a145854acd2d7.jpg""><br></div>Why are slow-twitch motor units recruited before the fast-twitch ones?"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Why are slow-twitch motor units recruited before the fast-twitch ones?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is because the cells with the highest input resistance (smallest) have the largest EPSPs!</div><div><br></div><div>If I gave the same input to a small motor neuron vs a large motor neuron (where the small one has a higher EPSP), the small motor neuron has a higher chance to fire!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-93ea325efd1b6bda020dc7f4756738a63eb834f4.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is the Henneman's size principle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It states that small motor neurons (and all neurons in general) are recruited before large ones}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-93ea325efd1b6bda020dc7f4756738a63eb834f4.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is Ohm's Law?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Voltage = current x resistance}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d6c47f9d45fa32f1ebc6c13d9185c88ba7a067b5.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
How does Ohm's apply to the Henneman's size principle?<div>Hint: 3 key concepts<br><div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Regardless of the size of the neuron, the same absolute voltage change (V) is required to reach threshold}}<br></div></div><div>2. {{c1::Input resistance of a small neuron is greater then a large neuron}}<br></div><div>3. {{c1::All motorneurons in the motor pool recieve similar synaptic drive (current)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Overall: {{c1::Knowing all this, since the smaller neuron has the higher resistance (and looking at the equation) it would mean that it reaches voltage threshold before the bigger neuron!!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d6c47f9d45fa32f1ebc6c13d9185c88ba7a067b5.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What type of muscle fibres do the small motor units recruit?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::slow-twitch}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8d4130a6a3b0d55ad250d6422ea76ded95c5ebc4.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What type of muscle fibre do large motor units innervate?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Fast-twitch fatiguable muscle fibres}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8d4130a6a3b0d55ad250d6422ea76ded95c5ebc4.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
Why is the resting membrane potential of a cell around -60 and not -102 (equilibrium for K+)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is because, even though K+ predominates during rest, Na+ still affects it (+56) and therefore increasing the membrane potential!}}<br></div>		KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Membrane_Potentials

What are the two main classes of motor neurons?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::alpha motor neurons and gamma motoneurons}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-255234a26bde09a2b9ac2332822cc8ec40046c06.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Textbook::Chapter33
What do alpha motoneurons do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::exclusively innervate large muscle fibres (extrafusal) that produce large forces}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-255234a26bde09a2b9ac2332822cc8ec40046c06.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Textbook::Chapter33

What happens during the acute phase of an traumatic SCI?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::disruption or dislocation of vertebral column fks up neurons and oligodendrocytes which fk up the myelination which escalate into a <b>secondary injury cascade</b>.</div><div>This cascade basically means that cell dysfunction and death will occur}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-210867e804a2f2fa0fbf8d9d35b8860ce5fc57f5.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-048bda02d9b6513ec48e1933671f5313b6df24da.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_372::Spinal_Cord_Injury

What are cystic cavitations?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A cavity of extracellular fluid which forms a barrier to direct axonal regrowth but is a poor substrate for cell migration}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c424866f4b63ccd27d2467da8dba5707753fe966.jpg"">"	KIN_372::Spinal_Cord_Injury

What is surface EMG?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::records overall activity of active motor units using electrodes stuck to the skin}}<br></div>	"Most commonly used technique<div><img src=""paste-fffcb8f4f66951461e5bed8c68df6e2817868eba.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What are the advantages to surface EMG? How about disadvantages?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::advantages are good for studying contraction timing/amplitude, and reflex and are <b>easy to use</b>}}<br></div><div>{{c1::disadvantages are that it lacks selectivity, and inability to record single units}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fffcb8f4f66951461e5bed8c68df6e2817868eba.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What are raw EMG signals vs Rectified EMG signals?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Raw: unprocess EMG, looks messy and typically used for synchronized whole population responses}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Rectified: takes the absolute value of raw, and makes it look smoother, good for measuring peak amplitude and timing events}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8107106aa80e68d9a343f24a7d62d2b9ccf3cf4c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is an integrated EMG signal?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::it is the area under a rectified signal to calculate for time of activation for muscle contraction!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8107106aa80e68d9a343f24a7d62d2b9ccf3cf4c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is EMG normalization?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::takes your contraction and makes it a percentage of your peak or mean level during a certain contraction. This allows us to normalize EMG because it will be different from person to person!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e4f0d2554997aca1d89beb625931bf28f220532a.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is intramuscular or needle EMG?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::thin needle with wire inserted into muscle. Take out needle with wire stuck in muscle which allows for taking info from muscle}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1d4b253f426c5c8de70ebd3e642cb950aedea1a2.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What are the advantages/disadvantages of intramuscular or needle EMG?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::advantages: gives a lot more detail of synaptic inputs to motoneurons}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::disadvantages: invasive, lack of stability, labour intensive}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1d4b253f426c5c8de70ebd3e642cb950aedea1a2.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units

What is the difference between MRI and fMRI?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::MRI studies brain anatomy: very good spatial resolution.</div><div>fMRI: funtional MRI studies brain function, high temporal resolution but lower spatial resolution}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ca45a3cbde62f1617387b067af6f582c16cc6425.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-bd9239d72fe3bda646110f6b44ddf56b7d9528ca.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Motorneurons_and_Motor_Units
What is uniform motion? What is the cases for uniform motion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Uniform motion is when acceleration is constant</div><div>Case 1: acceleration is constant hence <b>uniform acceleration</b></div><div>Case 2: acceleration is zero, hence <b>uniform velocity</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-540a9cec0f2a51f9d991d5245cbeeab2b5a25105.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Displacement_Velocity_and_Acceleration
What is projectile motion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When an object is in freefall and the only force acting on it is gravity}}<br></div>	Equation 1: Vf = Vi + at<div>Equation 2: d = vit + 1/2at<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;<br>Equation 3: d = 1/2(vi + vf)*t</div><div>Equation 4: Vf<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;= Vi<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;+ 2ad</div>	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Displacement_Velocity_and_Acceleration
Why are SCI's so unique in terms of the types of impairments (sensory and/or motor) that each individual experiences?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There are many nerves innervating different parts of the body. The different parts of the spinal column respond differently to different injuries. The ascending and descending pathways have different responses}}<br></div>		KIN_372::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Secondary_Health_Conditions_Article
Which secondary conditions would you be certain to ask your patient about during your initial interview? Why are each of these conditions relevant to exercise prescription?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pain, respiratory problems, and cardiovascular problems}}<br></div>	We need to find what pain levels are acceptable for the patients to establish a baseline and to know their limits<div><br></div><div>These are <b>contraindications </b>to exercise!!!</div>	KIN_372::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Secondary_Health_Conditions_Article

Are the preganglion/postganglion in the SNS short or long? For PSNS, is the postganglion neuron cholinergic or andrenergic?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::cholinergic: releases acetylcholine}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-a3bcea16fe6a343bec90494cca0d408352d9dcfd.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_372::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Ninja_Nerd_Video
"Explain the pathway of the sympathetic nerve pathway.<div><img src=""paste-f2ab9dc4ebb040287759d2a7efebf39eb991df15.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Starting at the sympathetic preganglionic motor neuron, it can travel through the white rami communicans to a <b>chain&nbsp;ganglion</b> which it then synapses to the postganglionic motor neuron. It then travels through the gray rami communicans to influence a bunch of sympathetic responses. The preganglionic motor neuron a level lower can synapse at a ganglion and do what the above did or travel out on its own. The lone travel is called a&nbsp;<b>Splanchnic nerve</b>}}</div>"	"Second splanchnic is it going to a collateral or pre-aortic!<div><img src=""paste-c0003fc6af9f5783c2db783960e22ec5cc49dd59.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_372::Spinal_Cord_Injury::Ninja_Nerd_Video

What is a rigid body?	An object that has mass and geometry where the geometry is assumed to be fixed or non-deformable.	"<img src=""paste-794a78669c5af9ff7c4791983416e1e3f9c3c411.jpg"">"	y	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Angular_Motion

What is the difference between absolute angles vs relative angles?	<b>Absolute</b> (segment): angle of rigid body relative to CCS (horizontal or vertical)<div><b>Relative</b> (relative): angle of rigid body relative to another rigid body</div>	"<img src=""paste-b5b52d2bc0acdb060d9100322cfd57110f199e4b.jpg"">"		KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Angular_Motion
What are the internal angle and the external angle?	They are both <b>relative angles </b>that start at difference places. Eg: A knee, the internal angle would be the posterior knee and the external angle would be starting from zero standing up.	"<img src=""paste-b07cf36040318ce23a1ad6410b7325eff68ba126.jpg"">"		KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Angular_Motion
What would be your argument if a coach says a deep squat is not necessary because the time to develop good ankle flexibility is not worthwhile?	Athletic activities requiring a partial squat movement require the <b>same forward leg rotation</b> (ankle dorsiflexion) as a deep squat!	"<img src=""paste-94a1a1bff106f6a77100292d5da645a63f4f7052.jpg"">"		KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Angular_Motion

For those injuried below ~T4/T5, how come their sympathetic input to increase HR and contractility is present despite sympathetic preganglionic neurons being located at T1-L2?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because of splanchnic nerves that travel out by itself! In essence then, the spinal sympathetic neural components that support endurance-based arm ex- <br>ercise arise from spinal segments located at {{c1::lower (caudal)}} spinal levels than those that contain the neurons and motoneurons generating rhythmic movements. What are 4 ways in which damage to the sympathetic nervous system affects exercise capacity for individuals with SCI?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::<b>Sympathetic innervation to the heart</b> (T1-T5), complete injuries at C8 and above have reduced capability of exercise}}</div><div>2. {{c1::<b>Reduced catecholamines release</b> and is absense in tetraplegic athletes (used for increasing blood pressure) (especially reduced in C8 and above)}}</div><div>3. {{c1::All persons with complete injury at C8 or above will be <b>unable to sweat in response to heat! </b>(temperature regulation)}}</div><div>4. {{c1::Substrate mobilization (tetraplegic have <b>reduced capability for fat oxidation</b>)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e350e1136681cf5e6e563b893fd75216f10d788d.jpg"">"	KIN_372::Spinal_Cord_Injury
Can brain stimulation still initiate locomotion after lesions remove all long direct descending pathways? What are the implications of this? When scientists discovered that they could initiate locomotion after the lesions to all long direct descending pathways in rats, how was this remotely relevant to people? <div>What type of receptors do stretch reflexes and tendon taps activate?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::muscle spindle receptors}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8025ca906b82e2e19c91efba6d2a19038642147d.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
What is the advantages/disadvantages of using stretch reflexes and tendon taps to test peripheral receptor response?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Advantages: natural and easy to apply}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Disadvantages: difficult to apply during movement}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8025ca906b82e2e19c91efba6d2a19038642147d.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
For stretch reflexes, what is the <b>M1 </b>response?<div>eg: response in the wrist extensors to sudden wrist flexion</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is the early muscle activity response right after a stretch, so fast that it only occurs in the spinal level}}<br></div>	"EMG: small contraction before stretch<div>M1: early latency response after stretch (a spinal pathway = because its so fast) - REFLEX</div><div>M2: middle latency response (~70ms) ( goes to brain and back down again) - REFLEX</div><div>M3: longer latency response includes some sort of voluntary cammand - VOLUNTARY?</div><div><img src=""paste-2ee12f9575bab1423586b448474b14c9b62386ed.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
For stretch reflexes, what is the <b>M2&nbsp;</b>response?<div>eg: response in the wrist extensors to sudden wrist flexion</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is the middle latency response, thought to have enough time to go to the brain and back. Still a reflex pathway though (~70ms)}}<br></div>	"EMG: small contraction before stretch<div>M1: early latency response after stretch (a spinal pathway = because its so fast) - REFLEX</div><div>M2: middle latency response (~70ms) ( goes to brain and back down again) - REFLEX</div><div>M3: longer latency response includes some sort of voluntary cammand - VOLUNTARY?</div><div><img src=""paste-2ee12f9575bab1423586b448474b14c9b62386ed.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
For stretch reflexes, what is the <b>M3 and above&nbsp;</b>responses?<div>eg: response in the wrist extensors to sudden wrist flexion</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is the longer latency responses thought to have some sort of voluntary control (not a reflex)}}<br></div>	"EMG: small contraction before stretch<div>M1: early latency response after stretch (a spinal pathway = because its so fast) - REFLEX</div><div>M2: middle latency response (~70ms) ( goes to brain and back down again) - REFLEX</div><div>M3: longer latency response includes some sort of voluntary cammand - VOLUNTARY?</div><div><img src=""paste-2ee12f9575bab1423586b448474b14c9b62386ed.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
What is the difference between electrical stimulation of axons vs synaptic input of axons?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::For synaptic input, resistance is the deciding factor (Henneman's size principle)}}<br></div><div>{{c2::For electrical stimulation, the current is the deciding factor: Thus the larger axons will be recruited first!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cd80f7cbed3e97559d9fc02400fd523a732d9d87.jpg""><br>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
T/F Electrical stimulation of excitable cells follow the Henneman's size principle<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False, current is the deciding factor here and therefore larger axons will be recruited first!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cd80f7cbed3e97559d9fc02400fd523a732d9d87.jpg""><br>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
What is the H reflex? Where do we test this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::thought to be a monosynaptic reflex by stimulating over a peripheral nerve in the popliteal fossa (sensory axon).}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-68d3865fc49006c22406318b989a677717e20ec9.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
What are the advantages/disadvantages of using the H-reflex?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Advantages: easier to deliver and control stimulation during movement}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Disadvantages: non-physiological stimulation (activates all large diameter afferents)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-68d3865fc49006c22406318b989a677717e20ec9.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
How many responses does stimulating the soleus H-reflex activate? What are these responses?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It activates two EMG responses:&nbsp;</div><div><b>M (motor) </b>wave: activation of motor axons (short pathway and latency)</div><div><br></div><div><b>H (Hoffman) (sensory)</b>: reflex from activation of <b>sensory </b>axons (longer pathway and latency: you will see this after m-wave in the EMG)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-ff19ae25a4abe9c6336cc623b64cdf1a632e0d96.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
Describe the stimulus-response for M waves and H-reflexes when providing stimulus to the back of the knee <b>(subthreshold)</b>.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is no response subthreshold}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-525a566240b4313f3764e88d2d99a962cc3fd79e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
Describe the stimulus-response for M waves and H-reflexes when providing stimulus to the back of the knee <b>(threshold stimulation)</b>.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::stimulation activates largest sensory axons which produce H-waves only (often because afferents are larger then efferents)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-85cc88c2067ebfeaae83ca6d38e024271157ff64.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
Describe the stimulus-response for M waves and H-reflexes when providing stimulus to the back of the knee <b>(increasing stimulation)</b>.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::You start seeing an m-wave with a large H-wave, however as you keep on going up, the m-wave gets bigger and the H-wave gets smaller}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d795f74a693c69b21e07fc4d85be98915088e94d.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
How come when you increase stimulation of an H-reflex, the H-wave gets smaller while the m-wave gets bigger?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::because of COLLISION! Motor signals are orthodromic AND antidromic. The antidromic signals collide with the orthodromic H-reflex and diminishes the H-reflex wave!</div><div><br></div><div>Antidromic M volley recruit largest motor axons first whereas orthodromic H reflex volley recruit smallest first --&gt; as intensity increases they will eventually meet and collide (with m-wave winning out)}}<br></div>	"<div>Sensory stimuli is stimulated which cause the spine to send down motor signals (m-waves) but we are also sending motor signals up the spine to produce H-reflex which cause a collision</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-761f3f5f344bccdec8a153c0de755bd346b9af46.jpg""><br>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
Describe the stimulus-response for M waves and H-reflexes when providing stimulus to the back of the knee&nbsp;<b>(maximum stimulation)</b>.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::very large m-wave and very small or even absent H-reflex!}}<br></div>	"<div>Sensory stimuli is stimulated which cause the spine to send down motor signals (m-waves) but we are also sending motor signals up the spine to produce H-reflex which cause a collision</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-32e6f8ab233bef50972fdbc316509a76e6b97faf.jpg""><br>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
Describe the full stimulus-response for H-reflexes and M-waves from threshold to maximal stimulation<div><br></div><div>{{c1:: Small H, no m --&gt; larger H, small m --&gt; largest H, larger m --&gt; smaller H, larger M --&gt; small H, larger M --&gt; no H, largest M}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-761f3f5f344bccdec8a153c0de755bd346b9af46.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
What is cutaneous reflexes?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::when you stimulate a nerve that contains only afferents from cutaneous receptors}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-7a1bae7fc1fc7c34428934d127e2420b1b147d3b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques
What are the advantages/disadvantages of activating cutaneous axons?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Advantages: ease of stimulus delivery}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Disadvantages: stimulus intensity is reported subjectively}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7a1bae7fc1fc7c34428934d127e2420b1b147d3b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Stimulation_Techniques

"Do cutaneous receptors contribute to human grasping movements?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::YES!</div><div><br></div><div>They found that there were ""contact"" signals that would initiate further stimulation of the grasping movement, and without that ""contact"" signal, the further stimulation that indicates the grasping movement disapears!}}<br></div>"	"<div><div>Signals were appropriate in the different phases of the grasp</div><div><br></div><div>Does those ""contact signals"" actually contribute to muscle activity?</div><div>contact signal provided a trigger to activate further signal</div><div><br></div><div>Are these differences due to the discharge of cutaneous receptors?</div><div>- they put on anaesthesia to get rid of contact signal</div><div>- found that signals were driven by contact signal</div></div><div><br></div><div>Conclusion: cutaneous receptors contribute to human grasp</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-aabb2efb790fc6a654a0deb6e125313fe758a229.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-77c003e682d860528473360a967c59c37b122c1a.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Cutaneous_Receptors

What is the different roles of an alpha motor neuron vs a gamma motorneuron in a muscle spindle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::alpha: go to extrafusal muscle and make it lengthen and shorten}}<br></div><div>{{c1::gamma: go to intrafusal muscle and control the muscle spindle}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e3224ef993e82370e5eacd27ead736dcf3d9dec5.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle
"What is <b>Alpha-gamma coactivation</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that once alpha motorneuron gets turned on, gamma motorneurons are activated alongside it which <b>maintains </b>the sensitivity of the gamma motorneuron</div><div><br></div><div>If we contract a muscle and the gamma motorneuron doesn't contract the intrafusal muscle, we wouldnt be able to see further discharge!</div><div><img src=""paste-8c6d21d1a8cf97b294989ec30e04952d3ab08b09.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div><u>It allows for continued sensory input while the muscle is shortening</u>}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-e3224ef993e82370e5eacd27ead736dcf3d9dec5.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-292b442e6e291c176048e2f344f62e237f0c622e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle
How is <b>alpha-gamma coactivation </b>different from <b>the fusimotor set</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::coactivation states that sensitivity of gamma motorneurons are maintained throughout the contraction whereas the fusimotor set states that sensitivity of gamma motorneurons change!}}</div>		KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle

"When does it mean when they say, after a spindle stretch, the bag1 fibre ""creeps"" to shorter length? What are the implications of this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It means that the opening of the sensory receptor is getting smaller over time from Bag1 fibres (due to the visco-elastic nature of bag1 fibres). This is what gives it it's dynamic sensitivity}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-2f8fbe0db3e6db7804d4f8e84180a96a49a0d3b6.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle

The semitendinosus and semimembranosus are both supplied by nerve roots {{c1::L5-S2}}		1 Midterm
{{c1::False::T/F:}}The semimembranosus, semitendosus and short head of the biceps femoris are all innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve.	<br><div>The Short head is innervated by the common peroneal division; while the long head, semimem and semitend are innervated by the tibial division.</div>	1 Midterm
True/False<div>bag1 fibres of the intrafusal muscles are stiff at every stretch</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::False, intrafusal bag1 fibres are <b>visco-elastic</b>. Meaning that its stiff at high velocities but elastic at low velocities}}<br></div>	"<div>t Why is bag1 muscle fibres affect dynamic velocity?</div><div>what gives muscle spindles it's sensitivity to velocity? How does it work?</div><div><br></div><div>Describe what happens to bag1 muscle fibres in a fast stretch --&gt; explain ""creep"" here</div><div>Describe what happens to bag1 muscles fibres in a slow stretch</div><div>- not as high firing rate but absolute change is still the same<br><div><img src=""paste-d2877bbcdb761ad767a0e9ecb75af7d642502622.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle
"Describe what happens to bag1 muscle fibres in a fast stretch and hold and why does it ""creep""?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::In a fast stretch, the bag1 muscle fibres are stiff which cause the sensory receptor increase in opening (which increases discharge). Then, over time, the elastic part of the bag1 fibres will start to ""creep"" and stretch out and reduce that opening. That's why we see a large peak and then drop in discharge!}}<br></div>"	"<div><br></div><div><div><img src=""paste-d2877bbcdb761ad767a0e9ecb75af7d642502622.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle
Describe what happens to bag1 muscle fibres in a slow stretch and hold?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The fibres will be less stiff during the stretch and therefore will have a smaller peak, but it will still stretch back out, just not as much resulting in a smaller peak opening compared to a fast stretch (smaller dynamic index)}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div><div><img src=""paste-d2877bbcdb761ad767a0e9ecb75af7d642502622.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle
Is the absolute opening of the sensory spiral different for bag1 fibres for a fast stretch compared to a slow stretch?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, the absolute stretch/opening will be the same!}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div><div><img src=""paste-d2877bbcdb761ad767a0e9ecb75af7d642502622.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle
"<div>If you were to input high fusimotor activity into a muscle spindle undergoing a stretch and hold, what would happen to the discharge or firing rate of that muscle spindle?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It would be similar to a ""fast"" stretch, where the input of high gamma activity will make the bag1 fibres more stiff and increase the opening of the sensory receptor which would result in a higher dynamic index.}}<br></div><div><br></div>"	"<div><br></div><div><div><img src=""paste-24c1833cda0159ef4e4a0994a6619514ad5a147d.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle
"<div>If you were to input low fusimotor activity into a muscle spindle undergoing a stretch and hold, what would happen to the discharge or firing rate of that muscle spindle?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It would be similar to a ""slow"" stretch, where the input of low gamma activity will make the bag1 fibres less stiff and decrease the opening of the sensory receptor which would result in a lower dynamic index.}}<br></div><div><br></div>"	"<div><br></div><div><div><img src=""paste-24c1833cda0159ef4e4a0994a6619514ad5a147d.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Receptors_In_Muscle

"What is Gallileo's <b>theory of gravitation</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::F<sub>g</sub>= G(m1m2)/r<span style=""font-size: 16.6667px;""><sup>2</sup></span></div><div>Where both masses perform a force of attraction on each other. With regards to gravity, Earth's mass is so dam big that our mass is negligible.}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-f76dd8b0bb0837c2e474c4b0526582bd46601794.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Newtons_Laws_of_Motion
How can we use Galileo's theory of gravitation to explain his thought experiment of dropping two cannon balls of different masses and them hitting the ground at the same time?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Since the gravitation force exerted from the ball to the earth is negligible, the only force acting on both of them is gravity!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-47feeaf15b6f7f73b8bcb5738c79e9dc97f37c9b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Newtons_Laws_of_Motion
"What is the equation for gravitational acceleration? What is Newton's First Law of Motion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::His&nbsp;<b>first law</b>&nbsp;states that every object will remain at rest or in uniform&nbsp;<b>motion</b>&nbsp;in a straight line unless compelled to change its state by the action of an external force. This is normally taken as the definition of inertia. In effect: the sum of the forces will equal zero<br>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fc9ec342679e630a1847f623eec91cfeb48db119.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Newtons_Laws_of_Motion

What is <b>dynamic equilibrium</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When the sum of forces is zero <b>but </b>the velocity is not zero but in uniform motion!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-07e75ba40eea05a8490b5a13401eb256cc1a96f3.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Newtons_Laws_of_Motion

What is <b>Newton's Second Law of Motion</b>? (1st interpretation)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A condition known as <b>dynamics</b>, where the change in velocity is not zero. In dynamics, forces acting on an object is unbalanced which causes a change in acceleration. We can find this acceleration by the equation F=ma</div><div><br></div><div>&nbsp;<b>Dynamics </b>(think dynamic equilibrium) where the sum of forces are not equal to zero}}</div><div><br></div><div><br></div>	"<div><b>UNBALANCED FORCES</b><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-5c47c6f041de6003dd9f5b01c0b49ccaf4101fc6.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Newtons_Laws_of_Motion

Do cutaneous receptors contribute to Kinesthesia?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Yes, the signals are appropriate. The discharge rate follows MCP movement (motor movement?)</div><div><br></div><div>Some evidence that says that blocking cutaneous receptors with anesthetic reduces movement detection}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2edd79b0140ce1333b7fbd4e0257d8fdb7db695a.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Proprioception
Give an example of evidence that contributed to the notion that cutaneous receptors relate to kinesthesia.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Dr. Collins did an experiment where he stuck two pieces of tape on the finger joint and stretched it to make it seem like it moved (but it didn't). He then made them close their eyes and tell them to move their other finger if they thought the taped one moved. He then triggered the stretch and they thought it moved for real!</div><div><br></div><div>This tells us that cutaneous receptors DO contribute to Kinesthesia!!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-afb780e90b289cce849289d3f67b8ad12d96bdfe.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Proprioception

How does vibration produce an illusion of movement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because muscle spindles are highly sensitive to vibration}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2978e88519df03314fa9cbf387f5993940d9ca6c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Proprioception
If you were to vibrate the bicep muscle, what would be the perceived perception of this affect? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They would get a perceived notion that the elbow is extended. This is because of the muscle spindles in the arm. Vibrations will cause multiple small stretches in the spindles which induce spindle discharge in that area. More spindle discharge means that the arm is lengthening which only happens at elbow extension}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2978e88519df03314fa9cbf387f5993940d9ca6c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Proprioception

Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The main purpose of rectified EMG is to ensure the signal does not average to zero, since a raw EMG has both positive and negative components. (synapse level)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-599f68d793e81cd98a5a5d74fc0261b285555ebf.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

"What do ""spiking"" interneurons do?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They generate action potentials that cause neurotransmitter release at axon terminal (think of the all-or-none action)}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-de54363ef4de16ebf37ac20b1f608a4d23ab5660.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

What are <b>last-order interneurons </b>also called? Explain the pathway of sensory input to the spinal cord.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sensory input enters via dorsal root --&gt; input diverges and travels rostral and caudal in dorsal columns --&gt; every 1-2mm axon gives off collaterals which descend into dorsal horn --&gt; afferent inputs terminate on different cells in spinal cord}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-50e9503cb910950b130e728c6a3a84924d9d42b5.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

What happens when the sum of afferent signals are excitatory on a inhibitory interneuron?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The inhibitory interneuron will activate and inhibit the subsequent neuron}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-eba938370e6ecd5241f52cc27dbaea3ef14f5ab1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
What happens when the sum of afferent signals are inhibitory on a inhibitory interneuron?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The inhibitory interneuron will be inhibited (not activate) and will not inhibit the subsequent neuron}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-eba938370e6ecd5241f52cc27dbaea3ef14f5ab1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

What is the <b>Renshaw Cell</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Its a cell that keeps the motor neuron from firing too much (the Warden)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-efcb836ab0dc05f3498929b160dcfe14a204b378.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
Explain the primary function of the Renshaw cell. Why does it do this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::excitation to alpha motorneuron that contracts muscle --&gt; alpha motorneuron sends signals to Renshaw Cell --&gt; Feedback to further inhibit alpha motorneuron contraction --&gt; Recurrent Inhibition occurs}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It does this so that you are able to limit the amount of force output and contraction duration, this way to don't go ape mode and continously contract your muscles forever}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-efcb836ab0dc05f3498929b160dcfe14a204b378.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
What is <b>Recurrent Inhibition</b>? What cell do we know at this point that is involved in this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is when something actively inhibits itself!}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The Renshaw Cell!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-efcb836ab0dc05f3498929b160dcfe14a204b378.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
What are <b>Ia Inhibitory Interneurons</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Interneurons that mediate reciprical inhibition in the disynaptic reflect arc (activated by Ia afferents (not the same thing!))}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2512ed7906e8e2eda11b919cdb38e503fbc15ad4.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
What is the function of <b>Ia Inhibitory Interneurons</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When group Ia afferents excite a motor neuron (lets say an extensor), it will also fire and activate the <b>Ia interneuron</b>&nbsp;so that the interneuron can inhibit the antagonist muscle (here its the flexor)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1c0e35a7068492a7675fe22bbb867dac47d536ea.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
How can Renshaw Cells affect the function of Ia inhibitory interneurons?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They can also prevent Ia inhibitory interneurons from too strongly inhibiting their antagonist! This helps ensure that there's a proper balance between contraction of flexors and extensors. This is especially important in times when we need to contract both flexors and extensors (stability movements)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1c0e35a7068492a7675fe22bbb867dac47d536ea.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
What are the two functions that a Renshaw Cell can do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Recurrent inhibition on its own alpha motorneuron}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Gating Ia inhibitory interneurons from inhibiting the antagonist muscle too much}}<br></div>	"<div>In essense, the Renshaw muscle really likes fking over the main guy!</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-ae713185e1f8b269dc24bd9ca8d393069c476126.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

What are the effects of Group I/II interneurons with inhibition/excitation of muscle groups?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They can simultaneously inhibit one muscle group while exciting the antagonist!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-94edfb131ddefa72f87447762e18fb3597ba7e84.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

What is the role of <b>presynaptic inhibitory interneurons</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They are responsible for the pre-synaptic inhibition of the spinal cord}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e5b24bc63e1b15e83935e8bbf0b6edec106b6959.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

(modulation)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because presynaptic modulation is more selective then postsynaptic!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e5b24bc63e1b15e83935e8bbf0b6edec106b6959.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons
How is presynaptic modulation more selective then post-synaptic modulation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because of the presense of presynaptic inhibition!</div><div><br></div><div>They act on the axon terminal directly, which allows you to inhibit a <b>specific location </b>rather then cause overall inhibition (presynaptic inhibitory interneurons)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e5b24bc63e1b15e83935e8bbf0b6edec106b6959.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Interneurons

"Are spinal reflexes <b>""hard-wired""</b>? Meaning, is spinal reflexes non-modifiable?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It was once thought to be non-modifiable, however, now we know that even the simplest reflex is modifiable</div><div><br></div><div><b>Reflex Modulation</b>}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-32aab49e81c17903de0a10a728018fd932f0ecf2.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes

<div>How does <b>negative feedback </b>work?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::A stimulus will cause a response which decreases that stimulus, which shuts off once the change from the stimulus is gone</div><div><br></div><div>eg: the stretch reflex}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-15f114d30595f522198b3de85a7f02b4992fe7a1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
How does <b>positive feedback </b>loop work?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A stimulus will cause a response which further increases that stimulus! Outside intervention needed to shut off feedback cycle</div><div><br></div><div>eg: take away cookie jar from niece or GTO reflex during locomotion}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-15f114d30595f522198b3de85a7f02b4992fe7a1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes

What is the <b>function </b>of Ia afferent <u>reflex pathways</u>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Its function is to oppose muscle stretch through negative feedback (when muscle is stretched it activates). This helps us overcome unexpected/unwanted disturbances during movements. SO IT CONTRACTS WHEN MUSCLE IS STRETCHED (tendon tap)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-18084631ed6a3d61e55096c1a5879daf03deff07.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes

What is the <b>Myotatic Unit</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Collection of neural pathways controlling a single joint to help with the coordination of synergistic and antagonistic muscles about a single joint in the spinal cord}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4b3d922e7925012f52d2f7b94ec421f1262268a1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
What does the <b>myotatic unit </b>use to enahance coordination of muscles about a single joint?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Ia afferents}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Recurrent Inhibition (Renshaw Cells)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Presynaptic Inhibition}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4b3d922e7925012f52d2f7b94ec421f1262268a1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
In the <b>myotatic unit</b>, where do presynaptic inhibitory interneurons synapse at? What does it do there?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It synapses on Ia afferent terminals}}<br></div><div>{{c1::It reduces neurotransmitter release of Ia afferents which affectively inhibit the contraction of the muscle}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4b3d922e7925012f52d2f7b94ec421f1262268a1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
"Where does the <b>Ia afferents </b><u style=""font-weight: bold;"">diverge</u>&nbsp;in the myotatic unit? What does it do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It diverges to the <b>synergistic motor pools</b>&nbsp;AND <b>Ia inhibitory interneurons </b>(reciprocal inhibition).}}<br></div>"	"<div>At this point, the Ia afferents seem to be hella contracting</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-4b3d922e7925012f52d2f7b94ec421f1262268a1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
What is an example of <b>divergence of Ia inputs </b>in the spinal cord? (give reflex example)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Tendon Tap</div><div><br></div><div>tendon tap --&gt; muscle spindle detects --&gt; signal goes up Ia afferents --&gt; afferent diverges monosynaptically to same muscle, and synergists to contract muscle --&gt; also diverges monosynaptically to Ia inhibitory interneuron --&gt; inhibit antagonist}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-008a934868d52e8c49ac1ea1752cd8ac0c3dfebd.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
"If Ia afferent reflex pathways are monosynaptic, how come we say it is more complicated then that?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because of divergence, it ""monosynaptically"" synapses at the same muscle, synergists, and Ia inhibitory interneurons!}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-008a934868d52e8c49ac1ea1752cd8ac0c3dfebd.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
What is another way to say <b>reciprical inhibition</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::dysynaptic inhibition}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2a3fd35a84a35d9928948bdc7e2ad9edbeb66d3e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
What interneuron mediates <b>dysnaptic inhibition</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Ia inhibitory interneurons!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2a3fd35a84a35d9928948bdc7e2ad9edbeb66d3e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
Is Ia afferents the only neuron that innervates the Ia interneuron?&nbsp; What does this mean?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, Ia interneurons get a <b>convergence </b>from multiple different inputs (descending and peripheral. They come from mono/polysynaptic sources and produce excitatory and inhibitory responses.)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This allows us to modulate reciprocal inhibition and adjust it for different tasks (the reflex is not that rigid)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5ddd6d73406fe51690fc2c1dc75061b2c7b0056b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
Why would a Ia interneuron inhibit another Ia interneuron?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If the other Ia interneuron inhibits your agonist muscle. You would inhibit to increase the contraction of your agonist.</div><div><br></div><div>The other interneurons agonist is your antagonist, and therefore you would want to inhibit it!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5ddd6d73406fe51690fc2c1dc75061b2c7b0056b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
"Explain this diagram with a tendon tap reflex...<div><img src=""paste-a6206b0d4c33d751d743c04459566083a4f2f442.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::In a tendon tap reflex, multiple signals will come to either excite or inhibit the Ia inhibitory interneuron in question. In this case, it will excite the Ia intern which inhibit flexors, then the Ia intern will inhibit the Ia intern that inhibits the extensors! LUL FKING W}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-5ddd6d73406fe51690fc2c1dc75061b2c7b0056b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
What is the function of <b>recipricol inhibition</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::In a relfex, It actively inhibits the antagonist muscle to allow the agonist muscle to contract unopposed}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-618d64988343e5c33ea6dc045518bc542290b15c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
How does <b>post-synaptic inhibition </b>affect the cell?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It inhibits the cell post-synaptically meaning, AFTER its synapsed. This means that there will be no action potential further triggered down the axon and everything is stopped at that point (general inibition)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5cc2ea363e2db233953a169d11297f44a212ed8f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
How does <b>presynaptic inhibition </b>affect the cell?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It inhibits the cell BEFORE it synapses at the <b>axon terminal</b>. This way, the cell can still excite other neurons (through other collaterals) and selectively inhibit a single branch! (selective inhibition)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5cc2ea363e2db233953a169d11297f44a212ed8f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
How does <b>presynaptic inhibition </b>affect Ia reflexes?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It <b>gates </b>the activity of Ia afferents!</div><div><br></div><div>In a sense, it makes it so that the reflex isn't as severe if left alone (very big H-reflex when left alone)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e775861e4a44cffb6340e4c7eda7d3ff0f93aa95.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
What does <b>gating </b>of Ia reflexes from pre-synaptic inhibitory interneurons allow for?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It allows the nervous system to modify reflex transmission according to the demands of the task}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e775861e4a44cffb6340e4c7eda7d3ff0f93aa95.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
What is a <b>powerful mechanism </b>for <b>gating </b>sensory input like Ia reflexes?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::pre-synaptic inhibition!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e775861e4a44cffb6340e4c7eda7d3ff0f93aa95.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes

What is the difference between Ia inhibitory interneurons and Ib inhibitory interneurons?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Ia inhibits stretch (contracts agonist and inhibits antagonist)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Ib inhibits contraction (inhibits agonist and contracts antagonist)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c3c8c3366eb169c6fc9325cfb5d428102cd117d4.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes

What is the <b>cross-extension reflex</b>? (You step on lego)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is a reflex that coordinates with the flexion reflex! It will also <b>diverge </b>and the contralateral leg, stimulating the extensors/inhibiting flexors so that you don't fall over when you step on it!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6f6787ec315aee7c22b1dbd6e086c6c7235d9e32.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes
