"What does it mean when we say that cutaneous receptors have <b>""reciprocal organization""</b>? What does this show us?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It means that when we pinch the skin overlying a muscle, it will lead to excitation of the muscle, whereas if we pinch the skin on the other side (dorsal aspect), it will lead to inhibition of that muscle.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It shows us that stimulation of different parts of our skin can change the function of different muscles in our body}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-6defb237f8178cb4f2eea0ec7079cf729ca7bbe5.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Pre_Midterm::Section_4::Spinal_Reflexes

Calculate!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-177dd185ef46e23c1f81cb79401fe41dd5f44418.jpg""><img src=""paste-b332bdeb22fec9cce02abc0b55aecbf1a0709475.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Pre_Midterm::Force_Measurement

What is <b>Newton's Second Law of Motion</b>&nbsp;(second interpretation)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Describing the effect of force using the&nbsp;<b>Impulse-momentum relation</b>. We can rearrange F=ma into Impulse = change in momentum. Thus to say, when an impulse is applied (force over a period of time) to an object, the velocity of the mass will change (assuming mass is constant).}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e652b30347469edb2e6b459ecb698d8839846fa3.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Lab_Section::Lab_2
What is the difference between the <b>first</b> and <b>second interpretation</b> of Newton's Second law of motion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::First interpretation describes a change in acceleration which causes a change in velocity due to an imbalanced net force}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Second interpretation describes a change in velocity due to the impulse-momentum relationship where when an impulse is applied (force over a period of time), there will be a change in velocity.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e652b30347469edb2e6b459ecb698d8839846fa3.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Lab_Section::Lab_2

What are the <b>three theoretical approaches </b>to F=ma (Newtons Second Law)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Continuously varying force}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Impulse-momentum}}<br></div><div>{{c1::work-energy theorem}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9b539847e7d96c4861899a898dcdc72109c170d5.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
How does the&nbsp;<b>continuously&nbsp;varying force </b>theoretical approach apply to F=ma?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Examines the effect of exerting a force on a mass for each instant in time. Force causes acceleration, which causes a change in velocity which causes a change in displacement.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9b539847e7d96c4861899a898dcdc72109c170d5.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics

Use the work-energy theorem to explain the vertical jump.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::First phase: No change cuz ur just standing}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Countermovement phase: ground reaction force &lt; gravitation force (dipping)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Propulsion phase: ground reaction force &gt; gravitation force (launch)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Flight: Only gravitation force at work here because in the air}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ad4274bd395c30733e7c7c65028f06e83c98837.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
How can we use work to <b>explain </b>the vertical jump?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Work is performed by the ground reaction force to overcome work by gravitational force --&gt; net work from initiation to take-off raises COM and increases vertical velocity --&gt; Kinetic energy is used after take-off to propel COM away from ground --&gt; when Kinetic energy is exhausted, the COM reaches apex</div><div><br></div><div><b>THEREFORE: </b>to jump higher, we must increase the force from ground reaction force!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-07b2f988ed7931de8f3381683f91574f0d1c3d9a.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics

Who was the first to find <b>evidence </b>for locomotor CPGs?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Thomas Graham Brown}}<br></div>	"<div>Took spinal cord of a cat, and transected it. Recorded muscle activation in gastroc and tib ant. He found that even tho the SI was fully transected, he still saw activity in tib ant and gastroc. Suggested that CPGs probably reside in the spinal cord and do not require input to the brain.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3c685be6a48b111a7c1c8d604918cd1659e76c2b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
What did <b>Thomas Graham Brown </b>discover with what experiment?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::He found the first evidence of locomotor CPGs}}<br></div><div>{{c1::He transected the spinal cord of a cat and measured muscle activity in its Tibialis Anterior and Gastrocnemius (hindlimbs) and found that there were still activity in these muscles with the spinal cord transected. This means that the CPGs are probably located in the spinal cord level!}}<br></div>	"<div>Took spinal cord of a cat, and transected it. Recorded muscle activation in gastroc and tib ant. He found that even tho the SI was fully transected, he still saw activity in tib ant and gastroc. Suggested that CPGs probably reside in the spinal cord and do not require input to the brain.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3c685be6a48b111a7c1c8d604918cd1659e76c2b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
In locomotion, what decides <b>when </b>and <b>how </b>we walk?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The basal ganglia}}<br></div>	"How do we know when and how to walk?<div>- controlled by the basal ganglia&nbsp;</div><div>- BG recieves input from various areas (eg: MLR and RF)</div><div><br></div><div>Role of BG:</div><div>- select appropriate locomotor style (eg: gait when walking vs running)</div><div><br></div><div>Output from BG is inhibitory. They decrease projections to brain regions that initiate locomotion.</div><div>- The more BG output, the more locomotive activity</div><div><img src=""paste-e97807d7dd3c08f2eb339c7d05eb82c412f460ac.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
"How does the basal ganglia decide <b>when </b>and <b>how </b>we walk?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It receives input from various cortical areas and project to cortical regions that initiate locomotion (eg: MLR, RF) ...note that BG is an inhibitory output, the more BG output, the less locomotive}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The BG selects appropriate locomotor ""style"" for a particular behaviour (eg: running vs walking)}}<br></div>"	"How do we know when and how to walk?<div>- controlled by the basal ganglia&nbsp;</div><div>- BG recieves input from various areas (eg: MLR and RF)</div><div><br></div><div>Role of BG:</div><div>- select appropriate locomotor style (eg: gait when walking vs running)</div><div><br></div><div>Output from BG is inhibitory. They decrease projections to brain regions that initiate locomotion.</div><div>- The more BG output, the less locomotive activity</div><div><img src=""paste-e97807d7dd3c08f2eb339c7d05eb82c412f460ac.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
In locomotion, what does the <b>MLR </b>stand for?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Mesencephalic locomotor region}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-d759e692ccf4ae3fa7087e5cd2276e2eae519f75.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
In locomotion, what does the <b>RF</b>&nbsp;stand for?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Reticular formation}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-d759e692ccf4ae3fa7087e5cd2276e2eae519f75.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
What does the <b>MLR</b> (mesencephalic locomotor region)&nbsp;do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::stimulation of MLR initates locomotion}}<br></div>	"<div>Stimulation of MLR initiates locomotion</div><div>- increased stimulation frequency = increased locomotion speed</div><div><br></div><div>MRL directly projects to RF</div><div><br></div><div>RF projects to reticulospinal tract</div><div><br></div><div>Reticulospinal tract releases glutamate and serotonin in the spinal and activates CPGs responsible for generating motor output for locomotion</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-d759e692ccf4ae3fa7087e5cd2276e2eae519f75.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

What is the role of <b>CPGs</b>&nbsp;in locomotion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They are responsible for <b>timing </b>and <b>pattern </b>of muscle activity for locomotion. They are also responsible for producing many types of rhythmic movements.}}<br></div>	"<div>CPGs are responsible for timing and pattern of muscle activity for locomotion</div><div>- also responsible for producing many types of rhythmic movements</div><div><br></div><div>CPGs for the hindlimbs for rodents are interconnects throughout the ventral part of the lumbar spinal cord.</div><div>More rostral parts are more excitable and therefore activated first</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-b7956b5083350a39b26de3742f5001ce824c16e9.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
For CPGs in <b>rodents </b>which parts are activated first? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Rostral (ventral) parts are activated first}}<br></div><div>{{c1::This is because they are more excitable}}<br></div>	"<div>CPGs are responsible for timing and pattern of muscle activity for locomotion</div><div>- also responsible for producing many types of rhythmic movements</div><div><br></div><div>CPGs for the hindlimbs for rodents are interconnects throughout the ventral part of the lumbar spinal cord.</div><div>More rostral parts are more excitable and therefore activated first</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-b7956b5083350a39b26de3742f5001ce824c16e9.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
If we didn't have a brain (no motor output), would we still be able to produce locomotion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Yes, it turns out that the spinal cord alone can produce locomotion}}<br></div>	"<div>Spinal cord alone can produce locomotion.</div><div><br></div><div>Decerebrate: Take the cerebrum and cut it off (motor cortical regions reside in the cerebrum).</div><div>- if we cut it off, motor signals won't be able to come from the brain</div><div><br></div><div>Spinalisation: Take the spinal cord and transect it (no signals are able to travel through the spinal cord anymore)</div><div><br></div><div>Flexors are active, extensors are not and vice versa (will adapt to changes in treadmill speed)</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3da91462861694a6bd4784dadeb87063da9cc3a8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
What is an experiment that provides evidence that the spinal cord alone can produce locomotion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::People decerebrated and spinalised it and put it on a treadmill. They then recorded muscle activities in extensors and flexors. They found that it still produced patterns (flexors active when extensors are not and vice versa), and that it actually increased it speed when the treadmill speed increased (remember, no input from brain!)}}<br></div>	"<div>Spinal cord alone can produce locomotion.</div><div><br></div><div>Decerebrate: Take the cerebrum and cut it off (motor cortical regions reside in the cerebrum).</div><div>- if we cut it off, motor signals won't be able to come from the brain</div><div><br></div><div>Spinalisation: Take the spinal cord and transect it (no signals are able to travel through the spinal cord anymore)</div><div><br></div><div>Flexors are active, extensors are not and vice versa (will adapt to changes in treadmill speed)</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3da91462861694a6bd4784dadeb87063da9cc3a8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
What is <b>decerebration</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Take the cerebrum and cut if off (if we cut it off, motor signals won't be able to come from the brain)}}<br></div>	"<div>Spinal cord alone can produce locomotion.</div><div><br></div><div>Decerebrate: Take the cerebrum and cut it off (motor cortical regions reside in the cerebrum).</div><div>- if we cut it off, motor signals won't be able to come from the brain</div><div><br></div><div>Spinalisation: Take the spinal cord and transect it (no signals are able to travel through the spinal cord anymore)</div><div><br></div><div>Flexors are active, extensors are not and vice versa (will adapt to changes in treadmill speed)</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3da91462861694a6bd4784dadeb87063da9cc3a8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
What is <b>spinalisation</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Take the spinal cord and transect it (no signals are able to travel through the spinal cord anymore)}}<br></div>	"<div>Spinal cord alone can produce locomotion.</div><div><br></div><div>Decerebrate: Take the cerebrum and cut it off (motor cortical regions reside in the cerebrum).</div><div>- if we cut it off, motor signals won't be able to come from the brain</div><div><br></div><div>Spinalisation: Take the spinal cord and transect it (no signals are able to travel through the spinal cord anymore)</div><div><br></div><div>Flexors are active, extensors are not and vice versa (will adapt to changes in treadmill speed)</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3da91462861694a6bd4784dadeb87063da9cc3a8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

How is a scratch reflex <b>modulated </b>by a CPG?&nbsp;<div><br><div>{{c1::Gets hand to correct position (reflex) and then rhythmic scratching occurs when in correct position (CPGs)}}<br></div></div>	"Example of CPG: Scratch reflex<div>- purpose is to remove annoying stimulus</div><div>1. get to correct position</div><div>2. rhythmic scratching occurs only when in correct position</div><div><br></div><div>Sherrington</div><div>- studied neural mechanism in spinalized dogs (scratch)</div><div>- reflex remained after spinal cord severed at C-level</div><div>- showed that rhythmic pattern was at spinal level</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-0d4a0aee54f8061edb31de89610ec875b31372ad.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

In a <b>scratch reflex</b>&nbsp;what happens when you increase the <b>intensity</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Amplitude increases}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Latency shortens}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Number of repetitions increase}}<br></div>	"In a scratch reflex, an increase in intensity will reduce the latency and increase the amplitude of the reflex.<div>- also increase in number of repetitions (more scratching)</div><div>- rhythm is stereotyped and automatic but can still be altered by sensory feedback</div><div><img src=""paste-c1c93f7bbc7ec37c0b3253dc08e8601dcb447071.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

What is the <b>half-centre model </b>in CPGs?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Its the notion that CPGs have interneurons controlling flexor and extensor motor neurons which have reciprocal inhibitory connections with each other</div><div><br></div><div>This allows you to do one movement while not being distracted by the subsequent in a locomotor activity}}<br></div>	"The Half-centre Model<div>- flexor-extensor ""half-centres""</div><div>- interneurons projected to ext and flex that inhibit them</div><div>- important because if ext was activated, we need flex to be inhibited</div><div>- they have <b>reciprocal inhibitory </b>connections</div><div><img src=""paste-d78b6eca562218dfc3b04b45cbb87c76d365558e.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6e5cbdb3ac2e7027ed0f44a347b45ac093a68b64.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
"What does this diagram represent?<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f57627eb1b410b99c5335bd7635785d36482e1db.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The Half-centre model in a CPG}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-00635256f0ddfd8ad2e3d9491a4aebc18398363a.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
"<div>Explain the process in this diagram...</div><div><img src=""paste-f57627eb1b410b99c5335bd7635785d36482e1db.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::First of all, this is a half-centre model in a CPG}}<br></div><div>{{c1::An input will be put into either A or B&nbsp;(let's say A)}} --&gt;{{c1::it will inhibit its opposing interneurons while exciting its agonist muscle}} --&gt; {{c1::discharge of A slowly declines because of adaptation}} --&gt; {{c1::this reduces inhibition on B which causes&nbsp;<b>post-inhibitory rebound&nbsp;</b>(because its been inhibited for too long)}}&nbsp;--&gt; {{c1::which activate B interneurons.&nbsp;}}</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><b>This process cycles and results in rhythmic movement</b></div>"	"<img src=""paste-00635256f0ddfd8ad2e3d9491a4aebc18398363a.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
What is <b>post-inhibitory rebound </b>in the half-centre model of CPG?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When an interneuron is inhibited for too long, once that inhibition starts to relax, it causes that inhibited interneuron to activate}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0dd9b540cdfd03d1eaa9f03a1a3747e7ec8a147f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology
In the <b>half-centre model</b>, how come after a while of an interneuron being fired for too long, discharge starts to decline?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Adaptation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0dd9b540cdfd03d1eaa9f03a1a3747e7ec8a147f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

How does the <b>Lamprey </b>perform locomotion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::RS}} --&gt; {{c1::eIN}} --&gt; {{c1::MN and iCN}} --&gt; {{c1::iCN will inhibit other side! (reciprocal inhibition)}} --&gt; {{c1::discharge will slowly decline (adaptation)}} --&gt; {{c1::causes contralateral eIN to depolarise from post-inhibitory rebound (rebound excitation)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-319f0bdab07336a980e184461bc50e7cfaaefbab.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

How come over time, the <b>discharge</b> of rhythm generating cells (eIN) <b>decline </b>(adaptation) in locomotion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When eINs are depolarised, calcium will enter causing K+ channels to open, hyperpolarising the cell and turning off the drive!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-eab604e9f1637f3007694263cf7069bb06bc8b42.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

(locomotion)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Located in the ventral portion of each side of the cord (ventral hemisegment of the spinal cord)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-43c33330c247afdef5811cee599b6a3ecdc93a47.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Locomotion::Circuits_And_Physiology

"What are the <b>4 general principles </b>of sensory feedback to locomotion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sensory feedback contribute to generation and maintenance of <b>rhythmic activity</b> (timing)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Sensory signals contribute to the <b>magnitude</b> of ongoing motor activity}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Sensory signals can initiate <b>""phase transitions""</b> (eg: <b>stance to swing</b>)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Transmission in <b>reflex pathways</b> is <b>flexible</b> and depend on motor task and/or phase of movement (can be modulated).}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-00ffe59ff2dff66b3cefd684f1fc3bc4ddf5c915.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback

In normal conditions it can flap its wings continuously. However, when they were deafferented (loss of sensory feedback), they couldn't maintain their locomotion!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ab01d24692778bb02fc1c0e98f7e4391de750e9b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback

He found that 30-60% of soleus activation was affected}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Stimulation of plantaris nerve, EMG increases with higher stimulation}}<br></div>	"<b>SENSORY FEEDBACK AFFECTED MAGNITUDE</b><div><img src=""paste-5038e0287a5ee35431285bf51c9c5042e8fa9394.jpg""><b><br></b></div><div><img src=""paste-7888d8a1dcfaf03c91817a67f46f58767c06e6e6.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What is an example of how <b>sensory feedback intitate phase transitions</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sherrington did an experiment on a cat, where he moved it's limb position which made it move into stance/swing phase!}}<br></div>	"Cat hip position, can make cat transition switch stances<div>- cats sense of hip position influence phase transition</div><div><img src=""paste-fd380ecbd0b67f7e5a0b70a206ec025422cc4afe.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What type of sensory feedback influences phase transition in locomotion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::position of limb (stretch)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::load}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e7867e43ef6160d06a851ec20d53f05a75518319.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-581cc31ada255b91cbad92483b7a70b7e9d47cdc.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What is the <b>If-Then </b>rules for a slow gait?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>IF </b>extensor force is low <b>AND </b>contralateral leg is loaded <b>AND </b>hip is extended <b>THEN </b>flex leg.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d48c6001b42fd683a62ceb39613b2e6d4b261748.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What is the <b>If-Then </b>rules for a backward gait?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>IF </b>extensor force is low <b>AND </b>contralateral leg is loaded <b>AND </b>hip is flexed&nbsp;<b>THEN </b>flex ankle and knee, extend hip.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d48c6001b42fd683a62ceb39613b2e6d4b261748.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What is the <b>If-Then </b>rules for a trip?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>IF </b>extensor force is zero&nbsp;<b>AND </b>hip is flexing&nbsp;<b>AND </b>skin contacts an obstacle&nbsp;<b>THEN </b>lift and place}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d48c6001b42fd683a62ceb39613b2e6d4b261748.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
How does feedback from peripheral receptors affect activity of the CPG? (Going from stance to swing phase)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::stepping forward with right leg behind --&gt; increased feedback from stretch sensitive receptors at hip --&gt; decreased feedback from load receptors in the extensors --&gt; excites flexors, inhibits extensors --&gt; stance-to-swing transition}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f2ec33815cd3279105bd3a5a6ebd57f0b0362f59.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
"Explain this graph (sensory feedback and CPG)<div><img src=""paste-5dd03f0aa9af0b87d15edc78419c679c68bedfd2.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is the right and left hip, When extensors are activated it will inhibit flexors and vice versa. Flexors will also inhibit the contralateral flexor (makes sure that if leg flexes, other leg doesn't flex at same time}}<br></div><div>{{c1::When stretch is applied to hip, and when load in extensors decreases, it excites flexors and inhibits extensors on that hip (causes stance-to-swing phase/flexion to occur).}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-f2ec33815cd3279105bd3a5a6ebd57f0b0362f59.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
How can sensory feedback <b>modulate reflex during locomotion</b>? (4)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Timing and magnitude of motor output has to be modifiable (eg: walking up a cliff or tripping on something) or locomotion would not be able to become flexible.}}</div><div>{{c1::Reflexes are modualted by descending commands, sensory feedback, and CPG outflow to interneurons and motoneurons}}<br></div>	"Transmission in reflex pathways is flexible<div>- hill walking on incline</div><div>- slipping/tripping</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3dfab6644be4cee80f20da03c881dc4d795a7b8b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What are the <b>3 major concepts </b>that suggest sensory feedback influence <b>reflex modulation during locomotion</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Task-dependent reflex modulation}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Phase-dependent reflex modulation}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Reflex reversel}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0ffa4c6e3cf5eadc7a963ae35b783238cdd8013e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What is an <b>example </b>of&nbsp;<b>task-dependent reflex modulation </b>in locomotion? How does this relate to sensory feedback?<div><br></div><div>Example:&nbsp;{{c1::When running, you will have a lot more sensory feedback then lying down. This allows your body to reduce sensory feedback when running or increased sensory feedback when lying down so that there isn't too little feedback when lying down or too much feedback when running.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-ea67bc94d6acfadc4ec3b60642f85a629ee31d87.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
In a task-dependent reflex modulation in locomotion, what happens to <b>H-reflexes </b>as you go from standing, to walking, to running?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::H-reflexes are progressively inhibited}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ea67bc94d6acfadc4ec3b60642f85a629ee31d87.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
Why are H-reflexes progressively inhibited from standing --&gt; running in a task-dependent reflex modulation in locomotion?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>What is the likely <b>mechanism </b>to this inhibition?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This inhibition is thought to allow motorneurons to remain responsive to relevant input (prevent saturation of motorneuron pool)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Presynaptic inhibition of 1a afferents (reflexes)}}<br></div></div>	"<img src=""paste-ea67bc94d6acfadc4ec3b60642f85a629ee31d87.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback

How does <b>sensory feedback </b>cause <b>phase-dependent modulation</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Transmission through sensory pathways is adjusted according to movement phase. Different H-reflex depending on phase of cyclic movement (Eg: swing vs stance phase)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Reflex reversal: reflex <b>sign </b>depends on the <b>phase </b>of the movement (excitatory in one part of the step cycle and inhibitory in another)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7254196507c1d31f187e5278f776d15286631e8d.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-d7318be1ab22ceb69c1b0159c8c799fde1e8253b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
"What is <b>reflex reversal </b>in sensory feedback's role in reflex modulation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Phase dependence: the ""sign"" of an EMG depends on the ""phase"" of the movement!}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-6fafdb79fb9f9c3dce70f787709bff5da6b7f6ae.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What is an example that a reflex switches <b>signs </b>depending on the task (reflex reversal in locomotion)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::At rest, reflexes from GTO's are inhibitory while during locomotion, input from group Ib afferents switches to excitation!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9671bd4860b972c2724e45bd69e068992e0b4a29.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback

What are some <b>evidence </b>that there is CPGs in humans?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Cyclic leg movements during sleep}}</div><div>2. {{c1::Vibration-induced air-stepping}}</div><div>3. {{c1::Walking in neonates (not fully developed)}}</div><div>4. {{c1::Spinal cord stimulation (induces walking)}}</div><div>5. {{c1::Rhythmic leg movements in SCI patients}}</div>	"1) cyclic leg movements during sleep: less brainstem control: still able to move<div>2) vibration-induced air-stepping</div><div>3) walking in neonates (corticospinal tract not fully developed, suggests walking is in spinal level)</div><div>4) Spinal cord stimulation (SCI)</div><div>5) Rhythmic leg movements in SCI patients</div><div><img src=""paste-b133d531eb361c52c05e9abbcdc52d05ee59830b.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6f0c8258d94c916f96fa45e48efd73a3eca38181.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_5::Sensory_Feedback
What are the <b>two equations </b>for power?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::P = W/t}}<br></div><div>{{c1::P = F*v}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ab75d98b6c05a417ab5f1783ecb5e543e20c265b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
Is power a cause of <b>change </b>in velocity? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No!}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Peak velocity is reached after force has dropped to zero. The velocity achieved at take-off is the result of all of the force applied over time (eg: impulse) which can also be described as the force applied over displacement (eg: work). Therefore, high velocity movement is a function of maximizing impulse and performing work, not power.}}<br></div>	"<div>NGL this is a bad explanation</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-ab75d98b6c05a417ab5f1783ecb5e543e20c265b.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
If work is important for high velocity movement, rather than power, is there any <b>value </b>in calculating power?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Yes, we can use a power-time curve to visualize work performed. Negative = eccentric work and positive = concentric work.}}<br></div>	"The force vs displacement curve is wack when trying to get info for work!<div><img src=""paste-aadf2bd8f6b9e1be6651e119f7575182d3fd01db.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-e7bb88cfbd4ef6c639cd808151a176a0adc40a8e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
An increased <b>power-time curve </b>means more {{c1::mechanical work}} is performed.	"<img src=""paste-83e2882aca27e6a37edbdb21997f70a11fc67136.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
What is the <b>difference </b>between static equilibrium and dynamics? (use equations)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Static: F=0 and M = 0}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Dynamics: F=ma and M = Ia}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9f7b145c9952471a5d46c8b15584960b93500289.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
What is <b>forward dynamics</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Looking at the effect of force/moment on an object with mass/moment of inertia}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Getting force and measuring its effects (acceleration --&gt; velocity --&gt; displacement}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c4eca84993be59e69ccf0beefa16d827df6584a9.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
What is <b>inverse dynamics</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Figuring out the kinematics to figure out force.}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Measuring displacement --&gt; velocity --&gt; acceleration --&gt; force}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c4eca84993be59e69ccf0beefa16d827df6584a9.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics
To increase power, can you increase velocity only?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, velocity is due to force over time or displacement and therefore to increase velocity you must also increase force. This is another reason why you can't only train velocity to increase power!}}<br></div>	"<div>Therefore, power is solely based on force and how fast we utilize that force.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-ef56e0c96034720af503b3b223002f849c38cd8a.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Dynamics

What happens to a <b>closed loop control system </b>when one of the parts of the system is blocked off?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It turns into an open loop system!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f120e94b5193ba2a69b97cc07fee11b041744351.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
How can a closed loop control system explain a <b>slow pointing movement</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Executive sends desired state to comparator --&gt; comparator compares with actual state from feedback --&gt; tells <b>input </b>the error (hand too close to body) --&gt; input tells <b>executive </b>--&gt; executive decides plan of action (select reach path) --&gt; tells <b>effector</b> --&gt; effector executes motor program --&gt; Output occurs (hand moves to desired state) --&gt; Feedback will go to comparator to see if it reached desired state (through vision of hand/proprioception/etc).}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-04d920ed515b8b8777b00a40cf354149bced027d.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
What kind of <b>feedback </b>do we receive for a motor movement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Vision and propriocepetion (etc...)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-468fcd190a1e63de8b6ff20b94c7c1bd95a2b1e8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
How do we store a desired state in voluntary motor control?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Through <b>efference copies </b>or <b>feedforward signals</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0b34d25fb73b8d4903039bd910c06563f2860f88.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
What are <b>efference copies </b>or <b>feedforward signals</b>, in motor control?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Information about the intended action or the expected feedback generated before the action begins}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0b34d25fb73b8d4903039bd910c06563f2860f88.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
Why can't we <b>sucker punch </b>or <b>tickle </b>ourselves?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because an efference copy is sent to our comparator before we do the action, so theres no way the action is surprising (we already anticipate it)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0b34d25fb73b8d4903039bd910c06563f2860f88.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
"<div>What is an example of a <b>closed loop control system </b>in something we learned in KIN 302?</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-c69be28d9d8a845904fecbde932b331cf705ed7b.jpg""><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Reflex</div><div><br></div><div>Stretch occurs on muscle spindle --&gt; executive tells comparator desired state, comparator compares feedback with desired state --&gt; muscle is too stretched --&gt; executive tells effector to contract the muscle --&gt; muscle is contracted --&gt; feedback to comparator!</div><div><br></div><div>}}<br></div>"		KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
What is a <b>consequence </b>of feedback control of motor movements (closed loop system)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The <b>speed-accuracy trade-off</b>: If you perform the same action more quickly, it will be done with less accuracy (Fitts' Law)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5aac87718b8ed401283e4d630d926ce11b0a6963.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law
What was Fitts' <b>experiment 1</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It was a reciprocal tapping task where he had participants tapping from one point to another point. He then manipulated the <b>amplitude </b>of the two tasks as well as the <b>width</b> of the task area. He restricted it to <b>15s </b>per trial and tested to see how much taps were done.}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-993642f3207041361375b2af2c5dea9589a86364.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>What was Fitts' experiment 1?<div>- reciprocal tapping task<br><div><br></div><div>What is Fitts' Law?</div><div>- what happens to movement time if there is a change in <b>amplitude </b>or <b>width</b></div></div><div>- <b>Movement time is proportional to index of difficulty</b></div><div><b>-- </b>M~A/W</div><div>- As amplitude gets bigger or width smaller; movement time will get bigger</div><div>- As amplitude gets smaller or width bigger; movement time will get smaller</div><div><br></div><div>What is <b>index of difficulty </b>in Fitts Law?</div><div>- Amplitude/Width</div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts_Law
What is <b>Fitts' Law</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>MT ~ A/W.&nbsp;</b>Its the fact that <b>movement time </b>is directily proportional to <b>index of difficulty</b>. As amplitude increases or width decreases, movement time will increase. }}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-3139d6afe37ccacf37515e03d0ea2febeab6a91e.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-cd7098ea0dac9347d408ec0bfe08b975b4e102a6.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>What was Fitts' experiment 1?<div>- reciprocal tapping task<br><div><br></div><div>What is Fitts' Law?</div><div>- what happens to movement time if there is a change in <b>amplitude </b>or <b>width</b></div></div><div>- <b>Movement time is proportional to index of difficulty</b></div><div><b>-- </b>M~A/W</div><div>- As amplitude gets bigger or width smaller; movement time will get bigger</div><div>- As amplitude gets smaller or width bigger; movement time will get smaller</div><div><br></div><div>What is <b>index of difficulty </b>in Fitts Law?</div><div>- Amplitude/Width</div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Voluntary_Movements::Feedback_Control_and_Fitts'_Law

"What is an example of how the motor homunculus is ""plastic""?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Researchers stimulated a part of the brain which caused the thumb to move up and right. They then had the participant continuously move their them down and left over and over again. When they stimulated the same spot on the brain, their thumb moved down and left! Over time though, it went back to up and right}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-3622cb50e2bc37d7b23232c78858ed14634bbfb0.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Primary_Motor_Cortex

"How is M1 discharge related to movement <b>direction</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cells fire at higher rates for movements in ""preferred"" direction. It acts as an inverse ""U"" curve where the closer you are to preferred direction, the more it fires}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-1415384ade181e8e3d6e4cdcd8dc06b6387712e9.jpg""><img src=""paste-da9929f60774eeba93eaa70b65b557d9ce2aa36a.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Primary_Motor_Cortex
What is <b>population coding </b>in the motor cortex? What can we use this for?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is the notion that our brains take the sum of all the directional firing of M1 cells to equate an overall direction.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Using this technique, we are able to determine in which direction an organism is reaching for}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2af2d2c39fd01a1609f51d690af13eb684776d04.jpg""><img src=""paste-26578a5f4972854d9e814b45084b24a2ff8dcf95.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Primary_Motor_Cortex

Why is knowing the <b>internal moment arm </b>useful?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It can be used to calculate the muscle force if the NJM/external moment is known}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8d0c30595e20ce3291b49c574cdab91c3f2afa6b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics

How are muscles categorised at the hip joint in the <b>sagittal plane</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Muscles acting in front of the axis of rotation (centre of the femoral head) will be hip flexors, and those with force vectors behind the axis (eg: glute max) are hip extensors}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2544096c345df6b5be32d5c85dd78f1828634ac9.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
When is the <b>gluteus maximus's </b>moment arm greatest?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When the hip is near full extension}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-16bdc174b9db6939059bcd326cc1578eb7fd3daf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
As the pelvis and hip joint flex, what happens to the gluteus maximum?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Its moment arm decreases and therefore it gets weaker (In turn, the hamstrings produce more force here because moment arm is larger)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-16bdc174b9db6939059bcd326cc1578eb7fd3daf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Why is the leg curl machine in a hip flexion position?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It allows the the moment arm of the hamstring to increase while decreasing the moment arm of the gluteus maximus. This way, most force is coming from the hamstrings!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-16bdc174b9db6939059bcd326cc1578eb7fd3daf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
The gluteus maximus is <b>strongest </b>and <b>most used </b>when in an {{c1::upright}} posture	"<img src=""paste-16bdc174b9db6939059bcd326cc1578eb7fd3daf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What muscles are active in the hip <b>frontal plane</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Adductors and abductors}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c70dd06fe07b51e4ece77334159374b3b678f97e.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What are the major hip abductors in the hip joint?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::gluteus medius, gluteus minimus and tesnor fascia latae (TFL)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c70dd06fe07b51e4ece77334159374b3b678f97e.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Why are <b>hip abductors </b>important for our posture and gait?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They play an important role in maintaining a <b>level pelvis</b>. The weight of our body when on one leg goes to the middle of the torso. This creates rotation at the hip, and this moment of force must be countered by the hip abductor muscles.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-deda98a54381ba7066f84e8971af9d930277eb34.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>internal </b>moment arm?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The perpendicular length between <b>muscle force </b>and <b>axis of rotation</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f069ff1d671c8237b6d67a54a84a207bb8c085e7.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>external </b>moment arm?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Perpendicular length between <b>resistance force </b>and axis of rotation (the one we've been looking at recently)}}<br></div>	"<div>Resistive forces include joint reaction forces</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-f069ff1d671c8237b6d67a54a84a207bb8c085e7.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
"What does it mean when we say our body is at a ""mechanical disadvantage""?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Our internal moment arm is a lot smaller then our external moment arm. Therefore we need a very large muscle force compared to the resistance force to overcome this.</div><div><br></div><div>We need a large muscle force for a relatively low task}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-04b9e854fc2bf16ed5656dc194242b23028b8610.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is <b>latency</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The time between stimulus delivery and the onset of an evoked response}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a5406880e0a75dcbfe12cfc6b1594d898acadad3.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Lab_Section::Lab_6
What is the <b>experimental equation </b>for nerve conduction velocity?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::CV = Distance betweem stim electrodes (m) / (Lactency A (proximal)(s) - Latency B (distal)(s))}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e70912c26057d14b6e54eeadf32056fcaaa0ec85.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Lab_Section::Lab_6
What is the <b>predicted equation </b>for nerve conduction velocity?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::NCV = 90.15 + age (-0.11) + height (-0.22)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e70912c26057d14b6e54eeadf32056fcaaa0ec85.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Lab_Section::Lab_6

What is the use of <b>brain computer interfaces (BCI) </b>in terms of neuroanatomy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is the use of recording cortical signals directly from the brain, and then computing it to restore function (in our brain)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b2c62950bb443bccd075a514987c96aad23919ab.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-42a3da6d0e720470e1cf794cbe90edc0e540db0b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Brain_Computer_Interface
What is <b>brain computer interfaces</b>&nbsp;based on?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::the principle of population coding: where movements are encoded in the activity of populations of cells}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b2c62950bb443bccd075a514987c96aad23919ab.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Brain_Computer_Interface
What happens to <b>confidence level </b>or variability when recording the population vector (population coding) of increasing or decreasing amounts of cortical cells (using BCI's)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When increasing the population size, confidence level decreases. When decreasing the population size, the confidence level increases (exponentially)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b2c62950bb443bccd075a514987c96aad23919ab.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Brain_Computer_Interface
With brain computer interfaces, would we want to record <b>multiple</b> cells or <b>fewer</b> cells? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We would want to record <b>fewer </b>cells}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because the smaller the population size recorded, the greater the confidence level (less variability)}}<br></div>	"<div>It pays to get BCI's that can fine tune recordings to a small number of cells!</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-a99c290f18943654add401402e9ecf118d718c98.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Brain_Computer_Interface

There also are dreams of using it to improve human abilities (science fiction type shit)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-42a3da6d0e720470e1cf794cbe90edc0e540db0b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Brain_Computer_Interface

How does <b>subacromial impingement </b>occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When the supraspinatus muscle and subacromial bursa are impinged between the head of the humerus and the acromion process}}<br></div>	"<div>Overtime, this condition leads to <b>""frozen shoulder</b>""</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-955015bd33460874448f8a63d6f1f453f1111c89.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Using Kaltenborn's rule, why does <b>subacromial impingement </b>occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When you go into shoulder abduction, and there is no muscle force to cause that downward glide, it will cause the humerus to move up and pinch the subacromial bursa and supraspinatus}}<br></div>	"<div>Overtime, this condition leads to <b>""frozen shoulder</b>""</div><div>Muscles that downward glide is the subscapularis, infraspinatus, and teres minor</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-955015bd33460874448f8a63d6f1f453f1111c89.jpg""><img src=""paste-a5cd795264c38e2f8ab18050a6a5a662e2cdfa96.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What are the muscles that contribute to the <b>downward glide </b>of the humerus when going into shoulder flexion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::subscapularis, infraspinatus, and teres minor. This is why rotator cuff exercises are often used to rehab or prevent shoulder injuries}}<br></div>	"<div>Overtime, this condition leads to <b>""frozen shoulder</b>""</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-955015bd33460874448f8a63d6f1f453f1111c89.jpg""><img src=""paste-a5cd795264c38e2f8ab18050a6a5a662e2cdfa96.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is a <b>sarcomere</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The smallest functional unit of muscle}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d32ffe87900799bff7ab72ee7c2be25458373483.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Describe the macrostructure to microstructure of a muscle.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Muscle (epimysium)}} --&gt; {{c1::Muscle fascicle (perimysium)}} --&gt; {{c1::muscle fibre (endomysium)}} --&gt; {{c1::myofibril}} --&gt; {{c1::myofilaments}} --&gt; {{c1::sarcomere}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d32ffe87900799bff7ab72ee7c2be25458373483.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What connective tissue surrounds the <b>muscle</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Epimysium}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d32ffe87900799bff7ab72ee7c2be25458373483.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the connective tissue that surrounds the <b>muscle fascicle</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Perimysium}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d32ffe87900799bff7ab72ee7c2be25458373483.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the connective tissue that surrounds the <b>muscle fibre</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Endomysium}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d32ffe87900799bff7ab72ee7c2be25458373483.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>sliding filament theory</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that myosin will grab onto actin and pull, which generates force. If the filaments slide, there is a change in displacement, and therefore the force generated performs work. This act of performing work by muscles is called the sliding filament theory}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-62257a375a4a684ed5102a0d81bc876b21e9559e.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
How <b>many</b> myosin and actin filaments are there in a single sarcomere?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::two sets of myosin filaments and two sets of actin filaments}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-62257a375a4a684ed5102a0d81bc876b21e9559e.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics

Myosin is also called the&nbsp;{{c1::thick}} filament	"<img src=""paste-6e089f20d47a4bbf682de5a2810eecc47898c4a7.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is an <b>actin-myosin cross-bridge</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Each myosin head grasping onto an actin filament is called a cross bridge}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6e089f20d47a4bbf682de5a2810eecc47898c4a7.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
The actin filament is also called the&nbsp;{{c1::thin}} filament	"<img src=""paste-6e089f20d47a4bbf682de5a2810eecc47898c4a7.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What happens to force when more cross-bridges are formed?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::More force generated}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6e089f20d47a4bbf682de5a2810eecc47898c4a7.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>power stroke </b>in a sarcomere?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When cross-bridges form, and the myosin head pulls on the actin filament}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d63097b1a34bd36456adc97f5ea09554245435b4.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
In a <b>power stroke </b>in a sarcomere, what muscle action occurs when the actin <b>slides in the direction</b> the myosin head is pulling?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Concentric muscle action}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d63097b1a34bd36456adc97f5ea09554245435b4.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
In a <b>power stroke </b>in a sarcomere, what muscle action occurs when the actin <b>slides in the opposite direction</b> the myosin head is pulling?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::eccentric muscle action}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d63097b1a34bd36456adc97f5ea09554245435b4.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What are the <b>three same's </b>of a sarcomere?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::All sarcomeres have the same <b>dimensions</b> (length/diameter)}}<br></div><div>{{c1::All sarcomeres have the same <b>number</b> of myosin and actin filaments}}<br></div><div>{{c1::All sarcomeres can generate the same <b>amount of force</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a35162c0d3a2b422789763a23b9adb8fa66241f6.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
If every sarcomere generates the same amount of force, how do we generate even more force?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The only way is to have more sarcomeres. In other words, more cross sectional area of the muscle. GET BIGGER}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a35162c0d3a2b422789763a23b9adb8fa66241f6.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
For sarcomeres, to generate more force we must add more sarcomeres. What is the two ways to add sarcomeres?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::In parallel}}<br></div><div>{{c1::In series}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ea633270ab97f0fc64903f0f9ad5ea66db91900.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
When adding sarcomeres in <b>parallel</b>, how does work increase?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When adding in parallel, the length stays the same, its just the amount of force from more sarcomeres that's at play here. So work increases through force}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ea633270ab97f0fc64903f0f9ad5ea66db91900.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
When adding sarcomeres in <b>series</b>, how does that affect work?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When adding sarcomeres in series, the force stays the same, but the length will increase. Therefore, the work increases through increase in length}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ea633270ab97f0fc64903f0f9ad5ea66db91900.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Increasing sarcomeres in <b>parallel </b>is called what?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::muscle hypertrophy}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e19a76c4b14f21be6dbf5eebafc38f175e6482aa.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Increasing sarcomeres in <b>series</b>&nbsp;does what to a muscle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It increases the muscle's suppleness}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e19a76c4b14f21be6dbf5eebafc38f175e6482aa.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
To maximize work performed of a muscle (sarcomeres), what are two things we have to do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Increase sarcomeres in parallel: muscle hypertrophy}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Increase sarcomeres in series: muscle suppleness (OFTEN NEGLECTED!)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e19a76c4b14f21be6dbf5eebafc38f175e6482aa.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is <b>specific tension</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The amount of force a muscle fibre can generate relative to its CSA}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe0bbcb85766ede0c28bb84c02b11204a31cf624.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Why are we interested in <b>specific tension</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::To compare the amount of force between different muscle fibres, we have to control for the size of the fibre. Different muscle fibres have difference sizes, therefore we can use specific tension (force/cross sectional area) to be able to compare them.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe0bbcb85766ede0c28bb84c02b11204a31cf624.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>equation </b>for specific tension?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Force/cross-sectional area}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe0bbcb85766ede0c28bb84c02b11204a31cf624.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Within the muscle fibre, there are <b>two types </b>of components. What are they and which ones generate force?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Contractile and non-contractile components}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Only the non-contractile components generate force}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe0bbcb85766ede0c28bb84c02b11204a31cf624.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
If the relative proportion of non-contractile components of a muscle fibre increases, what happens to the <b>specific tension</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The specific tension decreases}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe0bbcb85766ede0c28bb84c02b11204a31cf624.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics

When we say the cerebellum <b>fine tunes </b>motor movement, what does it do exactly?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Error correction}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Timing regulation}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Adjusts reflex pathways}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5ad18be793af926ed3e37f200cba4f95ec18dc96.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
<b>How</b>&nbsp;does the cerebellum fine tune movement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>Input:&nbsp;</b>Gets intended action from the <b>motor cortex</b>, and then compares it to sensory feedback from<b>&nbsp;sensory receptors</b>&nbsp;--&gt; <b>Output: </b>through cerebellar nuclei to <b>motor and premotor regions </b>(cycle continues)}}<br></div>	"<div>In simpler terms, the cerebellum compares the intended movement with the actual movement and responds to adjust the motor output accordingly</div><div><br></div><div>Basically a large ass feedback loop by the motor cortex, cerebellum, and the spinal cord</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-507ae4ac06bc0def02423eb00c01550ce4edaa0a.jpg""><img src=""paste-4c721e04a0e735646ce3e543dff763ba5c273177.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization

How does the <b>Purkinje cells </b>of the cerebellar cortex produce output?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Integrates info from parallel fibres and climbing fibres}} --&gt;&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::synapses (inhibitory) to deep cerebellar nuclei}} --&gt;&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Nuclei project to spinal cord which feed info to motor and premotor cortices (through spinal interneurons and motor neurons)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-91c22aeed4f22e0f89d978ba27038f791fc55e29.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Where does the cerebellar cortex obtain input information?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::From climbing and mossy fibres}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-91c22aeed4f22e0f89d978ba27038f791fc55e29.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-221dfb8ab0c95a03cb66439383e3f19d389bb858.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
How does <b>mossy fibres </b>of the cerebellar cortex take input information?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They project excitatory signals to <b>granule cells </b>and <b>deep cerebellar&nbsp;nuclei</b>. Granule cells then travel (parallel fibres) to synapse with Purkinje cells}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-221dfb8ab0c95a03cb66439383e3f19d389bb858.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-91c22aeed4f22e0f89d978ba27038f791fc55e29.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Describe the full <b>input --&gt; output </b>of the cerebellar cortex (basic cerebellar circuit)<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Mossy fibres project excitatorily to granule cells (and deep cerebellar nuclei) and climbing fibres project excitatorily directly to Purkinje cell body}}</div><div><br></div><div>2. {{c1::Granule cells synapse on Purkinje fibres}}</div><div><br></div><div>3. {{c1::Purkinje fibres inhibitorily synapse with deep cerebellar nuclei which projects outwards to the spinal cord}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-221dfb8ab0c95a03cb66439383e3f19d389bb858.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-91c22aeed4f22e0f89d978ba27038f791fc55e29.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
T/F The Purkinje cell <b>receives</b> ~200 000 <b>parallel fibre</b> synapses.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::True}}<br><div><br></div><div>T/F Excitation through mossy fibres via parallel fibres have <b>strong</b> excitatory effect on Purkinje fibres.</div></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::False, it has weak excitatory effect (resulting in <b>simple spikes</b>)}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-221dfb8ab0c95a03cb66439383e3f19d389bb858.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-91c22aeed4f22e0f89d978ba27038f791fc55e29.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Where does the <b>mossy fibres </b>of the cerebellar cortex get input information from?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Various origins (primarily pons and spinal cord?)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-221dfb8ab0c95a03cb66439383e3f19d389bb858.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Where does <b>climbing fibres </b>in the cerebellar cortex obtain input information from?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Inferior olivary nucleus in the brainstem}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Purkinje cells recieve input from how many climbing fibres (in the cerebellar cortex)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Each Purkinje cell recieves input from a single fibre!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
How many Purkinje cells does a <b>single climbing fibre&nbsp;</b>synapse on?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::1-10}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Does <b>climbing fibres </b>have a powerful or weak effect on Purkinje cells?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They have a powerful excitatory effect on Purkinje cells!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What kind of <b>spikes </b>do climbing fibres produce?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Complex spikes}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What type of <b>spikes </b>do mossy fibres produce on Purkinje cells (via parallel fibres)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Simple spikes}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-221dfb8ab0c95a03cb66439383e3f19d389bb858.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What is the <b>difference </b>between the <b>climbing fibre </b>and <b>mossy fibre </b>in the cerebellar cortex?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Mossy fibre project to granular cells (parallel fibres) which project weakly to Purkinje cells dendrites producing weak spikes. Also, a Purkinje cell receives <b>many </b>synapses!}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Climbing fibres synapse directly on the Purkinje cell body and is <b>strong </b>producing complex spikes. Also, a Purkinje cell receives <b>only one </b>synapse!}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-221dfb8ab0c95a03cb66439383e3f19d389bb858.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
How does <b>climbing fibres </b>receive input to the cerebellar cortex?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Gets info from inferior olivary nucleus (in brainstem)}}</div><div><br></div><div>2. {{c1::Projects directly to Purkinje cell body and wraps up around dendritic tree (purkinje cell recieves only one synapse from climbing fibre)}}</div>	"<div><br></div><img src=""paste-82b40010e04e634c861fb04a9c7d2e63f78b3fc1.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Do climbing fibres need <b>summation</b>&nbsp;to activate Purkinje fibres? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because only one climbing fibre will project to the Purkinje cell and it is <b>very powerful</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f0fee97b0beac19e93dc25cc413e8457d1aaf529.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Do mossy fibre/granule cell input require summation to activate Purkinje cells? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Yes}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because they give off weak excitatory signals but there are many of them so it is possible to sum!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f0fee97b0beac19e93dc25cc413e8457d1aaf529.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What are <b>simple spikes </b>recorded from Purkinje cells?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They are the Purkinje cell firing through the spatial and temporal summation of mossy fibre/granule cell input}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f0fee97b0beac19e93dc25cc413e8457d1aaf529.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What are <b>complex spikes </b>recorded from Purkinje cells?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Very powerful Purkinje cell discharge due to a climbing fibre}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f0fee97b0beac19e93dc25cc413e8457d1aaf529.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
"This is a recording from Purkinje cells. Which one are simples spikes and which one is complex spikes?<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-e132b16bfc3b8cb9a90074ba38ffed6863c37437.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The beginning is simple spikes while the latter is complex spikes}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-f0fee97b0beac19e93dc25cc413e8457d1aaf529.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
T/F The increased excitation of mossy fibres to the Purkinje cells will increase excitation to the Deep Cerebellar Nuclei.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False. Purkinje cells are inhibitory. Therefore an increased excitation of Purkinje cells (that project to deep cerebellar nuclei) will decrease excitation of deep cerebellar nuclei.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-59068671d0ab56ede6bbe14731ec178290789283.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Input from <b>mossy fibres </b>varies with what? What does this mean simple spikes do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Mossy fibres vary with <b>movement</b>}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Therefore, simple spikes encode movement parameters like speed or strength}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e4598120dfb5962907664c969008c11d9586c9f6.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What is an <b>example </b>of how simple spikes encode movement parameters?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::During movement, firing rates of Purkinje cells are modulated with movement and muscle activity (discharge of the deep cerebellar nuclei reflects Purkinje discharge)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8d037f06b6dbce5234d49f80a10df964e12c462c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
Does input from climbing fibres vary with movement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::no}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d9f06fe3b836fe9572ea3d1d89b37abbc17c22ef.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
If climbing fibre input (producing complex spikes) does not vary with movement, what is its <b>role</b> in the cerebellar cortex?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Long-term effect on how Purkinje cells respond to parallel fibre input and thus <b>controls the frequency of simple spikes</b>. This is thought to play a role in <b>motor learning</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d9f06fe3b836fe9572ea3d1d89b37abbc17c22ef.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What is an <b>example </b>of how climbing fibre input (complex spikes) affect motor learning?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>A monkey was trained to turn door handle --&gt; results in <b>smooth</b> consistent pattern of simple and complex spikes.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>However when <b>load was increased</b> (not trained for this) there is an <b>increase in complex spikes</b> and decrease in simple spikes (depression of mossy fibres).</div><div><br></div><div>After a while of training with the increased load (<b>adapted</b>), it changed<b> back to normal</b> consistent simple spikes/complex spikes.</div><div><br></div><div>This shows that <b>complex spikes tells us something unexpected happened and allows us to learn a new movement</b> to account for it (adaptation)!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4b131eceaab999454b2be1a22cade93ae185a2a2.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-9d8d6b96305e14783787b94761b591b3db134586.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What happens when <b>climbing fibres </b>send input to the Purkinje cell at the same time <b>parallel fibres </b>send input?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Climbing fibres will cause a cellular change that removes receptors for parallel fibres. This means over time, parallel fibres will give the same amount of input to the Purkinje fibre but will cause less EPSP amplitude. This leads to <b>Long Term Depression</b>. }}</div>	"<div>Suggests that <b>motor learning is a mechanism for long-term depression!</b></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-b97188578025269ad2f791c0047f1bf034f6ab71.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-9d8d6b96305e14783787b94761b591b3db134586.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Cerebellum::Overview_and_Cellular_Organization
What makes up the <b>contractile components </b>of a muscle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Myofibrils}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-49cc1457adad41ed1969d8f1f751d9274e3fd53b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What makes up the <b>non-contractile components</b>&nbsp;of the muscle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Capillaries}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Mitochondria}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sarcoplasm}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-49cc1457adad41ed1969d8f1f751d9274e3fd53b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What <b>muscle fibre adaptation </b>will occur for an individual who does <b>low volume </b>and <b>high intensity </b>exercise (resistance training)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No change in specific tension: proportionate increase in contractile and non-contractile components}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Large increase in muscle fibre CSA}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8ddf143db55b0d561f36ade5bb65c07d52450fe4.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What <b>muscle fibre adaptation </b>will occur for an individual who does <b>high volume </b>and <b>low&nbsp;intensity </b>exercise (aerobic training)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Decrease in specific tension: small increase in contractile component and large increase in non-contractile component}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Small increase in muscle fibre CSA}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8ddf143db55b0d561f36ade5bb65c07d52450fe4.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
How come in <b>high volume </b>and <b>low intensity </b>exercise, there is a disproportionate increase in non-contractile components compared to contractile components in the muscle fibre?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is due to the addition of capillaries and the mitochondria, which are necessary for the increased metabolic demands from this type of exercise}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8ddf143db55b0d561f36ade5bb65c07d52450fe4.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
"In this continuum, which side has more <b>specific tension</b>, which side has less?<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3bac6542d663ab3df17881d7e673460599ee5ee1.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The right side has more specific tension then the left side}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-0652f6db8cde324a93fe12492a6a7362bcd93866.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the equation for <b>maximum muscle force</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Specific tension * Physiological cross-sectional area}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a562da978cedc5f602ad4ed9223d120a626acdaf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What are the <b>two determinants </b>of muscle force?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Specific tension}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Physiological cross-sectional area}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a562da978cedc5f602ad4ed9223d120a626acdaf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is <b>specific tension</b>&nbsp;dependent on? (the determinants)<div><br><div>{{c1::The relative amount of contractile and non-contractile components in the fibre}}<br></div></div>	"<img src=""paste-a562da978cedc5f602ad4ed9223d120a626acdaf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>physiological cross-sectional area </b>of a muscle determined by?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Muscle hypertrophy}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Muscle morphology}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a562da978cedc5f602ad4ed9223d120a626acdaf.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What are the <b>two methods </b>to determine cross-sectional area of a muscle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Anatomical (taking slices with MRI or CT scan) or even taking circumference measure}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Physiological}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-88caf6d623ee047fffcbb05264166c677a174dad.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>physiological cross-sectional area </b>method?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cross-sections taken perpendicular to the length of each muscle fibre (allows accurate measurement of pennate muscles (pennate muscles are not all parallel to the axis of the bone)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3eaadd3d14e7d71ec1906caa25a0c86bb727aa29.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is a reason you would use the physiological CSA method over the anatomical CSA method?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Anatomical is easier to do, however it counts muscle fibres parallel to the axis of the bone. So pennate muscles that have fibres inserted at an angle will have some fibres that will not have been counted using this technique. Physiological CSA allows for angled CSA.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3eaadd3d14e7d71ec1906caa25a0c86bb727aa29.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
Why are some muscles <b>pennated</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Fusiform muscles can only have so much sarcomeres in parallel as the tendon has a fixed width. If the muscle fibres attached at an angle, there is more space for sarcomeres to exist in parallel. Therefore pennate muscles can generate more force then non-pennated muscles.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3eaadd3d14e7d71ec1906caa25a0c86bb727aa29.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
If pennated muscles can generate more force then fusiform muscles, then why not have all muscles pennated then?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A fusiform muscle has the muscle fibres pull in the same direction that the tendon changes length (causes larger length change of muscle)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::A pennate muscle pulls on the tendon at an angle (pennation angle). Therefore, for a given amount of force in the muscle, only part of it contributes to length change in the direction of the tendon}}<br></div>	"<div>These characteristics provide information on the main purpose of different muscles.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-ef3c874a6644676b5193334b2807276e164e7799.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the <b>pennation angle</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pennate muscle fibres pull on the tendon at an angle. This is called the pennation angle.}}<br></div>	"<div><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-ef3c874a6644676b5193334b2807276e164e7799.jpg""><div><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the equation for <b>muscle moment</b>? (muscle determinants)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Muscle moment = Moment Arm x Muscle Force*cosθ}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8c023b982a3ab4c214115988356e2520d1d1e26b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
In a <b>real life setting</b>, how do we increase muscle moment?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The <b>joint position </b>must be manipulated to allow the muscle to have a long moment arm: <b>technique training</b>}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The <b>amount of force </b>generated must be increased (increase PSA): <b>resistance training</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8c023b982a3ab4c214115988356e2520d1d1e26b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What are the <b>two types </b>of training that allows for best improvements in muscle moment?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Technique training: better joint angle}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Resistance training: increases PCSA}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8c023b982a3ab4c214115988356e2520d1d1e26b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
"As we shift left or right on the continuum, what happens to specific tension?<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-1e682183bdcc4612ee41268809c5b9cc215faf7e.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The more you go to the left side of the continuum, the less specific tension there will be, and vice versa}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-73931688b446d10cde8a4be95b05a9a887bf3448.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
What is the only <b>determinant </b>of muscle force that cannot be altered by physical activity?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Muscle Morphology}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-bbe71887b2a61d34c5bdb8e2925e10e4f120f6c4.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics
How do we calculate <b>tendon force</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Tendon Force = Muscle Force*cosθ}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8048ca92d417bdc12c56257be4bee1855c4ea6c7.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Muscle_Mechanics

What is the FLHA in OHS?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A formal hazard assessment done at the beginning of every day (or shift) before work begins at a site where conditions may change}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5d885686def99c699c7dc644d87763d47921ee35.jpg"">"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::OHSC_160::Module_2

How is arm abduction in the <b>scapular plane </b>different then regular abduction in the <b>frontal</b>&nbsp;<b>plane</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Regular arm abduction in the frontal plane causes abduction AND extension in relation with the scapula. When abducting in the scapular plane (35 degrees in front of the horizontal) it would result in pure humeral abduction relative to the scapula.}}<br></div>	"According to Tim Keeley, abduction in the sceptic plane is a good way to isolate for supraspinatus pain<div><br></div><div>Do regular arm abduction vs arm abduction in the scapular plane, what's the difference?</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-ab2e763207cf85f21ac50bd91957dc39ebe76f82.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::3D_Motion_Analysis

How is <b>perspective error </b>problematic in 3D motion capture?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because of it, all <b>motion capture is 2D</b>. No <b>quantitative&nbsp;</b>data can be obtained regarding depth (third axis cannot be defined).}}<br></div>	"Perspective Error: Near objects look bigger while far objects look smaller (can't determine distance, aka depth)<div><img src=""paste-bf8d5f98ceceb0ad84406cb7ddffee0516db02c4.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::3D_Motion_Analysis

How can 3D space be created both qualitatively and quantitatively with a single camera?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Steroscopic imaging where one image is viewed by the left eye and the other image is viewed by the right eye. This gives the image a sense of depth (eg: 3D movies)}}<br></div>	"Note: Emma showed be this at her house<div><img src=""paste-361fe6c3ff17da082eabb37cd41c4fe0a94e050c.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::3D_Motion_Analysis
