"Should you have the knees ""<b>pushed out</b>"" when doing a squat? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Nope. Having the knees ""push out"" may make sense when knee is extended, however when the knee is flexed, ligament tension is greatly reduced.}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-c08c9d951f4fd075bc391ed91608920d4da1500b.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::3D_Motion_Analysis
"To achieve a full squat, what rotation should the hip be in? What does this say about the ""Knees Out"" debate?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The hip should be in internal rotation. Externally rotating the hip would push the femoral head downwards, pulling the acetabulum down with it. In this way, externally rotating hips will not allow you to achieve full squat (knees out externally rotates hips)}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-dbd01b8b70c220ae00d727f46ad8210010d38849.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::3D_Motion_Analysis
"Use <b>ground reaction force </b>to debate the ""Knees Out"" squat controversy.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When doing a squat, to maintain static equilibrium, we need a medial ground reaction force. In order to generate this medial-directed ground reaction force, the hip must be <b>actively internally rotated</b>.}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-b43af9a25b27ca4fd4ec05729f59ec26733f70cc.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::3D_Motion_Analysis
What is <b>responsible </b>for generating the medial-directed ground reaction force during squatting type actions? How does this happen?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Glute Medius and minimus. Thus when doing a proper barbell squat (no knees out), elicits an effective method to train these muscles}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::When the thigh is flexed relative to the pelvis (squat), the gluteus medius and minimus change from hip abductors to hip internal rotators! (knees in trains these muscles too!)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2c9ed3a4cf471f6ae9f3cd7c590a402e8c822e62.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::3D_Motion_Analysis
What are the <b>four functions </b>of the digestive system?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Ingestion}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Digestion}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Absorption}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Elimination}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6dde139df0f2ec68977f47a5a96a56a3f5b01ff7.jpg"">"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_2::Digestive_System

How does the body <b>prevent </b>food from entering the trachea?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The epiglottis covers the trachea so that food cannot enter}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-555293899f2f0773b2d4ef33434ccb63178cf85d.jpg"">"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_2::Digestive_System
What happens to the <b>epiglottis </b>when you talk and eat at the same time?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It causes the epiglottis to open, so food can accidentally enter the trachea, causing you to choke!}}<br></div>	"Don't eat and talk at the same time!<div><img src=""paste-c284741de3a94f46e3106b2e68383adc376af6ff.jpg""><br></div>"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_2::Digestive_System

What is the <b>function </b>of sphincters in the stomach?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Prevent food from regurgitating (flowing backward from normal direction)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2a2529a69e5414c13ee91ba34ad95ad231d49a81.jpg"">"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_2::Digestive_System

How would walking up and down a slope change the vertical ground reaction force peaks of a <b>gait cycle</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When walking up a hill, you need more force to be able to travel up thereby causing more force to be presented in the push-off phase.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::When walking down a hill, you need force to be able to stop yourself from falling thereby causing more force to be presented in the weight acceptance phase.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6d2d1cad75843d6156ba36a5713f1f7a5c87576d.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Gait_Biomechanics

In a gait, what are the horizontal reaction forces due to? Explain.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::friction}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::In weight acceptance, a posterior directed force in needed to keep yourself from slipping. "Explain these graphs&nbsp;<div><img src=""paste-bc2534926818aa501c957bb9e872efbfee9460fa.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>Ankle: {{c1::Ao is where the ankle dorsiflexors perform negative work to control the foot as it rotates towards the ground and then positive to pull leg forward. A1 = ankle dorsiflexors in midstance. A2 = positive angle plantar flexor work for pushoff}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Knee:&nbsp;{{c1::K0: flexes in early stance. Is there a difference between activating the gastrocnemius versus the soleus in gait mechanics in the <b>stance phase</b>?<div><br></div><div>Gastrocnemius: {{c1::More ankle dorsiflexion, knee flexion, and less hip extension during stance}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Soleus: {{c1::Less dorsiflexion and greater knee extension during stance (also known as stiff-knee gait)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-712015cd59c90357e5b35c40da2c934562f8fc36.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Gait_Biomechanics
Is there a difference between activating the gastrocnemius versus the soleus in gait mechanics in the&nbsp;<b>swing phase</b>?<div><br></div><div>Gastrocnemius:{{c1::Decrease ankle plantar flexion, increase knee flexion (small), increase hip flexion (small)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Soleus: {{c1::Increase plantar flexion, increase knee flexion (large), increase hip flexion (large)}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-550a75491d545586675380aa5dae375c5d51b31d.jpg""><img src=""paste-5dc40799399e3e35e9934e22c9b09178021c49c3.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-712015cd59c90357e5b35c40da2c934562f8fc36.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Gait_Biomechanics
How come the gastrocnemius flexes the knee in weight bearing position of a gait?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If the gastroc is activated, it will pull on the foot and thigh. However in weight bearing position, the foot is locked, so it will pull on thigh, causing flexion at knee.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a6480f18c96974efd99d9279964e8cc6c6320733.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Gait_Biomechanics
How come an <b>imbalance </b>occurs in the calves when you start to age?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Most muscles tend to atrophy with age including the gastroc. However, the soleus is resistant to atrophy and thus this imbalance occurs as we age.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a6480f18c96974efd99d9279964e8cc6c6320733.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Gait_Biomechanics
What is an exercise that targets <b>only</b> the soleus specifically?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Seated heel-raise. By flexing the knee, the gastroc is placed on slack and the force it can exert is reduced, meaning the effort from the soleus will be increased}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3b695fb46aed854cd95f7e612dc47ba9692cbcce.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Gait_Biomechanics
What is an exercise that targets the gastroc <b>only </b>and not the soleus? Why?<div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Glute-ham-gastroc raise. Only exercise that is known to target gastroc instead of soleus&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>The hamstrings attach on the pelvis and leg, but not the thigh. Only two muscles attach on the thigh that can cause it to rotate into flexion (gastroc and biceps femoris short head)}}<br></div></div>	"<div>BRO! What is the <b>force-length relation</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The maximum amount of force a muscle can generate depends on the muscle's length. As joint angle changes, the muscle is either brought to a shorter or longer length}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-43ecf6d5e089e9e1fe4c6f0b24067fc16ee928d2.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Force_Strength_Relation

How does the myosin/actin filaments explain how sarcomeres can generate the <b>most amount of force</b> in the plateau region?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::In this region, the myosin and actin are overlapped optimally which means that the sarcomere can exert maximum force at these lengths }}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7885815cc64100cd82d98cb622415d54ba5bc35c.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Force_Strength_Relation
How come there is <b>less&nbsp;</b>force generated in the descending limb compared to the plateau region? (actin/myosin)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Actin is farther away from myosin, which means not optimal overlap (Z-disk is far from M-line that no cross-bridges can be formed)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-12be63b17adc3d5c75f723d297094aa0f14eccb5.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Force_Strength_Relation
How come there is less force generated in the <b>ascending limb 2</b>&nbsp;(myosin/actin)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Actin filaments start to bunch up and push against each other, which exerts a force pushing the actin filaments apart.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a1325278dbbb5016ac9a374277b05b5d5aeae4f9.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Force_Strength_Relation
How come there is less force generated in the <b>ascending limb 1</b>&nbsp;(myosin/actin)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Z-disks are so dam close to the m-line that it starts to push against the myosin filaments itself, reducing force even further!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-62e614e5a3055e5278115ce28e2b32e9c8a3f070.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Force_Strength_Relation

How does the basal ganglia receive input?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The caudate and putamen receive excitatory input from cerebral cortex}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-a4dbc8e3b12967ae44d7c55f1847f880be04fd19.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
How does the basal ganglia <b>output </b>information?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Caudate and putamen project to globus pallidus internal segment and then project to the thalamus and brainstem (typically inhibit target cells in the thalamus and brainstem)}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-a4dbc8e3b12967ae44d7c55f1847f880be04fd19.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
Explain the whole <b>input </b>and <b>output </b>process of the basal ganglia circuitry.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Gets excite input from cortex to striatum --&gt; projects to globus pallidus internal --&gt; projects inhibitory output to thalamus and brainstem}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-793b39305097ca44b5617743cd7b343c28ef2437.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia

What is the <b>direct route </b>of signal flow through the basal ganglia?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cortex --&gt; (glutamate - excitatory) --&gt; Putamen --&gt; inhibitory --&gt; Globus pallidus internal --&gt; inhibitory (GABA) --&gt; thalamus --&gt; excitatory --&gt; Cortex *premotor regions*}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0179dabc34222e41fdf7e5213ab3950cbb375284.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What is the <b>indirect route </b>of signal flow through the basal ganglia?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cortex --&gt; Excitatory (GABA) --&gt; putaman --&gt; Inhibitory --&gt; Globus Pallidus external --&gt; Inhibits --&gt; Subthalamic nucleus --&gt; Excitatory --&gt; globus pallidus internal --&gt; thalamus --&gt; Cortex *premotor regions*}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0179dabc34222e41fdf7e5213ab3950cbb375284.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
<i>T/F </i>In the direct route of signal movement in the basal ganglia, the more input from the cortex, the less excitation of the cortex. Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False! Cortex inhibits cells in the Gpi, which reduces inhibitory output of GPi thus allowing less inhibition of the thalamus and <b>MORE </b>excitation of the cortex}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-44f84fe3aa03734ced1dcdff99e914bd7bf85f1c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What does activation of the direct route in the basal ganglia result in?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Facilitation of movement. This is because more output = increase excitation of cortex}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-44f84fe3aa03734ced1dcdff99e914bd7bf85f1c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What does activation of the <b>indirect route </b>of the basal ganglia result in?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Inhibition of movement!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-dbf62027f244a59e9eee25fb7cb9fec0c88a8468.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
How does the activation of the indirect route of the basal ganglia result in <b>inhibition </b>of movement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cortex will excite the putamen --&gt; increased inhibition to GP external --&gt; decreased inhibition to STN --&gt; increased excitation to GP internal --&gt; increased inhibition to thalamus and therefore cortex (inhibiting movement)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-dbf62027f244a59e9eee25fb7cb9fec0c88a8468.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
How does the activation of the direct route of the basal ganglia result in <b>excitation&nbsp;</b>of movement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cortex will excite the putamen --&gt; increased inhibition to GP internal --&gt; decreased inhibition to thalamus --&gt; increased excitation to cortex (facilitates movement))}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b7b1192f882c1494ba14c05bb725c1b2c566efeb.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
Thalamic cells are&nbsp;{{c1::tonically}} active	"<img src=""paste-114f2dc0557e88c344aa4c922b07e2bfd150fe8b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What does the <b>dopaminergic path </b>do for the direct and indirect pathways of the basal ganglia?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Supports excitation in direct route and inhibition in indirect route! Essentially increases movement even more. }}<br></div>	"Remember that the indirect route inhibits movement. So if it inhibits the indirect route that means it increases movement!<div><img src=""paste-0dc055bdb6266a196e61965ff418be714ee4f064.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia

What is the function of <b>Dopamine </b>in the basal ganglia pathways?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Controls the balance between the two pathways by landing on D1 and D2 receptors in the <b>putamen</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d9a687c5530d70c6598ee28059bf683a0a618c0e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
Where is <b>dopamine </b>released that effects the basal ganglia?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Released from the substantia nigra pars compacta}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d9a687c5530d70c6598ee28059bf683a0a618c0e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What are the two different types of receptors that dopamine can bind to in the putamen?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::D1 = Facilitates direct pathway}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::D2 = Facilities indirect pathway}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d9a687c5530d70c6598ee28059bf683a0a618c0e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What is the <b>net affect </b>of dopamine on movement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::More dopamine = more facilitation of movement. Less dopamine = less facilitation of movement}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d9a687c5530d70c6598ee28059bf683a0a618c0e.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
Explain the different effects dopamine has on direct and indirect pathways of the basal ganglia.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::D1 = Excitatory to striatal neurons that project to the direct route}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::D2 = Inhibitory to striatal neurons that project to the indirect route}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It total = Facilitates movement even more}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-77f0e018880a8efc6306ce33649f21f7dbf54918.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
Is the basal ganglia <b>somatotopically organised</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Yes!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-336ac1481af9684921d02ae031b896e6b81ada78.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
When does <b>striatal input </b>cells increase activity?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::during movement, some to movement direction, some to specific muscles, and some related to movement context}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-336ac1481af9684921d02ae031b896e6b81ada78.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What does the <b>timing </b>of activity look like for the basal ganglia?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Timing is similar to the SMA = active well before movement onset}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-336ac1481af9684921d02ae031b896e6b81ada78.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
GPi cells (output) have {{c1::high spontaneous}} discharge.	"<img src=""paste-336ac1481af9684921d02ae031b896e6b81ada78.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What does to GPi do constantly to the thalamus?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It tonically inhibits the thalamus and thus cortical excitability}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-336ac1481af9684921d02ae031b896e6b81ada78.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What is <b>hypokinesia</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Disorder that results in less movement}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c426d23152ad21f4b260a8e242d2d8cc886b13e6.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What is <b>hyperkinesia</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A basal ganglia movement disorder that causes more movement}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c426d23152ad21f4b260a8e242d2d8cc886b13e6.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What causes <b>hypokinetic disorders </b>(in regards to the basal ganglia)? Give an example.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Degeneration of substantia nigra which produces dopamine. This causes less excitation to direct pathway and less inhibition of indirect pathway}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Eg: Parkinson's disease (hard time moving)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2925a3caec38705f86f300da1cc01e5d66c92024.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What causes <b>Hyperkinetic disorders</b>? Give an example.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Impaired activity in indirect pathway, which means direct pathway predominates (not much inhibition of the thalamus). Net result is disinhibition of thalamus which means its too active.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Eg: Huntington's, Tourettes}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-75bf2e01da2b9f8e7a4cd108a1ce370ba1a3a510.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_6::Basal_Ganglia
What are <b>Extrapyramidal disorders</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Disorders to movement that are outside of the pyramidal (corticospinal system). This usually refers to disorders of the basal ganglia.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6fe49c2ea4b67b65b36769546958108f826b3f01.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are the <b>two types </b>of extrapyramidal disorders?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Hypokinetic and hyperkinetic disorders}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6fe49c2ea4b67b65b36769546958108f826b3f01.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
"Describe the history of <b>Parkinson's Disease</b>.<div><br></div><div>1817:&nbsp;{{c1::Dr. James Parkinson published ""Essay on the Shaking Palsy""}}</div><div><br></div><div>1920's:&nbsp;{{c1::Found that Parkinson's patients had extensive degeneration of substantia nigra}}</div><div><br></div><div>1960's:&nbsp;{{c1::Parkinson's due to degeneration of dopamine in the SN (pars compacta). Therefore attempts were made to replenish dopamine using L-DOPA}}</div><div><br></div><div>1980's: {{c1::Drug addicts who took heroin (MPTP) started to exhibit Parlinson-like symptoms}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-6cd3a69274bafcf4f7f8f91cc89aa0237c02c506.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
How does&nbsp;<b>resting tremor </b>progress?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Starts with pill-rolling tremor of the hand which eventually goes to one or both sides of the body. Tremors reduced during movement, and <b>absent </b>during sleep}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9525c0d2e15b8f6f874dd6b0d2cdf9f44e541aa3.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are the three <b>cardinal symptoms </b>of Parkinson's disease?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Resting tremor}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Rigidity}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Bradykinesia}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ed83a1e7b8c96c3f79c53e663fe509975a3be1a0.jpg""><img src=""paste-4fbf215c75508df2777d9ced19807118cddb9f15.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are three symptoms of Parkinson's disease that are <b>not </b>cardinal symptoms?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Postural instability}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Festination: small quick steps}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Akinesia: inability to initiate movement (freezing)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ed83a1e7b8c96c3f79c53e663fe509975a3be1a0.jpg""><img src=""paste-4fbf215c75508df2777d9ced19807118cddb9f15.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What does the SNpc of a healthy individual <b>look</b> like vs an individual with Parkinson's? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A healthy person has a dark looking SNpc vs a Parkinson's individual who has a pale colour.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because dopaminergic neurons contain neuromelanin, a pigment that gives a dark colour}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-15b32e00413e5177455ed60d989703081949fd11.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
Parkinson's disease typically occur over&nbsp;{{c1::5-10 years}}	"<img src=""paste-0c81504e1bc5209644563d61eddd54d6194617ec.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What amount of dopaminergic neuron lost begins to incur Parkinson's symptoms?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::60-70% loss of dopaminergic cells in SNpc}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0c81504e1bc5209644563d61eddd54d6194617ec.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
"<i>T/F </i>Parkinson's occurs acutely.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False, typically it is the gradual loss of dopaminergic cells over time</div><div><img src=""paste-1b4f34ed61bd13fcde4e1229e9fadca152da208f.jpg"">}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-3154896c99a6010ff2baebe1ec34efa602a92520.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What is the average <b>life expectancy </b>of an individual after symptoms of Parkinson's start to appear?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::15-25 years}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3ddbc70ee14f961b6cc1865d77f11e165e970d53.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
Describe the <b>direct pathway </b>of the basal ganglia.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Excitatory Cortex --&gt; Inhibitory Striatum --&gt; Inhibitory GPi/SNpr --&gt; Excitatory Thalamus --&gt; Cortex (overall facilitates movement</div><div><br></div><div><b>Striatum excitatorily modulated by SNpc (dopamine)</b>)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-55355da90aac5e4acab660f423558c685fe998a7.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
Why is the <b>indirect pathway </b>of the basal ganglia known as <b>indirect</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because it has an extra pathway in the STN and GPe which bypasses the striatum and excites the GPi/SNpr}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5b35c42421e546c5a2230b3f90b8b54b764ddb7d.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
Explain the <b>indirect pathway </b>of the basal ganglia.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<div>Excitatory cortex --&gt; Inhibitory striatum --&gt; Inhibitory GPe --&gt; Excitatory STN --&gt; Inhibitory GPi/SNpr --&gt; Excitatory Thalamus --&gt; Cortex (overall inhibits movement</div><div><br></div><div>SNpc (dopaminergic) will decrease striatum inhibtion on GPe which facilitates movement (modulatory))</div>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5b35c42421e546c5a2230b3f90b8b54b764ddb7d.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What happens to the <b>direct and indirect pathways</b> of an individuals basal ganglia when they have Parkinson's Disease?<div><br></div><div><br></div><div>Direct Route: {{c1::</div><div>Decrease inhibition to GPi/SNpr which increases inhibition of the thalamus}}</div><div><br></div><div>Indirect Route: {{c1::Decrease inhibition of striatal neurons (more inhibition from striatum to GPe) --&gt; GPe decreases inhibition on STN which increases excitation on GPi)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-35e4e903ed896a107a62b9d1038603908d3cff9d.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are the <b>two targets </b>for treatment for Parkinson's disease?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Increase dopamine substantia nigra}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Disrupt excessive GPi output}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-76556c99020f8f64fa901bb5abda68382fb50bd2.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are some ways to <b>increase </b>dopamine in the substantia nigra?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::L-DOPA}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Stem cell or dopaminergic neuron implant}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-76556c99020f8f64fa901bb5abda68382fb50bd2.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are some ways to disrupt excessive GPi output?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Surgical lesions}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Deep brain stimulation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-76556c99020f8f64fa901bb5abda68382fb50bd2.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
How does <b>L-DOPA </b>effect the brain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::L-DOPA crosses the blood brain barrier and is converted to dopamine in the SNpc}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ac50646c522210474588127803168a392eca3e8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
How does the <b>treatment curve</b> look like for L-DOPA?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Often a dramatic reduction of symptoms in the first year but declines with use and over time}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ac50646c522210474588127803168a392eca3e8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
Why does the treatment curve of L-DOPA decline over time?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It can no longer offset the death of dopaminergic neruons in the striatum. Therefore no matter how much more dopamine you put in the brain, theres just not enough neurons there to uptake it.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ac50646c522210474588127803168a392eca3e8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What happens if you <b>overdose </b>on dopamine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::May result in hyperkinetic symptoms = more movement}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ac50646c522210474588127803168a392eca3e8.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What is the affects of <b>implanted </b>dopaminergic cells into the substantia nigra?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Increase in the number of dopamine receptors in the striatum 1-3 years later (very promising!)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-80f475c8f06af2804be4598b1302348df51abd6b.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are two types of lesions we can use to reduce Parkinson's symptoms?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::STN lesion}}<br></div><div>{{c1::GPi lesion (pallidotomy)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f049237674fa1d36f4b2f5d8236bcfac7453ed2c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
How does a STN lesion reduce Parkinson's symptoms?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::STN is what excites the GPi which inhibits movement!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f049237674fa1d36f4b2f5d8236bcfac7453ed2c.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders

What is <b>Deep Brain Stimulation</b>? (Reducing Parkinson's symptoms)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A lead is put into the brain that delivers electrical stimulation to the thalamus}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f0452836a31a163815b3c9e8ea68f630df558e14.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are the <b>5&nbsp;steps </b>of DBS implantation for treatment for Parkinson's disease?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Metal frame over head}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::MRI or CT used to map coordinates within brain (see where thalamus is)}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Hole is made for access}}</div><div><br></div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Target is located by listening to characteristic of discharge of cells}}</div><div><br></div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Once target is located, stimulating permits an even more precise localisaion}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e5400f646fc770968dcdea7ee458eb06b34e1257.jpg""><img src=""paste-7b8a8db12a7008dbfbffe987a6262b7146a4df46.jpg""><img src=""paste-c4520cac660ddc51ff060a74d7cdfd23553f3a31.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What is <b>Huntington's Disease</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is an inherited neurodegenerative hyperkinetic disease caused by loss of GABAergic neurons in the striatum (atropphy of caudate and putamen <b>(ask scott about cause)</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a725744eac8794b9e602a0e2326d6476b089a83f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What are the <b>symptoms </b>for Huntington's disease?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Abnormal movements, mild clumsiness, and eccentric behaviour, irregular slow writhing movements (chorea) and gradually worsening dementia}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a725744eac8794b9e602a0e2326d6476b089a83f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What is the <b>treatment </b>for Huntington's Disease?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is no known treatment RIP}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a725744eac8794b9e602a0e2326d6476b089a83f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders
What is the <b>cause </b>of Huntington's disease?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Atrophy of the caudate and putamen (striatum) which decreases GABAergic projection to GPi/SNpr <b>AND </b>GPe. Indirect pathway is more vulnerable and therefore result in hyperkinetic symptoms due to M1 compensating by increasing drive}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-198805ee211c3fe8049059ca8546ccf954374b07.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders

"How does Huntington's disease progress over time? (refer to direct and indirect pathways?<div><br></div><div>Direct Pathway: {{c1::Neurons start to die as disease progresses resulting in hypokinetic symptoms (bradykinesia)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Indirect Pathway: {{c1::Neurons here are <b>most vulnerable </b>to death and therefore result in hyperkinetic symptoms (Huntington's ""chorea"")}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-cd7e058acfeaa73ab6720b8e6d6ca3e980f1ba3f.jpg"">"	KIN_302::Post_Midterm::Section_7::Movement_Disorders

Is lumbar flexion <b>bad</b> compared to lumbar extension? Think of what Stu Mcgill said!<div><br></div><div>{{c1::In the lumbar spine, the maximum extension (beyond neutral) is about 16 degrees&nbsp; (1-5 degree at each FSU whereas flexion is 3x that. Therefore lumbar extension is perhaps a greater concern since so little motion can occur towards extension!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8ef10e8be9691577e39f03faf0277812cae0e607.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Spine_Biomechanics
What is the <b>maximum flexion </b>vs <b>maximum extension </b>of the lumbar spine? What is the <b>neutral zone </b>in the spine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Where the ligaments in the ligamentous spine are slack and some rotation is required to take up this slack. The place in which when a moment of force is first applied to an FSU, very little moment is required to cause rotation.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ffb8abcb8c413f5a861f6e26e5cdfbd258269d42.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Spine_Biomechanics
What is the <b>problem </b>with the neutral zone in the spine? What does the body do to decrease this problem?<div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is associated with instability as there is little resistance to motion here}}<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::To increase this stability, muscles are activated to generate muscular forces to stabilize the FSU in the neutral zone.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ffb8abcb8c413f5a861f6e26e5cdfbd258269d42.jpg"">"	KIN_306::Post_Midterm::Spine_Biomechanics

What is <b>voiding </b>in terms of the urinary system?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A broad term that describes the condition where there is poor coordination between the bladder muscle and the urethra.}}<br></div>	"Can include frequent urination (Sadeed? :0)<div><img src=""paste-bfe691aacc9682440c57029cf1c5c5c25a4c30e1.jpg""><br></div>"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_2::Urinary_System::Chapter_7
How does the Kidneys produce urine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Blood enters kidney through left and right renal arteries}} --&gt; {{c1::arterioles}} --&gt; {{c1::capilliaries}} --&gt; {{c1::Glomeruli filter blood (becomes urine)}} --&gt; {{c1::Glomerular (Bowman) capsule}} --&gt; {{c1::renal tubule (reabsorption)}} --&gt; whats left --&gt; {{c1::collecting tubule}} --&gt; {{c1::renal pelvis}} --&gt; {{c1::ureter}} --&gt; {{c1::urinary bladder}} --&gt; {{c1::urethra}} --&gt; {{c1::outside (urinary meatus)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-f192a98eb4aef4f3e8a14b91da033229f271839d.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-3936b9109493418369e96d12b634285d541c2314.jpg""><br></div>"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_2::Urinary_System::Chapter_7

Describe the <b>menstrual cycle</b>.<div><br></div><div>Day 1-5:&nbsp;{{c1::Blood cells, endometrial cells, and glandular secretions discharge from the body}}</div><div><br></div><div>Day 6-12: {{c1::Ovum grows in the follicle (estrogen aids in repair of endometrium)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Day 13-14:&nbsp;{{c1::Egg leaves ovary and passes through fallopian tube}}</div><div><br></div><div>Day 15-28:&nbsp;{{c1::Corpus luteum secretes progesterone; the uterus lining builds up}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-8dc09a7063a80c1761e91d7f3682b275df80d1a8.jpg"">"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_2::Female_Reproductive_System

What are all the <b>waves </b>of an electrocardiogram? What do each represent?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::P wave: excitation of the atria just before contraction}}<br></div><div>{{c1::QRS wave: excitation wave over the ventricles as the ventricles contract;}}<br></div><div>{{c1::T wave: electrical recovery and relaxation of ventricles}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7d4d474019310b74d0e1ad705ba1c007b4b613f8.jpg"">"	Emergency_Medical_Responder::ITMS_100::Assessment_3::Cardiovascular_System_Chapter_11

What is the difference between the <b>fitness after-effect </b>and the <b>fatigue after-effect</b>?<div><br></div><div>Fitness:&nbsp;{{c1::positive physiological response}}</div><div>Fatigue:&nbsp;{{c1::negative physiological response}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-625e310bef95c16bf5e43ab646c0202df432d5d5.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_1::Fitness-Fatigue_Model
What causes the <b>fitness after-effect</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Mostly neural in nature: coactivation of intrafusal fibres, decreased autogenic inhibition, and up-regulation of alpha- and beta- receptors with greater catecholamine release}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b1af56330948b973077237515d1f4614197da1af.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_1::Fitness-Fatigue_Model
What causes <b>fatigue after-effects</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Neural and metabolic in nature:}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Neural:&nbsp;{{c1::down regulation of alpha + beta receptors and decreasing catecholamines}}</div><div><br></div><div>Metabolic:&nbsp;{{c1::decreased storage and availability of substrates}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-00716a6c11e9da1dee617b81c1b71e26e146cba8.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_1::Fitness-Fatigue_Model
Higher volume training results in&nbsp;{{c1::decrease}} in circulating testosterone while higher intensity training results in&nbsp;{{c1::increase}} in circulating testosterone.	"<img src=""paste-a4f1c21f2b2ce6f03214aafaf3220ea45b86e070.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_1::Fitness-Fatigue_Model

What is the <b>best </b>evidence of fitness and fatigue after-effects?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Posttetanic potentiaion (or PAP) where there is an increase in muscle twitch force following voluntary or involuntary maximal contractions}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe59ab806e8badc63a55718936225ce4a7779d23.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_1::Fitness-Fatigue_Model
How does <b>posttetanic potentiation </b>cause an increase in muscle twitch force?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::maximal contraction will cause a decrease in Cpr however it also results inn phosphorylation of regulatory myosin light chain and H-reflex increasing the rate of actin and myosin}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6a75567257ba260787e6cebfbb43bf0931a296e5.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_1::Fitness-Fatigue_Model

What are the <b>4 things </b>a philosopher of ethical theory wants to talk about?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Nature or status of morality: does it derive from God or social contract?}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Nature and meaning of moral judgements: Is there a complete right or wrong or is it subjective?}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Fundamental rules, principles, and values justifying moral judgements: is happiness the ultimate value or are there multiple? "Describe the <b>progression/history</b> of anatomy.<div><br></div><div>130-200 AD:&nbsp;{{c1::Started with a physician named Claudius Galen who dissected bodies and wrote treatises (manuscripts) on anatomy/med}}</div><div><br></div><div>1400 AD:&nbsp;{{c1::Dissection theatre; dissections performed by anatomists while med students watched}}</div><div><br></div><div>1452-1519:&nbsp;{{c1::Leonardo da Vinci being a badass; detailed painting on anatomy}}</div><div><br></div><div>1514-1564:&nbsp;{{c1::Andreas Vesalius writes the first ""modern"" anatomy book (Corporis Humani Fabrica}}</div><div><br></div><div>20th century:&nbsp;{{c1::Progression of anatomy books from atlas --&gt; manual --&gt; classic Gray's anatomy}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-c5ce68e0079614e3993ce5cc4fb23310994379e1.jpg""><img src=""paste-d0c20d06d0455d7b957f67f7e6e350d8c545197b.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-36c7ce24629172cd8243416c9e3f5da9d61e5d92.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-55e00b54e240059064ebdc2756710bc740b1469f.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-d04282e7ca6cca5e333fda45a033e43794946498.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Anatomy_Kinesiology

"What is the <b>process </b>in which to dissect and find the <b>great saphenous vein</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Locate ASIS and pubic crest and find mid point}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Find medial/lateral aspects of the leg just below tibial tuberosity and find mid point</div><div><img src=""paste-d1cd8fbf4ce47e9b118228af72299e316b0d2ec6.jpg"">}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Imagine line between these two mid points and create incision (don't go too deep --&gt; proximal to distal)</div><div><img src=""paste-2d33873b1a99c7ed3b1cd96902cf2ebe040977ee.jpg"">}}</div><div><br></div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Make diagonal incision from pubic crest to ASIS (follow the inguinal ligament</div><div><img src=""paste-20c33020cdd0f127e553833b22136badd09aceb9.jpg"">)}}</div><div><br></div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Make horizontal incisions away from vertical incision distally (medial and lateral)</div><div>}}</div><div><br></div><div>-- Locate superficial fascia --</div><div><br></div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::locate deep fascia lata covering quads</div><div><img src=""paste-1319127f07a9e02a3c870e342f9bfab9b9d9f49f.jpg"">&nbsp;(lateral side is more thick and contains the iliotibial band)}}</div><div><br></div><div>7.&nbsp;{{c1::reflect superficial fascia and skin from deep fascia lata, exposing anterior, medial, and lateral surfaces of thigh}}</div><div><br></div><div>-- Locate and clean the great saphenous vein -- (great saph v. runs on top of deep fascia lata)</div><div><br></div><div>8.&nbsp;{{c1::separate vein from superficial fascia layer</div><div><img src=""paste-3e9e9b9c5ab0216362072c435ac06408c7ff1dc4.jpg"">}}</div><div><br></div><div>9.&nbsp;{{c1::Remove inguinal lymph nodes (12 -29). Remove these from superficial fascia}}</div>"	"Anterior Thigh<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a9cc8f0363a075b34093ddab754dbeac85e4a394.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3c0af65be78294e5d94e5d16bcd52d55fc6fb9a0.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Lab::Lower_Extremity::Thigh

Explain the theory of the <b>stimulus-fatigue-recovery-adaptation</b>. What is the problem with this theory?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::fatigue accumulates in proportion to strength and duration of stimulus. Involution will occur if training density is not met (stress applied with sufficient frequency).}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It assumes that fitness and fatigue share a cause and effect relationship.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-15435680dbe325e70eefd47b542f1407f003ee21.jpg""><img src=""paste-c975f0ecf298afb91a8bbf13503f1b4bdc3cb21b.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Foundational_Models_of_Stress_Response
Why is the <b>fitness-fatigue theory </b>considered more modern and appropriate?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is a two factor model that suggests an <b>inverse </b>relationship between fitness and fatigue stipulated by after-effects. For every stress applied, there will be both fitness and fatigue after-effects}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-deb0af065c10f95f629ef9ce3375c5cefd4ecd1a.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-96a036324a51c11ad14bdd7eb7e832d25190b87c.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Foundational_Models_of_Stress_Response
What are the <b>implications </b>to saying that fitness and fatigue have an <b>inverse </b>relationship?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is no way for you to get more gains without occurring more fatigue}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4f87c15ac774d1e6e94483d4cd6bf3bc2ff44441.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Foundational_Models_of_Stress_Response
<b>Planned overeaching</b> gets super specific once you start to use this model...<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Fitness-Fatigue Theory}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-38ac5aab5b1c683dcb99db97d0c981b15cbba95d.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Foundational_Models_of_Stress_Response

What are <b>good indicators </b>of an ethical judgement?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If it is a judgement of what we should or ought to do (obviously not fail-safe)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3d5e93a3218592fa8b39c3f0213486ac74805f45.jpg"">"	KIN_401::What_Is_Ethics
What are <b>examples </b>of bad ethical arguments?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Arbitariness: having no reason for the position you take}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Over-reliance on feelings}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Partisan behaviour: biased (favouring friends/family)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because a respected authority tells you}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Self-interest: selfish}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Whataboutism: sidestepping answer by shifting focus to something bad someone else did}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Bothsidesism: falsely equating both sides of an issue when clearly one side bears more/all responsibility}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d92413dca2c9a00ad63b9907069a05a72b09170c.jpg""><img src=""paste-6d835ddfb9d0972cb717e5196850dd4384d901b4.jpg""><img src=""paste-9f74249af1273bf4f809ff8dd71bf27195cee2ee.jpg"">"	KIN_401::What_Is_Ethics
What does the&nbsp;<b>utilitarian moral theory </b>urge us to do?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Always act so as to maximise the sum total of welfare among everyone affected by what we do}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-12232a588e263d9d57e547a8fe84155afbbb5f5a.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What is the <b>utilitarian </b>criterion of <b>rightness </b>of particular actions?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::An action is right if and only if in the situation there was no alternative to it which would have resulted in a greater sum total of welfare in the world}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-89f87ade8d7b7f9eca28e9c9c4f50ff8187c83c1.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What are the <b>three versions </b>of utiliariansim?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Classic utilitarianism: maximize happiness (also called <b>hedonistic</b>)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::preference utilitarianism: only the satisfaction of preferences that we hold for our own loves are of importance to our welfare}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Perfectionist utilitarianism: characterizing a life worth living}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-d54c2c0d76c634fe9dea7b279f60e223ec45a4a9.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-d516db37a4296f57061e2501e5058efc3880c4d0.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-14cce573cdc5bb03c4efe68ae78084b5e7841234.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What is <b>hedonistic utilitarianism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::To increase our welfare, we must maximise happiness or well-being. This form is measured through what we directly experience at the moment and asking: Does it feel better than a minute ago? The same?}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-360495e73e1a1a44caa7ece7a21a697951f816a0.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-3eff9169fafbf26138410af68c3fd65be2f53299.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What does <b>hedonistic utiliarianism</b>&nbsp;assume?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Assumes that there is only <b>one </b>hedonistic dimension of our lives. At each moment we feel what we feel and that is it. Our degree of pleasure is a quality of our total experience}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-50ef6c3c97a60de678c0b9f2fbaa444ef4422356.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What is <b>preference utilitarianism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Only the satisfaction of preferences, or desires, that we hold for our own lives (self-regarding preferences) are of importance to our welfare; moreover, only the satisfaction of intrinsic preferences matter.</div><div><b>It is only when my intrinsic desire for happiness is satisfied that my welfare is increased</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-04788d5fab33c2056c7322a37c14e845239483d4.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
How is <b>preference</b> utilitarianism different then <b>hedonistic</b> utilitarianism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Hedonistic simply states that there is only one form of well-being (happiness) that we experience whereas preference states that there are higher and lower forms of well-being where we should maximize the higher form.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c8659463301026f970ca35e7f1751cbd4a9f7e21.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What is a <b>problem</b>&nbsp;with preference utilitarianism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::What if two persons reach conflicting verdicts on a certain kind of pleasure, which of them are we to trust? Why search the higher pleasure rather than the lower, if the lower feels better?}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Often abandon preferences}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-ec9d6bf8a7f65519d97a5770455c4a6e3c3fed4e.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-baebdfbdbd668d5299ee2f93d427e25ca6c661df.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-9670dfd45814c7269e6e5601ff56828b32ccebf5.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
Both <b>hedonism </b>and <b>preferentialism </b>(utilitarianism) present us with&nbsp;{{c1::subjectivist}} notions of welfare.	"<img src=""paste-15cdd76d1f439878bae5d211115eb236f3c35e20.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What is the <b>objectivist </b>version of utilitarianism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::perfectionism}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-52a0ec0326562a17373d4f5a7b4543d62d74c2cb.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
What is <b>perfectionist utilitarianism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::An objective way of looking at utilitarianism where an increase in welfare is from aquiring important knowledge, friends, or certain things.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-52a0ec0326562a17373d4f5a7b4543d62d74c2cb.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg17_24
"What was Robert Nozick's famous <b>experiment-machine </b>argument against hedonism in defence of a perfectionist notion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::He argues that there is something that matters to us besides just experience (hedonistic perspective). What is the <b>main concept </b>of utilitarianism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is a definite right or wrong. There is no such thing as shades of grey (decided by tallies)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-475e147accc35dde2509f46aac69c1409906fb7a.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
"What is <b>Act Utilitarianism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A consequentialist where you try to maximize the good. Tallies up positive and negative consequences and the action with the highest score is the one you ""ought"" to take (no grey areas) }}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-9ab4519883f97b6120b4207435ca041f8cfea131.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
Using Act Utilitarianism, if one choice tallies up to 17 and another tallies up to 178, is the first choice just less good?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, using this framework, it's flat our wrong}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ab4519883f97b6120b4207435ca041f8cfea131.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
With <b>hedonist </b>act utilitarianism, what do we maximize?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::pleasure --&gt; Bentham's Felicific Calculus}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f28969ff29e2663baa7521e6c928dfdabac6da90.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism

What is <b>Rule Utilitarianism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Instead of calculating everything in which gives the most pleasure, there are rules devised that when everyone follows, create the greatest good. (more generalized)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-aa240127efbcb3fb0de10f40464e9aa2f146ee61.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
How would a <b>rule </b>vs <b>act </b>utilitarianism act in the Organ Transplant problem or sacrifice wealth to save poor scenario?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::AU would do it for the greater good, however it would be easy for RU to solve. Because if <b>everyone </b>sacrificed their organs, it wouldn't benefit the greater good}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5a41978e8b53622c3bef79b2cf91f9ab49baea08.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
What is the <b>trolley thought experiment</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The train track problem, deciding who to kill}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-16cc8b4ccd7102c4431667ba6f64051d2326b247.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
How would an <b>act utilitarinist </b>act in the trolley experiment?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They would consider the person there, friendships, families, and weigh how much pleasure it gives you}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-15d8f081f33de762f011a2956bb1a9380082bb97.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
How would a <b>rule utilitarianist </b>act in the trolley thought experiment?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They would save the side with the most amount of people regardless of relationships (if everyone saved specific people, then in the end, it wouldn't result in the greatest good)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-15d8f081f33de762f011a2956bb1a9380082bb97.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
What is the problem with AU and RU?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They only count actual or expected consequences. Doesn't consider consequences that are neither actual nor expected.}}<br></div>	"Eg: Peeping Tom example;<div><br></div><div>AU: is your welfare decreased more than the Peeping Tom's increase? (especially if you don't even know)&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>RU: Everyone benefits. He gets pleasure seeing you undress while you don't get any negatives. Everyone can follow this rule.</div><div><img src=""paste-436cc48f6cdb5c6bb5a686ef6a338d9294391572.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism

What are some <b>possible </b>mechanisms of neural adaptation from resistance training?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::increased activation of prime movers in a specific movement and appropriate changes in the activation of synergists and antonagonists}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fc725a57df5865b78faa995533483c3d24fc0b21.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_2_3::Sale_1988

What are the <b>3 rules </b>for a hamstrings muscle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Have a proximal attachment in the ischial tuberosity}}<br><br></div><div>{{c1::Have a distal attachment in the tibia or fibula}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Innervated by the sciatic nerve}}<br></div>	"- BFL<div>- ST</div><div>- SM</div><div><img src=""paste-c7c4afadd86643b0d8cfa989c120c1462940ddd3.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh

Why is the biceps femoris brevis and adductor magnus not a hamstrings muscle?<div><br></div><div>Brevis: {{c1::Doesn't have prox attachment at the ischial tuberosity and is not innervated by sciatic nerve}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Posterior head Magnus:&nbsp;{{c1::Doesn't have a distal attachment to either tibia or fibula}}</div><div><br></div><div>Anterior head magnus:&nbsp;{{c1::doesn't have attachment on ischial tuberosity or distal attachment on tibia or fibula}}</div>	"- BFL<div>- ST</div><div>- SM</div><div><img src=""paste-c7c4afadd86643b0d8cfa989c120c1462940ddd3.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh

(pulls it medially)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The vastus medialis oblique which attaches to the medial side of the patella.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because the quadriceps tendon causes a pull on the patella laterally (without oblique, it would pop the knee out)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ce331499614cefccb62a0af9850527dcc6daa1f4.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh

What is the difference in action between the adductor magnus <b>long head&nbsp;</b>and all the other adductor muscle groups? Why does it do this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It causes hip extension instead of hip flexion}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It does this because it's line of pull is slightly more posterior}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7c633322687be7eef134e57876178650f25426be.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh
Why does the adductor muscle group cause internal rotation of the femur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because of the curvature of the femur --&gt; pulling slightly in front of the axis of rotation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e85fadd0e1314c3c8e573cc2f0efa063ee3a3bfd.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh
What could be a <b>reason </b>for groin injury when doing high demanding tasks of the adductor muscle groups?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is because our adductor longus/magnus do hip extension in hip flexion and hip flexion in hip extension. When we run super hard, our adductor muscles will quickly go from concentric extensors to eccentric flexors which cause groin injury in this area!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-08608e2407751122ead5f5b50e48f4a30b19891b.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh
At how many degrees of hip flexion does our adductor muscle group turns into an extensor?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::60-70 degrees}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-08608e2407751122ead5f5b50e48f4a30b19891b.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh
What can you do to <b>prevent </b>groin injuries?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Possibly strengthen the hip extensor muscles like gluteus max and adductor magnus posterior so that the adductor muscle groups don't have to do hip extension}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-75f15a3f226e525a52917d81928f5d115792bbd6.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Thigh

How does <b>insulin-like growth factor </b>influence muscle morphology?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Has auto and paracrine functions that influence satellite cells. this promotes anabolism by increasing the rate or protein synthesis in differentiated myofibers}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-80059960bdbf04ce31a4e5e9f588ab7cdbda5d41.jpg""><img src=""paste-5b716923222503ec1cc7d8407ee91896cf7253a7.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
How does <b>testosterone </b>influence muscle morphology adaptation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Results in greater muscle hypertrophy by reacting to androgen receptors. This results in greater protein synthesis, less metabolism, and greater reliance on other energy sources.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-abf58f2e35e6afeb072f635951a9ce66d9a2dfdd.jpg""><img src=""paste-aa4eadc38853aa25dfb571cb93381d6081ae2314.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
How does <b>growth hormone (GH) </b>influence muscle morphology adaptation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A polypeptide protein that hsa anabolic and catabolic properties that play a role in the growth of all kinds of tissues (bone, muscle, and connective tissue). Role is still sort of unknown}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4bac8c5a34ae8cf537ef0d90b78584f177974d58.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What is a <b>motor unit</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Alpha motor neuron and the associated muscle fibers it activates}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7eed292c34b6d39b5e2216901cee05dd3fba3a87.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What does the Henneman's Size Principle tell us about <b>force</b> production?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::To produce max amount of force, all available motor units need to be activated}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-426e8855ad36ed375be8b8f99f4bd26ed5da58fa.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
"What does this graph tell us?<div><img src=""paste-8c55f9492f4c6128d9bae9aec14f4aa517f4a767.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::A lower intensities/volume, smaller motor units that innervate type 1 muscle fibres are recruited whereas at higher intensites/volume, we start to innervate type 2 muscle fibres as well!}}<br></div>"		KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What is the theory of <b>subpopulations of motor units utilized during strength training</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that at different portions of a workout, motor units will be recruited and exhausted}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-67b230359cb59240171b32a190a7068f2271ef90.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
Why is Henneman's Size Principle important for hypertrophy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We can utilize the principle to specify training in certain populations.</div><div><br></div><div>Eg: Untrained: Type 2 muscle fibers are used infrequently and thus should focus on high intensity low sets to induce hypertrophy of these fibers</div><div><br></div><div>Eg: Athletes: Want to utilize all muscle fibers for hypertrophy, therefore focus on more sets and higher tension (to recruit them all!)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-8643f8ca812860e8e56d3a0bc766632ea22f61da.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth

What are the pros/cons of a <b>long rest </b>interval for muscle hypertrophy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Full recovery of strength which allows for ability to train with max force capacity but decrease in anabolic drive}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ea13053067ecf4e1ae9b82c5da885fe82e5f5f3b.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What is the <b>optimal rep speed </b>of muscle hypertrophy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::concentric reps at fast to moderate speeds and eccentric reps at slower speeds}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-dd66ae142ffc55c792a0f3c3db3623c6a133d9c1.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What are the three <b>primary mechanisms</b>&nbsp;that effect muscle growth?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Mechanical tension: load}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Metabolic stress: biological}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Muscle damage: muscle (satellite cells)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-20307904b4e01cf2f84d279abcd6471861f47a2e.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What are the three <b>keys </b>to mechanical tension?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::The nature of tension (active or passive)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Role of external resistance}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::The effects of fatigue}}</div>	"All three of these factors are tied to how much tension is experienced by individual muscle fibers<div><img src=""paste-199b6b932a612afda3a9b73b1ffb76503840c469.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What is the <b>difference </b>between active or passive tension?<div><br></div><div>Active:&nbsp;{{c1::active, shortening muscle length over some sort of load}}</div><div><br></div><div>Passive:&nbsp;{{c1::Gravity}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-1e31b1691b18c33d6e4993fed08889c4eb4223aa.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What is the <b>role </b>of external resistance in regards to muscle hypertrophy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::external resistance slows down contraction velocities which allow more time for muscle unit recruitment = increase in tension that each fiber produces}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8551e4274eeb7fe19197dcb2e953e9fa7857ebed.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
How can we utilize fatigue to induce muscle hypertrophy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::An increase in fatigue decreases contraction velocity = slower speeds = more actin-myosin cross bridging = more mechanical tension on the individual fibers.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-237e5feefb3ae4e446c03766bb047329700a2854.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
"What is the ""Burn"" when working out?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Anaerobic glycolysis for ATP results in build up of lactate, and H+ resulting in acidosis}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-dba694c1f2065c2854cf31356f13e597d2770c20.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
"What is the ""<b>pump</b>"" when lifting?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Not that much evidence, but could be cell swelling as a defense mechanism; also, muscle ischemia occuring causing a restriction of blood flow --&gt; increases metabolites}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-d88ef02d140f0b7e39762f06b7b525fba36f8591.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
What is the difference between <b>eccentric </b>and <b>concentric </b>contractions to muscle hypertrophy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Eccentric increases muscle fiber length (sarcomeres in series)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Concentric increases muscle fiber diameter (sarcomeres in parallel)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a86c2abdaebd86ee4d59273a9b58432c2ffb0bc2.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
Which type of contraction results in the <b>highest </b>amount of muscle damage?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Eccentric contractions}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a86c2abdaebd86ee4d59273a9b58432c2ffb0bc2.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Physiological_Principles_of_Muscle_Growth
Should I lie to win in the game? How would an AU act vs an RU?<div><br></div><div>AU:&nbsp;{{c1::Depends on the circumstances of each team; lie if winning produces more pleasure overall}}</div><div><br></div><div>RU:&nbsp;{{c1::Lie only if you're sure you won't get caught and pleasure is increased}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-77785d862b02aeac3340d1f92cb79da9c0d08ed9.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
"What are the <b>5 critiques </b>with Utilitarianism?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Impossible to apply</div><div>- too much to measure, pleasure is quantified differently for everyone. How do we know something will certainly give us more pleasure then the other?}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Threat to close friends and family</div><div>- Inherently selfish, if ditching your friends give you more pleasure then do it}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Too demanding</div><div>- Since everything is black or white, it may lead to extreme decisions being the only right answer}}</div><div><br></div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Too permissive</div><div>- Motive doesn't matter as long as the end goal was morally good}}</div><div><br></div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Can't differentiate between equity or distributive justice</div><div>- can't separate two societies with similar utils of happiness but different distributions (can in essense justify slavery)</div><div><img src=""paste-707fb7dc71371a5652ad5b9a37149e422e3950b6.jpg"">}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-b69492e3c9f8d662955c9944027c431b78a464a2.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Utilitarianism
What are the two types of ways we can increase muscle hypertrophy (sarcomeres)?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::in parallel}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::In series}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-bb3b5071ff2e21b302625739412c434ba188bd7f.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_2_3::Schoenfeld_2010
What type of actions lead to a greater number of sarcomeres being generated in series?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::eccentric actions}}<br></div>	"Increases muscle suppleness<div><img src=""paste-06b49da3cdd6ecf8297cfd1b8d44eef92484dfd4.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_2_3::Schoenfeld_2010
What do <b>satellite cells </b>do for hypertrophy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This mediates the hypertrophy! Once aroused, satellite cells proliferate and ultimately fuse to existing cells or among themselves to create new myofibers providing the precursors needed for repair and subsequent growth of new muscle tissue}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2e717d86aab496a1e1c644683007dcca487db925.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_2_3::Schoenfeld_2010

What is <b>contractualism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Humans are innately egoistic, but we realized that teaming up had some advantages. Therefore, we go on a <b>social contract</b>&nbsp;between people where if I help you, you may help me in the future.</div><div><br></div><div>Deals with what we owe one another, not just pleasures/pains. <b>Not able to aggregate objections</b>}}<br></div>	"<div>If something brings greater happiness but is unjustifiable, it is still wrong.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-91bb9485ed3edb952d3d3aaa47108393384090d0.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-98c17a92d1a96ad16033cbf793f9e1fa93c589fc.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Contractualism
Social contracts are only valid if&nbsp;{{c1::consented to}}.	"<img src=""paste-ebb43835bcb0aef11dc0e62a9b3e7563962d41dd.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Contractualism
What are the <b>3 types of consent</b>? Does the social contract (contractualism) comply with these?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Actual: No, when we are brought up into society, we don't sign a form that governs all of us. Therefore this is factually incorrect}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Tacit - if we are there, then its moral: Insufficient for morality because there are no other options = no consent}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Hypothetical: most compelling; asks what would rational people agree to if asked. Focuses on the <b>reasons</b>&nbsp;people have for being there}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-09c0239093f231ee8af6ccb303613242e91d3b8c.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Contractualism

"What is the <b>prevailing </b>vs <b>challenging </b>perspective debate to hormone response to RT?<div><br></div><div>Prevailing:&nbsp;{{c1::Acute post-RE increases in anabolic hormone may not be necessary to cause muscle hypertrophy however their presence is ""optimal"" for anabolism of muslce (may counteract catabolic effects of RE - androgen receptors are down-regulated from exercise)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Challenging:&nbsp;{{c1::Acute post-RE in anabolic hormone is not necessary at all to induce muscle growth. What is the <b>moral principle </b>of contractualism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Treat people by principles they could not <b>object </b>to instead of a consensus}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3af82429ffe460d4b98055287a3a8def573fdfbe.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Contractualism
What does <b>object </b>in contractualism mean? 2 Features.<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Must be reasonable: if it negatively affects me, I can object. However, if it negatively affects others even more --&gt; their objection wins out (you withdraw your objection)}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Deals with more than well-being (contrast to utilitarianism): Burdens applied without respect for me as a person are unjustifiable, even if they produce equal well being.</div><div><br></div><div>Eg: Let's say you make fun of someone while everyone on the team is laughing. In a Utilitarian framework, everyone gets more utils of pleasure and therefore making fun of that person is the ONLY right thing to do}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-eff47341a00f3badb422d5f76f37f4b2d9bdae5b.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Contractualism
"<img src=""paste-44526380083222237ace397e5fc0df18571d47a3.jpg""><div><br></div><div>Use a <b>contractualist </b>viewpoint to walk through this issue.</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Justice matters too! This also causes suffering/disrespect to certain populations.}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-26b12f688389a927739e97f3b0c1d6636207e7e5.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Contractualism
"What are some <b>criticisms </b>of contractualism? Swimmers on rocks scenario.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Other people's objections may outweigh yours by alot...but do you have to save all of them? (non-aggregate)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::If there isn't a social contract to begin with, then the framework doesn't work! Do you have a contract with your friends/families?}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Swimmer Problem:&nbsp;{{c1::You can't sum objections that are the same. 5 person with the same objection vs 1 person with the same objection will have the same weight. Who's ""not want to die"" objection is more important?}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-1459fa4b108ad8d00483d3e5847539cc3d993441.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Contractualism

What is the <b>screwhome mechanism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The last 10-20 degrees of leg extension of the knee or thigh extension of the knee there is external rotation of the leg or internal rotation of the thigh to lock the knee in place (prevent further extension)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2f76c2ade0144ab70501a7386d67edae7262358f.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Leg
What muscle is important to <b>unlock </b>the screwhome mechanism?<div><br></div><div>Muscle:&nbsp;{{c1::Popliteus}}</div><div>Reason:&nbsp;{{c1::It does the opposite actions of the screwhome mechanism allowing the leg to return to normal position after extension (allows knee to go into flexion)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2f76c2ade0144ab70501a7386d67edae7262358f.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Leg
Rotating the tibia forward with a planted foot is also called&nbsp;{{c1::Dorsiflexion}}	"<img src=""paste-d9dac7634f80b39332e73273ffcc982d810efedc.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Leg
Rotating the tibia backwards with a planted foot is also called&nbsp;{{c1::plantarflexion}}	"<img src=""paste-d9dac7634f80b39332e73273ffcc982d810efedc.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Leg
In standing, the&nbsp;{{c1::Soleus}}, taking its fixed point from below, steadies the leg upon the foot and prevents the body from falling forward. What are the <b>three types </b>of collagen fibres? (connective tissue) Explain each.<div><br></div><div>Type 1:&nbsp;{{c1::Thick fibre with minimal stretch when force applied</div><div>eg: Ligaments, tendons, fascia, joint capsules}}</div><div><br></div><div>Type 2:&nbsp;{{c1::Thin fibers that provide structural framework</div><div>eg: hyaline cartilage}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Type 3:&nbsp;{{c1::Reticular collagen --&gt; very weak. Because of this, it can be cross-linked}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-bd298d6006f597df1e0936b53db77416325c241b.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Tissue_Anatomy
What is the&nbsp;<b>ground substance </b>of the matrix? Describe the <b>cellular </b>and <b>matrix </b>components of a bone?<div><br></div><div>Cellular:&nbsp;{{c1::Osteoblasts, osteoclasts, osteocytes}}</div><div><br></div><div>Matrix:&nbsp;{{c1::Low proteoglycan, high type 1 collagen (tensile strength), calcium phosphate crystals (compressive strength)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5c3d8a6c27b5ce18ca852a3d58624c813616ac44.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Tissue_Anatomy
What is the <b>functions </b>of a bone?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Structure, Support, Protection, Calcium Storage, RBC production::5}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5c3d8a6c27b5ce18ca852a3d58624c813616ac44.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Tissue_Anatomy
The lateral part of a femur has high&nbsp;{{c1::type 1 collagen}} while the medial part of the femur has high&nbsp;{{c1::Calcium phosphate crystals}}.<div><br></div><div>This is because...</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The way the femur is compressed and stretched. It is essentially in a bended position when we walk. Making the lateral part need to adapt to tensile forces (increase type 1 collagen) and the medial part to adapt to compressive forces (calcium phosphate crystals)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-839528db2a620e8bc76984637e1b3228159444fb.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Tissue_Anatomy
A femur is so strong. How does it get fractured?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The femur is strong in one side in compression and the other side in tension. If a force is applied to on the outside. It will cause compression and tension on the wrong sides causing a snap. Its strong where it's supposed to bend but weak where it's not supposed to bend}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ee9400e47432f7af8bf8591c197946057c3c10b0.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Tissue_Anatomy

A deontologist is also known as a&nbsp;{{c1::non-consequentialist}}	"<img src=""paste-29e12b6b9f099e7a3192435d5c18a6a8cf27437e.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What is the <b>categorical imperative</b>? (Deontology)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Act only on something which at the same time can become a universal law (becomes a perfect duty) This is a <b>fairness principle</b>&nbsp;(why should you be allowed to do something if everyone else can't also?}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f52d6ecb4635a8d2e844d1896d60f8d9267a591f.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What is a <b>perogative</b>? When is this used? (deontology)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::perogatives are parameters of a situation that is not perfectly constrained (I think)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-234d976ab5e679cd04cddde88e01b12f7d31778e.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What does it mean when something is <b>perfectly constrained</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If something fails the universal test}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-234d976ab5e679cd04cddde88e01b12f7d31778e.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
<i>T/F </i>You can have a perogative that violates a constraint in deontology.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False, constraints are primary. How the hell you gonna twist something if it is your perfect duty not to do it?}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-234d976ab5e679cd04cddde88e01b12f7d31778e.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What is the <b>sequential method </b>of periodization?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::specific time intervals to develop only one training goal at a time}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9a714be5dba1e59b8adf3bfa912dedff59f15efc.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_4::
What is the <b>difference </b>between the <b>long linear </b>method and the <b>short linear </b>method for periodization? What are the advantages/disadvantages?<div><br></div><div><u>Long linear</u>: {{c1::One training goal for each one mesocycle}}</div><div><i>Advantages:&nbsp;</i>{{c1::good for beginners, allows for rest and development, stress is likely new to them}}</div><div><i>Disadvantages:&nbsp;</i>{{c1::regression of goals from previous mesocycles}}</div><div><br></div><div><u>Short linear</u>:&nbsp;{{c1::A training goal for each microcycle}}</div><div><div><i>Advantages:&nbsp;</i>{{c1::Better than long linear and more suited for intermediate lifters; prevented de-training from shorter blocks}}</div><div><i>Disadvantages:&nbsp;</i>{{c1::Not appropriate for begginers}}</div></div>	"Linear: typically going from high volume/low intensity to low volume/high intensity<div><br></div><div>Long:&nbsp;<img src=""paste-64ba2af5099c4f8cec0360429a80a3eba721d99a.jpg""></div><div><br></div><div>Short:&nbsp;<img src=""paste-dd01f4f900293e40af3cf6efbce45df973a6837d.jpg""></div>"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_4::Jovanovic
What is the <b>long undulating method</b>? Explain the adv/disadvantages.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A waving progression training only one thing per mesocycle}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Advantage:&nbsp;{{c1::It's shit}}</div><div><br></div><div>Disadvantages:&nbsp;{{c1::It's shit}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-498503c5280b8aa37ba35cf83f00fd5b0215ff2a.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_4::Jovanovic
What is the <b>short undulating method</b>? Explain the adv/disadvantages. (periodization)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Wave like progression with changing goals each microcycle}}<br><div><br></div><div>Advantages: {{c1::His favorite one; greater refreshment and less boredom. Uses weeks of accumulation followed by weeks of intensification}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Disadvantages:&nbsp;{{c1::Not for beginners!}}</div></div>	"<img src=""paste-f9d487bb58d6c7e9528f866931a2612f0e5e76a0.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_4::Jovanovic
What is the <b>ordinary concurrent method</b>&nbsp;for periodization? Adv/Disadvantages?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Develops all goals in one microcycle}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Advantages:&nbsp;{{c1::No drop in ability; all abilities developed at the same time}}</div><div>Disadvantages:&nbsp;{{c1::Hard for advanced lifters to progress, and is harder to plan}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-6d81c9060c56cdcdc0e894709e89a405f600a489.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_4::Jovanovic
What is the&nbsp;<b>emphasized&nbsp;concurrent method</b>? What are the adv/disadvantages?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Concurrent but a training goal is emphasized in that one microcycle!}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Advantages:&nbsp;{{c1::Has a concentrate on a particular ability while developing the others}}</div><div><br></div><div>Disadvantages:&nbsp;{{c1::Focuses on only one goal throughout the whole macrocycle. Need to switch emphasis (which is conjugated)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-36e555164f9b5091b92e38ea030bd7a79b9beb08.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_4::Jovanovic
What is the <b>conjugate sequence system</b>? What is the difference between long and short? Pros/cons?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The most advanced periodization program combining both sequential and concurrent training}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Short:&nbsp;{{c1::Change emphasis each microcycle}}</div><div>Pros:&nbsp;{{c1::Lower level of fatigue/boredome}}</div><div>Cons:&nbsp;{{c1::1 week of emphasis only is kinda shit (may not elicit best adaptations}}</div><div><br></div><div>Long:&nbsp;{{c1::Change emphasis each mesocycle}}</div><div>Pros:&nbsp;{{c1::Same as short but better development of particular ability}}</div><div>Cons:&nbsp;{{c1::longer duration may not be better for planning and recovery (more boredom)}}</div>	"Short:&nbsp;<div><img src=""paste-397b2e1d24600908358dcdb59d69ef0a4923e976.jpg""><br></div><div>Long:</div><div><img src=""paste-8a17ca4b61214bf19fd77bf81e1ac6587cb2ba06.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Week_4::Jovanovic
What <b>matters </b>to a deontological framework?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A framework that is a non-consequentialist where some types of actions are prohibited, or obligatory, regardless of consequence}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-dc23dfc855462cf4a2d440f2ec996ccf6ad9e6d1.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg56_65
What is <b>Kantianism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Identified with an idea that the only thing that is good in all circumstances is good will}}<br></div>	"A part of deontological ethics?<div><img src=""paste-6d810363df793a8abdff734a9db35cc4219966f1.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Required_Readings::Tannsjo_2008::Pg56_65
What is the <b>difference </b>between the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the foot?<div><br></div><div>Intrinsic:&nbsp;{{c1::proximal and distal attachments both on foot}}</div><div><br></div><div>Extrinsic:&nbsp;{{c1::proximal attachment on a bone not in foot; distal attachment is on one or more foot bones}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-91eaaa39672932196a3a322c2418e0fc117baa59.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Foot
