Which causes that lift</div><div><br></div><div>Flexor digitorum brevis is in the middle of the foot so it supports both medial and lateral arches</div><div><br></div><div>Abductor Hallucis is on medial side so supports medial arch</div><div><br></div><div>Abductor Digiti Minimi is on lateral side so supports lateral arch}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-997e7c06d165a728f33763b642ed76b7ee9c294c.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Foot

What is being knock-kneed called? How about bow-legged?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Knocked: valgus}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Bow: varus}}<br></div>	"<div>Used to describe <b>static postures</b></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-472e3d610e447ae615d8b3192f9cde4b0e922e43.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee
What is it called when the <b>angle of inclination </b>of the coxal joint is too small? How about too big? What does this do to their <b>tibiofemoral alignment</b>?<div><br></div><div>Small:&nbsp;{{c1::Coxa vara (105 degrees) --&gt; will cause genu valgum}}</div><div>Large:&nbsp;{{c1::Coxa Valga (140 degrees) --&gt; will cause genu varus}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-f078f825b804c61027e479163f97e0a08591c1d5.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee
When happens to the tibiofemoral alignment with retroversion or excessive anteversion?<div><br></div><div>Retroversion: {{c1::will cause us to go into ER to realign and therefore lead to genu varum}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Anteversion:&nbsp;{{c1::will cause us to go into IR to realign and therefore lead to genu valgum}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c42a277736745d84db02659813f078b34b424044.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee
What are the two possible ways for genu valgum or varum of the tibiofemoral joint to occur?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Angle of inclination (frontal plane)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Anteversion/Retroversion (sagittal plane)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-a56473e0b224d9f55fff18e67d91fbd315a3b515.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-752d1a612537424d79bad84e4a76668dca9dd537.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee
For Deontology, what type of killing is prohibited? What ones are allowed?<div><br></div><div>Forbidden:&nbsp;{{c1::Active killing with intended death}}</div><div>Permissible:&nbsp;{{c1::Passive killing or active kill where death is already foreseen}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-6ce5f5aff6471963d21b4b25c4394d49d690ecdf.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
How can you determine something is <b>active unintentional killing</b>? (deontology)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Apply the doctrine of double effect; the medication has two effects --&gt; pain relief and hastening death. If the Dr. wants the former and there is no other alternative, then it could be ethically moral}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-833e7005a7853200812896b8c25826bf63eaa47b.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
<div>What are some <b>critiques </b>to Deontology (CI 1 = agent-centred)?</div><div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Selfish: I can treat my friends and my family different than I treat others (universalizable though)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Doctrine of double effect is complicated}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Ultra-strict: killer asks you where your family is --&gt; perfect duty not to lie}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Say's no a lot}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Logical problems: how often should you fulfill our imperfect duties}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-908e47b56934aece0e2729273d94216a9e64b51f.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What are the <b>strengths </b>of Deontology (agent-centred)?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Some things are just plain wrong}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::a certain degree of freedom without always maximizing utility --&gt; you can let people die to save your family}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-1e41f3cc21ab1d5bcbeabf49e1ece3c2ede1043e.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What are the 2 <b>categorical imperatives </b>in Deontology?<div><br></div><div>1:&nbsp;{{c1::Agent centred: Gives us our perfect duty}}</div><div>2:&nbsp;{{c1::Patient centred: Gives us our rights - fundamental rights of people (not a specific right (like the right to vote))}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b75d0b0cc1030ab4c361eba82e18c6a1f2585e5f.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-0b2ba9e78899d448807e8357408e59b9c309ac1c.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Deontology
What are the <b>two sides </b>to Deontology?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The side doing the acting (agent-centred)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The side getting acted upon (patient-centred)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-301b94b4472988dcd30aad50760d497b73083b75.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What are some problems with <b>patient centred </b>Deontology?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Using a person to hide from someone else (you used someone so its 100% wrong, even though the consequence is benign}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Do we have duties towards young children, animals, or people with disease? (things without an ability to be rational)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Can't answer using one person vs multiple people}}</div><div><br></div>	"<div>If you are not rational then you have no moral value</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-6b5816882a2a05cc6d9b0f6560690096b8f051ea.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
"<div>What is the ""Nike"" and ""walk on by"" problem for Deontology?<br><div><br></div></div><div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Killing for no absolute reason is hard to judge (Nike problem)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Helping someone is not required (walk on by problem)}}</div></div>"	"<img src=""paste-03cb650a6357ce813322208e124fdf9f959db798.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Deontology
What is <b>periodization</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::organized approach to training that involves progressive cycling of various aspects of a training program during a specific period of time}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-085015d9b02abafe8bce7f97b418738f66f9f2c7.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Periodization
What is <b>Block periodization</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Having blocks for specific goals with multiple competition peaks. Rationale is for accumulation of specific stages (residual training effects))}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Advantages:&nbsp;{{c1::Gives us a realization stage where we max out multiple times --&gt; more concentrated loading and good for intermediate/advanced athletes --&gt; less detraining}}</div><div><br></div><div>Disadvantages:&nbsp;{{c1::Max out blocks may be too much for novice trainers (basically not for beginners)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-89abf6e4e7e5b9617507ef38d9b93c7e6d22c30f.jpg""><img src=""paste-449b06fdbcd67774293c0e432706c5811e0d9128.jpg""><img src=""paste-ccbf0dfe541ee7abd069e7fb45e2e4c55ea0d37b.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Periodization

What is <b>virtue ethics</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A framework that follows the characteristics and motivations of the person acting. Instead of asking what to do, you build on your internal character and the answer will come naturally}}<br></div>	"""The right thing to do is what a good (virtuous) person would do""<div><br></div><div>Become the best version of yourself<br><img src=""paste-7ff98b9c38820508b03c12489bd0eb9c61546171.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics
For Virtue Ethics, how come a concern is that you will never achieve a true virtue for the rest of your life (ie: honesty)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because as a person you will always be a work in progress. Virtues like honesty, you have to display them multiple times over the course of your life. If you were honest the first half of your life but a crook the next, you can't really say you were an honest person}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7665d8fa0a30caa322f58027deae76f59aa42b12.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics
What is <b>practical wisdom </b>in regards to virtue ethics?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The experience to separate the important factors in a situation from the lesser ones --&gt; knows what is truly worthwhile --&gt; knows how to live}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-36d6294c664b83a8dfbdd80ad8f639a66f889a68.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics
What is the <b>golden mean </b>in virtue ethics?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Not have too much or too little of a virtuous characteristic</div><div><br></div><div>eg: too much courage = stupid, too little courage = a bitch}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5e6eb544c99104bd3f5fa8edd0f73c7127331422.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics
What is <b>Eudaimonia </b>in virtue ethics?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::flourishing/happiness as a human being living the good life. Self-actualization --&gt; fulfilling your purpose}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-36d6294c664b83a8dfbdd80ad8f639a66f889a68.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics
What are the <b>3 components </b>of virtue ethics?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Commitment to pursuing Eudaimonia throughout your life}}<div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Knowledge of the virtues}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Using practical wisdom to find the Golden Mean}}</div></div>	"<br><div><img src=""paste-e26a46d091271d606bc8a284b67a2a0fd4eea179.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics
"What are the <b>strengths </b>of virtue ethics?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::""bad people"" will never do good things (we can stop at bad). Comparing this to other frameworks, bad people can find loopholes. It also allows flexibility in ethics (because it ultimately depends on the person's internal character}}<br></div>"	"<br><div><img src=""paste-fe4503cadd4bc8ab213f996b3de710eee6e3ff0c.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics
What are the <b>critiques </b>of virtue ethics?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Doesn't tell us what to do, it just tells us what a good person is}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::there are no such thing as virtues (character traits are not single-tracked}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::cultural relativity}}</div><div><br></div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::conflicts between virtues (honesty versus compassion)}}</div><div><br></div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Justification problem (what is a virtue anyway?)}}</div>	"<br><div><img src=""paste-b8845df87181e55033d1ed024fb274f482e0a06b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics

What does <b>profligate </b>mean?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources}}<br></div>	"<br><div><img src=""paste-45fb4e33e3edfab34bd4d32edb724a2d71e2f307.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Virtue_Ethics

How do you make a <b>flexible </b>periodization program?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Make a plan BUT expect deviation, review it, and then plan for this change (did you expect for this to happen?)}}<br></div>	"<div>Always put in a <b>next time</b> in your plan</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-742bba9999c937a7de95a045f36f8c1a487331c2.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Periodization_Structure
What are the B3's <b>ReadySetGo</b>?<div><br></div><div>Goal: {{c1::macrocycle}}</div><div>Phase {{c1::mesocycle}}</div><div>Zone: {{c1::microcycle - the focus within the day/week}}</div><div><br></div><div>Ready:&nbsp;{{c1::Lower intensity; learning movements}}</div><div>Set:&nbsp;{{c1::medium intensity; sufficient movement with challenge}}</div><div>Go:&nbsp;{{c1::High intensity; near maximal}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d1a4b48dda5ce84d9a0b48ac38102f81b6d6f862.jpg""><img src=""paste-df398be6a1ff3a4f7d16342d0ec4e48855926206.jpg""><img src=""paste-cf1a9d09df4ad180596ebec4ea448938602c2afa.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm::Periodization_Structure
What are the <b>critiques </b>that Feminist's have on other frameworks?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Less concern for woman issues}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Less concern for household}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Imply that woman are less morally mature}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Overates masculinity}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Favour male ways of moralizing}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5f99065af6265b4cbef26915497e601c9e8fcf4c.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
What is <b>Standpoint Theory</b>? (Feminism)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that ethics is not a <b>universal code </b>to follow (your not god), in which ethics differs from person to person. Your one view can be universally applied to everyone such that everything against it is immoral.}}<br></div>	"<div>According to Feminism, ethics is not universal.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-985408652abc64d3937f1957ad4c24aa023795ce.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
What does it mean to be dominated/Dominate in regards to Feminist ethics?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Don't be dominating such that you tell others what is the right thing to do. Moral people create a moral world, but they also phase in and out of other peoples moral worlds and learn from it. --&gt; these people who see the world differently then we do, may change us as a result}}<br></div>	"Ethics are situational to the people you interact with according to Feminism<div><img src=""paste-4351198580f41f8a5219e71c62b72b082891095b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
What are <b>Kohlberg's Ethical stages</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Young children do things so not to get punished}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Children help others only if they get helped first}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Adolescents adhere to social norms to get approval}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Adolescents develop a sense of duty to gain respect/admiration}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Adults adopt a basic utilitarian perspective}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::Mature adults develop a universal Kantian ethical perspective}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-40dd2c1c4c31cc652d8f562947f227dc2fe6503a.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
What were&nbsp;<b>Carol Gilligan's </b>ethical stages? How come she made this?<div><br></div><div>Stages:</div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Overemphasize self-interests}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Overemphasize others' interests}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Weave together self and others' interests relationally}}</div><div><br></div><div>Reasoning</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Following Kohlbergs ethical stages, most woman only get to stage 3, so was it that women were just less moral? No! It's just Kohlberg looked at the world differently!}}<br></div>	"Care-focused Feminism<div><img src=""paste-61c01acc4a29404f98b4399b91a5128aa40f1481.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
What is <b>level 3 thinking</b>: relational caring? (Care-focused ethics)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Traditional ethics assume equality between two rational agents, however relationships are rarely equal --&gt; friend in need (not the same). This is where <b>caring </b>comes in where inequality becomes nurturing assistance}}<br></div>	"Care-focused ethics<div><img src=""paste-df507bc89289e34c74fe2b3421c8b4ddac64cbe0.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
In Care-focused Feminism, what are problems that can occur with relational care?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Care can go too far (unreciprocated}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Distorted care --&gt; care cannot be demanded or forced}}</div>	"Thus, as long as women do more than their fair share of care giving work, both sexes will remain morally deprived.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-74b82866b00343d958dd761aa56a9068339e1d73.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
In Care-focused Feminism, a life without caring relationships is&nbsp;{{c1::morally impoverished}}	"<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-74b82866b00343d958dd761aa56a9068339e1d73.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
In care-focused feminism, why not use <b>justice </b>as a way to replace care? If we treat each other justly, then care will come naturally.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Caring seems more fundamental than justice --&gt; emotions play a more central role in this framework compared to others}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-2bf54eb6d1cb84d6af0d2dfc1c14a2b5c0d5c389.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
Caring for someone means two things...<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Understanding what they need}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Being willing to change yourself if that is required}}</div>	"<div>You must also care about yourself</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2bf54eb6d1cb84d6af0d2dfc1c14a2b5c0d5c389.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
What is the <b>moral principle </b>for Care-Focused Feminists?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Caring relationships should be nurtured and this should guide our actions}}<br></div>	"<div>Care Focused is interpersonal. You can't just sit in a room and think about this.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2bf54eb6d1cb84d6af0d2dfc1c14a2b5c0d5c389.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
What is <b>power </b>in terms of Power-Focused Feminism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Not everyone has the same power to set or change moral terms. It means, what is ethical for one person may not be for another. Having power is not bad, it depends on what you do with it (oppression is when those with power, bullies those who are powerless}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6acf00cc2becad1bbc05478a788d1632667a03ba.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
How do we <b>change </b>oppressive power relations? (Power-focused Feminism)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::For the powerless, its crafting a version of themselves that resist the powerful whereas for the powerful, it means listening openly and being receptive to critique}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-00a7493744a7214cdf3d4b31a2662e7542ba28b8.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
In Power-Focused Feminism, is <b>oppression </b>males against females?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, there are multiple different things we have to consider}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7448e75d3ff72d3a6a4668346e23b7841fd2e47a.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
What is the <b>moral principle </b>for Power-Focused Feminism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Moral actions are those that challenge interlocking systems of oppression}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7448e75d3ff72d3a6a4668346e23b7841fd2e47a.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
What is the difference between oppression in <b>society/group </b>vs <b>individual</b>? (Power Focused Feminism)?<div><br></div><div>Societal:&nbsp;{{c1::Sociology --&gt; institutional barriers, social/economic inequality}}</div><div>Individual:&nbsp;{{c1::Domestic abuse, what you do as an individual}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-7f096eed16059f8cfc08da72f3876f85fa9de6e6.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
What are the <b>goals </b>of Power-Focused Feminists?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Identify moral critiques/actions that cause woman's (and other oppressed groups) subordination --&gt; look for morally justifiable ways to resist such actions --&gt; take oppressed groups moral experience seriously }}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6c308ebcda39a719af289df4d0264fa5504f048c.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Feminism
What are the <b>moral principles </b>for each of these frameworks?<div><br></div><div>Act Utilitarianism:&nbsp;{{c1::Act to maximize <b>well-being/happiness</b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Rule Utilitarianism:&nbsp;{{c1::Act according to a <b>universal rule</b> that would maximize society's overall well-being/happiness}}</div><div><br></div><div>Contractualism:&nbsp;{{c1::In <b>legit contractual situation</b>s, we owe it to others to act in ways they could not reasonably <b>object</b> to.}}</div><div><br></div><div>Deontology:&nbsp;{{c1::By respecting people's fundamental rights and never engaging in actions that violate <b>universality</b>, you derive maxims to live by}}</div><div><br></div><div>Virtue Ethics:&nbsp;{{c1::Use <b>practical wisdom</b> to fine the <b>golden mean</b> and act in accordance with <b>virtuous character</b> to achieve <b>eudaimonia</b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Care-Focused Feminism:&nbsp;{{c1::Act <b>situationally</b> to foster <b>nurturing caring relationships</b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Power-Focused Feminism:&nbsp;{{c1::Act to challenge <b>interlocking systems</b> of oppression}}</div>	"<div>Expand on things that are highlighted</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-ca47b093717270dcd8b14b2149bbfc1add043308.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-873d4b0644d00a3f7d6cbd69d9e51b3443dd17ba.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Feminism
"What is the problem with <b>non-aggregation </b>in Contractualism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::You can't sum up objections, objections are weighted individual to the person. Eg: 5 people on a rock vs 1 person on a rock but both sides wanting to be saved. If they both have the objection of ""Not wanting to die"", not one or the other is weightier. That is the problem with non-aggregation.}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-2ec571a297cd0ade9b67f7f8bf8611e7cf36501b.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Contractualism

What is the <b>function </b>of the ACL in regards to the tibia? Describe Kaltenborn's Convex-Concave Rule.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Femur rolling on tibia --&gt; roll and glide in <b>opposite directions</b>}}<br></div>	"<div>Due to the meniscus and muscles!</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-1d72641244c8903a57ba85f186088cd7025802a4.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee
Describe Kaltenborn's Concave-Convex rule.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Tibia rolling on the femur --&gt; roll and glide in the <b>same direction</b>}}<br></div>	"<div>Due to the meniscus and muscles!</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-5bf19038a46a8827ac32354953313b6d6aad75a9.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee
Describe an ACL strain (Anterior Drawer) using Kaltenborn's rule using femoral flexion of the knee.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If you flex the thigh at the knee (skiing accident) --&gt; cause posterior rolling and glide (strain on ACL) and you need that anterior glide to prevent this from happening (Kaltenborn's rule)}}<br></div>	"Remember that a posterior translation of the femur at the knee causes a strain to the ACL similar to an anterior translation of the tibia at the knee!<div><img src=""paste-4720dcc882c29e3f6b65c6fdf2e1dc98bbd573e5.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee
What is the <b>function </b>of the vastus medialis oblique in the tibiofemoral joint? Why does it do this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The VM-longus and VL both pull the leg slightly medially and laterally. In theory, they cancel each other out. However, the femoral shaft is slightly at an angle with the longitudinal axis of the femur. Thus, when these two pull, the patella is pulled more laterally. To combat this, the VM-oblique corrects this and pulls the patella more medially.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1b46a9c04bfdb82f7c5a5024ab28c8d09c188962.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Hip_and_Knee

What <b>ligaments </b>is the <b>medial longitudinal arch </b>supported by?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8853badbb90df581b1b9ee1d071ce1822039d4a8.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
At what point does the <b>transverse </b>arch of the foot collapse?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It crosses both the medial and lateral longitudinal arch. Therefore, if either (or both) of those fall, then the transverse is donzeo}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8853badbb90df581b1b9ee1d071ce1822039d4a8.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
How does the <b>plantar aponeurosis </b>support the foot arches? What are the two ways for this to happen? What is this known as?<div><br></div><div>How: {{c1::It attaches to the calcaneal tuberosity to the toes. This allows it to passively exert force on the calcaneal tuberosity, which resists calcaneal plantar flexion (resists pull from muscles that insert into calcaneal tendon.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Mechanisms: 1. {{c1::When the toes extend, it pulls on the calcaneal tuberosity which resists calcaneal plantarflexion}}. 2.&nbsp;{{c1::Plantarflexing the foot when the toes are fixed will also pull on the plantar aponeurosis (walking)!}}</div><div><br></div><div>Name: {{c1::This is called the <b>Windlass Mechanism</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a20664e2b36e80b99867495277eed9a7f9d85e24.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-725367c60b86fe30eef4029edbbb91bd72940328.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
What is the <b>problem </b>with the Windlass mechanism?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The plantar aponeurosis is a passive tissue/mechanism. You need to rely on other muscles to help support the arch. So in situations where you don't want to dorsiflex the toes or plantarflex the foot, you won't be able to activate the Windlass Mechanism to support the arch!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5a412dfc0b4a056a78dc2c0546386ffa16ea2450.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
What are the mechanisms that can support the arches of the foot (most important to least)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Intrinsic foot muscles (active)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Plantar Aponeurosis (passive)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Arch ligaments (passive and last line of defense)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-63355f10ca03cb500f2cb35e4c20829ee8cb9f1c.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
What <b>muscles</b> could we train (in the foot) to support the arches of our foot? Why?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Flexor digitorum brevis, abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi and quadratus plantae. This causes calcaneal dorsiflexion on its own, and its the best of both worlds because these muscles (if strong) can support the arch of the foot by itself (have a rigid and flexible foot)}}</div>	"<div><b>Toe Flexion exercises (inclined calf raises)</b></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-4cfcb6b77601f89cce4dabf953f5c2e75d8d5372.jpg""><img src=""paste-4d67d2ab24917bb7ab8abaf01ac38a89ea6788b1.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle

What is the average degrees of maximum dorsiflexion? What happens when we exceed this? When performing a deep squat, leg dorsiflexion needs at least 30 degrees. If the talocrural joint dorsiflexion is limited to 20 degrees, how is it possible to get this much dorsiflexion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We can use calcaneal plantarflexion to increase this angle while still keeping the 20 degree angle of the leg dorsiflexion! (flat footed people are wrecked)</div><div><br></div><div>Leg dorsiflexion = Ankle dorsiflexion + calcaneal plantarflexion}}<br></div>	"That's why when someone has ankle mobility issues, you give them heel plates, to allow for this arch to increase and therefore more calcaneal plantarflexion can occur!<div><br></div><div><b>Hightlights the importance of a flexible arch </b>(other times, rigid is good too)</div><div><br><div><img src=""paste-60592109814117c82ac9fcba494623715594e0e4.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
What is the <b>equation </b>for leg dorsiflexion?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::ankle dorsiflexion + calcaneal plantarflexion}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-20d781f65121dd213d3461a6606631cbd2c6882c.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
What do you need to have a more flexible foot arch? How about a more rigid one?<div><br></div><div>Flexible:&nbsp;{{c1::More calcaneal dorsiflexion through the plantar aponeurosis (windlass), and/or strength from Flexor digitorum brevis, abductor hallucis, abductor digit minimi, and quadratus plantae}}</div><div><br></div><div>Rigid:&nbsp;{{c1::More pull for the calcaneal tendon (more calcaneal plantar flexion)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2ced7959d63e52b5867dda3a3f1c9ae52310887d.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle
What are the muscles and strategies we could use on it to increase leg dorsiflexion?<div><br></div><div>Strengthen: {{c1::Causes calcaneal plantar flexion}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Stretch:&nbsp;{{c1::Tib post, FDL, FHL and possibly soleus (get's stretched)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Restricts (stretch):&nbsp;{{c1::FDB, Abd Hallucis, Abd digiti minimi, quadratus plantae (restricts calcaneal plantarflexion --&gt; causes calcaneal dorsiflexion)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-fba24dd2cd17ed8a4166b756e98ee26fb578b52f.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Pre_Midterm::Kinesiology_Foot_and_Ankle

Why is knowing <b>neutralization </b>charts important?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::He get to know how a muscle moves in only a single direction. Most of the time, when a muscle contracts, it causes multiple actions. This way, we can identify which muscles activate to <i>neutralize </i>the other actions so that we can do our preferred action. Yelling is not counted.<div><br></div><div>This punishment must not bring injury or intended abuse.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><b>His take is non-consequentialist</b></div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6471eeb4dbd8a76fac2767da7557370a0a4f49d5.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Punishment
According to Seifried (2008), what are the pros to punishment?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Restores fairness}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::repeat offendors less likely}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Reduces negative feelings toward the wrong-doer}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Upholds impartiality of status quo}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Promotes solidarity and cooperation}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::Allows wrong-doers to repent}}</div><div>7.&nbsp;{{c1::Motivates rule following (cuz fear of punishment}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-261682726111a6efcbe88a4b735e076f246be2d4.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Punishment
What is the <b>is-ought </b>fallacy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Saying something <b>does </b>and therefore we <b>ought </b>to do it. It doesn't actually give a reason in between}}<br></div>	Basically what Suzy did to me with pusilanimous	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Punishment
What are some <b>criticisms </b>to Seifried's use of punishment? (that Seifried said to himself)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Punishment is abuse}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Leads to shame and guilt}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Pyschological harm}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::May lead to more violent behaviour}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Not educative because wrong-doers cannot get the point.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-30c33274b3a82bbd5eb682fb4fd3d9eb44fa3262.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Punishment
What was <b>Albrecht's </b>issues with Seifried's definition of punishment?<div><br></div><div>Main point (fatal flaw): {{c1::Uses physical activity as a negative - you have to teach them that PA is bad}}</div><div><br></div><div>Other main points:&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Vague: It confuses punishment with discipline; the coach becomes the judge, jury, and executioner; what are you even punishing?}}</div><div>2. {{c1::damages relationship; reduces risk-taking; increases anxiety}}</div><div>3. {{c1::lowers self-esteem}}</div><div>4. {{c1::lowest denominator of moral development (doesn't teach me to do the right thing,&nbsp; but to avoid being punished)}}</div><div>5. {{c1::every professional organization has condemned it}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::Uses physical activity as a negative - you have to teach them that PA is bad (fatal flaw)}}</div><div>7.&nbsp;{{c1::Conflates punishment vs discipline}}</div><div>8.&nbsp;{{c1::Wastes valuable practice time}}</div>	"<div>The problem with #5 is that it is the is-ought fallacy!</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-827c01d440336ac9a1efe4c9e5b9acecd06c375e.jpg""><img src=""paste-aeacf462bf00bac93ee31436ded1d1a68bcbc8cd.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-45109fe9c239310c88212931caa5d8b70f63d50e.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2d0594e8af4a9ee0b956f1ec702601f6e4ded76f.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Punishment
"What was <b>Seifried's response </b>to Albrecht's issues?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Seifried focused on the fatal flaw that was mentioned (Treating PA as a negative.</div><div><br></div><div>First, he is talking about elite sport - which is winning-centred.</div><div><br></div><div>Then he gives his example of the ""line"" that he can't cross</div><div><br></div><div>He says: <i>Punishment is not about the promotion of hating PA but providing <b>information </b>to the athlete to help him/her avoid the behaviour through the use of PA</i></div><div><br></div><div>Athletes expect to receive punishment and in some cases appreciate the attention}}</div>"	"When he says elite sport is winning-centred, this is perhaps going into the hypothetical consent of contractualism.<div><br></div><div>His response is actually not that good --&gt; its more like what he believes</div><div>His other response on athletes expecting punishment is also not a good argument</div><div><br><div><img src=""paste-5e0fcc2e7ef1c07ea2608c419fd0ce3826550204.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6bc3dac74d3c211f4567583c89e6c450280a8761.jpg""><br></div></div><div><img src=""paste-643cb82fe80a4735ec5deb5af7a97fb184e7e723.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-170fecb5189143932e10a3e9537cc864ad5223ab.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Punishment
What is the difference between making an athlete practice a skill more and physically punishing them using that skill? (Seifreid and Albrecht)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is where it gets tricky and where Albrecht points out that Seifried mixes up punishment with discipline. They are essentially the same thing (according to Seifried). At what point does it turn into punishment? It's really only the additional instruction that's different. Maybe if we increased the amount of fundamental drill practice?}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3e2231dfea168754d31115a97cf39c86baa49a5a.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Punishment
When is it okay to cheat in sport?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Upton argues that you owe it to your teammates to try your hardest to win and therefore there may be cases where you have a moral duty to cheat}}<br></div>	"Eg: Cricket - not telling the umpire that you touched the ball to continue play<div><img src=""paste-733d2379d164291f454a6c76e1ca72e5c6cf209b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Cheating
What is a <b>Pro Tanto</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A <i>secondary </i>reason to act a certain way or not as long as a higher order reason doesn't over rule it. It gives us <i>partial duties</i>. }}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cd0582502cff31ad4a4309e4043240f7554192a4.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Cheating
What is <b>Upton's </b>argument for cheating in Cricket - not telling the umpire that you touched the ball?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The argument rests on three premises.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>1. Player owes his teammates max effort to win</div><div>2. Walking lets your teammate down<br>3. Walking is self-indulgent</div><div><br></div><div><b>There is a pro tanto duty to cheat</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cd0582502cff31ad4a4309e4043240f7554192a4.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Cheating
Royce (2012) disagrees with Uptons points on sometimes having a moral duty to cheat in sport. What are these points?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Often not a question of maximal effort - standing your ground (not telling umpire) really has nothing to do with giving your all in the sport}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::No such thing as Pro Tanto reasons - you either have one moral duty in that situation and that's it. You don't have a primary and then a secondary moral duty.}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::What is normal cannot confer moral duty - is/ought fallacy}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-366c432c9dab7296a24cf2338ab1ba3618e5add6.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Cheating
Is there such a thing as cheating? (According to Russell 2014)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::He argues that there is no distinctive conceptual core to the notion of cheating - if you dig deep into the concept of cheating, there is no actual substance we can grasp.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6c765c32100f0515f3083764dbfbfbc32dc76bd0.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Cheating
Russell (2014) argues that there is <b>no distinctive conceptual core</b> to the notion of <i>cheating</i>. What are the two possible reasons that could refute this?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::<i>Scale</i> Problem: the amount or level of cheating dictates if its right or wrong?}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Thinking in terms of <i>domains</i>: some behaviours fall under cheating, others under rule breaking and cheating, and some that don't fall under either. }}</div>	"<img src=""paste-44f5c31898fe443b173861c352369ba5b0b4b1dc.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-8c060b1d38eee266db7fc5da9abf245eee21c9aa.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Cheating
What is <b>Russell's </b>stance on using the <i>word </i>cheating?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::He says that it is a fuzzy term and should be retired. Just because everyone is using it doesn't mean you should as well (bandwagon fallacy) - because the premise is fuzzy}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe3f0b7b9f5a8b9ef64517a584ea1ebe75a4f708.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Cheating
What is the main <b>gist </b>of Russell's article on cheating?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Too much people be playing with Plato and haven't actually gotten on the field - their definition of cheating is too narrow and their examples too broad. There is widespread acceptance of the notion of lower reps for strength; mid range for hypertrophy; and high reps for endurance. Schoenfeld however argues that this repetition continuum has its faults. What are some faults you can pick apart here?<div><br></div><div>Strength:&nbsp;{{c1::Strength is highly correlated with the type of test your doing. If you train squats, you will get stronger in squats --&gt; it's not necessarily because of the amount of reps your doing}}</div><div><br></div><div>Hypertrophy:&nbsp;{{c1::Essentially to get hypertrophy, you just need a proper load, reps don't really play a role that much as long as the weight is heavy enough}}</div><div><br></div><div>Endurance:&nbsp;{{c1::Similar to strength in which the it depends on the transfer of training. Doing cycling will help with the Tour De France because your muscles are more resistant to fatigue. We should also note that higher reps (lighter loads) appear more specific to lower body musculature}}</div>	"<div>What I think Schoenfeld was getting at here is that we should be prescribing by intensity where the amount of reps are the consequences of that intensity. If we start to limit ourselves by reps, then our potential for growth would be reduced</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6174e7aea1cfdf6d35cd7d5fe0f1643dfcc9a938.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-a3522456b564230d2b3377ebe6f510f02e6b3a2c.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Transfer_of_Training

There are <b>5 tenets </b>to dynamic correspondence. Explain the number 1 (amplitude and direction of movement)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::For transfer of training to occur, we essentially want the ROM and direction of the movement to be similar to the sport. How do we understand rate of force development?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It takes time to recruit motor units and it takes many MU's to generate high force outputs. What <b>physiological changes </b>occur with an increase in RFD? How about a decrease in RFD?<div><br></div><div>Increase RFD:&nbsp;{{c1::increases muscle tendon stiffness; muscle fibre type changes from type 1 to type 2a; increase in neural drive during early phase of SSC}}</div><div><br></div><div>Decrease in RFD:&nbsp;{{c1::muscle fibre type changes from type 2x to type 2a; increases fascicle length}}</div>	"Type 2a = fast fatiguable<div><br></div><div>Decrease in RFD would be things like heavy resistance training.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-d88aaeca0ea92987d2a9075dbe4f6bd52863f396.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_Variables

In each of the three types of contractions, when does deceleration/acceleration occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Deceleration occurs in eccentric training, acceleration occurs in concentric training, and <b>amortization</b>&nbsp;occurs in isometric training}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-72032626a8d8f3828d1fea131eeaded9e40df7b1.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_Variables
What is the <b>stretch-shortening cycle</b>?<div><br></div><div>5 Phases:</div><div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::initial momentum phase: flexing knees beginning of a jump}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Electromechanical delay phase: contact with surface (floor) prevents limb from moving further and provokes muscle to contract}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Amortization phase: KE produces powerful myotatic stretch reflex (leads to eccentric muscle contraction)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Rebound phase: release of elastic energy - may include contribution by voluntary concentric contraction}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Final momentum phase: body is in air}}</div>	"Essentially, it is the notion that an eccentric contraction before a concentric one will lead to a more powerful subsequent concentric contraction<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3b6012e8b76c215a2fb1e62d73df13ad6ed6de9b.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f3a00118eb39c69e3ee1cf1ab4d2973c84ba150c.jpg""><img src=""paste-dc5085d15b22de3c6ad97ce6a72b3c28ac116aa2.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_Variables
In the stretch-shortening cycle, what is known as the <b>coupling time</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The time between the eccentric action and the beginning of the concentric action}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0fd29ff969dbe85f064846ec9d892ef58d03e208.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_Variables
How would muscle-tendon unit stiffness affect stretch-shortening cycle mechanisms?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::More stiff MTUs would be better for movements with large forces. Movements with smaller forces to be produced over longer period of time would be better suited to more compliant MTU's}}<br></div>	"Stiffer MTU = faster recoil speeds but has increased energy costs<div>- benefit may outweight the drawbacks for sprinters, but not as much for other athletes/sports</div><div><img src=""paste-85978a4417092a4d58a5cc953c22f1077953d931.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_Variables

What is <b>soft paternalism </b>vs <b>hard paternalism</b>?<div><br></div><div>Soft paternalism:&nbsp;{{c1::act or practice of preventing an action by another that is considered <b>to be harmful </b>to that person if that action is thought to be <b>involuntary</b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Hard Paternalism:&nbsp;{{c1::an action to protect <b>competent adults </b>against their will from the harmful consequences even of their voluntary choices and undertakings}}</div>	"<div>Soft Paternalism: Kid trying to jump off of roof and you stop them</div><div><br></div>Involuntary: without thought or rationale&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Hard Paternalism: Senior wants to run a marathon knowing the full consequences it will have on body and you stop them from doing it</div><div><br></div><div>Hard paternalism is harder to decipher and needs more reasoning</div><div><img src=""paste-bbde9604c754639b0f64bb9498962117fdae41d7.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Sports_Medicine

How are the cervical nerves named compared to the thoracic nerves?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cervical nerves are named after it's inferior vertebrae whereas thoracic nerves are named for their superior vertebrae (lumbar is also named for superior vertebrae)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1d05a834242a2415ac96bd858fedede173257c29.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Pectoral_Region_and_Brachail_Plexus
Why is there 8 cervical nerves when there is only 7 cervical vertebrae?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Since cervical nerves are named after their inferior vertebrae - in between C7 and T1 we can't call it T1 nerve because those are named for their superior vertebrae. What are the actions of all the portions of the trapezius?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They all do elevation, and upward rotation except the 4th portion which does depression (still does upward rotation and retraction)}}</div>	"<div>Traps 2, 3, and 4 do retraction while traps 1 does protraction</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-559df66b7b58d46e0171fccd7455d5fef75d5047.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What is a <b>force couple</b>? Why would we want to use this?<div><br></div><div>What:&nbsp;{{c1::Acting on an object with two more more forces}}</div><div><br></div><div>Why:&nbsp;{{c1::If we had a rotating object and pulled one top left and the other bottom right, it would cause CCW rotation. However, because they are pulling in opposite direction, the translational force is cancelled and therefore, it results in only pure rotational force}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2847d334966fff94c76d0980fdde1e93b9966f58.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What would be an example of a force couple in the trapezius only?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Traps portion 2, 3, and 4, all do upward rotation and retraction of the scapula. But Traps 4 does depression while traps 2 and 3 do elevation. These cancel out leaving only retraction and upward rotation of scapula. <b>If we add the serratus anterior</b>&nbsp;it will cause protraction which will then cause <b>only </b>upward rotation of the scapula.}}<br></div>	"<div>Basically a neutralization chart</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-cc05039c69e4160571119d431891d3b9f74d7ea7.jpg""><br>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What is a <b>functional spinal unit</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pair of adjacent vertebrae (superior and inferior vetrebrae}}<br></div>	"When we talk about the movement of FSU, we are saying the superior vertebrae moving relative to the inferior vertebrae<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c29ab4c60322cb15b710d5c3f5cf541a00df5022.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
How do you describe axial rotation of the FSU?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We describe it as left and right axial rotation <b>relative to the anterior </b>portion of the spine}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fdbad3a849be735f458eabd4140209c0d763935b.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What axial rotation will the right trapezius do on a FSU?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The right trapezius will do left axial rotation}}<br></div>	"Conversely, the left trapezius will do right axial rotation<div><br></div><div><b>Contralateral rotation</b><br><div><img src=""paste-84eea7d9f06d21255b81ba778bef8deca6ace46d.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What <b>neutralization </b>would the serratus anterior and pectorlis minor do on the scapula?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Protraction and depression of the scapula}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-733865cc88ca8a0f1615db7beceb78899233126d.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
There are 3 portions to the pectoralis major, what are these portions called?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::clavicular head, sternal head, sternocostal head (sometimes called abdominal head)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-55f13bdb20973b7c65d89b535553d2772c9eb38d.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What nerve pierces through the coracobrachialis? What are the implications of this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::musculocutaneous nerve}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The implications of this is that it is easily compressed and cause issues}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-bb549ad8f038b16430d473730f094d4e557652cc.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What are the <b>three heads </b>of the deltoid?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::posterior, middle (or lateral), and anterior head}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-62ee6b45809ca55cb6dbfcfb29e0b6243a751c98.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What are the <b>4 </b>rotator cuff muscles?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Supraspinatus, subscapularis, infraspinatus, and teres minor}}<br></div>	"Though the supraspinatus doesn't even do external rotation just abduction KEKW<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-0cbd111302337903644e207119e1d78c57daa12a.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What is <b>elevation </b>of the humerus?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::a combination of both abduction and flexion of the humerus}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e303c7ce78b6da3efd2bdb22ce454e82ddc39ac7.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
When the pectoralis major gains an elevation of more than 90 degrees, what happens to its actions?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It goes from flexion of the humerus at the shoulder to extension of the humerus at the shoulder}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-d4549ce53d156ea4f0cb22788371c94edab024b6.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-6f882003fdaaf50f45b2ef086fd309f876e161b6.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
<i>T/F </i>When doing a pull-up, you are only working your back.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False! In a full ROM, you are working your back AND your chest! When the arm is more than 90 degrees elevated, the pec major becomes an extensor; so from starting position to halfway up the lift, you working your pec major!}}<br></div>	"<div>Lat pull downs also work on the pec major KEKw</div><div><b>Grip doesn't change anything </b>(that's why our terminology is elevation and not flexion or abduction)</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-fcfb693bd4257e7f0c207f7e587d7d3d05d6086e.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What happens to the actions of the deltoid at a humeral elevation greater then 90 degrees?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The anterior and posterior head goes from adduction to abduction}}<br></div>	"It might seem weird but the anterior and posterior heads of the deltoids do adduction because where it pulls on the axis of rotation.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-cc2f05b4795d31be5e50b413220dfec4cf69be16.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle
What is the role of the rotator cuff muscles in humeral translational motion? Why is this important?<div><br></div><div>What: {{c1::They all cause compression of the humeral head against the glenoid fossa (stabilizes glenohumeral joint). Infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis do depression of the humeral head. }}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Why:&nbsp;{{c1::Kaltenborn's rule, when doing abduction of humerus, need inferior translation of humeral head to prevent the head from compressiong the supraspinatus with bursa}}</div>	"<div>Compression to supraspinatus can cause <b>frozen shoulder</b></div><div>- going to physio: they will give you rotator cuff muscle exercises to help with this inferior translation</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-83f7cbea639373ff71389bea8a7d170220ae7941.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Shoulder_Girdle

The brachial artery has a 3 branches that goes off and anastomose with another 3 arteries. "What is <b>(sport) </b>medicine? What are the implications of putting ""sport"" in front of medicine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Medicine is usually the notion to do no harm. However in ""sport"" medicine, athletes want to push boundaries, so they usually involve healthy people with limitations relative to what they want to do. Would they increase injury to increase performance? What should a sports medicine do for athletes with steroids or hybrid assistive limbs?}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-40912d33fbd726e89ab70ce023bcbd4e321f1d12.jpg""><img src=""paste-424e078dee7b760c6d12049ec062059592ed8453.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Sports_Medicine
Why is a <b>sports medicine</b>&nbsp;physician considered category ambivalence? What would be a solution to this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is no clear distinction between a purely therapeutic and performance improvement physicians - especially things in assitive limb technology/biolimbs}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Solution:&nbsp;{{c1::A solution would be to create a new category in itself! (eg: Assistive tech category}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-563e963483019b79bb69778a6202bd77d895af55.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-9ceaf708010f528f0ecb529703a5e723b760a1ef.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Sports_Medicine
What was the gist of <b>Pam Sailors </b>(2013): <i>Mixed competition and mixed messages </i>article?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The gist of the article is the complication of segregation of female vs male in sport. Arguments were made for and against allowing this to continue. People argue that there are physiological differences between men and women that can't be erased. People have also said that we should make sport more into a continuum then a binary system. However at the end of the day, the author argues that we should consider the <b>type of sport </b>before anything else.}}<br></div>	"- English says that it will segregation in sport will never cease and thus woman should make their own sport<div>- Alot of people argue against this because it makes it seem like woman are lesser and need a new sport</div><div>- The whole article is about woman segregation in sports</div><div>- wants to end the binary with a continuum instead of segregation</div><div>- another approach is to gradually integrate woman into mixed sport (since we are always talking about all-or-none</div><div>- have to consider the type of sport tho (contact or non-contact, amateur or professional, individual or team, direct or indirect competition)</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-80ea89880666c717d8c946b52d4a6826bbe0c169.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Sports_Medicine

"What are the <b>ten </b>commandments of logic?<div><br></div><div>1. <b>Ad hominum</b>: {{c1::Don't attack the person's character, but the argument}}</div><div>2. <b>Straw man fallacy</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Do not misrepresent or exaggerate an argument just to make it easier to attack}}</div><div>3.<b> Hasty Generalisation</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::don't use small numbers to represent all}}</div><div>4. <b>Begging the question</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::don't argue the position you are in by assuming one of its premises is true}}</div><div>5. <b>Post Hoc/False cause</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Just because something occurred before, doesn't mean its the cause}}</div><div>6. <b>False Dichotomy</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Do not reduce the argument down to two possibilities}}</div><div>7. <b>Ad Ignorantum</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Do not argue that because of our ignorance, a claim must be true or false (Miran)}}</div><div>8. <b>Burden of proof reversal</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Do not lay the burden of proof onto him that is questioning the claim}}</div><div>9. <b>Non sequitur</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Do not assume ""this"" follows ""that"" when there is no logical connection}}</div><div>10. <b>Bandwagon Fallacy</b>:&nbsp;{{c1::Do not argue that because something is popular, it is true}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-4998248f97124b69afa8c370470754b8bfeb0188.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Logical_Commandments

Falling <b>forwards</b> can result in an injury mechanism which injures a ligament in the arm.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Falling <b>backwards</b> does the same thing. What are these mechanisms and ligaments?</div><div><br></div><div>Forwards:&nbsp;{{c1::Landing with outstretched hand will cause FOOSH which results in radial deviation of the forearm and damage to the ulnar collateral ligament}}</div><div><br></div><div>Backwards:&nbsp;{{c1::Landing with hand behind will cause ulnar deviation of forearm and damage to the radial collateral ligament}}</div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0a21dfecffb7e79d5f86c562a744d612195f7f4a.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder

What is the <b>purpose </b>of the glenohumeral joint capsule?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Its job is to hold synovial fluid in place - not to provide rigidity, therefore there is no capsular ligaments here}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-048fc8cc0dc97f74e479472d5336d554c6a31bbe.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What are the <b>capsular ligaments </b>of the posterior part of the glenohumeral joint?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We don't have any there}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-048fc8cc0dc97f74e479472d5336d554c6a31bbe.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
Why don't we have any capsular ligaments at the posterior part of glenohumeral joint?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The only restriction we would need to have in this area is if we extended the arm, internally rotated the arm, and protracted the shoulder which is very rare (except for during martial arts - our body naturally restricts the movement because our body is a barrier)}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-03901bd0f0f73a6724ca014184ac95f9a19d5000.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-048fc8cc0dc97f74e479472d5336d554c6a31bbe.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder

What does the glenohumeral joint need to restrict in the posterior side vs the anterior side?<div><br></div><div>Posterior:&nbsp;{{c1::Internal rotation (that's why we don't need any ligaments here)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Anterior:&nbsp;{{c1::External rotation (need a lot more capsular ligaments here)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-505fa17e7dd12529cf02e40e51b0e9b362511008.jpg""><img src=""paste-2b7813f7dd562d5219e72c8c99cf7431ff869ab7.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What are the <b>three </b>capsular ligaments of the anterior glenohumeral joint?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Superior GH ligament}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Middle GH ligament}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Inferior GH ligament}}</div>	"Prevents external rotation of the arm at the shoulder<div><img src=""paste-0d80e000f4b9f7864362a7937781fc7d05a0ba6a.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What is an <b>extrinsic ligament </b>of the GH joint?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Coracohumeral ligament - sits outside of the joint capsule}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-0d80e000f4b9f7864362a7937781fc7d05a0ba6a.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What do the <b>three </b>capsular ligaments of the anterior GH joint restrict?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Superior GH ligament: limits inferior translation in <b>neutral position</b>}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Middle GH ligament: limits anterior translation and external rotation in <b>0 - 45 degree abduction</b>}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Inferior GH ligament: limits anterior translation and external rotation <b>&gt;45 degrees abduction</b>}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-f2f1201cddb8708646fccc0694ddb356134cee6d.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
<div>What is the most common mechanism for a <b>shoulder dislocation</b>? What would I tear from 0-45 degree abduction? How about beyond that (&gt;45 degrees)?</div><div><br></div>Mechanism: {{c1::anterior translation and external rotation}}<div><br></div><div>0-45:&nbsp;{{c1::Middle GH ligament tear}}</div><div><br></div><div>&gt;45:&nbsp;{{c1::Inferior GH ligament tear}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b4ab02ae976afb99ab6c8bf4fdace308217f9009.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder

What creates glenohumeral <b>elevation</b> vs glenohumeral <b>depression</b>? Why is knowing this important?<div><br></div><div>Elevation:&nbsp;{{c1::Anterior deltoid, middle deltoid, posteior deltoid}}</div><div><br></div><div>Depression:&nbsp;{{c1::Infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis}}</div><div><br></div><div>Importance:&nbsp;{{c1::Too much elevation will cause compression of the supraspinatus resulting in <b>frozen shoulder</b>. We need the depression from these rotator cuff muscles to neutralize these actions}}</div>	"The depression is important for kaltenborns rule!<div><img src=""paste-b89fc0b12a2917c3970afd401929a50eae21dab6.jpg""><img src=""paste-9ae8f8ed9c64747927df94f3a3ccf282c5bc2ed6.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What is the <b>scapulothoracic joint</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is a not a true joint because the scapula and the thoracic is not actually touching but it is important and held together by muscles}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6f279e0b783ca0210f79cdc924a7445735a03e48.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What is the <b>scapulohumeral rhythm</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The combination of both GH abduction and ST joint upward rotation. Typically, this rhythm is seen as a 2:1 where for every 2 degrees of GH abduction, there will be 1 degree of ST joint upward rotation combining to form arm abduction}}<br></div>	"GH: glenohumeral<div>ST: Scapulothoracic</div><div><br></div><div>This mainly occurs because GH joint abduction occurs in the scapular plane instead of the frontal plane.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f00325fe4ab68f89cce9ac20c88881c70553ce8d.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-98bea89f0cd942e978cfc935ab7b4e195f24b0ed.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What would abduction in the scapular plane look like?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::around 35 degrees in front of you}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ae328118befc1dd8eeb4c021f1c714c182e7944e.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What is the difference between scapular plane abduction vs frontal plane abduction?<div><br></div><div>Scapular plane:&nbsp;{{c1::Pure humeral abduction (35 degrees in front)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Frontal plane:&nbsp;{{c1::Humeral abduction + extension}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b88bbc43b4f1cd88a17af9393358ce1097e3a379.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
Why would we want to train scapular plane abduction more then frontal plane abduction?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Since frontal plane abduction requires humeral extension, there is a higher chance for impingement at the shoulder. In the scapular plane, the head of the humerus is in a more ideal spot. }}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b88bbc43b4f1cd88a17af9393358ce1097e3a379.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What are some techniques we can use to <b>limit </b>subacromial impingement?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Humeral depression: train subscapularis, infraspinatus, and teres minor}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Scapulohumeral rhythm: make sure we are having enough scapular upward rotation}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::train in motions that go into the scapular plane instead of the frontal plane - be able to control the scapular retraction/protraction so that it can adapt and accommodate motions in the scapular plane. This is why a lot of people look into the fluidity of our scapula!}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5d5375fcc57a5a7f488ae9692d3ce4ffbcde140b.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
How does the different planes that we can do humeral abduction affect the <b>anterior joint capsule</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. Scapular plane: {{c1::Movement in the scapular plane will cause pure humeral abduction so everything good here}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>2. Frontal plane:&nbsp;{{c1::The added extension of the humerus will cause stretch on the anterior joint capsule and could lead to shoulder dislocation}}</div><div><br></div><div>3. Scapular + Frontal:&nbsp;{{c1::If you are able to retract your scapula while going into that frontal plane then your all good bro}}</div>	"Looking to train in the scapular plane or identifying that someone needs to retract their scapulas during humeral abduction could lead to reduction of shoulder injuries!<div><br><div><img src=""paste-a46fbddcc5d9757681708b8c7c51ed4680eadc05.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Kinesiology_Elbow_and_Shoulder
What kind of <b>aponeruroses </b>does the lateral anterior wall muscles have? Where is it located?<div><br></div><div>Kind:&nbsp;{{c1::Bilaminar aponeureses}}</div><div><br></div><div>Where:&nbsp;{{c1::1 posterior and 1 anterior}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-1d860f8b47ba96cf93e99373d18352bb7078564d.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Abdominal_Wall_and_Anterolateral_Neck
What do we call the point in the abdominal wall where muscle, and aponeroses come together?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Line of fusion}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-54f02fb573899379fa4d951625011a1d02dce74c.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Abdominal_Wall_and_Anterolateral_Neck
Describe the aponeuroses of the TA, IO, and EO <b>superior</b> to the arcuate line. How about inferior to the <b>arcuate</b> line?<div><br></div><div><b><u>Superior to arcuate line</u></b></div><div><b><u><br></u></b></div><div>TA:&nbsp;{{c1::Both anterior and posterior will go behidn the rectus abdominus}}</div><div><br></div><div>IO:&nbsp;{{c1::Posterior will go behind RA while anterior will go in front of RA}}</div><div><br></div><div>EO:&nbsp;{{c1::Both posterior and anterior will go in front of RA}}</div><div><br></div><div><b><u>inferior to arcuate line</u></b></div><div><b><u><br></u></b></div><div>{{c1::All will go anterior to RA}}<b><u><br></u></b></div>	"TA: transverse abdominus<div>IO: internal oblique</div><div>EO: external oblique</div><div><br></div><div>All will run to thoracolumbar fascia</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-34b96b55845bf177a901b5503323f3f9947afc08.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-1dfecafbb8e099123f13633b7e55397b96d9a2af.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Abdominal_Wall_and_Anterolateral_Neck

Superior to the arcuate line, what lateral abdominal wall muscle makes up the posterior rectus sheathe? The external oblique, the internal oblique, and the rectus abdominis all compress the abdominal contents. When would we need to use this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::vomitting or building up intra-abdominal pressure (helps increase our blood pressure, give support to spine, or punching)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8b4c33b8103278b346b1b26fdb4af520dc4ff014.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Abdominal_Wall_and_Anterolateral_Neck

What is the significance of the <b>two portions </b>of the psoas major? Why is this important?<div><br></div><div>Two portions: {{c1::The posterior portion will extend the vertebrae its attached to while the anterior portion will flex the vertebrae its attached to}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Importance:&nbsp;{{c1::Allows us to consider whether to stretch the posterior or anterior portion of the psoas major }}</div>	"This is because the axis of rotation is different for both portions!<div><br></div><div>Anterior portion: Vertrebral discs T12 - L5</div><div><br></div><div>Posterior portion: transverse processes L1 - L5</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-86b60a4b6e36c79edd5597290d68eaa83f591372.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Abdominal_Wall_and_Anterolateral_Neck

What are the three types of respiration? What does each mean?<div>&nbsp;</div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Primary: breathing we do at rest}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Secondary: breathing when we do physical activity}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Tertiary: emergency respiration (not what we should be used - backup)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-3c66c18657bf9084e73e1621c104e8f5ea151a62.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Musculature_of_the_Abdominal_Wall_and_Anterolateral_Neck

"Why do we classify some ribs as ""true"" and others as ""false""? Also we have ""floating ribs""??<div><br></div><div>True:&nbsp;{{c1::Because it articulates directly with the sternum through costal cartilages}}</div><div><br></div><div>False:&nbsp;{{c1::Still articulate with the sternum but they all share a costal cartilage}}</div><div><br></div><div>Floating:&nbsp;{{c1::Don't articulate with the stern - just floating there}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-d166f03707336421a0919cb2cf0e677c627e1775.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs

What are the <b>superior </b>and <b>inferior </b>attachments of the external and internal intercostal muscles? What are the directions of these?<div><br></div><div>External:&nbsp;{{c1::Superior = inferior aspect of the superior rib; Inferior = superior aspect of inferior rib}}</div><div>Direction:&nbsp;{{c1::Start superior posterior and run inferior anterior}}</div><div><br></div><div>Internal:&nbsp;{{c1::Superior = inferior aspect of superior rib; inferior = superior aspect of inferior rib}}</div><div>Direction:&nbsp;{{c1::Superior anterior - inferior posterior}}</div>	"<div>Just from general observation:</div><div><br></div><div>External intercostals are angled outwards while internal intercostals are angled inwards</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-c56863f3f20f8c779b81bc459cd4d9cc8b84972b.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
What is the deepest of the intercostal mucles? What direction does it's fibers run?<div><br></div><div>What: {{c1::Innermost intercostals}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Direction: {{c1::Superior anterior - inferior posterior}}</div>	"The direction of the innermost intercostals are similar to the internal intercostal, however there is less of a diagonal and more vertical<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-4b606decbe87f884b517f1737f2a78a1e5a97f02.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
In the traditional view, what is the action of the external intercostals? How about internal intercostals?<div><br></div><div>External:&nbsp;{{c1::Elevate the ribs}}</div><div>Internal:&nbsp;{{c1::Depress the ribs}}</div>	"Allows for a <i>bucket handle </i>manoeuvre&nbsp;<div>- opens out to the side when elevated</div><div>- compresses inwards when depressed</div><div><br></div><div>Allows our lungs to expand when we breathe.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-08ee8739aca15c17424673e2d1fdd155ce68c847.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
What is the <i>bucket handle </i>manoeuvre? Why is this important?<div><br></div><div>What is it. {{c1::A manoeuvre done by our internal and external intercostal muscles which depress and elevate the ribs respectively. When we depress it, the ribs also compress inward, and when we elevate, the ribs push outwards similar to a handle of a bucket when you move it}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Importance:&nbsp;{{c1::This is important because this allows our lungs to expand in our thoracic cavity when we breathe in and also allows it to go back to starting position}}</div>	"Allows for a <i>bucket handle </i>manoeuvre&nbsp;<div>- opens out to the side when elevated</div><div>- compresses inwards when depressed</div><div><br></div><div>Allows our lungs to expand when we breathe.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-08ee8739aca15c17424673e2d1fdd155ce68c847.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs

What is the <b>distal attachment </b>of the diaphragm?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It inserts into itself! They insert into the fibers of the tendons of the other tendon. This location is known as the <b>central tendon</b>.}}<br></div>	"<div>Therefore, when it contracts, it pulls the central tendon out towards the side and downwards - which presses the abdominal contents downwards and therefore increases space for lungs to expand</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3c6384aa4323773eb1d9cbda565ce0a6ec25afff.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
What happens when the diaphragm contracts?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Since its distal attachment is itself, whereever the diaphragm contracts, it will pull the itself outwards and downwards giving space for the lung to expand}}<br></div>	"<div>Therefore, when it contracts, it pulls the central tendon out towards the side and downwards - which presses the abdominal contents downwards and therefore increases space for lungs to expand</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-3c6384aa4323773eb1d9cbda565ce0a6ec25afff.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs

What are the <b>three types of breathing</b>? What mode of breathing do we use for each?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Diaphragmatic: primary breathing (when we relaxing)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Thoracic expansion and contraction: secondary breathing (more strenous)}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Thoracic elevation and depression: tertiary breathing (emergency)}}</div>	"<div>In the tertiary breathing - it only does elevation and depression, forces your ribs up and down, not ideal but in case of emergencies.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-635104bc3539a2b3720c19e116d71579ff42051e.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs

What intercostal muscle is used for inspiration and which one is used for expiration?<div><br></div><div>Inspiration:&nbsp;{{c1::external intercostals}}</div><div><br></div><div>Expiration:&nbsp;{{c1::internal intercostals}}</div>	"I kinda remember this through opposites. <b>in</b>spiration uses <b>ex</b>ternal intercostals while <b>ex</b>piration uses <b>in</b>ternal intercostals<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-567897c3026cd5a10e8839acd7bff0cfbdf03a1b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
What is the first thing you have to consider when beginning programming for a youth athlete?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A needs analysis! Must look at sport specific qualities as well as individual needs}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-86869fcd48e7bd7f09f6b0789f132c3aaa5c5abd.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_for_Youth_and_Wrestling
What are<b>&nbsp;youth specific considerations </b>when creating a needs analysis for youth?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We have to consider how much training they would have to do, and cater towards this. This means taking into account any outside training they might be doing. We also have to consider other commitments, developmental, chronological, and training age.}}<br></div>	"Primary problem is managing the volume of training<div>- other commitments (physio, personal trainer etc.)</div><div>- must also take into account the development age and chronological age</div><div>- tolerance to amount of stress</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a50f3fbd9dfc482c1ad65d5cb1c365d6151f5c12.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_for_Youth_and_Wrestling
What is <b>developmental </b>vs <b>chronological </b>age?<div><br></div><div>Developmental:&nbsp;{{c1::Age relative to peak height velocity/growth spurt}}&nbsp;</div><div>Chronological:&nbsp;{{c1::Age in years (actual age)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-73923f274d47cc7195f02f9bc002b5fb657ee58c.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_for_Youth_and_Wrestling
What is the <b>process </b>of development we should program for youth athletes (pyramid)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We must first start off with the foundation (<b>Movement skills/work capacity</b>)&nbsp;- get that robust base in which you can build off from. Then go into <b>general strength/hypertrophy</b> --&gt; <b>max strength</b> --&gt; <b>explosive strength/power</b> --&gt; <b>speed</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-93aba854401eada7dd73d9b4c2ead91f67973bb2.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_for_Youth_and_Wrestling
If an athlete is still pre-peak height velocity, how does this relate to the pyramid of athletic potential?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::You should use an extended period of time to work on movement skills and work capacity}}<br></div>	"You can't expect to work on speed with someone who can't orient themselves in space first!<div><img src=""paste-75809a0c2feb6ffacfba9cd6d7a1b498365b7206.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_for_Youth_and_Wrestling
What is more important in programming for youth, developmental age or chronological age?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If your not stupid, its developmental age. Chronological age doesn't tell us anything about the athlete.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-75809a0c2feb6ffacfba9cd6d7a1b498365b7206.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Programming_for_Youth_and_Wrestling

What is <b>mitral valve regurgitation</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When the bicuspid valve doesn't work properly which causes the blood to return back from the left ventricle to the left atrium.}}<br></div>	"Occurs in 15-20% of people<div>Susceptible to bacterial damage<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3afa9656617c50e077d9847f5991061eeeec3e91.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
Why is the <b>Mitral valve </b>commonly assessed in the heart? Why doesn't the tricuspid valve have the same amount of caution?<div><br><div>Commonly: {{c1::It is susceptible to bacterial damage which can cause mitral valve regurgitation (flow back from left ventricle to left atrium)}}<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>Why doesn't:&nbsp;{{c1::This is because the mitral valve accepts blood right after it circulates in the blood which could latch on to the valve from the lungs - most common in Strep Throat (easy bacteria latching to mitral valve)}}</div>	"Occurs in 15-20% of people<div>Susceptible to bacterial damage<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3afa9656617c50e077d9847f5991061eeeec3e91.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs

What do <b>papillary muscles </b>do? What is the use of it?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Pull on the chordae tendinae which pull on the right AV valve which closes it during ventricular contraction}}<br></div>	"Also prevents prolapse from occuring (AV valve from opening backwards and causing regurgitation<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-be2f51864e2f671d9db1ff792822aa91bf60a53e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs

What is the positive feedback loop in the heart known as cardiac hypertrophy? How do we fix this?<div><br></div><div>Cardiac Hypertrophy:&nbsp;{{c1::As you work your trabeculae carnae muscles, it grows inward making the ventricular chamber smaller and therefore less blood will be pumped out per beat. The heart will have to compensate by beating faster, which will in turn increase the trabeculae carnae muscles and the loop goes on!}}</div><div><br></div><div>Fix:&nbsp;{{c1::Have as little trabeculae carnae muscles as possible such that we have more ventricular filling and more elasticity (decreases heart rate)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-7c2299f57a1e0ba190cdeeb4fb92f84151f4eedc.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
