How is the <b>sympathetic trunk </b>important?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Comprises of ganglia which activates the sympathetic nervous system after sensory information is received}}<br></div>	"Eg: If it is cold, sensory receptors will send signals to ganglia in the left and right sympathetic trunks which activate the sympathetic nervous system which makes us hotter.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3f9019a8fc9bbdb032ed376690b6f1f8d29f21f1.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Thoracic_Cavity_Heart_and_Lungs
What is the <b>golden mean </b>based on when we try to seek it?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is based on what is intermediate - but intermediate relative to us, not in the object}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2e6ce2d9c7a37f82bbe275be1ffec584c27b9ffc.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
Name the&nbsp;<i>origin</i>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<i>insertion</i>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<b>Palmaris Brevis</b>	<b><i>Origin</i></b><div>Ulnar carpals</div><div><br></div><div><b><i>Insertion</i></b></div><div>Skin of hypothenar eminence</div><div>Palmar Fascia</div>	"<img src=""paste-601942f873626e2d51de281667ea86ac06acbdde.jpg"">"		
What are the <b>pros </b>of doping bans?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Respect for the game}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Unfair advantage}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Harms (esp. health)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Coercion}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Unintended consequences}}</div>	"If someone else takes it, you may be coercing me to take it to be competitive<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-fd69505133e7d7ce663265aa8c35b2143d3c0ce6.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What are the arguments for <b>anti-doping</b> bans?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Unwarranted paternalism (don't tell me what to do!)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Singling out drugs is inconsistent}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Unfairness, coercion, and harm arguments lack force}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-fd69505133e7d7ce663265aa8c35b2143d3c0ce6.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
The <b>golden mean </b>in virtue ethics is relative to the&nbsp;{{c1::individual}}	"<div>Since its relative, we can't generalize it mathematically</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-e82d0c879817f5a54e3a2378838b61a858cbe67e.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-3add05737c2f62be83f3e75eebd8b8b149dbc696.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
Why should we strive to do things in the <b>golden mean</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::To achieve Eudaimonia}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cd2a65a70d92344ed1db6307f8849cc292c52b19.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
&nbsp;Does the golden mean apply to <b>everything</b>? (give an argument for and against)<div><br></div><div>Against:&nbsp;{{c1::There are actions that are completely wrong or completely good which doesn't have a mean. Eg: Love, peace, friendship are completely good and murder, adultery, and theft and completely wrong}}</div><div><br></div><div>For:&nbsp;{{c1::Something like having too much peace could be bad, if you are getting bullied and refuse to stand up for yourself, that could be harmful. }}</div>	"<img src=""paste-8da6293c4d89e6589fedef69f1aa4dea8ea556c8.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
Does drug taking in sport have a <b>golden mean</b>? (virtue ethics)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is an argument that it doesn't have a golden mean in virtue ethics by saing that you need to stay natural throughout}}<br></div>	"Some people say it doesn't have a mean --&gt; completely wrong<div><br></div><div>An argument for not taking drugs using virtue ethics would be that you have to stay natural. However, this could lead to the notion of not wearing glasses or not treating congenital defects. You won't even be able to take medicine if you take this position!</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-087ed693abda8250071dda261d50d5711ea52025.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
Is the ban on doping <b>justified</b>? Why? (Virtue ethics)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::First, we have to tie in the golden mean into doping. We have to find three positions: deficiency, excess, and moderation.}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>First Attitude: {{c1:: winning (indifference, fanatic, caring)</div><div><br></div><div>The ban is justified to <b>guard against fanaticism</b>, is unnecessary at the deficient position, and is possibly unnecessary at the moderate level (<b>If your virtuous you don't need to care about this</b>)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Second Attitude:&nbsp;{{c1::Agency (determinism - the though that you already lost, radical freedom - you can score 100 points!, constrained freedom - you can affect the outcome of the game but you can't get 100 points. (<b>you need some agency which may allow you to take drugs in this position</b>)}}&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Third Attitude:&nbsp;{{c1::health and harm (cowardice, rashness, courage) (<b>in this position, we may not want to ban but because we want people to be couragous and not that we want to protect them from it</b>)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Fourth Attitude:&nbsp;{{c1::Quality of performance (mediocrity, perfection, excellence) - (<b>virtous athlete wouldn't be banned for taking doping</b>)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-ee4bb647ee85f76b66715bd29eb9a2aaca05784c.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-d672ff86cadbcb311edecaa673257977fd433f69.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-d60c97ffe6c54bc9b1bdd14f88b8f7309610ba71.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-27a02c7731c631494edf0dcf10bdf580bded270f.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
Do <b>virtuous athletes </b>need a ban?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, they do not need a ban}}<br></div>	"However, sport in itself isn't virtuous, so it's hard to base your rules in sport on virtues ethics!<div><br></div><div>There, until athletes become virtuous, the ban is <b>likely needed</b>.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-bdfe5cbe1a3ff59e2afaa562f1a76777c98dbb48.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
Is virtue ethics <b>subjective </b>or <b>objective</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Artistotle claims that good living is dependent on <b>who we are </b>- it is subjective}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-39750621f569291f61492e72991c9b82947c22af.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
"What is the <b>gist </b>of the article ""Artistotle's Golden Mean: Its implications for the Doping Debate"" (Hwang and Kretchmer)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that we can use the Golden mean to figure out if a doping ban is justified or not. They take four different attitues and apply the golden mean model on it - deficiency, extreme, and moderate (golden mean) where to be virtuous is to be in the middle. It is concluded that if the every athlete is virtuous and the sport itself is virtuous, then perhaps we don't need a doping ban, however this is not the case in modern society, So until then, a ban is justified.}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-290cac6f56e2ddfdac9b7be6f1639507c3cc7057.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping

Which cranial nerves come off of the <b>cerebrum</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::CN I and II, 3-12 come from the brainstem}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3000c4e5b1fb49cebfc014be48cb26d6b77324ea.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Head_Neck_and_Cranial_Nerves
"Former WADA director Dick Pound has claimed that ""sport is governed by all sorts of agreed upon arbitrary rules. <b>Get over it</b>. You can opt out of them so you are free.<div><br></div><div>What are the <b>two main </b>problems with Pound's statement?</div><div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::There are only two choices: abide or leave. There is no possibility to abide by the rules and question the rules - this is paternalism of another level}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Pound also says that athletes consent to accept the ban but is it consent when presented with biased information? Eg: They say all doping is bad but do not address therapeutic doping.}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-aa81a42feaab50c668d4b8ccf31bb0711271b7a6.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-4ee93a0dedf5e391046314d194c0edd4d85d43d1.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
"Former WADA director Dick Pound has claimed that ""sport is governed by all sorts of agreed upon arbitrary rules.&nbsp;<b>Get over it</b>. You can opt out of them so you are free.<div><br></div><div>If you use virtue ethics to articulate this stance, what are the <b>implications</b>?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Well if I used virtue ethics, whatever Dick Pound said wouldn't matter to me, because virtue ethics deals with who I am as a person, not how other people are. I can't question that.}}<br></div>"	"If I am a virtuous athlete, the ban is irrelevant - focused on the person. (though a problem is ""what does that mean?"".<div><br></div><div>- This is because this framework doesn't deal with what I'm faced but with who I am.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-ec75de3a06fb1358a7316c7ed4bdc6e6fe126598.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What if doping becomes an <b>addiction</b>? Would would we say about the bans on doping?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If true, we can support the ban on certain addictive PED's, however, saying this would mean that the athlete may not be morally responsible which is a tough stance to stand on.}}<br></div>	"What I mean by being not morally responsible is that an athlete can take drugs and then just blame it on the addiction to avoid responsibility. It's like a killer coming to court and blaming it on a psychological illness - at what point is the person themselves responsible for what they've done?<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-1a4db073a04091f563ef90a6737760840127fdff.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What is JS Mill's stance on <b>Liberty</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::His stance is that the only time someone would be able to interfere with the agency of another is self-defence or prevent harm for others (protection)}}<br></div>	"Over himself, over his own body and mind, the individual is sovereign.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-69e8d5b9ea59a82ec705696bfb19acea075be568.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What is a problem with JS Mill's stance of doing no harm to others?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::What constitutes harm to others vs harm to oneself? Stuff like inferred harm (eg: not wearing a seatbelt = harm to self?) Is doping in sport harm?}}<br></div>	"There has to be a limit to what harm is to others.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-cbbf3e35770532bb1beaac31a14f7c2bf579fc15.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What is the <b>no harm principle</b>? (JS Mill)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We are free to do what makes happy until such action does not produce as many positive utiles as an alternation action (<b>principle of liberty</b>), and in many cases, harming others is not <b>optimific </b>(doesn't give the most positive utils) and as such, we cannot allow harm to others - The no harm principle.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6a39c4f72303d85814b4e6ad8bad537885963e55.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What counts as harm to others?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Can be direct/indirect comission or omission. Any notion of harm needs to encompass all of these}}<br></div>	"<div>Commission: doing something, committing to an action</div><div>Omission: failing to do something. Inaction or standing by</div><div>- each of these can be direct or indirect harm</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-fb1cb09cfe02b02f840ecb802fca17c32ecf0f64.jpg""><br>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What are the <b>two revisions </b>to JS Mill's no harm principle?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::The harmful conduct prevention principle: prevent direct and/or indirect harm}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::General harm prevention principle: harm encompasses commission and omission.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e79195e8f9131a23e463bc877a041eba727422a9.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
In the <b>no harm principle </b>we can compel people not to harm others (directly/indirectly) and to give help to prevent harm. However some conditions must apply, what are these conditions?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We must not compel when it produces more harm than the prevented act (eg: stopping someone by shooting them in the head). We can also compel those not capable of making informed choices (children) but more mature adults have more freedom}}<br></div>	"So prevent harm but in an efficient and economical way.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-713de642f579c0709fbf1709dca58612cc19bfd1.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
Is <b>doping </b>a form of <b>direct </b>harm? (thinking Rule Utilitarian)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We might argue that doping causes harm to others such that paternalism is warranted. There are two main arguments given here, <b>1. </b>If you dope and I don't, I'll lose the competitive edge, <b>2. </b>If you dope, it'll force me to dope (coercion)}}<br></div>	"The problem is argument #1 is that it assumes that I have a <b>right </b>to have that competitive advantage. If I was shit at the sport, why would I have a competitive edge and even more so a ""right"" to that competitive edge?<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-7e433e64c934ed787aab62d24982eac6850f7768.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
What is <b>RTP</b>? What is our role as a <b>S&amp;C coach</b>?<div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Process of integrating an athlete back into play --&gt; medical clearance of an athlete for full participation without restriction}}<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>Role:&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Optimize</b> loading with injury while <b>maximizing safety </b>and looking for <b>opportunities</b> to better the athlete globally even during pre-injury}}</div>	"Very rare chance to pull an athlete out of sport for a long time to better their foundation.<div><img src=""paste-491f9dedd557ae0e81d557e1037f4b979f17525d.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What are <b>integrated service teams</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::An athlete-centred approach where we have multiple professionals around them and cooperating to support the athlete}}<br></div>	"Think about Mexico where there were multiple people coming together for a child.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-9b9e3b88252f37fdefda119c99f32a1a59cbd60f.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the role of <b>sport's medicine </b>personnel for the injury of an athlete?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>Communicate</b> within the IST and educating the athlete about the injury while help determining roles in RTP. Being able to <b>outline </b>the structure of RTP based on injury/context (<b>milestones</b> and pre-participation requirements)}}<br></div>	"Also, they should be able to follow-throughout the whole RTP process!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-28b49f344990c5f46df80841249a9ebce80b372e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What are the <b>coaching staff's roles </b>during an athlete's RTP?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Accommodate athlete's needs through RTP process and tactically give guidance while reducing injury while keeping them <b>engaged</b>. Also, communicate!}}<br></div>	"Communicate: giving feedback to IST and outlining expectations of the athlete<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-8f4bd326e20e0d8241d4f92e2789ac31d9e7ace0.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>athlete's role </b>in their own RTP process?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Someone who <b>commits</b> to the RTP process, <b>communicates</b> well and open to changes in program (coping and mindset) - being able to <b>voice concerns</b>}}<br></div>	"We as the IST are also responsible for facilitating an open receptive environment, but the athlete can't sit in the backseat. They have to play an active role.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f65fe0cb6cbe21129440b211182f8a3ecc5036e5.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is <b>our </b>(Kinesiologist/Strength Coach's) role in an athletes RTP?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They communicate the most with the athlete and therefore must be really good with their communcations with the IST. Should also <b>involve </b>the athlete in the programming. -- <b>ongoing</b> evaluation (must stay flexible)}}<br></div>	"Communicate: update IST on status, share plan and program, and give them special considerations from medical<div><br></div><div>Allowing the athlete to involve themselves will give them freedom - allow them to gain control of their process (most commonly in injuries is the mindset of losing control)</div><div><br></div><div>By staying flexible, you can have a plan, but you need to have backups!</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-fd516b1b010f0c684216d7c814f3b1f08a8092cf.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>1st stage </b>of RTP according to Matt Yaworski? What happens in this stage?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Acute}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is where we should just respect the injury, <b>do not do jack shit that increases harm to the injury</b>. Take orders from the managing therapist and proceed with caution!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d31371a797e77de3398e2052b04ab23b7294c188.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>2nd&nbsp;stage </b>of RTP according to Matt Yaworski? What happens in this stage?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Introductory}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Start to integrate movement into the injured structure. Essential to <b>monitor</b> for pain, swelling, and change in ROM}}<br></div>	"Make sure to keep on asking about the injury!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2c3c26acae8a4c066837108be57155fcf36a1562.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>3rd&nbsp;stage </b>of RTP according to Matt Yaworski? What happens in this stage?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Building Capacity}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Start to <b>condition </b>the athlete while having more <b>autonomy</b> of S&amp;C. Return to <b>normal programming</b> but still consider <b>modifications</b> for injury}}<br></div>	"Monitoring is essential here! Not going too overboard with loading but also not too underboard as well<div><br><div><img src=""paste-941dee8c275bb5ea4bb663f32b842b81e91534ca.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>4th&nbsp;stage </b>of RTP according to Matt Yaworski? What happens in this stage?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Specialization}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Focus in on what they<b> need to do</b> to be able to perform successfully - look at where we <b>need </b>them to be - look for <b>key performance indicators</b> (Eg: get to X-inch vertical jump)}}<br></div>	"Getting them specifically ready for returning to sport. Mostly important during competitive season - not that important in the off-season where they would probably just do general training.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Also important to address the total amount of volume that they are doing away from S&amp;C. (adjust to respect total workload)<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a861fc4c0d99ab404598234bd3308cdf55c85372.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>5th&nbsp;stage </b>of RTP according to Matt Yaworski? What happens in this stage?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Return to Sport}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>Continuum</b> from individual skills practice --&gt; full game. S&amp;C plan will need to <b>change</b> to <b>reflect their participation</b>.}}<br></div>	"Athletes often return with the <b>minimum </b>required. Athlete is most of the time desperate to get back into play. Still trying to build and program the athlete to continue to improve and injuries and deficiencies (since they may not be at 100% in this stage)<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-4d35f85f959fe2d11b5887199a7dc5222e1c33a3.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>6th&nbsp;stage </b>of RTP according to Matt Yaworski? What happens in this stage?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Continued Montoring}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Making sure nothing gets unnoticed and that RTP is seamless!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-83dd23fe0cb0d165eb92d57102b05af2d6233bdf.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What are the <b>6 stages </b>of an athlete's RTP according to Matt Yaworski (purely anecdote from his experience)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Acute: just got injured}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Introductory: start movement}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Building capacity: start to condition athlete}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Specialization: focus on key performance indicators}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Return to sport: continuum from skills --&gt; full game}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::Continued monitoring: make sure nothing wrong happens}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2b653ba9405e128d5164ec9360e8d4e2d3820ca8.jpg""><img src=""paste-a0d2a1a5e5d2ad7d774047b3af619d0f899f2ebe.jpg""><img src=""paste-e41766bcea314e50553d3752392937970dc1a81a.jpg""><img src=""paste-bf034c9f96cea092c43df5069f7c7fbfa7523b4c.jpg""><img src=""paste-050a338b74e03fe046187e8aa6bfa03ccd848de9.jpg""><img src=""paste-c80b5ec2744382c30e50f62500fa60ad80416672.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
How do we <b>facilitate </b>athlete percieved readiness?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Have the coach put them in scenarios that let them succeed, have the medical/therapy staff clearly identify tests to boost their confidence, and discussions with sport pysch. }}<br></div>	"If the athlete is not ready for sport even though they are fully recovered - it may cause injury again!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-338de0f3ed0559f6fdf06ccae41faffc8b23516f.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring

What is <b>monitoring</b>&nbsp;(of an athlete)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Measuring the internal or external load of an athlete. It encompasses many things, and in an ideal world, where you are provided with unlimited amount of money, you could potentially monitor <b>everything </b>an athlete does}}<br></div>	"Includes internal loads like heart rate as well as external loads like training time or speed. (Sleep monitoring is also mentioned here)<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-b00aa006cc99f224af503b87e68f719376015e59.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>best </b>method of monitoring (according to Matt Yaworski)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A conversation in words and a connection with the athlete.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-4ba1db6f1738f77bffd38dc61ad3290a5636678c.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the <b>fundamentals </b>of athlete monitoring?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Collecting and analyzing date over and over to really get to know the athlete and figuring out their baseline.}}<br></div>	"Most of the time we don't have the budget, so we have to figure out cheap methods to collect data<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-592a8623248ea7f698798ed22bc48cb2f0ab72f8.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
"Matt Yaworski did his Masters on this graph, what does it represent?<div><img src=""paste-bf53778eff24f0ab0a8fef59da68749fc0cb20ce.jpg""><img src=""paste-25b16f7d6c3bd2896e234a951eed23b7ac6ecd3f.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::He measured the RPE vs heart rate of varsity ice hockey and athletes and found that they were very correlated with each other!}}<br></div>"	Perceived difficulty aligned with the expected difficulty. Is a cheap method that could be used to inform coaches on athlete's monitoring. Would probably not be appropriate for professional teams but could be good for lower budget where not everyone has access to a heart rate monitor.	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What can an <b>acute:chronic workload ratio </b>give us?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The amount of injury risk when doing an acute workload vs what they've done chronically}}<br></div>	"Acute = 1 week<div>Chronic = 4 week</div><div><br></div><div>Eg: If the ratio is 1:1 then the acute workload is similar to the chronic workload that the athlete has done for the past 4 weeks, the risk of injury is very low, whereas if the ratio is 2:1, the amount of risk increases by 20%!</div><div><br></div><div>This is why we should be mindful of the amount of workload and athlete is going through and a good way to educate the coach on.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-d181089c01c3769c4ab60eb0179825f5ac95304a.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring
What is the most important thing to keep in mind when <b>implementing </b>monitoring data for an athlete?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::N = 1 still applies, monitor for trends and do not react reflexively}}<br></div>	"Physically hard training is required to prepare athletes for the demands of competition (but also be aware of excessive loading for increased injury risk) - basically don't let the athlete be a bitch.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-cab5cb9a10cb9ccec582b9efc3a2bb5427672c2c.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Injury_Management_and_Workload_Monitoring

What does the <b>spinal posture </b>of a child look like? (9-11 female or 11-13 male)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A mther yking straight line. These mther ykers don't got curves}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ccb55c1a62d121591badd3563e1836c11cedb01f.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Why is our spine curved?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Balance - mainly cuz our head is fking big so our whole body compensates. Also our ribs and stomach stick forward do we need thoracic kyphosis to compensate it. Another reason is <b>energy cost </b>- this spinal curvature minimizes energy cost}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b217a86db07ea4c961d55a784560d7df6260c41d.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-1084245e9cd69b57fabfccb0870900b40874f42f.jpg""></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How does the spine <b>optimize </b>energy cost?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It allows the lever arm to be as small as possible while compensating for unbalanced weights}}<br></div>	"<div>This allows us to hold the spine in place with only small muscle activity and ligaments</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-e3a11f203673acade6b261b8813ef57590ea8a1c.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What are the <b>implications </b>of a moderate forward head posture on the spine? How about an excessive forward head posture? (Think torque)<div><br></div><div>Moderate:&nbsp;{{c1::You will lose cervical lordosis and move into cervical kyphosis --&gt; therefore you would now need muscles to go into head extension instead of flexion (pain in back of neck). You would also have an increase in thoracic kyphosis moment arm which increases muscle activity of the back.}}</div><div><br></div><div>Excessive:&nbsp;{{c1::Cervical lordosis will return only because there is excessive thoracic kyphosis. Even more muscle activity in the back will need to be used to compensate (larger moments arms!)}}</div>	"Mther fking smartphones bro<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-e32f8fbd8d12df3f73b089ac43792741aa00ee71.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How does the head create <b>lordosis </b>and <b>kyphosis </b>of the spine? (normal adult spine posture)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Weight of head creates extensor torque in cervical spine causing passive cervical lordosis. It also creates a flexor torque in thoracic spine causing passive thoracic kyphosis.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-723bd344b2f93da61eececa4a057497885e2a1a8.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What <b>determines </b>normal spine posture?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::One primary factor - the <b>sacral slope</b>}}<br></div>	"There are two big school of thoughts:<div>1. many factors affect spine posture</div><div>2. sacral slope</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>The most prevalent theory is 1, but Loren just shit on that theory.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c527ec2c7640283cd6673afdcb0f79aa34cbf095.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How does the <b>sacral slope </b>affect the overall spinal posture?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::One deviation in that one spot will carry upwards towards the lumbar, thoracic, and cervical spines! (functional spinal units will change)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This change occurs because of the structure of the functional spinal unit, where movement is possible in the sagittal, frontal, and horizontal plane. }}<br></div>	"There are two big school of thoughts:<div>1. many factors affect spine posture</div><div>2. sacral slope</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>The most prevalent theory is 1, but Loren just shit on that theory.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-c527ec2c7640283cd6673afdcb0f79aa34cbf095.jpg""><img src=""paste-731b2c9adc7874bf25bf7a72a25e4223687be3d1.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How many joints are in the functional spinal unit? What are these joints called?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There are <b>3 </b>vertebral joints!}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Interbody joint (between vertebrae), 2x Apophyseal joint (Facet joints)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7e8ee336fdfff2d06f52710d03c823878bd26ea1.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Why is the <b>intervertebral foramen</b>&nbsp;important?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is where the spinal nerve root exits}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7e8ee336fdfff2d06f52710d03c823878bd26ea1.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine

What is the portion where the <b>lamina </b>and the <b>pedicle </b>meet called?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::pars interarticularis}}<br></div>	"Literally means between the ""part between two joints""<div><br></div><div>Between superior articular facet of the bottom vertebrae and the inferior articular face of the top vertebrae<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-78a37600898d6f14acf212dd2f79abf5fd29d3b0.jpg""><img src=""paste-ec9ffd5484805f12330c23d358df4bb4c96db88b.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is a <b>common injury </b>to the vertebrae? How does this happen?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Stress fracture on the parts interarticularis (<b>spondylolysis and spondylolisthesis</b>)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>How:&nbsp;{{c1::usually from a combination of compression and hyper-extension of the spine}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-9d0e0d33f110fb33b91077bbb882552f77e95980.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is <b>spondylolysis</b>? What is <b>spondylolisthesis</b>?<div><br></div><div>Spondylolysis:&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Stress fracture</b> along pars articularis}}</div><div><br></div><div>Spondylolisthesis:&nbsp;{{c1::<b>complete fracture</b> of pars articularis - may lead to anterior translation of superior vertebrae}}</div>	"<div>More common in younger individuals (highschool - college students). As we get older, the chances for pars fractures is lessened.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-a63f80796d864bbb22af467d4232312aa0f3f7e6.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What are the <b>three </b>parts of the intervertebral disc? What are each made up of?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Nucleus pulposus: protein, mineral deposits, and water}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Vertebral endplates: hyaline cartilage}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Annulus fibrosis: fibrocartilage}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-2a0f70cff48aec70eb05013d84edf1d2403aae12.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What happens to the intervertebral disc during compression?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Compression causes dehydration to occur (nucleus pulposus is made up of water - and therefore causes its space to shrink by ~1 cm. When you sleep, the discs rehydrate and you gain your height again}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f48efa384cdbabd40c32d6718d53ffc8cb083ccb.jpg""><img src=""paste-b2eb67e13c0a209041fa3b88b27f6cfa0a737c8f.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine

What is the <b>role </b>of the global vertebral column ligaments?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Responsible for the passive tension that is required to maintain the normal adult posture of the body}}<br></div>	"Anterior = resists extension<div>Posterior = resists flexion</div><div>Supraspinous = resists flexion</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a1bb824db13edef4fc1220f4ab3afd77f1261f30.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What action does the <b>anterior longtudinal ligament </b>of the spine resist?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::vertebral extension}}<br></div>	"Anterior = resists extension<div>Posterior = resists flexion</div><div>Supraspinous = resists flexion</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a1bb824db13edef4fc1220f4ab3afd77f1261f30.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What action does the <b>posterior longtudinal ligament </b>of the spine resist?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::vertebral flexion}}<br></div>	"Anterior = resists extension<div>Posterior = resists flexion</div><div>Supraspinous = resists flexion</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a1bb824db13edef4fc1220f4ab3afd77f1261f30.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What action does the <b>supraspinous ligament&nbsp;</b>of the spine resist?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::vertebral flexion}}<br></div>	"Anterior = resists extension<div>Posterior = resists flexion</div><div>Supraspinous = resists flexion</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a1bb824db13edef4fc1220f4ab3afd77f1261f30.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the <b>role </b>of the ligamentum flavum of the spine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::resists flexion, and protects the spinal chord}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-eee4558fcc1912f9b707c8bc604359f122a3f2b4.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the role of <b>interspinous ligaments </b>of the spine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Resists flexion (weak)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-478055c808f71c318078f933e46d32191e63dc94.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the <b>role </b>of intertransverse ligaments of the spine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::resists contralateral flexion}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-478055c808f71c318078f933e46d32191e63dc94.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is an interesting phenomenon that occurs to the <b>interspinous, intertransverse, and supraspinous </b>ligaments? What does this mean for us as Kinesiologists?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::20-25% of people with no history of back pain have reported to have these ligaments ruptured at some point}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sometimes when a patient reports back pain and they get an MRI done with this ligaments ruptured, its easy to jump to conclusions, but this may not be the case!}}<br></div>	"<div>These ligaments are easy to get ruptured because they are relatively weak</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-e6c8797c55af586112bfb89fecbba7bee4019a7e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine

What happens to the facet joint angle from cervical to thoracic to lumbar spine? What does this <b>allow / limit</b>?<div><br></div><div>Cervical:&nbsp;{{c1::Frontal plane alignment ~45 degrees from vertical}}</div><div>Allow/Limit:&nbsp;{{c1::Allows flexion, extension, axial rotation, and lateral flexion}}</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>Thoracic:&nbsp;{{c1::Frontal plane alignment ~15 degrees from vertical}}</div><div>Allow/Limit:&nbsp;{{c1::Allows flexion, axial rotation, lateral flexion and <b>limits </b>extension}}</div><div><br></div><div>Lumbar:&nbsp;{{c1::~25 degrees from sagittal plane; vertical}}</div><div>Allow/Limit:&nbsp;{{c1::Allows flexion, lateral flexion, and <b>limits </b>extension, and axial rotation}}</div>	"The plane alignment is where the angle is based off of.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-3a7b1e523e7a88911b9732f4448d33308bc1d87c.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What does the <b>thoracic facet joint </b>limit? Why does it do this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It limits extension - this occurs because its long and pointed spinous process will be blocked from moving by the vertebrae below it. This is fine because we want the thoracic spine to be in kyphosis anyway (flexed position)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9f9ec477875b7707dc08237185c0fd18b90f9338.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the <b>main </b>difference in facet joints between the thoracic and the lumbar vertebrae?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The thoracic vertebrae moves in the sagittal plane while the lumbar vertebrae moves in the frontal plane}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d2113e346e23cd1d2201491541c0dd3fd1e11194.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How much extension can the cervical/thoracic/lumbar FSU allow?<div><br></div><div>Cervical:&nbsp;{{c1::~10 degrees/FSU so about 75-80 degrees in total}}</div><div><br></div><div>Thoracic:&nbsp;{{c1::~2.1 degrees/FSU so about 20-25 degrees in total}}</div><div><br></div><div>Lumbar:&nbsp;{{c1::~4 degrees/FSU so about 15-20 degrees in total}}</div>	"Extension beyond this is considered hyperextension.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-955f8a9d62a78e2deeb3d2298321325a492727af.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How much flexion can the cervical/thoracic/lumbar FSU do?<div><br></div><div>Cervical:&nbsp;{{c1::~6.3 degrees/FSU so 45-50 degrees total}}</div><div><br></div><div>Thoracic:&nbsp;{{c1::~3.3 degrees/FSU so 30-40 degrees total}}</div><div><br></div><div>Lumbar:&nbsp;{{c1::~10 degrees/FSU so 40-50 degrees total}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-3294215b95ffd2e8a6ce2a9f071eb2637223f169.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Ight, so the thoracic spine kinda sucks with its FSU extension and flexion. It's degree of flexion is much less than cervical and lumber. Why is it being gandoo?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It's because of the hearts and lungs (limited by costal cartilages). If we start to have big movement in our thoracic, it could potentially mess with these important structures}}<br></div>	"<div>Actually, the lumbar is <b>designed </b>for flexion instead! Did Stu mcgill lie to us?</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-018ff72008dcf6e24e1704567e91f0ade9c7734e.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How much <b>axial rotation </b>can we do in our FSU?<div><br></div><div>Cervical:&nbsp;{{c1::C1-C2 can do ~40 degrees! The rest do ~5 degrees}}</div><div><br></div><div>Thoracic:&nbsp;{{c1::~2.9 degrees / FSU and is limited by costal cartilages}}</div><div><br></div><div>Lumbar:&nbsp;{{c1::~1.4 degrees/ FSU}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d44d0f2b758cc4c8ed49f5827dba95942e3fb91c.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How much <b>lateral flexion </b>can our FSU do?<div><br></div><div>Cervical:&nbsp;{{c1::~5 degrees/FSU}}</div><div><br></div><div>Thoracic:&nbsp;{{c1::~2.5 degrees/FSU (limited by costal articulations)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Lumbar:&nbsp;{{c1::~4 degrees/FSU}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-511d3582df0a5fb85e89bef4e20028518e82067d.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
If you had too much motion in your spine (hyperextension/flexion), what could you do to combat this? Why would this way be beneficial from other ways?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We could immoblize certain FSU's by fusing the vertebrae together making that one FSU have zero motion. }}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::This way is more beneficial because it still allows you to move your other vertebrae while also restricting movement by that one FSU}}<br></div>	"<div>Other reasons for an immoblized FSU would be <b>congenital fusion </b>(born with) or <b>muscle tightness</b>.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-08a3c5f5c8cd6ad1fc2bb7c2afbc27563a74cd87.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Where is <b>disc hernation </b>most common in?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::cervical and lumbar spine}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cfc79ccb23d0a35eec5a65dbaa6773bda138dfac.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What causes an <b>intervertebral disc herniation</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Excessive motion of the spine}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-2e42e794ce3036a38338a609116796fdd947ea83.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What are the <b>types </b>of low back pain?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Non-specific: spondylolisthesis - pain not specific to an area}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Specific/focal: sharp pain, eg. injuring a facet joint}}\</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Radicular/radiating: pain felt away from the site of injury}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-0f01f31cee34f9b879b354611ad6dc0cd1bd01f8.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What are the <b>mechanisms </b>for disc herniation?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::hyperflexion of FSU}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::hyperextension of FSU}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Multi-axis - flexion + lateral flexion + axial rotation}}</div>	"Multi-axis herniation will cause posterior lateral herniation. The flexion part makes it posterior.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Both hyperflexion and hyperextension can cause posterior herniation</div><div><br></div><div>Anterior herniation is quite uncommon</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-ac77bfe96fa894b2c0c5bfe0ecfb203254addb81.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
"Draw the <b>intervertebral disc</b>.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<img src=""paste-2a0f70cff48aec70eb05013d84edf1d2403aae12.jpg"">}}</div>"		KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the <b>most common </b>mechanism for a disc herniation? How does this occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Hyperflexion}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>How:&nbsp;{{c1::During flexion, the superior vertebrae tilts forward causing the posterior FSU to shift up. The nucleus pulposus will start to shift backward and will start to push on and stretch the annulos fibrosis - making it weaker. }}</div>	"Too much stretch of annulos fibrosis will cause the disc herniation<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-cf4fc4feb4f905b5562723e4ae3a2e91ac47192b.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the <b>hyperextension </b>mechanism of disc herniation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Similar to hyperflexion but instead of the nucleus pulposus shifting backward it shifts forward. This will cause a stretch to the anterior annulos fibrosis. The anterior longitudinal ligament is protecting that side so most people say its safe to do hyperextension of the spine. However, from this protection, the nucleus pulposus will instead shift backward causing a posterior herniation just like hyperflexion.}}<br></div>	"This is why hyperextension can do posterior disc herniation just like hyperflexion<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f21290dcb86362721b58020daa70a4dc0b47c0bf.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
d1ece7a2c1854ef8b288ea3472bc0813-ao-1		"<img src=""tmpmx5zgk79.png"" />"	"<img src=""d1ece7a2c1854ef8b288ea3472bc0813-ao-1-Q.svg"" />"						"<img src=""d1ece7a2c1854ef8b288ea3472bc0813-ao-1-A.svg"" />"	"<img src=""d1ece7a2c1854ef8b288ea3472bc0813-ao-O.svg"" />"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine

<i>T/F </i>It is highly likely for a posterior/central disc herniation to cause nerve problems in the lumbar spine.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False, this is because the lumbar spine only has the cauda equina which are just bundles of nerve roots. It will just bend around the herniation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b72efe07ad49ca8af34a0adbb5df2d4179801f03.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Since it is <b>so hard </b>and nearly impossible to get nerve problems with a posterior/central disc herniation, how come people with disc herniation's get nerve root problems?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::These are instead postero<b>lateral </b>disc herniations! This lateral portion will cause the nerve root to be compressed by the bone (spondylophyte) causing pain. If it was just posterior herniation, then it would only press against the cauda equina (which would shift).}}<br></div>	"Posterolateral disc herniation is a combination of flexion, lateral flexion, and axial rotation.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-d07ea50d68bd633065c6ec15c5c64932d721f8b9.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2c9725bbcaf7b260830967381537a9e53c242eef.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-170c083f79aa7aceaa0532549666299f1e32d094.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
If you had a posteriolateral disc herniation, should you avoid flexion and go into extension?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, if you go into extension, you would decrease the amount of space in your intervertebral foramen causing even more pain! You would actually want to go into flexion because that would increase the space of the intervertebral foramen.}}<br></div>	"Most people would recommend to go into extension!<div><br></div><div>Note that this only is such if they have posterolateral disc herniation. If it was a central herniation, then extension would press against all those nerve roots which would be bad.<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-1eb43405c23c1e336020e361b4771edcbbad2cdb.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-03184c5795916ef750c72629be7008d64c9b4bf1.jpg""><br></div></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Is it possible to have problems from disc herniation with nerve roots S1, S2, S3, or S4?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::That's impossible, there is no disc in our sacral vertebrae!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-65ad36c51aa579c652d1342c2e83ce7b961879d2.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
"<i>T/F </i>Disc herniations are the biggest problems we have in the spine.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::False, many of us have disc herniations without even knowing it. Also, most ""low back pain"" is from pinching in the sacral nerves which don't have discs in them anyway! This means there's something else other than herniations that are causing us these problems}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-4ad0fcc782b667b2e14f4e1e7df6dd123fb12e06.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
If disc herniation is not our main issue for low back pain, what is then causes most of low back pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Spinal compression from muscle forces!}}<br></div>	"You don't see back pain in animals other than humans because they don't walk upright to cause this spinal compression!<div><br></div><div>Muscles are our main cause of back pain but also our solution to back pain!</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-110e5943dca916cc42e095d0b35267e5463d660e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Most spinal muscles create spinal compression which can cause low back pain. What can we do to alleviate this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We have to remember that we don't even use the spinal muscles all that often. It is only utilized to maintain our spinal posture! So if we maintain our posture (passively) it will decrease our compression!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f85413bd02cd2a869c8d07de58913eaab25dac8a.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is <b>motor learning</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Set of processes aimed at learning and refining new skills by practicing them}}<br></div>	"A task is 'learned' when it can be repeated, used with efficiency and transferred to different situations.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-0775da950d73523a9d8b6ca88ddd3e1933528120.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
Why is motor learning <b>important </b>in S&amp;C?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It will help improve technique. Actual <i>learning </i>must take place to have a meaningful impact, and a coach/program is only as good as the ability for the client to retain that skill}}<br></div>	"That's why motor learning is important<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-73fe2c5b47463df08669d9bd49c8e59a4467eadf.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
How would you <b>define </b>successful motor learning of an athlete?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A relatively permanent change, resulting from practice or experience, in the capability of responding}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d9d83aec4dc12c8f1917022712fbe827110eb9bd.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
Successful learning and retention is guided by <b>4 things</b>. What are these things?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Skill presentation}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Error detection/correction}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Feedback}}</div><div><br></div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Retention}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d9d83aec4dc12c8f1917022712fbe827110eb9bd.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
How is motor learning <b>tested</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We do a pre-test, then practice to do a post-test. Then we have a period of no practice which then is followed by a retention test. If the retention test is similar to the post-test but better than the pre-test, the motor learning was successful}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c50f597baa934895abddf3f8786ddc4e5c9230d3.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What are the <b>three stages </b>to the learning model?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Cognitive Stage: beginner or novice being introduced to new skill}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Associative Stage: Intermediate, begins to transfer knowledge to procedural knowledge. Less awkward movement.}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Autonomous Stage: Advanced! Enters a state of flow, and easily self-corrected movement}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-12d7327ec4d843f01f152873fb944e97c1e2b360.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What are the <b>motor learning </b>topics we should consider when coaching an athlete (KIN 435)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Contextual interference}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Goal Setting}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Augmented Feedback}}</div><div><br></div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Focus of Attention}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-85737ac588b63633e4aab99622462c70c51d41a9.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What is <b>contextual interference</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The thing that happens when an athlete must learn several tasks/skills together}}<br></div>	"The context here is that we want to use it to improve motor learning.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-5a6837bb499a728292ff9432b71a11a0ba6e5e2d.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What type of training gives the <b>highest </b>contextual interference?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When you are training skills at random <b>between </b>and <b>within </b>skills.}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-9d1d0426f297c2ff3107572396331ce3b868b225.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
Block trials are:&nbsp;{{c1::number of sets and reps of a skill all completed without interruption}}<div><br></div><div>Random trials are:&nbsp;{{c1::mix sets and reps of multiple skills in random order}}</div><div><br></div><div>Serial trials are:&nbsp;{{c1::mix sets and reps of multiple skills in a predictable order}}</div>	"Used to understand contextual interference.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-5a802a358b4d0af896ab39e734bbd644ed11ce48.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations

<div>What's more important, block vs random practice?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Random practice can increase retention which is better for practice (and also closer to game environment)}}<br></div>	"If you only do blocked practiced, all your focusing on is execution and technique, but you neglect reading and planning!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-abe99749c08493b20e25d205f05f01ae4fb6b78f.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations

Name <b>4 </b>feedback strategies we can use to train our athletes.<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Continuous feedback: feedback given continously throughout the whole movement (we want to avoid this as much as possible)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Summative Feedback: feedback comes at the end of the practice}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Faded feedback: More frequent feedback in the beginning and then less feedback later on when the athlete gains more retention}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Bandwidth feedback: Allows a range of error before giving a cue.}}</div>	"<div>Bandwidth is fine because we are using these lifts to improve their fitness, not to get them to become a high level elite athlete.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-804afcde4bee9438f85154304717dd84eb599762.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What is <b>internal </b>vs <b>external </b>focus of attention?<div><br></div><div>Internal:&nbsp;{{c1::Athlete concentrates on their body and its movements}}</div><div><br></div><div>External:&nbsp;{{c1::Athlete concentrates on objects or actions outside of the athlete's body}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-6a02599be96d2ef6bad166a051ab43e21b298f54.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What are different ways to <b>measure&nbsp;</b>performance outcomes?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Movement efficiency: measured by muscle activity/force, speed, or endurance}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Movement effectiveness: measured by balance or accuracy}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""paste-109246cb5a70f5e3ff1eb2b31416da6ce49ae6bc.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What was better, an internal or external focus of attention (single study)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Internal focus of attention subjects had more unsuccessful attempts versus those using external focus}}<br></div>	"<div>Goldberg did an experiment himself where he found that external focus of attention had greater backsquat increase then internal focus of attention</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-38bed52fdc1126736ad4cfe8d126220208947b2f.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-2c1f642b1c343b0b3d80bb2c47e3ae57cebbb1cf.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_435::Pre-Midterm_2::Motor_Learning_Considerations
What is the <i>origin </i>and <i>insertion </i>of the digastric muscle?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div><b>Origin:</b></div><div>Anterior belly: digastric fossa of mandible</div><div>Posterior belly: mastoid notch on temporal bone</div><div><br></div><div><b>insertion: </b>hyoid bone}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d8e0c5936ab3d2334f8991e77659e8f923ad4889.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Upper_Extremity::OIA
What is the <b>coercion argument </b>against PEDs?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is a argument against using PEDs by the notion that if we allow PEDs, it would create a situation where everyone must use it or they won't be competitive in high level sport}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-94d871e0602d165dbf5efde3aa1763184b372beb.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Veber_2013
According to the <i>coercion argument</i>, those out to protect individual rights ought to be <i>against</i>&nbsp;lifting the ban on steroids. Why is this the case?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If we lift the ban on steroids, then we give the athlete no other choice but to use PEDs to compete at the highest levels (coercion). If we are coercing athletes, then we are undermining their autonomy, therefore if we lift the ban on PED's in sport, then we are undermining the autonomy of athletes.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b92f1af0206456c62abd3cff26860258f2aaf13a.jpg""><img src=""paste-445af91c6d892f625e37fc8b7a7bb34e773fa617.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Veber_2013
Veber (2013) talks about the first problem in the <i>coercion argument</i>&nbsp;being <b>where to draw the line</b>. What does he mean by this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::One of the main arguments to banning steroid use is that it is inherently dangerous and risky towards your health. But, we need to draw a line to what is acceptable to harming our health vs unacceptable. Eg: playing football may be more dangerous then using steroids but we still deem it as acceptable. Another eg: Pro skater invents a move that is very difficult and could cause serious damage, but, the only way other pro skaters can compete at the high levels is to practice this move. Is this not coercion used in the coercion argument for banning steroids?}}</div>	"Therefore, we have a problem with this argument on what constitutes acceptable harm vs unacceptable harm and if steroid use is more or less harmful then something that is acceptable.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-b358a947dc6a1ed7b3a8ead9ec6d75d81f6e5048.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Veber_2013
The <i>second problem </i>to the coercion argument is that there is coercion either way with a question of numbers, what does this mean (Veber 2013)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We say that if we allow athletes to use steroids then we are coercing those who don't use steroids to use them. But, if we think about it the other way around, banning steroids would coerce those who use steroids into not using steroids. Now, the argument goes that we should cater towards the health risks (but that is debated in problem 1) as well as the majority of people vs the minority. So a common argument against this problem is that the majority does not use steroids. However, there is no evidence for this yet (question of numbers)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b957fcb0100f347742a1cb7045de7c504daab5ba.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Veber_2013
The <i>third problem </i>to the coercion argument (Veber 2013) to doping is that we don't know if it is coercion at all. What does this mean?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Veber introduces Nozick's analysis to a coercion and what makes something considered coercion. There are three conditions that must be met for something to be considered coercion according to him and the very first one is <b>A aims to get B to do X</b>. The unlift the ban on doping, noone is telling B to do anything, and therefore allowing PEDs in sport does not amount to coercing anyone. Sure, you can say that these conditions don't define coercion, but then you would have to make up your own conditions which hasn't been done yet. This is perhaps the most serious problem for the argument}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e3d3d0af848fb692cbb49af4ef1343bb9c8a3f1b.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Veber_2013
"The <i>fourth problem </i>to the coercion argument (Veber 2013), is the notion that allowing doping would impede the <b>highest level of sport</b>&nbsp;however, how do we know that. Explain this notion.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A main concern to doping is that it would coerce people to use doping to compete at the highest level. Veber brings in an argument saying that if we allow doping, would doping still be the highest level of sport? He says that eventually, a ""non-doping"" league would emerge and wouldn't that be the highest level of sport? Eg: Wouldn't powerlifter fans rather watch a raw bench vs an assisted bench press?}}<br></div>"	"An argument against this would be that fans wouldn't be interested in ""natural"" leagues, but then it isn't a problem with the ""highest level of sport"" but with fanfare and attention.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a1d18850a93cef0b1d9fd3dff5a12184d2f0c977.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-de13874e7edd374449213523c51049437a37c300.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-920298846d69ba9381597479eb121bbe847ce018.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Veber_2013
What are the <b>four problems </b>to the coercion argument against doping (Veber 2013)?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Where to draw the line (what is considered harmful?)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Coercion either way and a question of numbers (we would also coerce the people who want to use drugs to not use drugs KEKW)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Is it even coercion? (According to Nozick's analysis and conditions of coercion)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Doping blocks non-dopers to compete in the highest levels of sport? (They can just play in a different league that has non-doping regulations)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-a54e917a2386e14c1fcfd08360615027d53490c7.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Veber_2013
What are the <b>two main arguments </b>against doping in sport?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::If you dope and I don't, I'll lose the competitive edge}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::If you dope, it'll force me to dope (coercion)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e38147176d16513ba67fd6583a17e9503e2ded7e.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping
"What is the <i>gist</i>&nbsp;of the Burk &amp; Symons (2016) article: <b>Anti-doping policies&nbsp;and the Gay Games; Morgan's treatment-enhancement distinction in action</b>.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It investigates the policies for doping in the <b>Gay Games </b>and expresses it as a unique way for us to look at doping rules. They say that ""as a rule, drug testing is not appropriate for Gay Games"" however they won't be drug testing because that shit wastes a lot of time and money. There is also the argument that it impedes on the privacy on athletes who want privacy (LGBTQ shit). Also, if we were to drug test, how would we draw the line between steroid use for health and steroid use for enhancement, especially with steroid use being a common medication for HIV (highly prevalent in gay individuals)}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-a460a708ec953c44ce4b68f0b0af493bdec35464.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Burke&Symons_2016
<b>Burke &amp; Symons </b>(2016) - (the Gay Games article) talks about the <b>treatment-enhancement distinction </b>and <b>socialising the debate</b>. What do they mean by this?<div><br></div><div>Treatment-enhancement distinction:&nbsp;{{c1::They change the ban on doping from being morally justified to being morally permissible. This changes the reason for a ban on doping to begin with! It leads to the argument that sport should be a perfectionist practice and that policies should protect that notion. Therefore recognising substances like steroids and EPO that will allow athletes to recuperate faster and thus perfect their craft may be more beneficial. We also have to take into account that recreational drug use may even be detrimental to practice. Therefore we have to make a distinction between what drugs give treatment vs enhancement and if that supports the notion of a perfectionist sport}}</div><div><br></div><div>Socialising the debate:&nbsp;{{c1::Basically getting the policies from the Gay Games more known by making it mainstream. This may give opportunities to educate concerning the LBTQ.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b15a21d07480d5b1840abd87c5e7ff56d3488d74.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Burke&Symons_2016

What do they mean by that?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Certain situations with the LGTQ community require the prescription of steroids as treatment for HIV. Therapeutic use exemption was used in the Gay Games by signing a waiver - however WADA doesn't have this waiver because they believe it is a functional disorder (something you caused yourself)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-129ab1610aeddc4343f9af5cf5ccca24c2ae0d02.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Doping::Required_Reading_Burke&Symons_2016

"What is a problem with the <b>physiological equivalence </b>argument in sport where we say ""Men are stronger and thus we should split up the categories""?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The problem is that it reinforces the cisgender binary and therefore transgender athletes are also forced into this binary. So it burdens already marginalized individuals and it <b>hinges on a misunderstanding of sport</b>}}<br></div>"	"Misunderstanding of sport: sport is actually about meaningful narratives - and if sport is blocking you from these personal unique narratives then that is a big problem<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2187ddab79888d4b47f0299d1c96be64d7e1b52b.jpg""><img src=""paste-9ca840533e91821861103b0fc394ae27f540de65.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Transitioning_Athletes
Gleaves and Lehbrach (2016) say that we are really misunderstanding what sport is about which is about <b>meaningful narratives </b>of the individual. What does this mean? What is the counterargument to this?<div><br></div><div>Narratives:&nbsp;{{c1::Everyone has a unique narrative, and if the sport is blocking you from expressing your narrative, then that is ethically wrong - eg: transgender and intersex athletes in sport have a right to express gendered narratives as any athletes}}</div><div><br></div><div>Counterargument:&nbsp;{{c1::Might make sport more unfair; men might switch genders to win in female competition; and it rules out mixed sport}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-840d3e4a245db8a7a706fefc2ef02c161aa056d7.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-a792ac19ff02ae9d8ba9186867d095d3b5446c35.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Transitioning_Athletes
Gleaves and Lehrbrach (2016) talk about the <i>incompleteness </i>of the <b>physiological equivalency argument</b>. What do they mean by that?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This notion fears that the intersex condition may confer an unfair advantage over their cisgender counterpart (eg: transgender competing in womens games). First, they talk about how testosterone is not scientifically proven to have any beneficial effect on performance (or give an athletic advantage). They then go on to say that athletes who emerge that do upset the accepted range are validated and trophied whereas transgender athletes are under similar conditions but get invalidated. Finally, they say to exclude transgenders for the benefit of inclusion misrepresents sport (which they talk about <b>narratives</b>)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-481231343407a1d09662e35c87931a48c067340e.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Transitioning_Athletes::Required_Reading_Gleaves&Lehrbach_2016
What is Gleaves and Lehrbrach's (2016) argument against gender segregation in sport? We say segregation in sport in necessary because woman are physiologically disadvantaged compared to men.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::First, they say it <i>risks </i>reaffirming attitudes about women as second-class athletes, it also decreases the equality of women athletes. Also, a category based on inclusion (of women( results in practices of exclusion (transgender and intersex).}}<br></div>	"Though I want to mention that equality is different from fairness. A women can well out say that it is unfair to compete against a man and that would be valid!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2f373e43f23fb5526253f9f331b324bc0a55d7e2.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Transitioning_Athletes::Required_Reading_Gleaves&Lehrbach_2016
How does <b>Gleaves and Lehrbrach (2016)</b>&nbsp;explain the <i>nature of sport</i>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They say the nature of sport is based off of narratives. Sports are created and shaped by communities to provide individuals with explanatory accounts about certain meaninful characteristics in pubicly demonstrable activities.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-55f29e22e073ff155f17105d8bee2986ddcb7ac1.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Transitioning_Athletes::Required_Reading_Gleaves&Lehrbach_2016
What does the notion of sport being made up of <i>meaningful narratives </i>say about transgender and intersex athletes (Gleaves &amp; Lehrbach 2016)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This notion supports gender segregation in sport by using gender narratives. However, with this notion, transgender athletes should be able to express their own narratives without having to conform to a binary. That means policies that force intersex/transgender athletes to undergo hormone therapy is ethically wrong and that they should be able to participate in any gender segregated sport. They then go on to say that this should be implemented in every organization.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-413bce783b0453e780b93510acb8f8079fb69b24.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Transitioning_Athletes::Required_Reading_Gleaves&Lehrbach_2016
What is the <i>gist </i>of the Gleaves &amp; Lehrbach (2016) article: <b>Beyond fairness: the ethics of inclusion for transgender and intersex athletes</b>.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They argue that the <b>physiological equivalence </b>argument to segregate transgender athletes is flawed. They say that it perpetuates a notion of inequality between all genders. What we have to do it look at sport through meaningful narratives. This way, gender segregation through gender narratives would be valid, and on that note, transgender athletes with their own meaningful narratives should be able to participate in any gendered sport.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-17b6f05d58f01751771b76ce7c3995b74c7571e9.jpg"">"	KIN_401::Post-Midterm::Transitioning_Athletes::Required_Reading_Gleaves&Lehrbach_2016
How does a <b>forward head posture </b>cause low back pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Forward head posture increases the moment arm for flexion of the thoracic spine. We would then need to use our erector spine muscles to counteract this flexion, however this then causes a lot of spinal compression as well as lumbar extension. Lumbar extension and spinal compression reduces neural foramen space and thus causes low back pain}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b6c000fb0a7dea6c99590f5d892304a2e916aaa4.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
How is the <i>multifidus</i> and the <i>erector spinae</i> <b>different</b> for humans compared to other animals?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Humans are bipedal and therefore withstands a lot more compression forces on the spine because of our vertical nature. Animals on the other hand walk on four limbs and therefore their spinal compression is perpendicualar. Because of this, our multifidus proportionally to our erector spinae is a lot bigger compared to other animals.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-61a76866b804cd064b57e2bb93834f76ff917187.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
The multifidus, like the erector spinae causes spinal extension. How come we say we want to strengthen our multifidus to cure low back pain when spinal extension is the cause for spinal compression?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The multifidus is weird. For every multifidus pulling the vertebrae downwards, there will be a multifidus pulling the vertebrae upwards. In other words, the upward tension will cancel the downward compression! }}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-30a92b864ed7d744046d6a1087430b02c4874278.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the <b>difference </b>between global vs local muscles of the spine?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Global muscles cross many intervertebral junctions whereas local muscles cross few intervertebral junctions}}<br></div>	"Global: erector spinae, rectus abdominis, internal oblique, external oblique<div><br></div><div>Local: trasnversospinal muscles, psoas major</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-b57c23be0214b32f051c01d3ae97392e0911371e.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What are global muscles <b>associated</b> for <i>compared</i> to local muscles?<div><br></div><div>Global:&nbsp;{{c1::Higher force-like actions}}</div><div><br></div><div>Local:&nbsp;{{c1::Stability of the spine}}</div>	"This is actually important to note because we really don't use our global spinal muscles all that often. If you weren't doing deadlifts or picking something up, it isn't that common for us to need to do high spinal force movements.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>Most of the time we use our local muscles for stability!</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-8c2d847a8ed106dc3f20c643ddc10d4f27299ff0.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Explain the mechanism spinal compression and tension of the multifidus. How come the multifidus can cause extension of the spine without spinal compression?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The multifidus has forces pulling the vertebrae into flexion and extension at an angle. These angles create an upward vertical tension force and a downward vertical compression force. These will essentially cancel out. However, the moment arm of the flexion force is smaller then the extension force, thereby causing the spine to go into overall extension without creating spinal compression.}}<br></div>	"<div>Minimizing spinal compression will stop the neural foramen from pressing down on the nerves causing low back pain.</div><div><br></div><div>The multifidus is important because <b>it is the only muscle </b>that can reduce spinal compression!</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-f3dfbfe11e7345ad650694441d38058a42b32752.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What is the <b>common </b>sacral slope angle?<div><br></div><div>Common angle:&nbsp;{{c1::~40 degrees}}</div>	"Angle of the sacrum relative to the horizontal<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6ddc498bbabc54bd693dc0fe341f08405f1543e3.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
Why is the intervertebral disc of L5 - Sacrum (sacral slope) wedge shaped whereas all the other vertebrae is rectangular shaped? How is this important?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This is due to the <b>multifidus </b>causing extension of this spinal unit from its extension AND tension forces}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Importance:&nbsp;{{c1::This is very important because the angle between L5 and the sacrum determine the sacral slope, which is determined by the multifidus! Well, if the spine was neutral, the sacral sclope angle would be determined soley by how well the multifidus could create this spinal extension}}</div>	"This is the only spinal unit where the multifidus' upward tension does not cause spinal flexion. This is because it originates at the sacrum, which furthers that spinal extension instead!&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>~ 40 degrees for sacral slope angle</div><div><br></div><div>Therefore, the <b>most important mther fking muscle </b>is the multifidus</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-b63f5294ae3f72aff0cb0df6be650b3b6c82e517.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What are the <b>main reasons </b>why the multifidus is so mther fking important (actually the most important muscle)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It neutralizes spinal compression}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It determines our sacral slope which affects our whole spinal postural column}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-5c56b01e2e9646ed6d875e47cb017a3724da8eed.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-fc85a9803f20c3fb1829c2cd4c461fcd0ab8b7b1.jpg"">"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine
What are exercises you can do to optimally train the multifidus (since its so important)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::From my experience of biomechanics, the multifidus in anatomical position is in <b>ascending 2 </b>position of the force-length curve. To get the optimal force production from our multifidus, we have to go into hip flexion! Therefore, perhaps the best way to train the multifidus would be to go into slight hip flexion and then do spinal extension exercises. Perhaps something like the deadlift pull off racks, or even half rep deadlifts without going all the way up to anatomical position!}}<br></div>	"To date, there is no universally best accepted exercises to train the multifidus so take this advice with a grain of salt.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-964dbfb9a7f276a5ed5922f5461ff7022a15e148.jpg""><br></div>"	KIN_400::Post_Midterm::Spine

What is this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Segmental interrlation (how one joint will affect another)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e17cf06b07b5beb785168719cffa164b460294c4.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Suarez_2019

What is the <b>foundational </b>element required for the development of power?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Strength, this is because the ability to produce high force is highly correlated with power output. This is especially important in the younger or untrained athletes}}<br></div>	"<div>Once they reach maximum strength levels, sport specific training for power will then help them!</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-b0952fbe2319c0e623a9e7f39560bd1e4958ab61.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Haff_2012

What is the recommended training to maximize/optimize power output? How do we do this?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Mixed methods of high and low intensities}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>How:&nbsp;{{c1::Training should be vertically integrated and horizontally sequenced}}</div>	"<div>Remember, power specific training should only happen after sufficient strength is achieved!&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Vertically integrated: all parts of the force-velocity curve</div><div>Horizontally sequenced: increases in load over time</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-c18444d4ea06532aacafa11ff92aabdfc6e078b8.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Haff_2012
Although strength training is good to develop power, how does <b>Turner (2020) </b>also suggest we train?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Ballistic training}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-16284d7546f61b48e4dc5ad04bc6b75b3a3fcc83.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Turner_2020
Why would we decide to use ballistic training over strength training to improve power or vice versa?<div><br></div><div>Ballistic:&nbsp;{{c1::Although strength and power are interdependant, ballistic training is preferred when training within the first <b>300 ms </b>of movement. This is important because most athletic sports are within this range (don't give enough time for max force development to occur)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Strength:&nbsp;{{c1::Training strength is good for improving the peak height of power - the highest power you can achieve.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-01ca5f211e422ad4022951072eba4f5aed7618ab.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Turner_2020
According to Turner (2020), why is a mixed methods approach to training generally advised when training for power?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because strength training shifts the force side of the force velocity curve while speed training shifts the velocity side. Power shifts only the middle (specific). Therefore, a mixed method will be able to shift everything to the right}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-e40b1e3fb4c1e14b2e6ac8c65db35c36952fba29.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-a238de518b1986997def6fda03f7260358001fc4.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Turner_2020
What are the relative contraction speeds we should do to target in the force velocity curve?<div><br></div><div>Speed:&nbsp;{{c1::&gt;1.5m/s}}</div><div>SPD-STR:&nbsp;{{c1::1.0-1.5m/s -- Lower: &gt;0.5&lt;1.0}}</div><div>STR:&nbsp;{{c1::0.23-0.5m/s}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c8a84c39b61f009d74e9d901bc03db504d6926aa.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Turner_2020

What is the<i> Acute:Chronic-workload Ratio</i> compared to the <i>Internal:External-Load Ratio</i>?<div><br></div><div>Acute:chronic:&nbsp;{{c1::identifies risk in athletes where it compares the load your working with with what the athlete is used to to determine the amount of risk involved with doing that lift}}</div><div><br></div><div>Internal:External:&nbsp;{{c1::Compared psychophysiological stress of an athlete. An increase in internal load to a standard external load may infer athlete fatigue (eg: higher heart rate to the same load) whereas a decrease in internal load to a standard external load may infer athlete fitness (eg: lower heart rate with same load)}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-16c202e41fa0ef7ff0ed3f09f1beee530427dda3.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-1549f1b739c6ae6bc881392c5e1a087c12dc159e.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Bourdon_2017
The Acute:Chronic workload ratio described by Bourdon (2017) has a U-shape. What does this represent?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This means that there is a sweet spot in load where you would have the least amount of risk. And going more will increase that risk. What's interesting is that <b>doing less </b>will also increase that risk!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c556b5a8c207c569b0e4f39a1da46bfc5cb1dcc7.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Bourdon_2017
