What is the <b>critical decision-making framework </b>you should consider when getting new technology for sport? (Windt 2020)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Would the promised information be helpful?}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Can you trust the information you will be getting? - Validity theory}}\</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Can you integrate, manage, and analyze the data effectively?}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Can you implement the technology in your practice?}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Is it worth it?}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c2ff74f8b4aa005785283b14483dd4955c1ecd6e.jpg"">"	KIN_435::Required_Readings::Windt_2020

What is <b>health</b>? (WHO)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A state of complete physical, mental, and social well-bing and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f6da0868fa5efced747d1bc07dd399a1773637df.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Introduction
What is <b>health psychology</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Aggregate of the educational, scientific, and professional contributions of the discipline of psychology and the relation to</div><div>- Promotion of health</div><div>- Prevention of illness</div><div>- Health policy formation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f6da0868fa5efced747d1bc07dd399a1773637df.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Introduction
It is proposed that <b>single-category/cause/effect models</b> of health and illness are being replaced. What is it being replaced by?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::multi-category/cause/effect models}}<br></div>	"Eg: The biopsychosocial model<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-0c094284f7c233d3306a6c398b6c8dde6a61c683.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
What is the <b>Patient Evaluation Grid</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is something used to highlight how <b>clinical </b>data can be collected biopsychosocially.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ab6732b37145c9e4076b622134fdec22bc66f6da.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
What is the <b>ultimate challenge </b>facing behavioural medicine towards the <i>biopsychosocial</i> model?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Empirical testing and to consider the unique roles that psychology as a discipline can play in meeting this interdisciplinary challenge.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a0496e15f20cb023b60dc823645fc02c7d8f6ba8.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
What are the <b>4 </b>ways of thinking about health and illness?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Formistic: Things are categorical in which certain things are in a category and others are not. Binary.}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Mechanistic: Things only have a single cause and effect. Eg: You got cancer because a single pollutant in your area}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Contextual: Things are mutli-caused}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Organistic: Effects are made from multitudes of causes added together (parts)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-757e12c3e314dbdb6df636e980300921a4532688.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
How does the 4 ways of thinking about health and illness represent <b>stages </b>of clinical research?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Formistic}} --&gt;&nbsp;{{c1::Mechanistic}} --&gt;&nbsp;{{c1::Contextual}} --&gt;&nbsp;{{c1::Organistic}}</div>	"<b><div>Implications for Stages of Clinical Research</div><div><br></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Says that the natural progression of the history in medicine (eg: a disease) goes through stages in which we use the 4 ways of thinking above.&nbsp;</span></div><br><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Stage 1 (Formistic) = healthy vs unhealthy → Stage 2 (Mechanistic) = Find direct single cause of why unhealthy → Stage 3 (Contextual) = Realize multiple factors may be involved in unhealthy behaviours → Stage 4 (Organistic) = Identify the multiple factors</span></div><br><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Analytic approach = reflects a more reductionistic and serial process</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Serial process = reflects a more systematic and parallel approach</span></div></b><br>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
"What are the <b>challenges </b>in testing the biopsychosocial model?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Affecting/Treatment to one aspect can eithre benefit or detriment another aspect of the model}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">If we look too much at the bigger picture (systems approach) we may lose focus on the smaller key details</span></b>}}</div>"	"<b><div>The Challenge in Testing the Biopsychosocial Model</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">First, the biopsychosocial model brings about two predictions. </span>1. <span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Every medical diagnosis should encompass biological, psychological, and social factors. </span>2. <span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Treatment will affect all three factors</span></div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">There were two challenges that were described.</span></div><ol><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Affecting one aspect can either benefit or detriment another aspect of the model</span></div></li><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">If we look too much at the bigger picture (systems approach) we may lose focus on the smaller key details</span></div></li></ol></b>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
How does the biopsychosocial model help <b>define the roles</b> of psychologists vs physicians in <i>behavioural science</i>?<div><br></div><div>Psychologists:&nbsp;{{c1::specialist in the field helping with research and aide}}</div><div>Physician:&nbsp;{{c1::Interdisciplinary best equipped to take responsibility for integrating and coordinating the patients biopsychosocially}}</div>	"<b><div>The Roles for Psychology and Medicine and for Psychologists and Physicians in Behavioral Medicine</div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Allowing the biopsychosocial model to exist will more clearly define the role of psychologists and physicians in behavioural science where psychologists would be considered the </span><span style=""font-weight: 400; font-style: italic;"">specialist </span><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">in the field of psychology and can aide in the research aspect. Physicians on the other hand are not specialists in single biological, psychological, or sociological field however they are trained as a interdisciplinary profession. Therefore they are best equipped to take legal and ethical responsibility for integrating and coordinating the patients biopsychosocially.&nbsp;</span></b>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
"What is an important structure in the brain that is not labelled in this diagram? Why is it an important?<div><img src=""paste-4c624f0e7509123b1863e0a650f6c7989b83586f.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The pituitary gland}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Important because it plays a major role in the endocrine system (hormone-secreting gland)}}<br></div>"		HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What is the <b>main functions</b> of the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain?<div><br></div><div>Forebrain:&nbsp;{{c1::thinking, emotions, endocrine functions}}</div><div><br></div><div>Midbrain:&nbsp;{{c1::Breathing, postural stability, etc}}</div><div><br></div><div>Hindbrain:&nbsp;{{c1::Moving, sleeping, arousal}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-b0d3d699fef07191829090203918fdb175d36179.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
Give a brief overview of each part of the Central Nervous System.<div><br></div><div>Central vs Peripheral</div><div>{{c1::Central is brain and spinal system while peripheral is everything else}}</div><div><br></div><div>Somatic vs Autonomic</div><div>{{c1::Somatic is intentional movement whereas autonomic is not}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Sympathetic vs Parasympathetic</div><div>{{c1::sympathetic increase activation whereas parasympathetic decreases activation}}</div><div><br></div><div>Nervous vs Endocrine</div><div>{{c1::electrical through nerves or chemically through endocrine functions}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Electrical vs Chemical</div><div>{{c1::tie back in to nervous and endocrine}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-89801b7525da6deaf9b5ee0b9eeb42edb3f64eac.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways

There are two types of <b>stress responses </b>our body has, what are these responses?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Sympathetic Adrenal Medullary (SAM)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal (HPA) axis}}</div>	"acute vs chronic<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-88df6ee634920a94badac22a7866fffa4a02fe2c.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
"What is the <span style=""font-style: italic;"">stress response </span>difference between SAM and HPA?<div><br></div><div>SAM:&nbsp;{{c1::First to be activated; more of an acute response to stress - release of adrenaline/norarenaline having the whole body on alert (fight/flight response)}}</div><div>HPA:&nbsp;{{c1::Activated from long-term stresses - releases cortisol which increases our access to energy stores}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-88df6ee634920a94badac22a7866fffa4a02fe2c.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What are the different theories for pain?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Specificity theory: we have a separate pain system (bell and rope)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Pattern theory: receptors are shared with other senses}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Neuromatrix theory of pain: explains phantom limb pain - conceptualizes feelings between limb and brain; that's why you get phantom limb pain (brain still trying to communicate with lost limb}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Gate-control theory: most modern - a neural gate opening causes the experience of pain}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-1d17372366665b9d4faecd04e2dcf57beee8769a.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What is the <b>gate-control theory</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Is is the most modern theory for pain where we have a <b>neural gate</b>&nbsp;in which when it opens causes the experience of pain. This pain is based on the activity of pain AND other fibres. It could also be influenced by the CNS}}<br></div>	"A-delta fibres - sharp and brief pain<div>A-beta fibres - harmless stimulation - when rubbing the pain</div><div>C-fibres - dull pain</div><div><br></div><div>The gate control theory of pain asserts that non-painful input closes the nerve ""gates"" to painful input, which prevents pain sensation from travelling to the CNS.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Hence, rubbing the painful area may override the painful stimulation from nociceptive fibres.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Think of painful stimuli being excitatory and non-painful being inhibitory. If the net stimuli is more inhibitory on the transmission cells then that's whats going to be transmitted.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-93a57d083f54f109b04e4b54e3f1f875ad4330a9.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What are the conditions that <i>could</i>&nbsp;open the gate in the <i>Gate-Control Theory</i>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>Emotional Effect: Pyschological effects (depression and stuff)</div><div>Injury: biological effects</div><div>Social Effect: If you get an injury and someone screams, it could increase your perception of the pain your feeling}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What are some <i>examples </i>of psychoneuroimmunology of our body?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Being sick around exam time, or after a major life event. We tend to not get sick during the summer}}<br></div>	"The more stressed we are, the more weaker our immunology<div><img src=""paste-05d76ce934d0fc18750f8045b414418ab75addd7.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What is the <b>purpose </b>of our immune system?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Recognize the enemy and attack. We can have cell-mediated immunity or anti-body mediated immunity}}<br></div>	"Cell-mediated: macrophages<div>Anti-body mediated: the ones that release antibodies and attach to antigens</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-730fc7cc25c44c4303a973b301b5c59e5a118604.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What is the <b>difference </b>between T cells and B cells in the immune system?<div><br></div><div>T-cell:&nbsp;{{c1::Action cells - going for the attack (cell-mediated immunity)}}</div><div>B-cells:&nbsp;{{c1::memory cells (anti-body mediated immunity)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-89553bf7c28ceaecd34cf4da631085a1258452fa.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways

What is the <b>cost </b>of CP to society?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There is an economic cost ($560-630 billion annually), health and quality of life cost, fitness and moral cost, and cost to spouses or people around them.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1ffa8c7ba238ce554009d9d7e264d1d656bc9109.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
"What are the <b>4 </b>psychological models and treatments of chronic pain?<div><b><ol><li>{{c1::Operant conditioning mode<span style=""font-weight: 400;"">l: theoretical foundation for behavioral pain treatment</span>}}<br></li><li>{{c1::Peripheral physiological models<span style=""font-weight: 400;"">: theoretical foundation for relaxation training and biofeedback interventions</span>}}<br></li><li>{{c1::Cognitive and coping models<span style=""font-weight: 400;"">: understand and develop treatments</span>}}<br></li><li>{{c1::Central Nervous System neurophysiological models of pain<span style=""font-weight: 400;"">: gate control theory of pain</span>}}<br></li></ol></b></div>"	"<img src=""paste-11146ce829ab20e89b63c2b5ab29d3f499fce71f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
"How does the <b>operant </b>model relate to chronic pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">The theory that all behaviour is sensitive to the effects of environmental response to that behaviour. For example, when someone is sick, pain behaviours followed by reinforcing events like time off or affection will only increase its frequency. However, it pain behaviours are ignored and functional behaviours are reinforced, then over time, these “well behaviours” will increase and pain will decrease.</span></b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-260ff2ad9a5aff1f4fcfe2ba279ff360d5a00757.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
How does the&nbsp;<b>peripheral physiological&nbsp;</b>models relate to treatment of chronic pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that relaxation training may affect autonomic peripheral nervous system activity to reduce pain. Though there is growing research, the benefits are quite limited}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f642055bf3d173296c1bed8733b444b5842ab780.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
How does <b>cognitive and coping models</b>&nbsp;relate to treatment of chronic pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that we can use a patient's beliefs and thoughts to relieve the pain of the individual. This is because their beliefs are interlinked with the body's physiological responses}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e97fa75a930c28950da8675a7fdf6a74982072cc.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
"How does&nbsp;<b>Central neurophysiological models</b>&nbsp;relate to treatment of chronic pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Shift in focus from peripheral to central processes. Specifically in dealing with the Gate-Control theory. We can utilize treatments that alter one’s sense of physical comfort and psychological calm (eg: relaxation training) or treatments that alter pain-related thoughts (virtually anything) can be beneficial to chronic pain treatment</span></b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-008c9200569943c3cb06334723dedb139c0525ba.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
What are some <b>future directions </b>we could take in researching about chronic pain treatments using psychology?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>1. Objective measures of pain</div><div>2. Knowing about <i>how</i>&nbsp;psychological treatments specifically work</div><div>3. Looking at genetics (phenotypes/genotypes)</div><div>4. Looking at advanced technology}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-01edb26ea0d95cca9f1960d20b184c29ab258515.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
Are combined treatments of psychological and biomedical better or worse then just individual treatments on chronic pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Not much evidence yet but it's predicted that combined is always better}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-771f77425755b908d95e39add707d6f59b02d9b8.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
How does <b>treatment responders and treatment matching </b>matter in the ongoing research on chronic pain treatment?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Individuals are different and respond to treatment differently. This is especially important in things like behavioural medicine which is very unique. Thus, instead of treating everyone the same, we should match them to specifically how they respond!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a93b4e06973b9ed80edf447d763684235f1f40cc.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
Why is knowing about psychological pain treatments important and should matter to ALL psychologists?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Going with the biopsychosocial model, everything is interlinked, and thus knowing about these treatments may help with other areas of psychology and give inspiration to other theories!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-7c0af67396adbb46bd7a4f53b54420dd36adae74.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Jensen_Turk_2014
Does relaxation or mindfulness have anything to do with cognitive processes?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Relaxation and mindfulness was based off of the peripheral physiological model which influences the autonomic nervous system. Studies have shown that this pain intensity decrease is mediated by a patient's outcome and cognitive beliefs.}}<br></div>	"So, in short, yes, it is linked with cognitive processes. If we use the biopsychosocial model, everything is interlinked in a way.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-9c271c01cd20574f9f4496578d36916c9adbef24.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
"How does <b>operant conditioning </b>relate to the development of pain behaviours?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::If we reinforce painful behaviour with affection or time off, then it would only increase the frequency that this behaviour occurs. On the other hand, if we ignore that behaviour and instead reinforce functional behaviour, that ""good behaviour"" will increase while the painful behaviour will decrease}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-2c6a7a131ff1af886015b9d3f09d8dc851ca8ce3.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What is our <b>best method </b>of assessing pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::self-report from the patient}}<br></div>	"We could also observe patient's behaviour and make inferences based on these observations, but a self-report would be the best way to assess pain. There are future studies looking into fMRI studies and such though.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-8f710ccbd771c09db163664560b2324dc6d321e5.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Biopsychosocial_Pathways
What are a healthy 70-year olds chances of reaching 90?<div>What if they had either sedentary behaviour, hypertension, obesity, or smoker?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Originally, they have a 54% chance of reaching 90, but these chances progressivly reduce going down the list. And actually reach only 14% if if 3 are present}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-aebd85f99e338c38ba76ac9fff455fb443858d16.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook
Where did the biopsychosocial model come from?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Started off from Cannon where he proposed that homeostasis could not only be applied to biology but psychology and sociology as well. It then branched off into the notion of multiple interdisciplinary fields forming within and between the behavioral and biomedical sciences. It came to notion that the boundaries separating disciplines were becoming less rigid and that new connections were possible between different disciplines. And so, the biopsychosocial model was created.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f5550377d3347fab2985406eb2e7021199b5178b.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::1b_Schwartz_1982
What is regarded as the <b>master gland</b>? Why is it important?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The pituitary gland; it is important because it regulates a lot of the major hormones (FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH)}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_2
What is the difference between diastolic and systolic blood pressure?<div><br></div><div>Diastolic:&nbsp;{{c1::blood pressure at rest}}</div><div>Systolic:&nbsp;{{c1::blood pressure during contraction}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-3c89a319689afd089c2180f1df9efdfe3925596c.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_2
How does the <b>stress response </b>affect our cardiovascular health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Usually in our daily life, we are introduced to chronic stressors so constant activation of HPA-response. The stress response system is repeatedly activated and the cardiovascular system is potentially exposed to excessive wear and tear. Over time this increases our risk to ill health and cardiovascular disease.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-aae93f4e1e4e7f5228078747f66c57e51d6bd99e.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_2
What are the differences between the A-delta, A-beta, and C fibres in the Gate-Control Theory?<div><br></div><div>A-Delta:&nbsp;{{c1::sharp and brief pain}}</div><div>A-Beta:&nbsp;{{c1::Harmless stimulation}}</div><div>C-fibres:&nbsp;{{c1::Dull pain}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c9b6fd3e8f6ac987b36cdfb89595bdd0c18f65f8.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_2
What was an advancement of the Gate-Control theory and why was it utilized?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The neuromatrix theory of pain, it was utilized mainly because the Gate-Control theory couldn't explain phantom limb pain. The main theory behind this is that the brain is trying to communicate with the missing limb causing this pain.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9ad85c2b1118315c3a8a9ea3582335d7539dcfbe.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_2
What are the <b>three aproaches </b>to stress? Explain how these are somewhat chronological.&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Stimulus-based approach: stress as environmental demand}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Response-based approach: stress as general physiological change (blood pressure)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Pyschological 'interactional appraisal' approach: relationship between person and environment (how we perceive the situation)}}</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b>1. </b>A stress from outside affects us --&gt; <b>2. </b>our body responds by activating the SNS --&gt; <b>3. </b>We evaluate the situation which can either increase or decrease the stress}}</div>	"Note that from my MCAT study, this isn't necessarily chronological. There are different theories on how we interact with stress.<div><br></div><div><b>The psychological approach seems to be the most fitting</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6397c32bfa63adb03d2bce0fa4769ba9d6dde020.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory
Why is the psychological 'interactional appraisal' approach the most fitting to stress theory?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Because it gives us the most information about why we get stressed! For example, if your a public speaker vs a 1st time speaker, the response-based approach will not give us information on the difference in stress between these two!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6397c32bfa63adb03d2bce0fa4769ba9d6dde020.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory

What was the <b>early approach </b>to stress theory? <div>What are some measurements of stress you can think of from these factors?</div><div><br></div><div>Objective:&nbsp;{{c1::Heart rate, BP, cortisol}}</div><div>Subjective:&nbsp;{{c1::Self-report, body language, facial expressions}}</div><div>Life Events:&nbsp;{{c1::Lost job? What is <b>allostatic load</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Allostatis is the notion of bringing the body back into homeostasis --&gt; thus allostatic load is the amount of work it takes to return to homeostasis}}<br></div>	"Some reasons to look into this is figuring out the allostatic load of stress!<div><br></div><div><b>Allostasis</b>: our bodies anticipation to stress and thus changes in biopsychosocial factors.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Those with higher allostatic load scores are in greater risk of death.</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-fc972d15c6610730e782b1033bf55ad58675a79d.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory
What are the <b>four situations </b>associated with allostatic load?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Repeated 'hits' from multiple stressors;}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Lack of adaptation}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Prolonged response (no recovery)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Inadequate response}}</div>	"Each situation differs in terms of how often we encounter stressful situations and whether we can cope with them.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-756228e209f3446571def4851b7e0b525fd10b27.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory
How do <b>life events </b>affect an individuals stress? (What is the <i>life events </i>approach to stress?)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Events that happen in life that are stressful require adaptation. However life events will give differing amounts of stress (bad sleep vs car accident) AND it will differ between the person (eg: I think speaking in front of 100 people is stressful but the president doesn't}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Like a utilitarian, you tally up your life events and then see how stressed you are}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fcf008872253335343e60cc15209b0f60ce58479.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory
What is the <b>transactional theory </b>of stress?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Your stress levels are dependent on how you appraise the situation. (Eg: if the challenge is unimportant, it will likely not stress you out) This appraisal will then determine the person's coping processes.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>Unlike the life events approach, this approach includes daily hassles of life.}}<br></div>	"Stress if a transaction between the individual and the environment (Lazarus, 1990) in which it is based on how we appraise this transaction. Therefore stress is a constantly changing relationship between person and environment. (includes many variables of inputs/outputs and mediating factors)<div><br></div><div>With this method, there is no <i>single satisfactory measure (eg: life events)&nbsp;</i>for stress (multi-categorical).</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-f57223f6f594b8413725070d5c5df0862659ecbf.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory
What is the <b>conservation of resources theory </b>of stress?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Different from the transactional theory that deals with subjectivity, the conservation theory is a more objective approach. It dictates that <b>stress is caused by a loss, threatened loss, or a failure to keep our resources</b>. As humans, we tend to build our resources to deal with future losses; a loss is more significant to us then a gain.}}<br></div>	"<div>Resources may include economic, social, cultural, and physical factors among other things.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-d607ec45f788217a29e2bae909cad839e760b574.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory
Why are some people more vulnerable to stress than others (stress-diathesis)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This could be due to a number things. It could be because of their social support (having friends vs no friends) or their personality. It could also be due to stress reactivity (chill vs not; morning bird vs night owl) and stress recovery (losing job at 25-years old vs 55-years old)}}<br></div>	"Btw, night-owls are more likely to experience stress!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a06e23affe4d9cd5f8cafbd6659dbae4ef924410.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory
What is <b>perserverative cognition</b>? How does it relate to stress?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A notion linked to cognitive processes where how we think about stress may affect our overall stress. Perhaps thinking differently can affect our experience of stress. Ruminating about something so much that it stresses you out is indicative of perseverative cognition.}}<br></div>	"Stop being a bitch and thinking/worrying about shit. Just do it.<div><br></div><div>We could re-experience stress every time we think back to a stressful situation. Learning to move on and to understand that everything will work out is the opposite of a perseverative cognitive mindset.<br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-29aa0bc6f3ce006578a247e033482eb83af703ea.jpg""><br></div></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_Theory

Maybe in the morning, you will say one event is more stressful vs in the evening.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6fdb43cefeb196923a63d3a11897e7d5fa0d4a56.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_3
What is the <b>stress diathesis model</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that some people are genetically more susceptible to stressors compared to others}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9c84f092a96ccf29661e812efa7604e4b9d506d1.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_3
How did the transactional theory progress stress theory?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Previously we had the life events approach. The transactional theory allowed people to start looking at daily hassles that cause us stress. Studies have shown that daily hassles are more predictive of ill health then life events!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9a64d42a16ed6e7e5b2f42b3d9a81e2ec26a13c8.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_3
According to the <b>conversation of resources theory </b>for stress, which gives bigger impact; loss or gain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::According to this theory, loss of resources will give us more stress}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-dc30908478085a1961805577077aea23acb51ff4.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_3
What is the difference between the <b>transactional theory </b>(Lazarus) vs the <b>Conversation of resources theory </b>(Hobfall)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Though Lazarus states that the points in the conversation of resources theory are presented in the transactional theory and is thus useless, others (Schwarzer) says it has to do with what is emphasised. Lazarus emphasises subjective measures (appraisals) whereas Hobfall emphasises objective measures (resources). They both include the other measure (subjective and objective), the difference is only in the emphasis.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-67a2bd94ee060f6aa4e6617da263656f5e5ceb9e.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_3
What is the <b>stress-reactivity hypothesis</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that individuals who have large emotional and physiological responses to stress may be more likely to develop health problems in the future}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e12affa8509dd244acb8751d3d971cb0fa0c91b5.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_3
What is <b>stress recovery</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The amount of time it takes the body to return to normal after stress}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c1855b09f46640d8a0ba63aa59e959e9d5fae6d9.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_3
What happens to our stress recovery as we age? What is the <b>differential exposure hypothesis </b>(social inequality)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There are higher health problems in low SES groups because they have greater exposure to psychological stressors}}<br></div>	"<div><img src=""paste-ce97500db41e7190c8322b50d65bf90db2927196.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-a34271a2519eace8bb34fd0a754893b4b4bb78b4.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
What is the <b>differential vulnerability hypothesis </b>(social inequality)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Low SES groups are less equipped to deal with stressors and are therefore more stressed. They are associated with higher cortisol, adrenaline, and noradrenalin = more stress = more illness. }}<br></div>	"<div>Prevalent to social causation.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-a34271a2519eace8bb34fd0a754893b4b4bb78b4.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
What is the <b>self-determination theory</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::a theory that says there are three major constructs that a person needs to have control over their life</div><div>1. Demonstrate skills = competance</div><div>2. Pursue goals = autonomy</div><div>3. Have interpersonal contact = belonging}}<br></div>	"If we don't have the ABC's then that would contribute to stress<br><br><div><img src=""paste-47a41572435a5a3fce7569edd9f27f094d681acc.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
What are <b>three theories </b>of work stress?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Karesek's Job Demand-Control Model (JDC)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Job Demand-Resources Model (JD-R)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Effort-Reward Imbalance Model (ERI)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-cec9f07adfc31cfb3d4db91dd487b69a772931be.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
What is <b>Karasek's JDC Model</b>? What are the two <b>hypothesis </b>that come from this model?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that our work stress is contributed by the demand of the job as well as how much control you have on the job. For example, you would feel more stress if you had a job with high demands and low control (eg: fast food) whereas you would feel less stressed if you had a job with low demand and high control (eg: making your own product)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Hypothesis:&nbsp;</div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Strain Hypothesis</b>: you will have more psychological strain and illness in the higher strain quadrants comparatively}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Buffer Hypothesis</b>: A high demand job can be buffered by having high control}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5109c1aff24c0bd12ac7b5dc4462586e1d3f4ffd.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
What is the <b>Job Demand-Resources Model </b>to work stress?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that there is a relationship between demands and resources on work stress where the higher the demand, the higher the stress. However, this can be negated by having high resources and help with motivation</div><div><br></div><div><b>This model was mainly proposed as a model of burnout where </b>stress results from a lack of equilibrium between sets of broadly positive (resources) and broadly negative (demands) variables.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5f877c0c3f7abd3efb8d5107aad49cb54b2b790f.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-5563a2897ed4ef018772b219eab7e5468ca82701.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-ef84e0ba7bbe01b49bfa5eebeb207b89e4f5c0b1.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
What is the <b>effort-reward imbalance model </b>to work stress? What kinds of interventions would assist with greater balance between effort and reward?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that if we have high job demands but with low rewards then it could cause an increase in stress. This would then would decrease our motivation. This is the notion that <b>people expect reciprocity </b>and if this is not met, then it is stressful. An imbalance will cause negative health outcomes for employees}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>When:&nbsp;{{c1::A higher wage could offset and high demanding job. Also freedom or choice.}}</div>	"We have to take into consideration when a person would be okay with an imbalance (delayed gratification)<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-473f83dbf2fff1d93b10e12f2f3a302bf43a216b.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-5f3f7770a60f875ee36565382361c9091622c50d.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
How does working from home increase conflict? (work stress)? What are some hypothesis associated with this?<div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Kids coming in to mess with you, not being able to separate work stress with personal life, etc. Where is the <b>boundary</b>?}}<br></div></div><div><br></div><div>Hypothesis:</div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Spillover: </b>bringing stress from work back home}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Compensation: </b>compensating stress at work for fun at home (eg: active work life is compensated by lazy home life}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Segmentation: </b>leave work stuff at work, so when you get home you don't think about work anymore (eg: work life and home life are independent and don't relate)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-8139c414fc386a275df78bce5e563336e0fdef72.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health

How would you <b>recover </b>from work stress?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Changing the work environment: increase control for employees}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Stress management training (CBT or mindfulness training}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Counselling}}<br></div><div>{{c1::Lifestyle change intervention (exercise, financial, or physical supports)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-736ab39b38f69c273a7ebb59ddc84251dcbbd5a3.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Stress_and_Health
What and where is stress? (Challenge #1 - Segerstrom)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Stress can be defined as ‘external events or conditions that affect the organism. This includes physiological stressors like heat, cold, and exertion as well as psychological stressors such as disease diagnosis and treatments. Role changes (transition of life) seems to be the most important stressors because of their significant downstream effects (in their personal life and other people’s lives as well - social disruption). This downstream effect is best explained using the resource model of stress where fewer resources are predictive of further loss and therefore increases our stress even more. Another popular approach - the Appraisal Approach (Lazarus) focuses on whether we determine the event to be a threat or not. This can explain why two different people may respond differently to the same stressor. It can also tell us about stressors on appraisals of subsequent events.}}</div><div><br></div><div>Why is it a challenge?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Stress is the basis (stressors), response (stress), and cause (distress) all in itself. Therefore pinpointing what actually gives us stress is difficult. This also means it functions similar to a positive feedback loop where it can just feed off itself. (Also, stress is individualized and downstream cascading with this feedback loop, knowing what actually causes the stress is hard)}}</div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::2_Segerstrom_Oconner_2012
"What and where is <b>coping</b>? (Challenge #2 - Segerstrom)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Coping is the reaction that occurs to a stressor on the individual. There is a widely used distinction in coping known as problem-focused coping and emotion-focused coping. Though what is more important is whether the individual is using approach or avoidance strategies (whereas approach strategies would be better). They also talk about perseverative cognition and how its a function of coping (by rumination)</span></b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Why is it a challenge?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::We know that coping strategies contribute to a viscous cascade after a stressor OR protects against it but we don’t actually know <span style=""font-style: italic;"">why</span>.&nbsp;</div><div><b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">We know problem-focused coping helps but we don’t know what exactly it helps. We also don’t know what is the </span>best model <span style=""font-weight: 400;"">for coping? Is it the mediation model where stress affects and causes coping? Or is the moderation model where stress is affected by coping and moderated by it?</span></b>}}<br></div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::2_Segerstrom_Oconner_2012
"How is a need to incorporate personality and lifespan approaches to stress a challenge? (Challenge #3 - Segerstrom)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Talking about the stress-diathesis thesis where certain genetics will influence how we intake stress. In particular, they want to look at certain personality traits, and they have found that certain personality traits affect stress levels. However, we should also look at them over time because personality can change over time by a little or a lot. This is what makes it challenging.</span></b>}}</div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::2_Segerstrom_Oconner_2012
"How is embracing multilevel methods in stress research a challenge? (Challenge #4 - Segerstrom)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Stress in a scientific setting mostly focuses on life events of the individual over a cross-sectional period. However, this is saying we should start to focus on things like daily hassles which may be a better indicator of stress. Also, life events cascade down into daily hassles as well! An effective measure for daily hassles would be the use of a daily diary. There are three different diary method protocols we should be interested in:</span></div><ol><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Interval contingent: at a set time each day right down in daily diary (eg: end of day)</span></div></li><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Event-contingent: only write when something happens (eg: smoking)</span></div></li><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Signal-contingent: write at random alarm intervals</span></div></li></ol><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">An alternative to the daily diary method is the </span><span style=""font-weight: 400; font-style: italic;"">day reconstruction method</span><span style=""font-weight: 400;""> which is a diary you write of the previous day. It is said to be more efficient and less-time consuming. It also gives the patient a more objective view of their day.</span></b>}}</div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::2_Segerstrom_Oconner_2012
What are the three different diary method protocols we should be interested in (stress - Segerstrom)?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Interval contingent: at a set time each day right down in a daily diary (eg: end of day)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Event-contingent: only write when something happens (eg: smoking)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Signal-contingent: write at random alarm intervals}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-689ce5fe561152913fe3a7063b3cfb3f3f45ec4d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::2_Segerstrom_Oconner_2012
What is <b>epidemiological transition</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::As we increase gross national product (average income) in a country, it is correlated with an increase in life expectancy, HOWEVER, at a certain point, this correlation disappears - meaning, as we they get richer, there is no longer an increase in life expectancy}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-60602b9d21a3bd4519ec8deadb0e46a29aca0e46.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_4
What is the difference between primary vs secondary appraisal in coping?<div><br></div><div>Primary:&nbsp;{{c1::Assessing whether the stress is a threat or not}}</div><div>Secondary:&nbsp;{{c1::Figuring out your options from there/ How should you cope}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-58042b3ccf94c4bc20f6c7884c6dc1b4ea241e61.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is <b>problem-focused </b>vs <b>emotion-focused </b>coping?<div><br></div><div>Problem:&nbsp;{{c1::More practical (like me) - what can you do in this situation?}}</div><div>Emotion:&nbsp;{{c1::Drown your sorrows - just be sad about the situation or cry}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-7980d3dd8a84fcb49980d0a725731006dbeb9440.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is the difference between <b>cognitive </b>vs <b>behavioural </b>in coping?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Cognitive is thinking about the problem and behavioural is what you actually do about it}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-138933dbbe8e98092ce721b41bdc61ee3daf84ce.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is <b>situational coping</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Coping based on the background, information, and other factors around the situation. Eg: Getting pulled over by the police, the way you cope will be a lot different depending on what you were doing, what car you were driving, etc.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c59e9277054d201dfe699c90534d5d37504e26e2.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
<div>What is the difference between <b>repressive </b>vs <b>suppressive </b>coping?</div><div><br></div><div>Repressive:&nbsp;{{c1::Unconscious coping, can be indicated by physiological indicators or defensiveness (high heart rate but not saying it)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Suppressive:&nbsp;{{c1::Consciously coping, pushing back down bad emotions}}</div>	"Repressive coping is linked to CHD, cancer, hypertension, and CVD<div><br></div><div><b>Alexithymic personality</b><br><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6ba71cc6447ddc88b18151f947dcbd9d8d0b2650.jpg""><br></div></div>"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is <b>Alexithymic personality</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::People who can't understand their own feelings. }}<br></div>	"30% of prisoners are alexithymic.<div><br></div><div>Similar to repressive coping</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-73bd6cd15d8e3dc24dafb3089acd2962aa38b70c.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is <b>monitoring </b>or <b>blunting </b>in coping?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::An information processing option in coping. Monitoring: seeking info to worry about (or try to stop worrying about it). Blunting: actively avoid the information</div><div><br></div><div>They are usually regarded as independent of each other such that we are regarded as high and low monitors vs blunters (not opposites)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b07885e5108facd75c578e971d20529e28153ded.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What are the <b>three different </b>model to personality and coping?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Mediational Model: personality determines how you cope}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Additive Model: Personality and coping are independent of each other and add together to affect well-being}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Interactive Model (moderation): Coping will moderate/buffer personality's effect on adjustment}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-0d113f2eaddff632d529063ab496e304de8bc707.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What are <b>positive approaches to coping</b>?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Positive Affect (just being happy): positive psychology and look for the silver linings (positive reappraisal), positive reappraisal, more problem-focused coping. Just smile and became happy after!}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Benefit finding: find the good in the bad, links to both optimism and positive affect}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d8fbc7a8a4ab163b61d1d9fdd0546fc89b536c75.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is <b>resilience</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::originally defined as the ability to overcome negative childhood experiences but then that meant you had to have negative childhood experiences to begin with. Now the definition is shifting to the <b>ability to have a stable reaction to an event.</b>}}<br></div>	"<div>Personality, social networks, income, education, etc, seem to have an effect on resilience.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-cf8c3e546e51baca73095d70303def18b298de1b.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
Is it better to have 100 decent friends or one really good one?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::One really good one. At the end of the day, if your dying, who are you gonna call?}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-84333475d9be65a40ed59e9fade536a943ce722d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support

What is the <b>difference </b>between social isolation and loneliness?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Social isolation is the lack of social networks whereas loneliness is the perception of that}}<br></div>	"So you can have social isolation and not be lonely and vice versa.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-390f92962fd0409064a3e8c083749cf5a29cba65.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is the <b>internet paradox</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that a greater use of the Internet was linked to reductions in communication with others in their household, and social circle leading to feelings of depression and loneliness EVEN THOUGH it was mainly used for communication purposes.</div><div><br></div><div>However, 3 years later they found that these negative affects go away (but had an increase in stress). Though in the long term, the internet was more beneficial for extroverts and less so for introverts. It can also give benefits for those who are forced into social isolation (diseases)}}<br></div>	"<div>In Cyberspace, there is potential for very positive (mostly for extraverted people) or very negative outcomes.</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-44b1cb54282dc5bf371e42080c232cfd42903a32.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What affects did <b>loneliness </b>have on health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::linked to physical illness, depression, cognitive decline, Alzheimer's disease, blood pressure, inflammation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-44b1cb54282dc5bf371e42080c232cfd42903a32.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
"Potential Test Question<div><br></div><div>""It has been suggested that excessive internet use makes people isolated and withdrawn. Discuss whether you think this is the case.""</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::I think it depends on how the individual uses the Internet. In some instances, the Internet is very good for connecting people to others (eg: global connections). However, I think the majority of the time, it does make people more isolated and withdrawn. Here is why I think so.</div><div><br></div><div>1. You can satiate your boredom with other things: I would think that without the internet, whenever we wanted to play or have fun, we would call up our friends to go play with them. However, with the internet, we could play games and stuff by ourselves</div><div><br></div><div>2. No need for social interaction: Back in the day, we needed to talk to other people to date, to get a job, to do research (in a library). Now a days, we can just use the many apps and softwares. And the best part is, that it's easy. So the introverted people who didn't want to hang out with others in the first place and the extraverted people may just be too lazy to go out if there's an easier option</div><div><br></div><div>3. Bombardment of dopamine and ""thrills"": on the internet, all you see is the super highs or the super lows (because that's what gets your attention). Looking at these, other stuff becomes boring, you need a higher dopamine rush to counter the dopamine your getting from looking through the internet. Therefore, why go out and interact with others if you don't get the same rush?}}<br></div>"	"<img src=""paste-76c0a6f8efd4ce066325780d98630ce69267171a.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Coping_and_Social_Support
What is the <b>difference </b>between loneliness and social isolation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Loneliness is the perception of social isolation and not objective social isolation}}<br></div>	"For example, an individual can be relatively solitary but not be lonely, whereas another can be rich with multiple friends but be lonely.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-ba7726dfa5d5bcb095e463bfe19cdfcc491fcdf3.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
How does <b>loneliness </b>matter for physical health and mortality?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Studies have shown that feelings of loneliness was a good indicator for depression, cardiovascular disease, and chronic illness}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f3bb0a6c8d6970b60c9dc448699f2ca6069829d3.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
How does loneliness matter for <b>mental health </b>and <b>cognitive functioning</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Loneliness is an indicator/precursor to depressive symptoms as well as stress. What is most riveting about this is that it is a high indicator for cognitive decline in elderly (over 70). A decrease in IQ and dementia is associated with loneliness!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6410e281541dbbfcd7e894d2fc9c5aa2a19df599.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
"What is the <i>loneliness model</i>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">The notion that perceived isolation (loneliness) is the same as feeling unsafe with the social environment as a threat. Thus begins a self-fulfilling prophecy where lonely people distance themselves from people and attribute it to others and beyond their control (positive feedback loop). This leads to feelings of hostility/pessimism leading to adverse health effects in the future</span></b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-9e17575b3d2b6d9e7681499c03366f55a1a9004a.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
How does loneliness affect <i>health behaviours</i>? (Lifestyle choices)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Loneliness diminishes a person’s capacity for self-regulation such that less effort is applied to the maintenance and optimization of positive emotion. An example of this would be less desire for physical exercise which is beneficial for health.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-7b5745f39052db03c082e9be5f088980573d34b3.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
"How does loneliness affect <i>sleep</i>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">We know sleep is essential for healthy living and functioning. Loneliness is associated with imparied sleeping with more nightly </span><span style=""font-weight: 400; font-style: italic;"">micro-awakenings</span><span style=""font-weight: 400;""> which also results in greater daytime dysfunction.</span></b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-fd4db37772f2996813eea33fe0474fd201b0fbb8.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
"How does loneliness affect <b>physiological functioning </b>and <b>neuroendocrine effects</b>?<div><br></div><div>Physiological: {{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Loneliness may lead to higher blood pressure and seems to accelerate the dysfunctional effects of aging</span></b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Neuroendocrine:&nbsp;{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Loneliness affects/activates the HPA axis which releases cortisol. Studies have shown an increase in cortisol release for lonely individual which can be detrimental for health chronically</span></b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-fd5bb56a6180a676e063d7c41ce82714dffbaa7a.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
How does loneliness affect <b>immune functioning</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Loneliness has been associated with impaired cellular immunity. In young adults, loneliness was associated with poorer antibody response to a component of the flu vaccine. Testing this via chronicity, age, life-stress, etc with loneliness needs further research}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-bd6ce3c22ba0924e91b8865de5447700ed3b5c1c.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
"What were the <b>four main </b>interventions with loneliness research and what was effective? What does this bode for future research?<div><br></div><div>Four Main:&nbsp;{{c1::</div><div>1. Enhancing social skills</div><div>2. Providing social skills</div><div>3. Increasing opportunities</div><div>4. Addressing maladaptive social cognition}}</div><div><br></div><div>What worked?&nbsp;{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Only number 3 found success. They did their own research (meta-analysis) and found that number 4 may be more effective though. Essentially cognitive behavioural therapy seemed pretty good.</span></b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Future research:&nbsp;{{c1::It was found that reducing loneliness had a reduction in depressive symptoms. And this carried over two years after the intervention was over. Similarly, they found that people became more socially active, found new friends, and experienced a feeling needed. Though the problem is that we don’t know if that is attributable directly to decreased loneliness or not. Thus we should look into this for the future.}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-cba4d49c59d2590f79d158e65d201665d00bb0cb.jpg""><img src=""paste-da7a873d8fb482d243c21235abc7652c7a7b52e6.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
<b>1) Why might there be changes in the experience of loneliness over the life span?&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::<div>As we grow older, we tend to meet new people and learn new experiences on life. Compared to when we were a child, our feelings of social isolation and loneliness is greatly diminished. Also partly because we are forced to interact with others now. I would say children have high notions of loneliness because as was stated “loneliness is the perceived threat of the environment to the self which creates a positive feedback loop”. As a child, everything is new, wondrous, but also dangerous which can accumulate into emotions like loneliness and such. That’s what it is such a critical time for a child.&nbsp;</div><br><div>And the other spectrum, like a U-shape curve, elderly also seem to be sanction to symptoms of loneliness. This may be due to loss and grief. I would say that the more you grow older, the more you lose and remember. The more you undergo perseverative cognition. Friends leave you, spouses gone, and there is a lot of nostalgia mixed in with every little thing you do. It may feel like all your real friends have left you behind already.</div>}}<b><br></b><br></div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
<b>2) Are there any social experiences at the root of social isolation?&nbsp;</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::would say yet. The name literally has “social” in there. Different social experiences, be it positive or negative may be impactful to how social isolation is played out. For example, if a person has a particularly bad experience socially like making a fool of himself in front of everyone, that person may not want to be around people anymore in fear of it happening again which would cause social isolation. On the other hand, social experiences are also positive like hanging out with friends and such. We can also talk about bad relationships and abusive/toxic relationships in the argument of social experiences at the root of social isolation. However, we must know that everyone is different thus it might not be a social experience thing but it might just be personality and genes. Though I feel like social experiences play a large part if not the majority of social isolation symptoms}}<b><br></b></div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
<b>3) If it is known that social isolation is present, what kind of interventions are possible? Which would you recommend?</b><div><br></div><div>{{c1::<div>My very first intervention would be to slowly integrate social experiences to the individual like having a friend come over weekly or watching shows together. Interactions where you don’t need to talk but just have someone present. Also, online interactions/friends (playing games) could be a large help as a first intervention. This is because there is more protection to the individual such that they feel less threat from the environment from the safety of their own home. Then slowly integrate them to in person interactions and such. I would say that the worst thing to do is force someone to hang out somewhere if they don’t want to. This causes feeling of discomfort and threat which may be counterproductive (from personal experience).&nbsp;</div><br><div>Speaking from the article, there are 4 major interventions possible.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>1. Enhancing social skills</div><div>2. Providing social skills</div><div>3. Increasing opportunities for social interaction</div><div>4. Addressing maladaptive social cognition</div><div><br></div><div>Though Cognitive Behavioural Therapy seems to be the one that they are recommending.</div>}}<b><br></b><br></div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
<b>4) Are there any physiological indicators that are associated with loneliness or social isolation?</b><div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::Loneliness is associated with higher activation of HPA axis (long term stress), which means higher blood pressure, cortisol release, and chances for cardiovascular diseases and illness. In the aging adult (elderly), it is associated with a cognitive decline to IQ and dementia. In young adults, it is associated with worse sleeping habits and lifestyle choices (eg: exercising) which may lead to worse physiological indicators.&nbsp;}}<b><br></b></div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Hawkley_Cacioppo_2010
What is the <b>difference </b>between the differential exposure hypothesis and the differential vulnerability hypothesis for social inequality?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The exposure hypothesis is the notion that people with low SES get more ill because they are <b>exposed </b>to more stress whereas the vulnerability hypothesis is the notion that people with low SES are less equipped to deal with stress and therefore get more ill health}}<br></div>	"In a sense, they kinda seem to go hand in hand.<div><br></div><div>We first get more exposed to stress (differential exposure hypothesis) due to low SES which makes us more vulnerable (differential vulnerability hypothesis)</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-b0ed743d93eed426699069d28cb9db4f392441d4.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_4
What are the <b>nine key stressors </b>which are essential for good mental work health?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Control}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Variety}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Clarity}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Money}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Security}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::Position}}</div><div>7.&nbsp;{{c1::Opportunity to demonstrate skills (competence)}}</div><div>8.&nbsp;{{c1::Opportunity to pursue goals (autonomy)}}</div><div>9.&nbsp;{{c1::Opportunity to have interpersonal contact (belonging)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-51500d61157f93d9a8874b7752bb87c967b638f1.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_4
What are the <b>two job types </b>in Karasek's JDC model?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Active jobs: high demand but also high control. These are hypothesized to be less stressful than high strain jobs (buffer hypothesis)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Passive jobs: low demand and low control. These are associated with learned helplessness and reduced activity}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-87ca1ce4f2924ac70182798a858d3603bde81da6.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_4

What personality dimensions are linked with <b>poor health outcomes</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Neuroticism (negative affect), type A personality, and hostility}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-af6b6b92ef52ece53e1dd4a64749a285f4b01aa6.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health

What is the <b>type C&nbsp;</b>personality trait?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::High levels of denial and suppression of emotions (particularly anger). High rationality and a rigid control of emotional expression (related to Alexithymia). This personality has higher risk for Cancer and thus - Type C}}<br></div>	"<div>Others include conflict avoidance, high social desirability, over-compliance, over-patience</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-f19b825b203cfa81d90cd352eb7e4b2a9ebb5965.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is <b>optimism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Expectation that the <b>future </b>has good things in store for you. Having a sense of <b>hope</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a76b322b26e903ebb5a41569e838fe663110eab7.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
How would an optimist attribute bad events vs a pessimist?<div><br></div><div>Optimist:&nbsp;{{c1::More external, unstable and specific causes. Eg: I got sick because I was 'run down' from being busy from work}}</div><div><br></div><div>Pessimist:&nbsp;{{c1::More internal, stable, and global causes. Eg: I got sick because I'm always susceptible to such things no matter what I do}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-f5706198981d1ad8d22e70c047ebc1ad17c87944.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What are the health benefits of <b>optimism</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::increased psychological well-being, better physical health, and even greater longevity}}<br></div>	"On the flip side, pessimism is associated with decreased health benefits<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-17440e978762ec67b3bbf54a5883faaad554c906.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is type A behaviour? How does this relate to health?<div><br></div><div>Type A:&nbsp;{{c1::A personality trait of competitive drive, aggression, chronic impatience, and a sense of time urgency}}</div><div><br></div><div>Relate to Health:&nbsp;{{c1::It was previously believed that the Type A personality was an indicator to CHD and studies have shown that it was twice as much risk as Type B (laidback). However, after 22 years they found that type A behaviour no longer showed significant relationship with CHD. So that avenue was blocked, BUT, they did find a possibility that a component of Type A (hostility) may be an indicator of CHD.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-fe44dd55bcc1a481eb361434e8d64fcdb4c8049d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is <b>hostility</b>? How does this relate to health?<div><br></div><div>Hostility:&nbsp;{{c1::A negative attitude towards others, consisting of enmity, denigration, and ill will.}}</div><div><br></div><div>Health:&nbsp;{{c1::Found that hostility was an independent risk factor for CHD with heightened physiological response, increased conflict, and less social support. Studies found that interventions to reduce hostility significantly reduced hospital visits and blood pressure of those with CHD.}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-50d3165b81aa3583225ab196e3c7d2ea047fc90c.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-1c0687eb050b684df94760fb69ecf1c0c5247d3f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What are the 5 possible models to the mechanisms of hostility to health (negative health)?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Psychophysiological reactivity model}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Psychosocial vulnerability model}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Transactional Model}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Health Behaviour model}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Constitutional vulnerability model}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d339a7a614d637a2e2090ccf0d2e364bb768cc05.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is the <b>psychophysiological reactivity model </b>to hostility (negative health)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Suggests that hostile individuals show exaggerated cardiovascular and neuroendocrone responses to stressors (leads to worse health)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-06bea2c9427c66eccffc231c312ed20c264cf61f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is the <b>psychosocial vulnerability model&nbsp;</b>to hostility (negative health)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Hostile people experience more conflict and thus more stress leading to less social support}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-06bea2c9427c66eccffc231c312ed20c264cf61f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is the <b>transactional model&nbsp;</b>to hostility (negative health)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A double whammy, hostile people have more conflict and show exaggerated response to stressors (psychophysiological + psychosocial)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-06bea2c9427c66eccffc231c312ed20c264cf61f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is the <b>health behaviour model&nbsp;</b>to hostility (negative health)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::hostile individuals engage in more risky behaviour and don't listen to health warnings and such (bad behabiouv}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-06bea2c9427c66eccffc231c312ed20c264cf61f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is the <b>constitutional vulnerability model&nbsp;</b>to hostility (negative health)?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Hostility and CHD is due to individual differences (might be genetics) and thus due to a third variable}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-06bea2c9427c66eccffc231c312ed20c264cf61f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is <b>type D personality trait</b>? How does this relate to health?<div><br></div><div>Type D:&nbsp;{{c1::Distressed; individuals who experience high levels of negative emotions (negative affectivity) and inhibit the expression of these negative emotions in social interactions (social inhibition).}}</div><div><br></div><div>Health:&nbsp;{{c1::This personality is a risk factor for adverse health outcomes in cardiac patients. These people have more activated immune systems and inflammation as well as higher blood pressure in reactions to stress}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e10900c773d02ccec5e04235f5f3ae25604502eb.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What are <b>personality traits</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Stable individual differences in thinking, feeling, and behaving across a range of different situations}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a98d76a4fc879d2a978138d6a13a39c32cdae888.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is <b>neuroticism</b>? How does it affect health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is the tendency to commonly experience negative emotions such as distress, anxiety, fear, anger and guilt (negative affect).}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Health:&nbsp;{{c1::More reporting of pain, more stress, maladaptive coping, more smoking and alcohol, and less healthy eating and exercise. It is also associated with a reduced immune function.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-07f96be2151c933acccacf84502f66b06f737c28.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is <b>extraversion</b>? How does it relate to health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Extraversion is being outgoing, social, assertive, and energetic}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Health:&nbsp;{{c1::Tends to have more positive moods, lower rates of disease and better coping/social support. However this relationship is not yet that clear. For example, extroverts appear to be associated with health-protective behaviours like exercise but also health-risk behaviours like smoking}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-6d78680a95d412531799c856f988c11dd0852fce.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health
What is conscientiousness? How does it relate to health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The ability to control one's behaviour and to complete tasks}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Health:&nbsp;{{c1::Tended to be more problem focused, have positive reappraisal, dependable, and support seeking coping strategies. Those with this have higher longevity and lower mortality rates with higher exercise behaviours and more resistance to alcohol and cigarette use.}}</div>	"Lower conscientiousness was also associated with increased brain aging.<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-0d49351795affb2e525906dcb7343d59ce0b327b.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Personality_and_Health

What are the <b>three aims </b>of Ferguson's paper (2010) on personalities central role in health psychology?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Personality influences the health process}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Develop a more theoretical framework}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Establish clinical relevance of personality traits}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c0e3c86e00f9ea0c5e3491e87d94c128bed35676.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
What is the multi-level framework of the illness process? (Ferguson 2013)<div><br></div><div><b><ol><li>{{c1::Level 1 = Individual level (most common - eg: mortality rate and health outcomes)}}<br></li><li>{{c1::Level 2 = Group level (family, social interactions)}}<br></li><li>{{c1::Level 3 = Organisational (Health care system in general) (eg: selection of medical staff)}}<br></li></ol></b></div>	"<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Having a multi-level approach will help us target interventions at the correct level as well as understanding that each level influences each other!</span></b><div><b><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><br></span></b></div><div><img src=""paste-98369a7182ceda678d553285e0db3f461108290f.jpg""><b><span style=""font-weight: 400;""><br></span></b></div>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
Why is a <b>personality hierarchy </b>important for health psychology? "What is the <b>general factor of personality </b>model?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::GFP exerts that a <span style=""font-style: italic;"">single </span>trait influences a wide variety of health outcomes whereas the FFM exerts that there are 5 factors that influence health outcomes (in regards to personality)}}</div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
What is the 5 factor model to personality?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that there are 5 main personality traits an individual has.</div><div><br></div><div>O: Openness</div><div>C: Conscientiousness</div><div>E: Extraversion</div><div>A: Agreeableness</div><div>N: Neuroticism}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-886b8747bd5cf62e2218de88766c179403a7ce4f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
In general, how does OCEAN (personality) relate to health at the level 1 level? (Ferguson 2013)<div><br></div><div>O:&nbsp;{{c1::Overall good for health}}</div><div>C:&nbsp;{{c1::Overall good for health}}</div><div>E:&nbsp;{{c1::Overall good for health though conflicting evidence because more likely to take health-risky behaviour}}</div><div>A:&nbsp;{{c1::Overall good for health, especially when it involves someone else}}</div><div>N:&nbsp;{{c1::Overall bad for health}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-17542f62c51f94e52b14a9a57c33a4f8747be08e.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-950b5106a242617c40372286b67242708cf9c6e6.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
How does the FFM model affect health at the level 2 level?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::In dyadic interactions, it is shown that high C predicts positive health outcomes in their partners (compensatory conscientiousness)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-675935b3aa53a213251e0e56a9ceb1e61fbe5445.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
What is <b>compensatory conscientiousness</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The benefits of conscientiousness of your partner will transfer over to you}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-675935b3aa53a213251e0e56a9ceb1e61fbe5445.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
"How does the FFM of personality affect level 3 of Ferguson's theoretical framework?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Level 3 examines factors linked to health care provision (physician health, selection and training, staff turnover). C has been linked to success in medical training while N is linked to increased physician burnout.</span></b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-dde632b0a7847f1e1106cbe0989d7a640e937dda.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
"Does the FFM model have any synergistc effects with each other? Give an example of this.<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Looking at how different traits interact with each other. For example, a high N and C are related to reduced health limitations whereas N on its own related to poorer health outcomes. Though this could be explained by </span><span style=""font-weight: 400; font-style: italic;"">compensatory health behaviours </span><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">where people think that there good health behaviours (C) offset the bad behaviours by N. However, this has not been explored within health psychology as of date</span></b>}}<br></div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
What are the <b>four </b>health specific traits beyond the FFM?<div><br></div><div><b><ol><li>{{c1::Empathy: desired in medical practitioners}}<br></li><li>{{c1::Health anxiety: association with medically unexplained syndromes}}</li><li>{{c1::Type D personality: correlated with CHD}}</li><li>{{c1::Alexithymia: affects up to 10% of the population}}</li></ol></b></div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
"How does <b>empathy </b>affect health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Empathy is a precursor for helping others which is linked to longevity however the empathic distress may be bad for the empathiser which can cause negative health outcomes (negative moods, smoking, etc.)</div><b><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Looking at a level 2 perspective, empathy is desired in physicians to relate with their patients however it may be bad for the physician themselves (increased depressive symptoms for the physician)</span>}}</div></b>"	"<img src=""paste-0ed7da7db50d6052960bc385184ad84a3523daf0.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
"How does <b>health anxiety </b>affect health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<div>HA represents fears and worries about illness, coupled with bodily preoccupations in the <span style=""font-style: italic;"">absence</span> of objective illnesses. People with HA are linked to poorer stress and coping responses.&nbsp;</div><br><div>This is important at a level 2 and 3 level because there is a strong link between HA and symptom reporting. Helping with HA may help with saving hospital resources!</div>}}<b><br></b><br></div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
"Do personality traits evolve? How does this occur?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The most plausible explanation for the evolution of personality is the <span style=""font-style: italic;"">frequency-dependent model </span>where <span style=""font-style: italic;"">balancing-selection </span>is important. This is the notion that there is no good or bad traits, it just depends on how we can use it to solve/adapt to problems in our environment. Our personality evolves to adapt to these, and the trait that is most frequently used it what is represented (there is no good or bad traits).&nbsp;}}<br></div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
How can we apply research into personality to clinical practice?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Identify those at risk where psychosocial interventions should be targeted}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Look at how illness will affect personality over time}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-612960904bea47f7a92a388d0f16a5006c081d6f.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
"What is a multilevel approach to personality and how could that help to improve health?<div><b><br></b></div><div><b><div>{{c1::<b><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">The multilevel approach is the notion that we should look at three levels of how personality can affect health</span></div><ol><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Individual</span></div></li><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Group</span></div></li><li><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Organisation</span></div></li></ol><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">The most research in health psychology and personality has to do with level 1, however knowing level 2 and 3 will help us deal with more social aspects of personality. Namely, how the people around the individual and their personality and how that affects the health of the individual in question. Knowing level 3 will help us in picking physicians as well as looking at the turnover in health related fields etc.</span></div></b>}}<br></div></b></div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
To what does Level 1, 2, and 3 refer when discussing this multilevel approach?<div><b><br></b></div><div>{{c1::<div>Level 1: Individual: how personality directly affects the health of the individual in question</div><div>Level 2: Group: how does the personality of your partner/doctor affect your health?</div><div>Level 3: Organization: How can we use personality to select medical staff members and see if they are suited for the job?</div>}}<b><br></b><br><br></div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ferguson_2013
