What is <b>personality</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Sometimes referred to as disposition where it is the overall organization of psychological characteristics - thinking, feeling, and behaving - that differentiates us from others and leads us to actions consistently across time and situations}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8b2d9808cf80e3f0380c3f419584a4628af5e389.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_in_Sport

What is the difference between <b>harmonious </b>passion vs <b>obsessive </b>passion?<div><br></div><div>Harmonious:&nbsp;{{c1::engaging in activity as part of one's identity and for the pleasure of the action (more internal)}}</div><div><br></div><div>Obsessive:&nbsp;{{c1::More rigid and uncontrolled urge to engage in activities because of external control of feelings of guilt (more external)}}</div>	"Obsessive is bad whereas harmonious is good<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-6905e22a48f550ea4e3ff36848d9cbb3f74bebd3.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Personality_in_Sport
What are common points for those with<b>&nbsp;mental toughness</b>?<div><br></div><div>1. {{c1::Appraise the situation as a challenge to be overcome}}&nbsp;</div><div>2. {{c1::Belief that they have control over the experience&nbsp;}}</div><div>3. {{c1::Have confidence they can overcome challenging experiences&nbsp;}}</div><div>4. {{c1::Strong commitment to achieving personal goals}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-3848974b285f6e0df2f9e103980e60be2d578f2e.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Personality_in_Sport
How does the sympathetic adrenal medullary (SAM) response system respond to stress?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It is an acute response similar to the fight or flight response. The adrenal glands release adrenaline and noradrenline to increase heart beat, quicken breathing and dilate the eyes}}<br></div>	The SAM is akin to lighting a match whereas the HPA is akin to starting a fire.	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_2
How does the <b>hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis </b>respond to stress? What are the side-effects of long term HPA axis release?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::hypothalamus --&gt; CRF --&gt; pituitary gland --&gt; ACTH --&gt; adrenal cortex --&gt; cortisol</div><div><br></div><div>Cortisol will increase energy stores, increase protein and fat mobilization and decrease inflammation}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Side-effects:&nbsp;{{c1::If the stress system is repeatedly activated, the cardiovascular system is potentially exposed to excessive wear and tear which may in the future lead to ill health by increasing risk to CVD. This may be the result of atherosclerosis (fatty plaque build up in blood vessels). Cortisol increases liberation of glucose from glycogen stores and may also help with this plaque buildup process.}}</div>	"Too much plaque build up may obstruct blood flow and in serious cases, lead to stroke<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a8ba19adb599dabe6778f97c4dde3ecd31196e37.jpg""><br></div><div><img src=""paste-45a443afc839b087dc335af559e2a0f05b4e0669.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Things_I_Learned_In_Textbook::Chapter_2
What is <b>health cognitions</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::the thoughts and feelings that the individual associates with a certain health behaviour}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d2b8c795b811a76edfbf15abe8c299e7c1700b08.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
Can we predict who will perform health behaviours? What factors are involved in this?<div>&nbsp;</div><div>{{c1::There is a range of differences between those who do and do not engage in health behaviours. These factors include demographic, social, personality, and cognitive factors. An example of this is age, peer pressures, parental figures and personality among other things.}}<br></div>	"Did you know women are generally less likely to smoke, and consume alcohol (but also less likely to exercise)<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-1809727bbaffd67bdba02032d324498426555712.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
Demographics and personality have correlation with health behaviours, however they are not easily modifiable. What is an intervention that may be easily modifiable?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Knowledge about behaviour health (risk-awareness) seem to be an appropriate intervention. Though it is not perfect! }}<br></div>	"Just look at smoking!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-ec6bb8f5cde52838004654a0fecb6e32b84ddd2b.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What are health behaviours?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Any activity undertaken for the purpose of preventing or detecting disease or for improving health and well-being}}</div>	"The previous definition was ""any activity undertaken by a person believing himself to be healthy for the purpose of preventing disease or detecting it at an asymptomatic state"" though this was bad because it was mainly targeted at the biomedical model of health<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-2878027b87ea5ee076a1af537f21d53999f1f541.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
Give an example of each.<div><br></div><div>Health-enhancing behaviours:&nbsp;{{c1::exercise participation and healthy eating}}</div><div><br></div><div>Health-protective behaviours:&nbsp;{{c1::health screening, vaccination, and condom use}}</div><div><br></div><div>Avoidance of health-harming behaviours:&nbsp;{{c1::not smoking or drinking alcohol}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-a2058f710c061864c843fe922b51ef26db2b0b18.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
How do health behaviours impact health outcomes? (3 pathways)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There are three major pathways in which health behaviours influence health outcomes</div><div>1. Direct biological changes (alcohol damaging liver)</div><div>2. changing exposure to health risks (condom use protects against HIV)</div><div>3. Ensuring early detection and treatment of disease (testicular examination = early detection of cancer)}}<br></div>	"Some key behaviours that positively affect health outcomes are:<div>1. not smoking</div><div>2. moderate alcohol intake</div><div>3. sleeping 7-8 hours per night</div><div>4. exercising regularly</div><div>5. maintaining a good body weight</div><div>6. avoiding snacks and eating breakfast regularly</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-52089ee255116bd9c9a8cca50a0395490f598277.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What are the two <b>phases </b>of self-regulation activities (social cognition models)?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Motivational phase: costs and benefits are considered in order to choose between goals and behaviours (intentions I think)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Volitional phase: planning and action directed towards achieving the set goal predominate (end goal)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c2d1a0db4a8e160bbe6b1c1720619309fe630b6c.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What are the 4 key <b>social cognition models </b>in self-regulation research?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::The health belief model}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Protection motivation theory}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::The theory or planned behaviour (reasoned action)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Social cognitive theory}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-49c11d5bea2508b7cebe2a3a6c50c3727b5f3f5d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the <b>Health Belief Model</b>? (4 beliefs)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The earliest developed SCM in health psychology. Essentially this model expresses that people engage in more health behaviours due to perceptions on their health. These perceptions are:</div><div><br></div><div>1. Perceived susceptibility to the illness (Am I likely to get it?)</div><div>2. Consequences of the illness for the individual (how bad would it be?)</div><div>3. Costs</div><div>4. Benefits}}<br></div>	"<div>A study was done where the intervention group was nurses telling the patients how likely it was for reoccurance of illness if left untreated. They found a 30% increase in patient follow-up compared to control (they scared lol)</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-36b5f1c9059124e66a50a28aff13670cf683f9ca.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-0bdb8c7e7f1d1bee30aaf5f8651e7536e21c9ba6.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
How might the health belief model explain the response to COVID restrictions?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Looking at the four motivations, the younger generation's perceived severity was low and therefore did not adhere to restrictions that well. The perceived susceptibility was low, however when cases started ramping up, they started to get scared and really shut down everything. Really shows our motivations to healthy behaviours.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-8405a8d33edaa37f230154713cf36adef1a5a9ba.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the <b>protection motivation theory</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A revision/extension of the health behaviour model which incorporates appraisal processes. These appraisal processes are:&nbsp;</div><div>1.<b>&nbsp;Threat appraisal</b></div><div>2. <b>Coping appraisal</b></div><div><br></div><div>Together, these appraisal processes result in either adaptive (adopt health behaviour) or maladaptive (deny health risk) responses. }}</div>	"<img src=""paste-4456cf1607f2383eea93c61dd1019921bf1a2a63.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-66843c07f306c0ed374d913e6100675c3fa93557.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the difference between <b>threat </b>and <b>coping </b>appraisal in the protection motivation theory (SCM)?<div><br></div><div>Threat:&nbsp;{{c1::Assessing the costs and benefits of the threat/illness to decide whether to adopt or not adopt health behaviour}}</div><div><br></div><div>Coping:&nbsp;{{c1::Assessing the alternative that might diminish the threat. This is based on <b>response efficacy </b>(expectancy that a behaviour can remove the threat) and <b>self-efficacy </b>(belief in one's capability to execute recommended course of action)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-4456cf1607f2383eea93c61dd1019921bf1a2a63.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-66843c07f306c0ed374d913e6100675c3fa93557.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the <b>theory of planned behaviour </b>(3 main factors)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that an individuals behaviour is determined by 3 factors</div><div>1. <b>Attitudes: </b>forming an intention to quit smoking will make it more likely to quit</div><div>2. <b>Subjective norms: </b>having people around you that do not value smoking will make more it more likely to quit<br></div><div>3. <b>Perceived behavioural control: </b>having a perception of control and confidence will make it more likely to quit}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-cc65ac03510619d4d49ea80b0a20c7f6b91b3e93.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What does the <b>theory of planned behaviour </b>have in advantage to the health behaviour and protection motivation theory?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::States that health beliefs affect behaviour <b>indirectly</b>; through attitude and intention}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Takes into account social influence (subjective norms)}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-68bd279deb675f0b5501cf07b05aa1433ca9cdc2.jpg""><br></div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-cc65ac03510619d4d49ea80b0a20c7f6b91b3e93.jpg""><div><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is <b>social cognitive theory</b>? (SCM)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Behaviour is held to be determined by three factors:</div><div>1. <b>Goals: </b>have a goal of quitting smoking is more likely to quit</div><div>2. <b>Outcome experiences: </b>perceiving various positive physical, social, and self-evaluative outcomes will be more likely to quit</div><div>3. <b>Self-efficacy: </b>Perceive that they have confidence to quit will be more likely to quit}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-99e5d9944c5afc0705da82848ee66ecb29ceb933.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the <b>stage models </b>of health behaviour (eg: Transtheroetical model)? Why was this model created and what are its flaws?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Most social cognitive models explain behaviours through both action and maintenance as the same. This model dictates that we have different behaviours depending on what stage we are on the specific health model. These stages are:</div><div>1. <b>Pre-contemplation: </b>not knowing that smoking is bad for you</div><div>2. <b>Contemplation: </b>knowing smoking is bad but not really doing anything</div><div>3. <b>Preparation: </b>planning to stop smoking</div><div>4. <b>Action: </b>actually stopping smoking</div><div>5.&nbsp;<b>Maintenance: </b>maintaining not smoking for a long time}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Flaws:&nbsp;{{c1::We can't objectively define time periods from one stage to the next. There is also a lot of flip-flop from one stage to another and we can't really say when someone is in which stage or not (eg: when are you in the pre-contemplation vs contemplation stage?}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-393781a1f2f46e187842dc72ae29e0f7eeaf4439.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the <b>intention-behaviour </b>gap?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::People's intention (or motivation) to perform a health behaviour but not always translating to actual behaviour. Eg: wanting to quit smoking but not really doing it}}<br></div>	"this was identified via the stage models of health behaviour from their research going from one stage to another<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-7c587970f3b3310fb4b5d60fccd7d1439ddaef53.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the <b>integrated SCM </b>and why is it a thing?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Basically a model that integrates all the other SCM models together. Because a combination is always better in science KEKW. It identifies 8 key behaviours:</div><div>1. <b>Intention</b></div><div>2. <b>Necessary skills to perform behaviour</b></div><div>3. <b>Environmental constraints</b></div><div>4. <b>costs and benefits</b></div><div>5. <b>social norms</b></div><div>6. <b>no cognitive dissonance</b></div><div>7. <b>emotional reaction</b></div><div>8. <b>self-efficacy</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-52436260d740663bc4f2e9ebaa1318c9b09dcfd3.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-6c2c1e5e5ec8b5ae5ad60df8f43c11a00ede9dda.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What are the advantages to using SCM's?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::provide theoretical background}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::reliable and valid measures}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::provide us with descriptions}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::identify key targets for interventions}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-a8a30b0eea3aef305e281ec14d9199c25c798f20.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What are the disadvantages of SCM's?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Developing interventions}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Empirical testing}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Question behaviour effect (measurement itself prompts behaviour change)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-5b0c02b36bc36dc107f63f86bc4a6048acaf8661.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the <b>question-behaviour effect </b>of SCM?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A known disadvantage where the measurement itself prompts a behaviour change}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d2b730f5f1769d0cace1d2cfb6c847618c32684d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
How did <b>intention stability </b>affect the intention-behaviour gap?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They found that the more stable an intention to do a behaviour over time, the less gap in an individuals intention-behaviour}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-845f4063820160dccf1e0f9f94241c72ddfc2c5a.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
How did <b>SES </b>affect the intention-behaviour gap?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::They found that those with lower SES had a wider gap. This is hypothesized that it is due to lack of available resources to translate healthy intentions into health behaviours. It could also be that they just have weaker intentions}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f59aa389023e205b817104ca43f8d18eb7830284.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
If you were trying to increase physical activity in lower socio-economic status <br>groups what strategies would you use to try to increase intentions to exercise and <br>reduce the intention–behaviour gap?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::I would use things like Soccer or running (things that don't need a lot of money) and advertise those and something fun to do instead of just about healthier behaviours}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f59aa389023e205b817104ca43f8d18eb7830284.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is <b>implementation intention formation </b>and how does that affect the intention-behaviour gap?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Basically the notion of creating an intention and a plan to do it. Thus, we pass control of intention to the environment helping us with common problems like forgetting. This would then help us reduce the intention-behaviour gap.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-041fb2de65f3313e22960c5135e685d010850da1.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is <b>missing </b>from the health belief model?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Self-efficacy}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-6f4e7a719940dddc44dd77ff7b4f82c3edcba687.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Health_Cognitions
What is the difference between <b>analytic </b>vs <b>synthetic </b>truths? (Ogden 2003)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Synthetic truths are truths through exploration and testing while analytic truths is something that is true by definition. Eg: asking the participant how often they use a condom during sex vs actually tailing the man and seeing if hes using a condom or not.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-a9bae971368da46647aecee2b46c4785a9da7a68.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ogen_2003
According to Ogden (2003), what are the <b>3 flaws </b>to social cognition models?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::The SCM models can't be disproven, and thus cannot be tested (at least one variable in each study was not associated with health behaviour)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Too much focus on analytic rather than synthetic truths where a lot of the questions asked were subjective (little objective measures)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::The models themselves may create and change cognitions and behaviour rather than describe them (if presented to participant - especially if novel)}}&nbsp;</div>	"<img src=""paste-c91bbc31996f79bdf5c8eaf691aceb47eaf87b39.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ogen_2003
"Ajzen refutes Ogdens claims on the challenges to the SCM models? What were these refutes?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Ogden states that SCM models cannot be disproven and thus cannot be tested:</div><div>Ajzen: It can be disproven...if all the factors don't correlate. Also, it's normal to have vartiation between factors which is stated in the model itself}}</div><div><br></div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Lack of objective measures (synthetic truths)</div><div>Ajzen: Self-reports are pretty fking good already and objective measures are more expensive and may alter the cognitions of the participant even more!</div><div><br></div><div><b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">One of Ogden’s concerns is that PBC and intention are so similar that there almost always will be a correlation between them. However, what was stated above, just the notion that there is variance between these variables indicates strong individual indicators.</span></b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Questionnaires creating instead of describing cognitions</div><div>Ajzen: Basically there is no evidence for this}}</div>"	"<b><div>Questions Raised by a Reasoned Action Approach: Comment on Ogden (2003)</div><br><div>Can the Theory be Tested?</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">One of Ogden’s main challenges to SCM’s is that it cannot be disproved. This is because in most studies at least one of the factors (eg: subjective norms in TPB) didn’t predict behaviour. Ajzen argues that this is not even important because these factors should vary from population to population and behaviour to behaviour (already stated in the theory I guess). Also, it can be disproved, simply if none of the three factors or even if 2 of the factors do not correlate. Also they also say that yea sure there is some unexplained variance but that didn’t stop the theory from having favourable results.</span></div><br><div>Is the Theory True By Definition?</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">One of Ogden’s concerns is that PBC and intention are so similar that there almost always will be a correlation between them. However, what was stated above, just the notion that there is variance between these variables indicates strong individual indicators.</span></div><br><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Another concern is that a lot of the models use subjective measures instead of objective measures which will lead to cognitive bias. However, Ajzen argues that self-reports are pretty fking good already and are good indicators for some behaviours (eg: condom use) while bad with others (eg: drinking and driving). But essentially objective measures are just too difficult and expensive to do while also might change behaviour even more then just a simple self-report!</span></div><br><div>Do Questionnaires Assess Or Create Cognitions?</div><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">The last challenge that Ogden brings up is that the questionnaires will change the way the participants will think in itself. First of all, this concern is common in all questionnaires in general. Ajzen argues that there is no evidence that questionnaires changes later cognitions and if so, it was very little. Also, if the questionnaires were done appropriately, then cognition change would already be put at a minimum.</span></div><br><div><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">“Whether, in a given study, questionnaire completion has biased self-reports of behavior, has changed cognitions, or has influenced later behavior are empirical questions that cannot be answered by speculation.”</span></div></b><br>"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Ogen_2003
How can <b>providing information </b>cause behaviour change (bad and good)? What can we do to increase the credibility of our information?&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Information alone can prompt behaviour change, especially information regarding threats to the individual's health. The more trustworthy and/or consistent the information, the better it is. However, inaccurate information can be detrimental. Eg: an article saying vaccines will cause death.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Credibility:&nbsp;{{c1::The presentation of the pros and cons can give stronger credibility and reduce skepticism}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-8393936417226ed2add46d70b9a7aeddabb42421.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
How can you provide good information to people such that they would change their behaviours?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Make sure that the information is trustworthy, consistent, and displays the pros and cons. We should also make it <b>accessible </b>and <b>wanted information.</b>}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5bf59d23ceefb3746e590bea500b361681c06d98.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
How can you make information more <b>accessible</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Make sure it is easily understood and have very low reading difficulty as possible. Also, have an organized presentation of information}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5bf59d23ceefb3746e590bea500b361681c06d98.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
How can we organize information such that it is easier to give to patients?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Having a logical order with explicit categorization and a lot of visual aids will help with giving information to patients}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-5d214753d7e785adeecce55096eff7ca03179e70.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What is <b>explicit categorization</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Telling the audience what you are about to tell them. }}<br></div>	"Can enhance recall.<div><br></div><div>Eg: ""First, I am going to tell you what i think is wrong...""</div>"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What is the importance of <b>message framing </b>in persuading others? What are some flaws to this?<div><br></div><div>Importance:&nbsp;{{c1::People tend to be 'risk averse'. Thus, when thinking about gains, they avoid risk and when thinking about potential losses, they tend to take risks. Using this, it was predicted that <b>preventative behaviours </b>will be most effective when it focuses upon potential gains, while health promotion information about <b>detection behaviours </b>will be more effective when it focuses upon potential losses.}}</div>	There is some evidence to support this. For example, Detweiler et al. (1999) gave people going to the beach messages that either emphasized&nbsp;gains associated with sunscreen use (e.g. ‘If you use sunscreen with SPF 15 or higher, you increase your chances of keeping your skin healthy and your life long’) or losses associated with not using sunscreen (e.g. ‘If you don’t use sunscreen with SPF 15 or higher, you decrease your chances of keeping your skin healthy and your life long’).&nbsp;<div><br></div><div>They found that those who read the gain-focused messages were more likely to redeem <br>a coupon to collect sunscreen. Moreover, this (gain-focused) group were more likely to intend to use sunscreen with a sun protection factor of 15 and to intend to apply sunscreen repeatedly.<br></div>	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
Persuasion is a&nbsp;{{c1::social}} influence		HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
Normative influence can be strengthened by three key features:<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Positive relationships: better persuasion if they you like them}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Reciprocation: better persuasion if you get something out of it}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Approval of valued others: validation is always great}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-59d62cf5fd3b13666b48c50ed29d175dcc940855.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What are the <b>factors </b>that influence who we will listen and get persuaded by?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Source credibility: a more valid source is better (informational influence, more credible from doctors). We follow experts.}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Perceived consistency (personal): cognitive dissonance theory, we tend to agree with things that fit our worldview, if not, it creates cognitive dissonance (uncomfortable). Confirmation bias would fit in here. We follow people like us.}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Perceived consensus: we follow the biggest group of people}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-f63287ed7cd11ac10d60da9fd5d0a061d5b5c053.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What are the two different types of ways to be persuaded in groups? What is the difference?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::There can either be persuasion by conformity (majority) or conversion (minority).}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The difference is that conversion by minority is more likely to be stronger and less likely to have an opinion change. Persuasion by majority on the other hand is not as strong.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c020186f49a7b3fd3e19cfeb0d4503c4ba64d7c1.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What is the role of self-affirmation in increasing the effectiveness of persuasive messages?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Self-affirmation is reflecting on one's cherished values, actions, or attributes. People are strongly motivated to maintain self-integrity, and therefore health messages are perceived as threats to their self-integrity. Self-affirmation can result in two things:&nbsp;</div><div>1. play down the health message</div><div>2. try to restart health behaviour.</div><div><br></div><div>Evidence shows that self-affirmation has a more positive effect then negative }}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f86025c56655f85e0e9cb8785f9d13bced00bdc6.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
How does authority affect decision making? How would you tie this in with informed decision making?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::When people occupy a role in which they accept that another person has the right to direct other people's actions, they are more easily persuaded. For example, there was a shock experiment where participants shocked to a greater extent then was predicted just because an authority figure told them so. On the other hand, nurses who are familiar with a drug are less likely to overdose even if a Doctor tells them so. This means authority is important but also being <b>well informed</b>.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b4ea9e4cd254f4e8073f1e3f17fcb1e73aac234b.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
Why is there resistance when we try to persuade someone of something?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::We do not like others who try to influence us. <b>Reactance </b>is an emotional response that leads people to take the opposite view of what is recommended.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-e64980554cc5022734523ffd9dc1f7668128fd5e.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
How would you <b>overcome </b>resistance to change?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Avoid coercive attempts and when possible, encourage the 'opt in' or choice method of behaviour change}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ded4a4ac59580d60a5798a0dea4cfc37a534af84.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
Design a set of arguments that could be used to persuade young people to donate blood, drawing on evidence-based principles of persuasion.<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Frame the message as a gain then a loss (prevention-based): donating blood will help so many other people}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Social influence: donating blood will help others <b>like you</b>&nbsp;live another life. Doctors all approve of donating blood.}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Persuasion in groups: everyone is donating blood so you do it too}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Self-affirmation: donating blood will make you a hero}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::Present the pros and cons of donating blood}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::Choice-based model: at the end of the day, it is your choice to donate blood}}</div>	Informative and normative influence	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What is <b>attitude change </b>dependent on?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::How a recipient responds to a persuasive message}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-31e82db194b3fc406f6a65ed07309a6accc2bd83.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What is the <b>elaboration likelihood model</b>? What is the difference between the two routes in regards to attitude change?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that attitude change can be made through two different routes:</div><div>1. <b>Central route</b>: systematic processing where the meaning of the message is required (really understanding the argument (cognitive elaboration))</div><div>2. <b>Peripheral route</b>: superficial understanding of argument, using mainly heuristics (eg: expertise = accuracy)}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Difference:&nbsp;{{c1::The difference between the two is that the central route will be more persuasive and stable. The peripheral route will be less stable and more prone to change via counter-arguments.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-59c907eeeac10659edb33b5f18a7700e6dc88b04.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What is <b>heuristics</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A&nbsp;<b>heuristic</b>, or a&nbsp;<b>heuristic</b>&nbsp;technique, is any approach to problem solving that uses a practical method or various shortcuts in order to produce solutions that may not be optimal but are sufficient given a limited timeframe or deadline.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-ce48d8fd6a3f57e285bf405ab12c6cd852308a2d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What are the <b>three types </b>of self-efficacy?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Action SE: believing one can succeed in completing a planned behaviour}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Maintenance SE: believing one can maintain the action over time}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Recovery SE: believing one can adopt the behaviour again after a relapse}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-760feebe49a0b02bf6c65ec8ef6a3272a4d6dd1a.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What are the <b>benefits </b>of high self-efficacy?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Those with high self-efficacy are able to exert more effort, set more challenging goals, minimize stress, and are more persistent in times of setbacks}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9864aa79c593a522cc30d9f03b006468cb314046.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
How can self-efficacy effect health?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Low SE generates stress and therefore more HPA activation. This would in turn increase HR and blood pressure as well as lower immune system response. On the other hand, a high SE is associated with better health.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-360c5d733005e17436916010476eab67e477521d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What are the <b>four main approaches </b>to enhancing self-efficacy? Give an example of each.<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Mastery experiences: experience of successfully performing the behaviour will give you confidence that you can tackle new tasks because you've done it before}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Vicarious experiences: living vicariously through another person (my mini-speech). If you're a coach and your athlete wins a medal, you get increased self-efficacy.}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Verbal Persuasion: you can be persuaded to be more confident in yourself}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Perception of physiological and affective states: having a good mood would increase self-efficacy}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-e1609a1be8057d18435b3ed38e495f11340a21ce.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
How can <b>self-management </b>influence behaviour change?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Evidence shows that self-management will increase self-efficacy (control over their life) and therefore increase health benefits, knowledge, better symptom management, and coping techniques among other things.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9710a1b2a401ad89ca22f100fcac03c533785986.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation
What is the difference between informational vs normative influcence?<div><br></div><div>Informational:&nbsp;{{c1::influence from the information itself which can be strengthened by credibility, expertise, consistency, and consensus}}</div><div>Normative:&nbsp;{{c1::influence from society: strengthened by positive relationships, reciprocation, and approval}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-cfa6e9c6fc31b792c03c17bcc44c0a36076b5319.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Motivation

What is <b>intervention mapping</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::A practical guide for optimal design and evaluation procedures for interventions.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c316bfefb3d94064418868d60c37206c868f3996.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What are the <b>6 steps </b>to intervention mapping?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Does anything need to change (needs assessment). Is an intervention necessary?}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::What are the objectives of the intervention?}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::What techniques should be used (unwanted and wanted behaviours are identified)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Support the intervention with evidence-based solutions and practicality}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::How can the intervention be delivered?}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::Evaluation: does the intervention work in context?}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-c316bfefb3d94064418868d60c37206c868f3996.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What is the <b>social ecological model</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that there are different levels in which processes that regulate behaviour patterns can operate. These are:</div><div>1. Individual</div><div>2. Interpersonal</div><div>3. Organization</div><div>4. Community</div><div>5. Society</div><div>6. Supranational}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-f0a104e98b6b0dea97996c56d0576d58eac7254e.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How can we think of regulatory processes in the context of behaviour change and its importance operating at different levels? (social ecological model)<div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::Interventions targeting behaviour change should</div><div>1. Be relevant to the target group</div><div>2. Be specific</div><div>3. Take the social context into account</div><div>4. Include accountability measures (interpersonal)</div><div>5. Use policy and institutional support where possible (supranational)}}<br></div></div>	"Think of the social ecological model<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-bfedfa9f83eefeea5061007cb66c8967a606de92.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What is the <b>dual process models </b>to behaviour regulation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::The notion that our behaviour is regulated by two processes. <b>Conscious </b>and <b>Automatic</b>.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div><i>Conscious behaviour regulation</i> is being deliberate with your actions (self-monitoring)</div><div><i>Automatic behaviour regulation</i> is going on auto-pilot: these may then result in urges and cravings}}<br></div>	"<div>They mention two regulation process models.</div><div>1. Context, Executive and operational (conscious)</div><div>2. Reflective impulsive model (automatic)</div><div><br></div><div>These two go hand in hand to create the dual process model</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-352731b8ee55f950037b84fd0626a7e091ef3470.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What is the <b>IMB Model</b>? (Information, motivation, and behavioural)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Proposes that changes in the operation of the reflective system occur when individuals are well-informed, highly motivated, and have the skills necessary to perform a desired behaviour}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-9867643144854beba2926aea71f5fdfebb400798.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
The IMB model proposes that motivation is influence by ABCDE. What is this?<div><br></div><div>A:&nbsp;{{c1::Advantages (of changing behaviour)}}</div><div>B:&nbsp;{{c1::Belief that others approve (of the behaviour)}}</div><div>C:&nbsp;{{c1::Consistent with self-image}}</div><div>D:&nbsp;{{c1::Distressed feelings not among involved emotions}}</div><div>E:&nbsp;{{c1::Efficacy is well-supported by the behaviour change}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-a67d1dbbead247f76dc5d846c98a7c8dabc2f8af.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What are the <b>3 broad skills </b>required for behaviour change?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Self-regulatory skills (self-control and discipline)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::SMART goals (have goals)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Social skills (being able to enforce your behaviour in social situations}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-6b665354c74b3a8ec694bcd5f8cc9ec258a08a35.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How could you use <b>fear appeals </b>as a way for behaviour change? What are things that people are doing right now with fear appeals that are wrong?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Protection motivation theory implies that fear appeals should emphasize perceived susceptibility and severity (something like prevalence). We should also use a lot of pictures. Think about promoting <b>relevancy</b> and <b>self-efficacy</b>!}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>Wrongs:&nbsp;{{c1::Most compaigns are focusing on just the outcome and not the relevancy, self-efficacy or <b>behaviour</b> of the user. Just showing the person what bad things might happen might be redundant and cause lashback.}}</div>	"<div>Promoting relevancy and self-efficacy will counter the challenges to fear appeals</div><div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-be62795efe424511b8b9d143c9dfa98fb2030e81.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-53a856fec6a9384bd1aa7dbcfcf19877de4b5b8c.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How might fear appeals <b>fail </b>to persuade a behaviour change?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::If the threat is not relevant to them, they won't care}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::If people believe they can't do anything about it (low self-efficacy) they might protect themselves psychologically by blowing it off}}</div>	"<div><img src=""paste-be62795efe424511b8b9d143c9dfa98fb2030e81.jpg""><br></div><img src=""paste-53a856fec6a9384bd1aa7dbcfcf19877de4b5b8c.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
"<img src=""paste-6bbf40172440949247e2d3cf282793f101c2c35c.jpg""><img src=""paste-c85d92ce75b5fea973806a47ceb425d4c26a201b.jpg""><div><br></div><div>What is the difference between the top and the bottom screenshots? Which one would you more likely support?</div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::The top only displays the outcomes and doesn't take into account behaviour of the individual.}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::I would support the bottom one, it gives us information about the severity of smoking (5 thousand cigarettes) and increases our self-efficacy by giving us information on who to call. It targets our behaviour instead of only the outcome of our behaviour. This way, it makes us seem like we can do something about it}}<br></div>"		HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How would you go about <b>changing </b>impulsive processes? (3)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>1. Going with the operant conditioning model, we could reward functional behaviour and punish impulsive behaviour</div><div>2. Inhibition training (implementation intention formation (if then): basically a part of operant conditioning where you are stopped when desired object comes into view</div><div>3. Consider the context: maybe change environmental factors to make it easier to do better habits and harder to do bad habits}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ec6e5a121e57c216342f167b7ac74e6489990c33.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What is <b>habit reversal therapy</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It uses behavioural replacement rather than trying to suppression to stop unwanted behavioural responses.}}<br></div>	"Thought suppression can have rebound effects (scientific evidence found)<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-1c07ed2c6c7abdfdfe53bc89454600bbf3b17927.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
Is it better to suppress bad habits and unwanted behaviours?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::No, it was found that acknowledgement or acceptance of unwanted thoughts or urges was more effective then suppression. Suppression could lead to backlash.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-0890574314410db0152364196ac27346c991bbf9.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
"What are some <b>complex interventions </b>we could use to change behaviour? (4)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Cognitive dissonance (hypocrisy theory): basically have the participant make a committment (""I will not eat McDonalds"") in which, if they are presented with McDonalds, if they eat it their a fking hypocrite (will cause cognitive dissonance)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Self-talk (thought regulation)}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::SODAS (Stop, options, decide, act, self-praise)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::NUDGE}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-38551b2eb238ce07e7103dab34196b2b0bf9cbf5.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How can we use <b>cognitive dissonance </b>as a way to change behaviour?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::You get the person to agree to a commitment (eg: I will workout 3x a day). If they don't do it, then it would cause cognitive dissonance because they are going against what they just said (hypocrisy theory)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-38551b2eb238ce07e7103dab34196b2b0bf9cbf5.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How can <b>self-talk </b>can behaviour change?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It allows us to elaborate and accept our circumstances instead of suppressing which has been found to be more effective}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-38551b2eb238ce07e7103dab34196b2b0bf9cbf5.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What are <b>SODAS </b>and how can we use it to change behaviour?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Stop, Options, Decide, Act, Self-praise. Gives us a step by step and allows for great self-efficacy.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-38551b2eb238ce07e7103dab34196b2b0bf9cbf5.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What is NUDGE and how can we use it to change behaviour?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::N = incentives (eg: money); D = Default (eg: least effort option)</div><div><br></div><div>Nudge is the notion of using incentives and low-effort defaults to cause behaviour change. For example, people will be more likely to lose weight if they get money out of it. They will also be more likely to eat more healthier if the only food in their house is fruit and they would have to drive somewhere to get chips.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-38551b2eb238ce07e7103dab34196b2b0bf9cbf5.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What are the three broad types of intervention <b>evaluation</b>? What does each mean?<div><br><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Outcome evaluation: did the intervention do anything? (RCT? Significance? Effect size?}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Process evaluations: how did the intervention work, and did it change mechanisms targeted?}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Economic evaluations}}</div></div>	"<img src=""paste-b2fbec0cb2ee73cd4994fbac744459c7bf983baa.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How would you evaluate processes in interventions? (3) +1<div><br></div><div>{{c1::3 Key elements</div><div>1. Mechanisms of change (what changed?)</div><div>2. Intervention delivery (how did you give out the intervention?)</div><div>3. Contextual factors (social factors? personality factors? biological factors?)</div><div><br></div><div><b>Also, RE-AIM </b>(Reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-b2fbec0cb2ee73cd4994fbac744459c7bf983baa.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
What are some things that you should consider when evaluating the <b>economics </b>of an intervention?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Interventions are costly, thus we should target the relevant focus group instead of just everybody. We also have to consider that even if the intervention is costly, it may still be less costly than the negative health behaviour and their effects!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f37d14ce3f1b3ff201da7de3d479434ff5637fda.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Changing_Behaviour
How do you create a new user to linux? How do you delete the user? How would you change the password for this new user?<div><br></div><div>Create:&nbsp;{{c1::sudo adduser [name]}}</div><div>Delete:&nbsp;{{c1::sudo userdel -r [name] //only use -r if you want to delete EVERYTHING}}</div><div>Password:&nbsp;{{c1::sudo passwd [name]}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-fc436dd04b8242b78db89e34f2ed09035ee143dc.jpg"">"	Computer_Science::Linux
How would you change the password for your current console?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::use the <i>passwd </i>command}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-c034dc55ca254589ae550c3f3129d22728fb1bb6.jpg"">"	Computer_Science::Linux
How would you check for information about the users on your system?<div><br></div><div>General:&nbsp;{{c1::cat /etc/passwd}}</div><div>Passwords:&nbsp;{{c1::cat /etc/shadow}}</div><div>Groups:&nbsp;{{c1::cat /etc/group}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-bb216d8f3cbc39af98905d1ef54d09e238af1fa0.jpg"">"	Computer_Science::Linux
How do you add and delete groups in linux? How do you add/remove yourself to this group?<div><br></div><div>Add:&nbsp;{{c1::sudo groupadd [groupName]}}</div><div>Delete:&nbsp;{{c1::sudo groupdel [groupName]}}<br><br>Add yourself:&nbsp;{{c1::sudo usermod -aG [groupName] [yourName]}}</div><div>Remove yourself:&nbsp;{{c1::sudo gpasswd -d [yourName] [groupName]}}</div>	Check with <i>groups</i> [yourName] or<i> groups</i> after restart	Computer_Science::Linux
What are the <b>two processes</b> that regulate behaviour change?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This would be the <b>dual-process </b>model.&nbsp;</div><div>1. <b>Reflective, goal-oriented system</b>: driven by our values and intentions</div><div>2. <b>Automatic, affective system</b>: driven by our immediate feelings at the environment}}<br></div>	Nudging mainly operates through the automatic affective system	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
Of the dual process model of behaviour change, what does nudging operate under?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Automatic affective system}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-f9dc4c3c31e04b7a760b78d1637960bdd1d24199.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
What is <b>nudging</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Anything that alters a person's behaviour in a predictable way without forbidding options or crazily changing their economic incentives.</div><div><br></div><div>It plays on the notion that people will most likely go for the low hanging fruit. That is, they will go for the option that is easiest. With this knowledge, we could silently change the environment such that we can affect the automatic system to go for the low-effort option that is better for behaviour change.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-803c1c78691c4a338c0d3832e2ecae061e1c4450.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
<div>What are the <b>good and bad&nbsp;</b>of nudging in our society today?</div><div><br></div><div>Good:&nbsp;{{c1::Putting fruit near the cash register will increase the change of people buying more fruit}}</div><div>Bad:&nbsp;{{c1::Advertisement and food sellers making fast-food more easily accessible would increase obesity rates.}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-98d4059eefbe105fb0005bc0d15a061bdc7b650d.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
"Could nudging be <b>harmful</b>? Two types of harm.<div><br></div><div>Direct:&nbsp;{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Perverse reponses to nudging: people tend to underestimate the stimuli if nudged compared to not. For example, if presented with a lone hamburger vs a hamburger with three celery sticks, they would say the latter has less calories</span></b>}}</div><div><br></div><div>Indirect:&nbsp;{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Actual interventions may have been more effective than nudging itself: for example, limiting the availability of alcohol, increasing the price of cigarettes, and regulating food labels to children may be more effective then just nudging</span></b>}}</div>"	"<img src=""paste-f03deb622295c54cdb8687e8059f2dd70c9c33cb.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
"Is the decline in health inevitable? What can we do about it?&nbsp;<br><div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">No, we could use nudging as a way to subconsciously make people choose more healthier options.</span></b>}}</div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
"Why might nudging be helpful?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">Nudging may be more helpful if we don’t want to get backlash from people from forced interventions. With nudging, the behaviour change would be manipulated by us without stripping the choice of the individual. If they want to smoke, they could still do it, it would just be more troublesome to do so.</span></b>}}</div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
"When might the environmental details be negative for behaviour change?<br><div><br></div><div>{{c1::<b><span style=""font-weight: 400;"">It may be more negative for things like advertisement and industry using it to get to buy more stuff and make more money. For example, fast-food and unhealthy food are a lot easier to obtain than healthy food. This could be considered a nudge to a more unhealthy behaviour.</span></b>}}</div>"		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
Who should oversee the reduction of alcohol consumption in North America? The alcohol industry, consumers, government?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::For me personally, it should be the government. The alcohol industry will just try to increase the incentive for people to buy alcohol so they could make more money. On the other hand, the consumer would just do whatever they wanted, and with societal standards at the moment, they wouldn’t want to stop drinking. The government on the other hand can act as an objective bystander without any bias. They would be able to see the negative effects alcohol has on society.}}</div>		HEED_321::Required_Reading::Marteau_et_al_2011
Why do or when would a patient consult a health professional about their symptoms?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::People are more likely to consult their health professional if the symptoms are <b>more severe, perceived as serious, perceived effectiveness of treatment, inhibit goals, activities&nbsp;and attractiveness</b>. <b>Advice </b>from others is also another important trigger.}}<br></div>	If the patient is more unclear about their symptoms, they are probably more likely to seek health aid	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What are the <b>5 broad dimensions </b>within which beliefs about symptoms and illnesses can be categorized? (In which we would consult a health professional)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Identify</b>: the label of the symptom and how we interpret that will have different meanings. For example, saying that you are 'fatigued' carry a different tone then 'cancer'}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Cause</b>: our understanding of the processes generating symptoms: indigestion vs heart attack will carry different meaning based on their causes}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Consequences</b>: perceived severity of symptoms}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Timeline</b>: chronic or acute? How long will the symptoms persist?}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::<b>Control and treatment</b>: how well can the symptoms be controlled and how well can it be treated?}}</div>	"<div>IT triple C</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-05dfaf1e241021e3b4240fce8549a9978b4910fe.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How can personality and emotional responses affect symptom interpretation?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Those high in neuroticism are more likely to report symptoms, and pessimists are more accurate in assessing their health. On the other hand, conscientious people tend to detect symptoms earlier on.}}</div>	Optimistic people were less accurate about their death, but that also meant that's because they lived longer	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What is the <b>difference </b>between the belief in symptoms consequences and effective treatments between neuroticism and conscientiousness?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Neuroticism will have higher beliefs about the consequences and lower beliefs about effective treatments while conscientiousness has high beliefs about treatment!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3033f20760c56b93f9f7eca687a2762d0ddb691e.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What is <b>adherence</b>?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::means following advice given by health care professionals to a certain plan}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How many patients in general adhere to prescribed medications as recommended?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Only 50%!}}<br></div>	That's why even if doctors prescribe certain medications, the intervention may not even work because of non-adherence!	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How can we <b>measure </b>adherence?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Self-report measures are good estimates of adherence, however patients sometimes tend to overestimate their adherence}}<br></div>	"Overestimating adherence can be negative because that means treatment ineffectiveness would be wrongly attributed to the treatment instead of inadherence<div><img src=""paste-3f566eecf9de37ca82ea9a39eb505327477c0847.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How might <b>social support </b>affect adherence?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::People with social support are more likely to adhere then those without support. Practical support increases self-efficacy and actual control over adherence (social cognitive theory and theory of planned behaviour) and may also reduce stress which will all increase adherence.}}<br></div>	"It was found that those with higher stress and younger were more likely to not adhere to medications<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-0cb5070a64f6a528b49115ad84501e33daf57911.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
Why do patients not follow advice?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::This could be do to a number of factors, some of them being:</div><div>1. Forgetting</div><div>2. Side effects</div><div>3. Fear</div><div>4. Disagree</div><div>5. Satisfaction with doctor</div><div>6. No social support}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How might <b>satisfaction </b>affect patient adherence?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It was found that those who were more satisfied with their doctor's (warmth, concern, communication) were 3x more likely to adhere to advice. This satisfaction depends on the doctors concern, competence, sensitivity, and respect to the patient. Just like a loop, <b>patients satisfaction --&gt; doctors job satisfaction --&gt; patient's adherence --&gt; patients satisfaction</b>}}<br></div>	"Thus, you should provide your patient with satisfaction. Don't make them wait too long in waiting rooms!<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-a0368f07c2f681c090d68d19dd054825d7298412.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What were the <b>4 conclusions</b> that researchers came up with for improving adherence?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Interventions are generally effective (even if effect sizes were small)}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::No particular intervention worked better than any other but combinations were better than singular techniques especially if they targeted <b>education, behaviour change, and emotional response</b>}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Adherence was more effective for some conditions (eg: diabetes)}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Broader approach to identifying outcome measures could be beneficial (eg: patient satisfaction, understanding, and quality of life)}}</div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What was the <b>difference </b>between <i>short term </i>and <i>long term </i>interventions in regard to adherence?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::short term drug treatments could boost adherence, but for long-term treatments, no particular technique and only some complex interventions led to improvements in health outcomes (complex = social and psychological factors as well)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ee37ae9e97d6e8f121e8c4f8981a0023bbff6f2a.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How might <b>understanding and recall</b> affect patient adherence?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Patients must understand advice before they can follow it and remember it beyond the consultation to shape behaviour. These are then associated with patient satisfaction which will in turn increase adherence}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3c155d9e696edb4ef8b6d4fbe9fe2df405f85f00.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How might one <b>increase </b>the adherence of their patients? (6)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::</div><div>1. Focus on complex interventions like education, behaviour change, and emotional responses</div><div>2. Target the intervention to their focus target group (increase relevance)</div><div>3. Maximize patient understanding and recall --&gt; improves patient satisfaction</div><div>4. Simplifying treatments (reducing the number of pills)</div><div>5. Monitoring devices (calender's)</div><div>6. Helpful instructions (self-efficacy)}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3d6aff3ff70a00d9f9d28b1ffe9ad0d2aa396d80.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What are the 6 phases which form the structure of successful consultations? (more modern one)<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Initiating consultation}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::gathering information}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::building the relationship}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::providing structure}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::explanation and planning}}</div><div>6.&nbsp;{{c1::ending the consultation}}</div>	"<div>Consultations can go wrong in phase two if the doctor can't identify the true reason for consulting or phase 5 if patient fails to understand the diagnosis which will undermine adherence</div><div><br></div><img src=""paste-7521ad5b3300e9bdae02b28dbc2ec58463735e98.jpg""><div><img src=""paste-d0ac73a64bb31a35a1f3a46fa1b752fd50643388.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What is the difference between <i>patient-centred </i>vs <i>doctor-centered </i>consultations?<div><br></div><div>Doctor-centred:&nbsp;{{c1::focuses on eliciting information necessary for precise diagnosis and treatment (illness centered}}</div><div><br></div><div>Patient-centred:&nbsp;{{c1::Doctors ask more open questions which allows the patient to explain their perspective. Builds a relationship with the patient (seems to be better then doctor-centred)}}</div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What are the <b>5 aspects </b>of patient-centredness?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Building a partnership}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::Taking an interest in patient's life}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::establishing a personal relationship}}</div><div>4.&nbsp;{{c1::Providing health promotion (risk factors and lifestyle)}}</div><div>5.&nbsp;{{c1::taking a positive and definite approach (eg: concrete guidance on what was wrong and when it would be resolved)}}</div>	"Patient satisfaction was related to building a partnership and taking a positive approach<div><br></div><div><img src=""paste-acd3c5ae262a3b2385a5148f43f8f7643257794d.jpg""><br></div>"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How might patient-centred consultations affect patient satisfaction?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::It would increase relationship building and allow the patient to feel more empowered. This was related to fewer symptoms and allow for patients to share key barriers that would have been not shared otherwise. This will then in turn increase patient adherence!}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What does&nbsp;<i>establishing concordance with patients</i>&nbsp;mean?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::mutual understanding and agreement about treatment and implementation}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-3791561ed98b5382ce13bd7618757d241610b167.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What is the benefit of <b>patient empowerment </b>in consultations?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Patients would be more engaged in information seeking and asking questions. This was associated with perceptions of control over health, preferences for an active role in health care, greater recall of information, better adherence, and improved clinicla outcomes}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How can we increase <b>patient&nbsp;ennoblement</b>? (increasing patient self-efficacy)<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Patient ennoblement was associated with <b>longer </b>consultations and knowing the doctor better&nbsp;}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What is CAM? What are <b>placebo effects</b>? Do they work?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Placebo effects refer to well-being gains observed following administration of pharmacoloigcally inert interventions such as saline injections or sugar pills}}<br></div><div><br></div><div>{{c1::It was found that 35% of patients showed health gains in placebo conditions so it does work. However for objective clinical outcomes, there is no benefit.}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-1d5b91ba8cf86577a74c9b94261b51f11ceef4fd.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How might <b>placebo </b>actually affect a patient?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Multiple processes are involved so what I'm about to say is not all of it. Placebos will increase a patients expectation to improve. This will then liberate the patient to spend more time on life-enhancing pursuits, alter coping strategies (increase social support seeking), and reduce <b>stress and anxiety</b>. Reduction in stress will have effects on HPA, immune system, and endocrine system for the better}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How might <b>classical conditioning </b>explain placebo effects?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Administration of placebo treatment that is completely similar to 'real drug' will lead to association between placebo and stimulus!}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-ffd678200531980fb95c49c42cb19c11e253b06e.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What are <b>three mechanisms </b>which might explain placebo effects?<div><br></div><div>1.&nbsp;{{c1::Increase in patient expectation which will reduce stress and anxiety}}</div><div>2.&nbsp;{{c1::classical conditioning}}</div><div>3.&nbsp;{{c1::Neurobiological processes (explains how placebos can very across conditions)}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-457f765c1a0cfc3aa278e63466fb92df5f9c5c94.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What if an alternative therapy was found to have no effects on clinical outcomes over and above placebo but was found to have a noticeable effect on patients’ reported happiness or sense of empowerment? Would this constitute effective health care?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::On the basis of health psychology, I would then say yes it does have effective health care = but only if you want to waste money and you know no knowledge}}<br></div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
What is the <b>challenge</b> to most people with long-term illnesses?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Adapting to their illness, adopting the best coping strategy with social support, maintaining high self-efficacy and having a high quality of life}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-fe564d02f08c42287ea48fc057e59de3836c2f16.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
Is <b>behaviour change </b>effective for long-term illnesses?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Yes, lifestyle and behaviour change was found to have improved health effects on those with long-term illnesses}}<br></div>	"<img src=""paste-d7b2932f60c0ffa736a388e25e7df5628b2aac51.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients
How could we <b>manage </b>chronic pain?<div><br></div><div>{{c1::Similar to that article we read before</div><div>1. Operant conditioning: rewarding functional behaviour and punishing painful behaviour</div><div>2. Peripheral physiological: relaxation techniques</div><div>3. Cognitive and coping: cognitive behavioural therapy</div><div>4. central nervous system: gate-control therapy (distractions)}}</div>		HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients

What is <b>OPQRST </b>in terms of symptom interpretation (pain)?<div><br></div><div>O:&nbsp;{{c1::Onset: when did the pain start?}}</div><div>P:&nbsp;{{c1::Provoking/Palliating: when makes the pain worse? What makes it better?}}</div><div>Q:&nbsp;{{c1::Quality: how would you describe the pain?</div><div>- don't butt in, let them describe the pain in their own words}}</div><div>R:&nbsp;{{c1::Radiation: does it move up and down or is it isolated pain?}}</div><div>S:&nbsp;{{c1::Severity: from a scale from 1-10 how much does it hit?}}</div><div>T:&nbsp;{{c1::Timing: how long have you had this pain?}}</div>	"<img src=""paste-d1d7cbed32bdc1c0773e023de8d08aefba2765aa.jpg"">"	HEED_321::Relating_To_Patients

What are the <b>three types </b>of variables in doctor-patient communication research?
